fields.body:
Saturday
Well, that's one in the eye for the nay-sayers, the doubters, the cynics and assorted tosspots what make up the media and that. Despite predictions from all quarters - including, I have to say, Wattsy opening a book on the subject - the massive security operation surrounding Euro 2000 has proved to be completely over-hyped.

Yeah, everyone said it wouldn't happen - it couldn't happen - but yours truly slipped undetected through Dover and arrived in Belgium - the home of the famous according to Rodney - without once being turned back as a known category-A hoolie.

This was mainly thanks to the wearing of a baldie wig and 14-inch platform heels, and passing myself off as a replacement Czech forward every time I approached passport control. But even so, whatever anyone says on telly, England's top lads could well be looking at a trouble-free passage across the water over the next few days. Which is good news all round for the assembled reporters, photographers and media men sent over to cover the off, who so far have had to content themselves with doing nothing more strenuous than making sure the waiters give them receipts in triplicate.

Course, you might be wondering what Darren Tackle is doing continent-bound in the first place. Not his natural environment, dipping chips in mayonnaise and having a mussel floating around in the froth of his lager.

Initially, after old Badger Hair shocked the nation with his choice of Phil Neville ahead of the over-lapping wing back on everybody's lips, yours truly was resigned to observing the tournament from a safe distance. Particularly when I gets a call from the floppy-fringed student what runs this paper's sports section.

"What I really want you to do, Dazz," he says when he bells me a couple of days before the big kick-off, "is give us a new insight into the tournament: fresh, innovative, different. And - I'd like to stress - incredibly valuable to us."

"What," I says, "you mean like an insider, telling it how it is from the very heart of the England camp? You'll, like, send us over there to be the shoulder to cry on when Becks is missing his Posh, or Oweny's missing his mam?"

"No," he says. "I was thinking more that you might tell us how it feels to be left behind when the biggest sporting party of the year is raging just over the pond. You know, I thought you might fancy reporting on Euro 2000 from the unique perspective of your living room."

"You haven't got me any tickets, have you, you tosser!" I says. "In one," he says. So there I was, anticipating three weeks with sod all to do but worry about whether you can get bed sores from lying on the sofa, when the mobe chirrups up. Imagine my surprise when it turns out to be Badger Bonce hisself on the other end of the line.

"Mate, Kevin Keegan here," he says. "Are you busy?"

"Yeah." I was short with him. "Matter of fact, I was just off out to stock up on Doritos and chocolate chip dip."

"Thing is, mate, bit of a crisis in the England camp. Wondered if you could come over at short notice and sort of help us out."

Frankly I was not surprised.

"What?" I says. "Finally woke up to Neville, has you?"

"It's not so much on the park that we need your help, Dazz. Bit of a hush-hush mission, mate. You know, don't want the world and his wife learning about it through that newspaper column you do."

"No need to worry on that front," I says. "It's in the sodding Guardian."

So here I am Belgium-side. Turns out the top secret mission Badger Bonce was on about involves the hotel the England lads is staying in at Spa. And maintaining the morale of the party while they is trapped inside same while the assorted reptiles, parasites and vermin of the media circle outside like Apaches.

"Basically, Dazz, we thought we'd covered every eventuality," Badger tells us when I arrives at the place this morning.

Apparently, they'd got themselves a hotel with every facility - pool, snooker room, porn channel for those lads following the Freddie Ljungberg approach to preparation - and best of all a video games room. Unfortunately, what with lads like Beckham and Scholes what wasted their youth doing extra work out on the training field, Gareth Southgate more interested in a good book and Tony Adams perfecting his piano playing, there's no-one in the squad with the good old-fashioned footballer's virtues of knowing their way round a computer games console.

"We need someone to show the lads the cheats on Alien Death Mayhem IV," Badger says. "Steve McManaman has got to level four, but keeps getting eaten by flesh-eating zombies before he can release the werewolf of truth. And since David James was left behind we've got no-one here. It's getting very frustrating."

"Why didn't you just call James up anyhow?" I says.

"Physio put a block on the idea," says Badger. "Terrified he might drop a Gameboy on someone's toe before the big match."

So here I am. And I tell you what, if the way some of the lads is already shaping up to Fifa 2000 under my instruction is any omen, there's only one country will be taking the trophy home with them come July. France.

fields.headline: Getting a better salary
fields.trailText: 13 June: I love my job - I just don't get paid enough.
fields.body:
The problem

My current job is loosely based in Administration. It covers a number of areas and I enjoy it. My colleagues are great & my manager is fine. My only dilemma is the poor amount of pay I receive.

We are a French owned company so requesting pay rises can get a little complicated. I am contemplating looking for a new, better paid job, but I am reluctant to leave a position I so enjoy.

The solution

The first step is to try and suss out the complicated way in which pay rises might be awarded. It sounds like you have been put off from even asking, but it seems a shame not to try before contemplating a move from a job you love.

Prepare a written case on why you feel you deserve a rise. This should include as much of the following documentation as possible:


 tasks and jobs you have performed exceptionally well.
 tasks you do that are beyond your original job description.
 special achievements or ways you have saved the company money.
 Comparative salaries for similar jobs in other companies (do some research, perhaps with a recruitment agency).

In your documentation, you should state the salary that you are on, and the salary that you want to be on. Stress how much you enjoy the job and any positive feedback you have had from colleagues, managers, customers, etc.

Once you have prepared this document (taking care to ensure that your presentation is tip top), give it to your line manager with an accompanying (and dated) memo. The memo should request that your manager either deal with the enclosed request, or ensure that it is passed on to the appropriate person.

Then, sit tight and wait. If you have heard nothing after say three weeks, follow it up by finding out exactly who the document has ended up with. Send them a memo requesting a response.

If, at the end of all this, you don't get a decent rise, then you will have to decide what is more important to you - job satisfaction or fair remuneration. Of course, it is possible to get both as your next job could prove.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: A tasty blend
fields.standfirst:
Joanna MacGregor/ Moses Molelekwa
The Spitz, London
****
fields.trailText:
Joanna MacGregor/ Moses Molelekwa
The Spitz, London
****
fields.body:
Like a dating agency for artists with wild streaks, the Serious Sampler series puts together performers prepared to spend a night with a driven stranger - whether it takes them to heaven, hell, or just to the desire to get out of each other's way before somebody gets hurt.

Two pianists who had never worked together before - the classical virtuoso Joanna MacGregor and the young South African jazz musician Moses Molelekwa - picked up the Serious Sampler baton this time around. It was one of the pro ject's most ambitious and intriguing pairings. Molelekwa is widely hailed as the inheritor of Abdullah Ibrahim's mantle, a creator of hymn-like harmonies rolling under jubilantly jazzy melody lines, propelled by the leaping vitality of South African township music. MacGregor is comfortable in any company from Django Bates to Pierre Boulez.

Squeezed on to the sweltering Spitz's small stage, facing each other at two grand pi anos, they could have made their own kinds of music simultaneously but separately. But, in the spirit of the Sampler's mission, they found remarkable ways to intertwine them.

When Molelekwa played in a churning, post-boppish McCoy Tyner-like manner, MacGregor shadowed him with emphatic, clamorous chords - the sustained percussiveness of her playing was a characteristic of much of her work on the show. When they doctored the strings to produce drum and marimba-like effects, MacGregor sometimes sustained drumlike patterns behind her partner's gentler rhapsodising, sometimes spun glistening romantic arpeggios off the South African's chords when he turned to an insistent, brooding, left-hand riff.

A contemporary Japanese favourite of MacGregor's repertoire shifted gradually from its hypnotic rumble of harmony movements couched in sustained trills, to a looser and jazzier feel, and the traditionally African-jazz incantation of Molelekwa's dedication to his grandfather took on a softer liquidity in MacGregor's delicate hands. The only downside was that it lasted barely an hour. To judge by the reception, the audience would have liked twice as much.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst:
Ion
Aldeburgh Festival, Snape Maltings, Aldeburgh
**
fields.trailText:
Ion
Aldeburgh Festival, Snape Maltings, Aldeburgh
**
fields.body:
Param Vir isn't the first composer to fail to deliver a commission on time, and he won't be the last, but his inability to finish his new opera Ion for the scheduled premiere at Aldeburgh (with further performances at the Almeida later in the month) left the festival with a real dilemma. Rather than find an 11th-hour replacement for the opening night, the decision was made to go ahead with a semi-staged performance - some movement, casual dress - of what Vir had written.

We heard what was apparently 70% of the score, with a narration (delivered by Janet Suzman) filling the gaps in the story. David Lan's libretto boils Euripides's wordy and slightly diffuse play down to its essentials. Ion looks after the shrine of Apollo at Delphi, where the Queen of Athens, Creusa, comes to consult the oracle. She wants to find out why her marriage to King Xuthus remains childless, though she fears she already knows the truth: as a young women she was ravished by Apollo and had abandoned the child that resulted. Ion, of course, is that child; eventually mother and son are reconciled, and Ion sets off to return to Athens.

Though Lan's text is elegant and economical, it remains a curious, refractory choice for an operatic subject, and Param Vir's music, what there is of it, is unlikely to convince anyone otherwise. Under conductor David Parry, the cast (led by Rita Cullis as Creusa) have clearly worked hard in difficult circumstances, but their words are rarely audible (the opening invocation by Hermes, boldly sung by Garry Magee, is an exception), while the music, always unfolding at the same deadening pace, rarely delivers any striking theatrical ideas and never points up either the wit of the text or the lyricism that is implied.

There are brassy, Tippett-like volleys to open, but the rest is mostly long stretches of Brittenish word-setting underpinned with delicately coloured chords indebted to Messiaen. Some of it is very spare indeed, and in the circumstances it is natural to wonder whether this is intended as the final version, or is just a preliminary sketch of what might be if and when the score is finished. It is difficult to believe, though, that the missing music will provide the dramatic impetus that is so clearly wanting.

 Performances at the Almeida, London, on June 23, 24, 26, 28 and July 1 (Box office: 020 7359 4404).

fields.headline: Lynden David Hall
fields.standfirst:
Forum, London
***
fields.body:
The British soul fan has long been searching for a Great British Soul Star. Someone with all the talent, glamour and hit-making potential of the American masters, but with his or her homegrown take on the tensions between the sacred and profane, boudoir and dancefloor, heart and groin. Tonight a large and adoring young crowd appear to have decided that the search is over. But no one looks more shocked at the level of lurve in da house than Lynden David Hall.

Despite his apparent humility, Hall must know that all the ingredients are present and correct. The waif-like 26-year-old is strikingly handsome and has a voice like Al Green having his tummy tickled. His new album, The Other Side, is almost entirely written, sung, arranged, played and produced by the multi-talented man himself, while his 1997 debut, Medicine 4 My Pain, has recently gone gold. Plus, in songs like If I Had to Choose and the infectious latest single, Sleeping with Victor, he displays an increasingly rebellious view of the world, subtly subverting macho and bohemian soul cliches.

Hall's tight band provide a discreet platform over which you expect him to soar. But he never does. During an unplugged Don't Wanna Talk, he sings the line, "My soul is battered and bruised", without suggesting an ounce of pain. Hall's obvious influences - Green, Curtis Mayfield, Ronald Isley - could all drop the throatiest holler. Hall can't, or won't, and without those spine-tingling moments, the good-natured mutual seduction between performer and audience on the closing Sexy Cinderella is as good as it gets.

fields.headline: Coldplay
fields.body:
For their ardent supporters, Coldplay are the great white hopes of British angst rock. For their equally vociferous detractors, they are miserable musos who have listened to too much Jeff Buckley and Radiohead. What nobody has predicted is that their live performances can induce unabashed joy and merriment: there isn't a soul who doesn't leave this marvellous gig grinning from ear to ear.

The reason for this is guitarist/ pianist/singer Chris Martin. The man is a master of deadpan wit, self-mocking hilarity and genuine warmth. The contrast with the band's spellbinding melancholia could not be more profound. It's as if God couldn't find Moses for the Sermon on the Mount and gave the job to Norman Wisdom. Far from detracting from the material, this lack of pretentiousness means that Coldplay's philosophical songs are strangely detached from the mortals onstage. Each magical moment is painstakingly heartfelt, with the cherubic Martin's voice framed by Jonny Buckland's crystal guitar chimings.

Yellow, this month's single, which will almost certainly propel them into a bigger league, has instant universal appeal. As the gig progresses, it becomes apparent that we're witnessing something very special. Nobody goes to the bar; before long the staff actually abandon their posts to join the throng. Eventually, Martin cuts himself some slack to cry, "Remember this as a little secret between us when we come back next year and we're massive." He's still smiling sweetly, but you wouldn't want to argue.

 Coldplay play the Cavern, Exeter (01392 495370), tomorrow, then tour.

fields.headline: Cosi Fan Tutte
fields.standfirst:
Glyndebourne
****
fields.trailText:
Glyndebourne
****
fields.body:
Cosi Fan Tutte has always been one of Glyndebourne's calling-cards and in the past performances invariably played to packed houses. On the first night of this revival, however, a number of seats were empty - a sign, perhaps, of trouble. I don't believe for a moment that today's audiences are tiring of this greatest of all operas, but is Glyndebourne itself losing its allure? Or has the unenthusiastic reception originally accorded Graham Vick's 1998 production put people off?

I missed its controversial first outing and can't tell whether any changes have been made, but it strikes me as being gravely flawed. Its much vaunted sparseness could - and should - have thrown the opera's excruciating emotions into sharp relief. Vick, however, alights on the work's images of artifice and manipulation, and won't let go.

What we get is a group of performers effectively rehearsing Cosi Fan Tutte in the drab confines of what looks like a church hall. They are in jeans and practice costume, using minimal props. Every action is self-consciously stage-managed, whether cued by the performers or by an onstage production team floating around wearing earphones. The result flies in the face of Mozart's vision. Cosi exploits formal theatrical artifice to probe the painful irrationalities of love and desire: the characters' emotions, however confused and ambivalent, are real. But Vick's characters are just a group of people play-acting; all we see is an insincere charade.

This is a shame, for on a musical level the evening is staggering, with intense, edgy conducting from Louis Langrée - Glyndebourne Touring Opera's excellent music director - and incandescent playing from the LPO, though the brass, on this occasion, took a while to settle.

Some of the singing is wonderful. Alexandra von der Weth, in an outstanding British debut, is a gob-smacking Fiordiligi, with a voice of sensual purity that recalls great Mozartians of the past like Irmgard Seefried and Gundula Janowitz. The American baritone Nathan Gunn is a tremendous Guglielmo, sexy, vulnerable and generating such an erotic charge with Laura Polverelli's voluptuous Dorabella that the pair make your blood pound. Alan Opie is a grizzled, handsome Alfonso, while Elizabeth Gale's Despina, looking like Anna Magnani, is knowing, sensitive and anything but coarse. As Ferrando, Paul Austin Kelly struggles a bit with his high laying arias but is strong in the ensembles. You need to hear it - but the latter verb is carefully chosen. Some might prefer to shut their eyes.

fields.bodyText: Cosi Fan Tutte has always been one of Glyndebourne's calling-cards and in the past performances invariably played to packed houses. On the first night of this revival, however, a number of seats were empty - a sign, perhaps, of trouble. I don't believe for a moment that today's audiences are tiring of this greatest of all operas, but is Glyndebourne itself losing its allure? Or has the unenthusiastic reception originally accorded Graham Vick's 1998 production put people off? I missed its controversial first outing and can't tell whether any changes have been made, but it strikes me as being gravely flawed. Its much vaunted sparseness could - and should - have thrown the opera's excruciating emotions into sharp relief. Vick, however, alights on the work's images of artifice and manipulation, and won't let go. What we get is a group of performers effectively rehearsing Cosi Fan Tutte in the drab confines of what looks like a church hall. They are in jeans and practice costume, using minimal props. Every action is self-consciously stage-managed, whether cued by the performers or by an onstage production team floating around wearing earphones. The result flies in the face of Mozart's vision. Cosi exploits formal theatrical artifice to probe the painful irrationalities of love and desire: the characters' emotions, however confused and ambivalent, are real. But Vick's characters are just a group of people play-acting; all we see is an insincere charade. This is a shame, for on a musical level the evening is staggering, with intense, edgy conducting from Louis Langrée - Glyndebourne Touring Opera's excellent music director - and incandescent playing from the LPO, though the brass, on this occasion, took a while to settle. Some of the singing is wonderful. Alexandra von der Weth, in an outstanding British debut, is a gob-smacking Fiordiligi, with a voice of sensual purity that recalls great Mozartians of the past like Irmgard Seefried and Gundula Janowitz. The American baritone Nathan Gunn is a tremendous Guglielmo, sexy, vulnerable and generating such an erotic charge with Laura Polverelli's voluptuous Dorabella that the pair make your blood pound. Alan Opie is a grizzled, handsome Alfonso, while Elizabeth Gale's Despina, looking like Anna Magnani, is knowing, sensitive and anything but coarse. As Ferrando, Paul Austin Kelly struggles a bit with his high laying arias but is strong in the ensembles. You need to hear it - but the latter verb is carefully chosen. Some might prefer to shut their eyes.  Till August 14. Box office: 01273 813813.

fields.headline: Come the revolution
fields.standfirst:
Mrs Steinburg and the Byker Boy
Bush Theatre, London
**
fields.trailText:
Mrs Steinburg and the Byker Boy
Bush Theatre, London
**
fields.body:
Michael Wilcox's latest play whiles away a happy couple of hours. But it's not funny enough to be totally entertaining, not sharp enough to count as satire and is too insubstantial to really pass comment on the ethics of making and spending money, and the difficulties of being a socialist in the New Labour, e-commerce world.

What it does do is create a real, believable world in the basement of the Red Flag charity shop in Newcastle, ruled over by the imperious Mrs Steinberg, a card-carrying communist who admits "I'm less Stalinist than I used to be". Here the light-fingered April, canny Janice and sweet-natured, gay Peter provide their labour for free, each finding a way of happily clawing back what they want or need.

Then young Matty arrives on work experience. He has never heard of Marx and in Mrs Steinberg's five-week absence sees an opportunity to transform the rundown charity shop into a thriving, profits-motivated business whose heart is in the basement where the computer gives internet access to an international market of buyers. For the rechristened New Red Flag shop and its volunteers with their profits-related bonus schemes, it's a case of rags to riches, almost overnight.

The clash between old-style socialist values and New Labour entrepreneurship is never given more than cursory attention, and the main enjoyment of the evening comes from the soap opera-like developments in the workers' personal lives, from Janice's "shag of a lifetime" to the burgeoning relationship between Matty and Peter, sweet on the surface but pregnant with violence and power. But like so much else in this play it is not sufficiently developed.

This is so close to being a much better play that it seems a pity the Bush hasn't helped to push the promising script that further mile. But there are no problems with Natasha Betteridge's snappy production or the performances, particularly from relative newcomers Paul Nicholls, who plays Matty with a sly, knowing smile, and Aidan Meech, whose Peter is like a lovable, trusting puppy who will always end up kicked.

 To July 8. Box office: 020 8743 3388.

webTitle: Byers stirs row over cheap car imports

fields.headline: Byers stirs row over cheap car imports
fields.standfirst: Dealers dub hopes of 30-40% cuts 'fantasy land'
fields.trailText: The government yesterday stirred up a hornet's nest with global motor manufacturers when it said UK dealers could import cheaper cars via authorised colleagues in the European Union as part of the drive to bring down the cost to consumers by at least 10%, or £1,100 a vehicle.
fields.body:
The government yesterday stirred up a hornet's nest with global motor manufacturers when it said UK dealers could import cheaper cars via authorised colleagues in the European Union as part of the drive to bring down the cost to consumers by at least 10%, or £1,100 a vehicle.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers - thought to have sprung this move on the manufacturers last Friday - said the measure would bring greater competition and lower prices by stopping suppliers discriminating against dealers.

Consumer bodies hailed Mr Byers' move to make it easier for consumers to import cars from elsewhere in the EU - as much as 12% cheaper - as going beyond their wildest dreams. But dealers warned that talk of prices falling by 30% to 40% was "fantasy land".

The greatest row, however, is brewing behind the scenes with manufacturers based both in the UK and mainland Europe warning that Mr Byers was effectively forcing them to pay double commission, and hence producing a scheme that was unworkable.

Under present EU rules, authorised British dealers are free to import cheaper cars from a fellow dealer in mainland Europe but are deterred from doing so as such cars do not count towards their sales target or sales bonus.

But the trade secretary, who is seen within the industry as milking a new populist bandwagon now his reputation has recovered from the Rover debacle, proposed ending that anomaly in a series of measures to implement the competition commission's April report on car pricing.

One insider said: "We warned him on Friday that it wouldn't work, and he should remove it and he hasn't. His plan could mean that we pay double commission and that could mean at worst there would be no incentive for a dealer to sell any cars. There will be a big fight on this."

Mr Byers, who has spearheaded a campaign to end the so-called rip-off Britain, has given the industry 30 days to consult on his plans which include, as expected, measures to enable dealers to offer the same discounts to individual customers as they now offer to fleet buyers. But even here, industry sources said, he faces a bitter fight over definitions.

Mr Byers' unexpected move prompted Sheila McKechnie, head of the Consumers' Association, to talk of a huge leap in buying from overseas and to look forward to even bigger changes from next year when the EU changes the block exemption rules allowing manufacturers to control prices. The CA has set up its own scheme to allow consumers to buy cheaper European models.

Edmund King, executive director of the RAC Foundation, the body's campaigning arm, said prices had already fallen by 6% in recent months.

10-year war to trim prices

There have been numerous investigations into new car prices by competition authorities and MPs.

These include:
 Monopolies commission inquiry in 1990-91. Report published in 1992.

 European commission report on car price differentials, published in May 1992 and car price surveys every six months since May 1993.

 Commons trade and industry select committee investigation and report on vehicle pricing in 1998.

 Competition commission inquiry began in February 1999, resulting in a 738-page report published in April this year.

The industry has had to review sales and distribution practices after an EC threat to abolish the agreement which exempts carmakers from some competition regulations.

The agreement, known as the block exemption, runs out in September 2002. It allows carmakers to maintain networks of exclusive franchised dealers. Competition commissioner Mario Monti is unsympathetic to carmakers' pleas for its renewal.

webTitle: AOL signs deal with mobile retailer

fields.headline: AOL signs deal with mobile retailer
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Carphone Warehouse yesterday announced a joint venture with America Online to muscle its way into the potentially explosive market for mobile internet access.
fields.body:
Carphone Warehouse yesterday announced a joint venture with America Online to muscle its way into the potentially explosive market for mobile internet access.

The deal will see AOL take a 15% stake in an internet portal being launched by Carphone Warehouse, which it aims to install on phones sold through the chain. AOL is paying $25m (£16.5m) for the stake and has the right to buy a further 4.9% during the next 12 months at a rate which would value the yet-to-launch portal at $700m.

The business, which Carphone Warehouse claims has 50 content and service provider deals already in place behind the scenes, will trade under the Mviva brand. AOL will also provide content and services.

The deal with AOL should add further lustre to the £2bn stock market flotation of Carphone Warehouse which was announced last week.

Charles Dunstone, the founder of Carphone Warehouse, said: "This is all about leveraging the relationship we have with our customers and our position in the marketplace. For a while the market became all about entry level pre-pay services but with the arrival of wireless data we are returning to a more sophisticated product and we owe it to ourselves to be there."

He said AOL's involvement with Mviva was a strong endorsement of Carphone Warehouse's position as Europe's biggest independent retailer of mobile phones, with 800 stores across six countries.

"Users of mobile phones will be drawn toward brands they know from PC-based internet and AOL will be a powerful partner," Mr Dunstone said. The portal will launch this summer and will be cobranded "Mviva - powered by AOL".

For AOL the deal shifts the its name further into wireless. AOL faces the same problem as the likes of Microsoft which need to migrate their services to media other than PCs or else face the prospect of losing their place in the market. AOL will be promoting Mviva to its fixed line customers.

webTitle: Byers sends Bupa hospitals takeover to watchdog

fields.headline: Byers sends Bupa hospitals takeover to watchdog
fields.trailText: The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, has referred Bupa's proposed £260m takeover of Community Hospitals to the competition commission, prompting calls for a wider enquiry into the private healthcare market.
fields.body:
The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, has referred Bupa's proposed £260m takeover of Community Hospitals to the competition commission, prompting calls for a wider enquiry into the private healthcare market.

The deal would add 21 hospitals to Bupa's network of 36, giving the private healthcare group one in four of Britain's private hospitals.

Mr Byers said he agreed with the office of fair trading's view that this raised "competition concerns in respect of both the private medical insurance and private medical services markets in the UK".

The decision was welcomed by the British Medical Association, which joined the Consumers' Association in lobby ing for the deal to be blocked.

Derek Machin, chairman of the BMA's private practice committee, said: "I think this is absolutely appropriate. It's a very unhealthy situation to have a monopoly insurer also becoming a monopoly provider of hospital facilities."

Bupa has about 40% of the private insurance market, while its biggest rival, PPP, has a further 30%. Both have been keenly expanding by buying hospitals and nursing homes.

Critics say this causes problems because insurers are controlling both the cost of care and the price of policies, although Bupa and PPP insist they have "Chinese walls" separating their facilities from their insurance arms.

The office of fair trading made informal inquiries into the private healthcare market last autumn but opted not to begin a formal investigation.

A Bupa spokesman said last night: "We're disappointed, obviously. The issues which some of those who opposed the bid were airing had, we felt, been dealt with by the OFT last year."

Bupa's 650p-a-share bid automatically lapsed yesterday and Community Hospitals' shares fell 40p to 522.5p.

webTitle: Crashes turn Cahoot launch into a disaster

fields.headline: Crashes turn Cahoot launch into a disaster
fields.standfirst:
Frantic Abbey blames demand for website collapse

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Technical problems plunged the launch of Abbey National's much-hyped new internet bank into chaos yesterday, resulting in its website being out of action for much of the day.
fields.body:
Technical problems plunged the launch of Abbey National's much-hyped new internet bank into chaos yesterday, resulting in its website being out of action for much of the day.

Computer staff at Cahoot were last night frantically trying to sort out the difficulties, and the bank admitted it was unable to say why the glitch had occurred or give any assurances as to when normal service would be resumed.

It appeared that millions of pounds invested in what Cahoot described as "superior systems" and partnerships with leading players such as IBM were unable to prevent the new e-bank falling victim to a problem that afflicted Egg and other banking newcomers - underestimating demand.

The Cahoot website crashed soon after going live yesterday morning, and was out of action for three to four hours. The site was operating intermittently after 1pm but many would-be applicants were still being told: "We apologise, but due to unprecedented demand the application process is not currently available. Please check back at another time."

"It is an extremely large bummer," admitted Tim Murley, Cahoot's managing director. The task now was "to restore confidence," he added.

While the website was blaming the problems on the sheer number of people trying to log on, Mr Murley said he was not convinced this was the reason. At some points yesterday there were more than 1,000 people trying to log on at once, but Mr Murley said: "We had catered for more than that."

Interest in Cahoot was stirred up by its well-publicised introductory offer of interest-free overdrafts and credit cards for a year to the first 25,000 successful applicants.

Cahoot launched with just two products on offer - a current account and a credit card - but will be adding more in the coming months. Online share-dealing is due to be up and running by the end of September, and personal loans and savings accounts are planned for later this year. However, unlike e-banking rival Egg, Cahoot will not be offering mortgages.

Abbey National is investing £50m in the venture this year, including £18m on a major television, press and billboard advertising campaign. It is anticipated that the business will move into profit in 2003. Cahoot's target group are those aged 25-45 who are "comfortable with technology". The company has started life with a staff of just 56 - it is outsourcing nearly all of its functions and claims this will enable it to be a low-cost provider, passing on cost savings directly to its customers.

With the launch coming on the day that Egg began trading on the stock market, there has inevitably been intense speculation about whether Cahoot would follow suit. Mr Murley confirmed that it "had not ruled out" a partial flotation of the venture. "We are in discussions with venture capitalists at the moment in terms of them taking a stake in Cahoot, which would not be more than 20% to 25%. Should we choose to go down that route the venture capitalists would want an exit, and one of those would be a potential partial flotation," he added.

Shares in Egg ended their first day of trading at 177.5p, leaving investors - including 85,000 customers of the bank - sitting on more than 10% profit for the day and giving the company a value of £1.44bn. The bank's shares had been priced at 160p a share.

webTitle: Luck but few ideas on side of Holland

fields.headline: Luck but few ideas on side of Holland
fields.trailText: Richard Williams casts a critical eye over the first four games of the tournament.
fields.body:
Earlier there had been plenty to enjoy when Italy, more effective than expected, and Turkey, who were a little unlucky, provided a prologue to France's masterclass in the exploitation of Denmark's offside trap. At last, Euro 2000 was the stage for players who could transfer the ball accurately over a variety of distances and think two, three or even four passes ahead.

And then came Holland, whose players have the capacity to produce more diverse football than any in the competition. In theory, all they need to do to win the competition is to make common cause with each other for the next three weeks. On the evidence of last night's match, Frank Rijkaard's first competitive game as manager, it may well be beyond them, unless they can continue such slices of luck as the one represented by Pierluigi Collina's award of a penalty for Jiri Nemec's challenge on Ronald de Boer.

As expected, Rijkaard sent his side out in a straightforward 4-4-2 formation with Dennis Bergkamp in his favourite role of shadow striker, just behind Patrick Kluivert. Whenever Edgar Davids was pulling the strings from his normal station in central midfield, Holland looked dangerous. But Kluivert and Bergkamp were receiving harsh treatment from the Czech defence and the chances were few, with Pavel Srnicek making sprawling saves to deny Kluivert twice in the first quarter of an hour.

Four years ago the Czechs were the surprise package of Euro 96, reaching the fi nal by beating France on penalties in the semi-final before taking Germany all the way to extra time. Unbeaten in their qualifying matches for this year's tournament, they are nobody's dark horses now.

But their methods in the first half last night were not calculated to divert a neutral's affection away from the men in orange. With one extremely big man, Karel Rada, at the back and another, Jan Koller, up front, they relied on a posse of scurrying midfield players to make rapid breaks and to put themselves in the way of the Dutch as soon as possession was lost.

By half-time they must have felt they were succeeding. Although they had mustered only a single shot, when Pavel Nedved lashed a 30-yard drive into the side netting just before the break, they had managed to disrupt the Dutch movement and give Bergkamp and Kluivert a pair of sore ankles apiece.

They demonstrated more positive intentions early in the second half, almost taking the lead when Karel Poborsky just failed to make proper contact with Nedved's cross from the left. Nor was this a token effort. Suddenly Nemec was peppering the Dutch goal with shots from the left, while Koller finished an exchange of passes with Nedved with a clever shot which brought a brilliant diving save from Ed van der Sar. When Nedved hit the post from Vladimir Smicer's left wing cross, they were virtually over-running their hosts.

With Holland's novice manager pacing the touchline, his players could make only a spasmodic response. Bergkamp's long cross brought a fierce but inaccurate volley from Ronald de Boer, but at the other end Poborsky won a free kick from a frustrated Reiziger and then watched as Koller met his free kick with an angled header which bounced off the Dutch crossbar.

Not only had the home side mislaid their ability to link the play, they looked as though they had run out of ideas - surely a matter of serious concern after only an hour's play of a tournament in which, if they are to regain the trophy won by their predecessors in 1988, they will need to play half a dozen games. And they will not always have Signor Collina to come to their aid.

With one extremely big man, Karel Rada, at the back and another, Jan Koller, up front, they relied on a posse of scurrying midfield players to make rapid breaks and to put themselves in the way of the Dutch as soon as possession was lost. By half-time they must have felt they were succeeding. Although they had mustered only a single shot, when Pavel Nedved lashed a 30-yard drive into the side netting just before the break, they had managed to disrupt the Dutch movement and give Bergkamp and Kluivert a pair of sore ankles apiece. They demonstrated more positive intentions early in the second half, almost taking the lead when Karel Poborsky just failed to make proper contact with Nedved's cross from the left. Nor was this a token effort. Suddenly Nemec was peppering the Dutch goal with shots from the left, while Koller finished an exchange of passes with Nedved with a clever shot which brought a brilliant diving save from Ed van der Sar. When Nedved hit the post from Vladimir Smicer's left wing cross, they were virtually over-running their hosts. With Holland's novice manager pacing the touchline, his players could make only a spasmodic response. Bergkamp's long cross brought a fierce but inaccurate volley from Ronald de Boer, but at the other end Poborsky won a free kick from a frustrated Reiziger and then watched as Koller met his free kick with an angled header which bounced off the Dutch crossbar. Not only had the home side mislaid their ability to link the play, they looked as though they had run out of ideas - surely a matter of serious concern after only an hour's play of a tournament in which, if they are to regain the trophy won by their predecessors in 1988, they will need to play half a dozen games. And they will not always have Signor Collina to come to their aid.

webTitle: Red devils have the best tunes

fields.headline: Red devils have the best tunes
fields.standfirst: Belgians, in an understated sort of way, get into the carnival mood
fields.trailText: The lack of brouhaha in Brussels about Euro 2000 reflects part of the Belgian character. With their fondness for chips, ale and pigeon-racing there is something very northern about the Belgians. And like any proper northerners they do not want a lot of fuss.
fields.body:
On Friday night here the only hard evidence of an impending international football spectacular is to be found alongside the park on Rue Royale. Two dozen dark blue Iveco personnel carriers fill up the parking bays. Inside the riot police chat or read comics or adjust their tan leather shoulder holsters.

By midnight they have disappeared. Back perhaps to the strange compound their colleagues have constructed in Place de la Rogier station using first world war-style barbed wire entanglements. A laager to combat the effects of lager, it is packed with uniformed men and heavy duty equipment including a couple of Mol crowd-control vehicles with roof-mounted searchlights and water cannon.

On Saturday a few more positive things emerge. In the window of a shoe shop at the bottom of the Chausée d'Ixelles is a tasteful display of black socks which have the badge of the Belgian FA halfway up the calf. Another shopkeeper near the Colonne du Congres has opted for something slightly more spectacular, a two-foot high model of the Atomium, the spheres replaced with black and white footballs, the whole thing made out of chocolate. And, actually, that's about it.

The lack of brouhaha in Brussels about Euro 2000 reflects part of the Belgian character. With their fondness for chips, ale and pigeon-racing there is something very northern about the Belgians. And like any proper northerners they do not want a lot of fuss. They only make a song and dance on really special occasions. Belgian towns are generally quiet but once a year most of them hold a carnival of some sort. These vary in size, length and general nuttiness, but they are all noisy and joyful. One of the most famous is in the southern town of Binche. It is from the excesses of the Binche carnival that we get the word binge.

On the tram up to Heysel on Saturday evening it becomes clear that the opening game has been marked as a day to go en f te . From the streets of grey-brick terraces with the pull-down shutters and the cacti in the windows and crumbling art nouveau apartment houses comes a stream of red devil worshippers. They have felt tails, plastic horns, capes, red-painted faces.

Twice I nearly lose an eye in diabolic inflatable pitchfork-related incidents.

Outside the ground the air is scented with hops. Every step you take produces the crunching of plastic cups. Belgians roll up the streets chanting in Flemish, in French and, in the case of "We hate fucking Sweden", English, the international language of air -traffic control and mindless abuse.

The enthusiasm even survives the opening ceremony. It is called "Kick Off - A Boy's Dream". Its designer Franco Dragon's mixture of stilt-walkers, 250,000 balloons and what appears to be a giant Habitat lampshade is far better than those that ushered in Euro 96 and the last World Cup for one simple reason: it is much, much shorter.

The game that follows is an illustration of what is sometimes referred to by local ironists as "Belgitude". Just as the Germans are never beaten until the final whistle, so the Belgians have never won until the ref points to the tunnel. And even then they are not altogether convinced.

From an apparently impregnable position the diables rouges do their best. Filip de Wilde, who looks like Don Howe's elder brother, falls over. Then fantastically Gert Verheyen who has, unbeknown to him, been substituted while receiving medical treatment on the touchline attempts to re-enter the action.

A match-forfeiting 12-man team is narrowly avoided by the frantic collective yelling and waving of every Fleming and Walloon in the stadium. With one near moment of madness the midfielder has united his disparate countrymen in the sort of collective endeavour many thought entirely beyond them.

When the match ends, the PA plays a rumpety-pumpety Belgian tune, the players celebrate as if they have won the tournament and several middle-aged men in over-elaborate knitwear pass by me blowing their noses and dabbing at tears.

In the three-storey blocks of flats outside the ground old ladies with blue-rinsed hair lean out of the windows, elbows resting on cushions placed across the metal window ledges and yell "Allez Belgique!" A group of lads in hats shaped like cones of frites chant "Champions, Champions", devil head-dresses flash on and off, orange in the dark. Over somewhere to the south rockets burst in the sky. A group in red, yellow and black fright wigs sing "Jupiler, Jupiler, Jupiler" in celebration of Belgium's biggest selling beer. The euphoria is so great, so infectious that it is not until I have been walking for 15 minutes that I realise I am heading in completely the wrong direction.

Back on the right track I follow two rotund, jester cap-sporting Francophones. They sing, bellow, wave at the girls screaming from the windows of passing cars. Then one of them shouts "Now for Italy!" "Ah," his friend answers thoughtfully, "but Italy will be a different thing".

"Yes," the first man agrees, "Italy will be tough."

"Just look at their players, "the second man counsels, "Inzaghi, Totti . . . "

"Del Piero," the first man adds. At that they lapse into silence.

Northerners that they are, the Belgians do not like to get carried away. Well, not for too long, anyway.

webTitle: Portugal's beautiful ones find hard edge to match their brilliance

fields.headline: Portugal's beautiful ones find hard edge to match their brilliance
fields.standfirst: England must stop Portugal's dynamic midfielders
fields.trailText: "No more excuses," says Humberto Coelho, Portugal's coach. He and his team are proud of the widespread admiration they attract from purists and romantics for the elegance of their play, but now is the time to turn all that aesthetic appeal into a trophy.
fields.body:
"No more excuses," says Humberto Coelho, Portugal's coach. He and his team are proud of the widespread admiration they attract from purists and romantics for the elegance of their play, but now is the time to turn all that aesthetic appeal into a trophy.

Not that this means abandoning their principles. One thing Euro 2000 will not lack is tactical variety, and no team is likely to provide armchair analysts with a more absorbing sight than England's first opponents, whose coach is combining a conventional defence with a highly unorthodox attack in an attempt to bring success to a perennially underachieving nation.

Coelho, aged 50, took over after Artur Jorge, his predecessor, had failed to win qualification for the last World Cup. A former libero with Benfica and Paris St Germain, known as the Portuguese Beckenbauer while receiving 64 caps between 1969 and 1983, he appears to have healed the rifts that characterised the previous regime, re-establishing unity within a squad based around a group of players who are in their late 20s and have played together since they were juniors.

In front of a standard back four and two holding midfield players, Coelho has constructed an attacking unit around the composed skills of Manuel Rui Costa, the Fiorentina playmaker who was his country's most admired player in England four years ago. The three forwards are allotted nominal positions, but tend to rotate around Rui Costa in a manner which can make them hard to decipher for defenders accustomed to thinking in straight lines.

Sometimes it works a treat. Portugal scored 32 goals in their qualifying matches, although it must be said that the opposition included Azerbaijan, Slovakia, Hungary and Lichtenstein, as well as the group winners, Romania. And in all the preparatory games for the tournament over the past few weeks, there has been nothing finer than the three goals scored by Luis Figo, Ricardo Sa Pinto and Nuno Capucho against Wales, each strike the product of luxuriant artistry combined with ruthless finishing.

Here, it seems, might be the long-delayed realisation of the potential evident in 1989 and 1991, when Portugal won the European Under-20 championship with a cadre of young players who became known as the "golden generation", the heirs to the legacy of the great Portuguese teams of the middle 1960s. Mind you, something similar was being said in the run-up to the 1996 finals, when roughly the same group of players arrived in England and took on the role of sentimental favourites. They turned out to be not quite up to the task, beating Croatia 3-0 before falling to the Czech Republic by the only goal of their quarter-final, Karel Poborsky's memorable running lob. But the experience gained by their top players with some of Europe's biggest clubs over the last four years is unlikely to have done anything other than strengthen their ability to compete with top international sides.

Oddly, Portugal have qualified only twice for the World Cup - although in 1966 they reached the semi-finals, falling to England after Eusebio had succumbed to the attentions of Nobby Stiles - and three times for the European championship, most memorably going down in the 1984 semi-final to a goal from Michel Platini which gave France, the ultimate champions, a 3-2 win in the last minute of extra-time.

But a lack of confidence is unlikely to be a problem for Coelho's squad. Last week, in their final warm-up game, they put 11 goals past a Dutch amateur side without reply and without even bothering to remove their training tops. And in Luis Filipe Madeira Caeiro, better known as Luis Figo, they possess a player who ranks with Zinedine Zidane, Raul Gonzalez and Edgar Davids among the tournament's most valuable individuals. Spoken of by many top coaches as the best attacking player in Europe last season, Figo cannot win games by himself but he is strong, skilful and persistent, and at 27 he is in his prime.

He is also one of those rare footballers capable of defining his own role. He wears a No7 on his back, and can be found most of the time on the right wing, from which he produces excellent crosses, but he likes to cut inside on runs that often carry him across to the opposite flank. Since he has both a fierce shot and a good sense of how to link the play, covering defenders can never be sure of his intentions.

Phil Neville, who is likely to be marking him tonight, spoke admiringly of his gifts at England's training camp last week, but managed to sound as though he was looking forward to the contest. The way to handle him, Neville said, will be for England's left side to keep Portugal's right-back so well occupied that Figo is both starved of possession and forced back to help out with defensive duties.

Portugal's other attacking players include Sa Pinto, the Real Sociedad forward who is the closest thing Coelho possesses to a recognised centre forward, and Joao Pinto, of Benfica, who is likely to line up on the left side. Rui Costa's companions in midfield will probably include Capucho of FC Porto and Sergio Conceicao of Lazio.

"We may be more or less the same group as in '96, but we're much more experienced now, particularly in midfield," Rui Costa observed. "Whatever shape the team is asked to adopt, we're confident. When we play with only one attacker, perhaps it gives Figo and Joao Pinto more freedom. But we've got other formations that we can use, with an extra attacking midfield player or two strikers, depending on the opposition."

Pre-tournament injury worries have surrounded their goalkeeper and captain, Vitor Baia, whose 69 caps are a Portuguese record, Abel Xavier, the Everton defender, and Sa Pinto, who injured his right knee before the weekend. All are apparently responding to treatment but another troublesome right knee has cost them the services tonight of Paulo Sousa, the player described by Rui Costa as "fundamental" to the team.

"Even though we aren't among the favourites," Rui Costa concluded, "we're hoping for strong performances and we want to go as far as possible, maybe even all the way to the final day. The Portuguese people expect a lot of us, and that puts a lot of pressure on the players, but we accept it. And it's the same for everyone in a tournament like this - the first game is vital. Against England, we want to get off to a good start."

fields.headline: Defeat is not an option
fields.standfirst: Kevin Keegan must keep his attacking instincts in check
fields.trailText: It is hard to recall a time when so much of the country wanted a popular personality to do well, yet so few people had confidence in the ability of the England team to do well by him.
fields.body:
As an England footballer Kevin Keegan was the mouse that roared. Tonight, as his team take on Portugal here in their opening game of Euro 2000, the nation will begin to find out if he has a similar stamp of greatness as England coach or whether at this level he is merely an optimistic pipsqueak.

It is hard to recall a time when so much of the country wanted a popular personality to do well, yet so few people had confidence in the ability of the England team to do well by him. The fitful, desperate manner of England's qualification under both Keegan and Glenn Hoddle has had much to do with this, but as Tony Adams said at the weekend: "That's gone, finished. It really doesn't matter how you get there."

True enough, yet the reality is that unless England show a marked improvement on the majority of their performances in the qualifiers they will be swiftly exposed by the punctilious nature of Portugal's passing game and reduced to trusting in the wayward nature of Portuguese finishing. Rarely has an England side needed to concentrate so hard on not giving the ball, and possibly the game, away.

Such thinking will influence the mood and character of the team Keegan will field tonight. The England coach is acutely conscious of his limitations as a tactician and does not want to be remembered as a cardboard cavalier, abandoning caution and leaving his side exposed to sucker counterpunches.

England, therefore, will approach Portugal much as they approached Brazil at Wembley just over a fortnight ago. The need to attack will be tempered by the necessity to cover space and not get caught out by opponents well tutored in the art of infiltrating defences.

Keegan is well aware of the importance of achieving the correct balance. "If we set out to stop Portugal then we'll be thrown on to the back foot immediately," he said last night. "Of course we'll have to defend well but there will be times when we need to go forward and cause them problems. I like my teams to be adventurous because that's the sort of person I am."

Tonight, however, it will not be a case of adventure unlimited. "I knew my team two weeks ago," Keegan admitted, and few will be surprised if he makes just the one change to the side that held the Brazilians 1-1, a result that would leave both England and Portugal satisfied, if unfulfilled, here this evening. It may simply be a case of Adams replacing Martin Keown in the back four and leaving the rest unaltered.

This would mean Dennis Wise retaining the short straw in the angst-ridden position on the left of midfield with the specific task of denying Luis Figo free runs at Phil Neville. Of course Keegan could yet persuade himself that Steve McManaman's natural aggression might have the same effect, but the England coach was impressed by the way Wise handled Brazil's Cafu.

The other matter Keegan has to decide is whether playing Sol Campbell alongside Adams would be too big a risk given Campbell's alarming loss of form and judgement in recent England games. Keown is Adams's regular partner at Arsenal, and with his tenacity and powers of concentration is better equipped to snuff out a specific danger.

Either way one of the more crucial roles tonight will be performed by Paul Ince, who played in front of the back four against Brazil and was England's outstanding player for the way he read and restricted the runs of Rivaldo, Amoroso and Ze Roberto. Keegan will want Ince to repeat the process against Rui Costa, the Portuguese player most likely to get between England's midfield and their defence.

Attacking potential

The way Paul Scholes is used tonight will be equally important. For some Keegan's order to Scholes "not to get on his bike" against Brazil but to play more of a holding game in midfield was evidence of the coach's readiness to compromise his positive instincts and deny England the free spirit that had so uplifted Newcastle United.

Yet Keegan possesses, in Scholes, Wise, McManaman, David Beckham, Alan Shearer, Michael Owen, Robbie Fowler and so on, the attacking potential to make a significant impact this time and banish to history the trail of tears that European championships had become for England teams before Euro 96. Keegan, remember, would have achieved something no other England manager has if he wins three matches in open play in this tournament.

It is less a matter of being cautious than taking care. That is taking care not to hand Portugal an early initiative with one careless pass. Taking care not to be caught on the break in a natural eagerness to score the first goal. Taking care not to invite long periods of Portuguese possession through aimless clearances or hopeless punts up the flanks from Gary or Phil Neville.

If Campbell does play he should be discouraged from making too many of those ambitious forays deep into the opposing half that may rouse England's supporters but usually set up counter-attacks when, almost inevitably, he loses the ball. Adams is better at going forward but England are as far away as ever from possessing defenders who can step out from the back at their ease and cause considerable problems with their creative play.

If England are to win tonight so much will depend on Owen getting the ball early enough and accurately enough to use his pace to catch Portugal's defenders on the turn. Shearer's strength in holding the ball up should enable Scholes to make those runs into scoring positions so crucial at this stage, and the quality of Beckham's crosses, whether in free play or from set-pieces, remains England's most reliable source of goals.

Having resumed training on Saturday morning and trained again yesterday evening Shearer's participation is no longer in doubt. Nevertheless the England captain has needed an anti-inflammatory injection to ease his knee injury.

fields.headline: Evergreen Hagi still flourishing
fields.standfirst: Germany v Romania
fields.trailText: Germany v Romania: Paul Gascoigne has probably got fed up doing it. But if he still bothers to think about what might have been, then he can only envy Gheorghe Hagi.
fields.body:
Paul Gascoigne has probably got fed up doing it. But if he still bothers to think about what might have been, then he can only envy Gheorghe Hagi.

Romania's veteran playmaker is 35, Gazza 33. Yet Hagi is still fit enough and good enough to play in Euro 2000 while Gascoigne is a spent force. It shows the difference when you look after yourself.

And it is to Hagi, coaxed out of international retirement to help Romania qualify top of their group, that the team look for inspiration in search of their first win in a European Championship finals. Romania's prospects of beating Germany tonight depend largely on how much more can be squeezed from an ageing squad.

Unlucky to be knocked out of Euro 96 and France 98, Romania's experienced warriors qualified without losing a game, beating Portugal away and drawing at home. But they lost to Greece in a warm-up match.

The fact that Hagi has shrugged off a groin strain has given Romania a timely lift. "At the moment there is not one German player who is capable of stopping Hagi," said his team-mate Dorinel Munteanu.

Hagi's status in Romania is almost royal. When he fell out with the coach Victor Piturca it was Piturca who was sacked. Emerich Jenei replaced him.

Hagi's fellow thirtysomethings include Chelsea's Dan Petrescu, 33, Gica Popescu, 33, Munteanu, 32 later this month, Miodrag Belodedici, 35, Ioan Lupescu, 32, and Bogdan Stelea, 33. So the pace and guile of the two strikers, Adrian Ilie and Viorel Moldovan will be crucial.

Germany could be without their striker Ulf Kirsten, who injured his back in training yesterday. But the 39-year-old libero Lothar Matthäus, who makes Hagi look young, has recovered from a thigh pull and is set to extend his world record of international appearances to 148. The midfielder Thomas Hässler, by comparison, will win only his 100th cap tonight.

Liège

Referee K Nielsen

(Denmark)

fields.headline: Euro 2000 Shorts
fields.trailText: 100% Raul, Nilsson dazed and confused, and Baby-faced Noah Solskjaer.
fields.body:
 Queues marooned thousands of fans at the German-Dutch border yesterday as police searched vehicles for potential troublemakers. Border police said more than 3,000 Turks, around 2,000 Italians and at least 1,000 Czechs had crossed the border by midday.

But some of them did not make it. German border police reported that they had turned back 16 fans since Saturday, including four Italians for being "potential trouble-makers", four Germans for being in possession of more than 100 tickets and five "anarchists".

One of the anarchists was arrested after they scuffled with guards who were trying to search their car, police reported.

There was trouble in Belgium when they showed the Italy-Turkey game on a large screen at Genk's ground. Fighting broke out between rival fans when stewards prevented supporters from coming on the pitch. No serious injuries were reported.

 Raul will be fit for Spain's first game today against Norway. The Real Madrid striker has not played since injuring a thigh in the Champions League final on May 22 but declared himself "absolutely fine, 100%" yesterday.

 Roland Nilsson was dazed and confused after Sweden's 2-1 defeat on Saturday and not just when he let in Bart Goor for Belgium's opening goal. The 36-year-old former Coventry full-back was substituted at half-time and spent Saturday night in hospital after suffering a concussion. He will miss Sweden's game against Turkey on Thursday.

"He is feeling better now," Sweden's team doctor Anders Valentin reported, "but he will definitely miss the next game and we are not sure about Italy."

 Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, the "baby-faced assassin" of legend and cliche, has had a baby of his own. On Friday night the Norway and Manchester United striker's partner presented him with a son, Noah.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 Diary
fields.standfirst: An open and shut case of type casting
fields.trailText: An open and shut case of type casting.
fields.body:
There will be plenty of glib stereotyping going on over the next few weeks, and some of it will actually appear accurate. More than a few Englishmen, no doubt, will be out to prove that the Anglo-Saxon can be just as sly, stupid and vicious as he is painted. Your Belgians will obviously be intent on eluding fame all over again. And your Slovenes, well, we'll find something to pin on them eventually.

Occasionally these stereotypes can be handy, as the Belgian police discovered at the opening game on Saturday. A Swedish supporter was robbed of his tickets and passport a few hours before the kick-off in Brussels, but police found the guilty men among the 50,000 fans at the game. They were alerted, they claimed, by the presence among the Nordic-type visiting supporters of two men exhibiting an excess of swarthiness. Case proven, your honour.

 Her majesty's press corps were ready on Saturday to get the batons out for one hapless tabloid news hack. After the Alan Shearer injury scare, delicate negotiations with the FA had gained representatives of the Sunday newspapers an audience with Kevin Keegan after training at Spa on Saturday, on the understanding that it would be carried out at pitchside and last no more than five minutes. Forty seconds into the interview, the news hack, tiring of information about the state of the centre-forward's knee, addressed the England manager: "Kevin, the Swedes have banned sex. What do you think?"

End of press conference.

 Some concerns are already being expressed about the organisation of the tournament. Outside the Gelredome yesterday fans suffered more than the usual ignorance and confusion. The company that had been contracted to provide signs for the venues is reported to have gone bust before they could deliver.

Our man at the match finally found the right entrance, only to discover, along with a number of other reporters, that the seat he had been allocated in the press box apparently did not exist.

A club steward was eventually called to help. "We have made a mistake," he told the by now sweaty and belligerent hacks. "There is no row three. You will have to leave."

He was eventually placated with the help of a seat in the radio broadcast area, but he has to cover two more games from Arnhem. "I'm a little worried," he said yesterday. "I'm in row three for those games too."

 The England squad is being supplied with copies of the Daily Mail and Daily Telegraph. But on Saturday these arrangements were found to be entirely inadequate - and an urgent request was sent out for the Racing Post.

 Clive Tyldesley must have something else on his mind. Possibly he had been seduced by the advertisement for TalkSport in Saturday's papers that depended to some extent on finding laddish amusement in the idea that Keegan "should be playing with two big strikers up front". How else do you explain his description of one of the Belgian forwards as "the buxom Strupar"?

 The Belgian team, it may have been pointed out to you, contains a number of players with names that are not famous even in Belgium. But tragically no room could be found for the sonorously named former Molenbeek striker Lambic Wawa, whose father named him after his favourite beer.

Much the same must have happened to Sol Campbell.

fields.headline: Bierhoff claims final belief
fields.standfirst: Germany's captain has regained the scoring touch just in time
fields.trailText: Oliver Bierhoff, 32, does not mind who partners him, now that he has rediscovered his scoring touch in time for another major tournament, having scored twice against the Czech Republic in the final of Euro 96, when he was a substitute.
fields.body:
Alan Shearer's insistence that he played against Malta for a bit of confidence-boosting flat- track bullying before Euro 2000 almost cost him his place in England's side for tonight's opening match against Portugal. And, as well as incurring the most talked about wounded knee since the eponymous battle, Shearer failed to score in a performance so poor that it re-opened the whole debate about the merit of his selection.

Germany's captain Oliver Bierhoff, another hero of Euro 96 who these days has to stand with his back against a wall to avoid the critics' knives, might also have questioned his wisdom after a similar exercise against Liechtenstein in a final warm-up. Though Bierhoff headed a goal after 56 seconds, he did not manage another in an 8-2 win while his striking rival Ulf Kirsten scored a hat-trick and Carsten Jancker two.

It goes to show that Tony Blair is not the only one whose attempts at manipulation tend to blow up in his face. And for Bierhoff, like Shearer, there was no need to risk injury against such pygmy opposition since he is certain, despite his own battalion of critics, to start tonight's game against Romania in Liège.

Again, as with Shearer, the argument is only about who plays the supporting role to Bierhoff's lead and that has become a late headache for Germany's coach Erich Ribbeck after a training injury to Kirsten yesterday. Although Jancker is third in seniority, Ribbeck thinks his style too similar to Bierhoff's and is likely to start with Bayer Leverkusen's Paulo Rink, the surprise member of the squad.

Bierhoff, 32, does not mind who partners him, now that he has rediscovered his scoring touch in time for another major tournament, having scored twice against the Czech Republic in the final of Euro 96, when he was a substitute. Despite a long run of poor per- formances and a belief that many German players are beginning to show their ages, the camp is once again running full of confidence.

While many German fans fear their side are so poor that they might fail to beat England, let alone qualify from their group, Bierhoff is worrying only about whom his team may face in the final. "I think it will be Holland," adding with typical German modesty, "and it will be hard to pick the winner from that game."

Secretly he has no doubt already cleared a space on his mantelpiece for the winner's medal and, quite possibly, the golden boot, too, as top scorer. He says of his critics: "They should remember what I have done for the country and the goals I have scored. I can still score goals against the best opposition and everyone in the team believes we can win this competition."

Bierhoff, however, was humiliatingly dropped to the bench after going more than 600 minutes without a goal. He ended that with two goals against the Czechs last month after coming on as a substitute, allowing Ribbeck to rub out his pencil marks and ink his captain's name into his team for tonight. He applied a rubber stamp over the top of it after the Liechtenstein goal.

Bierhoff says: "Everyone made a fuss because the Ger man captain was sitting on the bench but we are a team of 22 and it is normal that I am left out sometimes, just like the other players."

Ribbeck was impressed with the way his captain showed that he would fight for his place and age is clearly not a factor for him. After all, Ribbeck could hardly restrain himself from performing a couple of cartwheels when the 39-year-old Lother Matthäus passed a fitness test yesterday and Thomas Hässler, 34, is also expected to start tonight.

Matthäus, of course, who will no doubt ruffle Tony Adams's hair on Saturday and tell him, in whatever the equivalent German phrase, that he is nowt but a lad, has not suffered the physical battering that Bierhoff has. But Bierhoff, like Shearer, believes he is still his country's best and both players have their manager's backing - at least until after tonight.

webTitle: Adams stirred by spirit of Harry and St George

fields.headline: Adams stirred by spirit of Harry and St George
fields.trailText: Football journalists are a decent bunch on the whole. Tony Adams is reading Henry V but despite the sharp intake of breath that greeted this unlikely news nobody spoiled things by telling him who won.
fields.body:
Football journalists are a decent bunch on the whole. Tony Adams is reading Henry V but despite the sharp intake of breath that greeted this unlikely news nobody spoiled things by telling him who won.

"I've had an interest in Henry V for some time," Adams explained. So shortly before England departed for Euro 2000 he bought a copy in a Putney bookshop.

Question: "Did the guy say have a good European Championship?"

Answer: "No, he said £2.99 please. I'm no different from any other human being going in and buying a book."

In truth there is more of ancient Pistol about Adams nowadays than Harry the king. Last September he had a double hernia operation and more recently he has had a spot of back ache. And though Adams insists that "I'm fitter than I've ever been," he is careful to add that "I'm 33 not 19 so I cherish each moment as though it might be my last".

Interviews with Tony Adams have become something of a tradition before England's first match in a major tournament. As a reformed alcoholic and changed character he is almost the holy man blessing the troops on their way to the front.

Adams, however, no longer sounds like a suitable case for counselling and has broken the habit of talking about himself in the third person, which could get a little confusing. Yet it is clear that he continues to live for the day, the match, the moment, and that this is the attitude he will adopt for England's opening game against Portugal here tonight.

In Kevin Keegan's eyes Adams is the team's most important defender, perhaps its most important player. Instead Adams prefers to keep faith with fate. "Sometimes it's your moment, it's your time," he muses. "But sometimes you get injuries and people dip in and out of form. If they dip into form at the right time then you've got a chance of winning it.

"Obviously you've got to have talent. You have to work and prepare, but it's not just a matter of hard work and having luck at the right time. To win these tournaments you need talent."

He'll ask the players what they think."

But as he explained: "Captaincy depends on your relationship with the manager. If you've got the armband on you sometimes get more respect from the players but here they seem to respect me anyway, armband or not."

This is as it should be. When Steven Gerrard won his first full cap against Ukraine Adams took the 20-year-old Liverpool midfielder aside for a chat later described by Keegan as the most important two minutes of Gerrard's career so far.

Certainly Adams will appreciate his moment in Eindhoven this evening. He is not going to quote aloud from Henry V until or unless England make significant progress in Euro 96, but you hope he has reached the bit about storming breaches and trust that the walls he organises will not be filled with English dead.

webTitle: Abstinence and the opposite of sexy football

fields.headline: Abstinence and the opposite of sexy football
fields.trailText: Jorge Valdano: In this European Championship sex is a burning issue and I feel obliged to toss in my own depth charge. During the 86 World Cup some of the Argentina squad asked for a meeting to address a vital issue: sexual relations.
fields.body:
In this European Championship sex is a burning issue and I feel obliged to toss in my own depth charge. I apologise to sensitive readers but the language of football is not very academic and, also, a minimum of realism is required.

During the 86 World Cup, when we had been cooped up in Mexico for a month, some of the squad asked for a meeting to address a vital issue: sexual relations.

On the team bus the squad chanted terrace-style songs on the subject in the direction of the coach. Side 1: "Bilardo, Bilardo/stop messing around/give us permission/because we want to shag." Side 2: "Give us some time off/a bit of freedom/so we can shag a little/and give up wanking." (These rhyme in Spanish.) Romanticism, as you can see, knows no creative barriers.

When the players and the technical team spent a long time debating if there should be permission for a general cutting loose, Ricardo Bochini, who spoke little but always said the right thing, got up to speak. "I don't understand you lot," he said. "You'd put the cup at stake just to have sexual relations."

It was an observation of impeccable responsibility but Bochini had an ace up his sleeve related to what in sport is known as delayed gratification and on the stock market as investment. "Don't you understand that, if we win the World Cup, the next day the whole country will want to shag us?" Socrates, the Greek philosopher (not the Brazilian) never reached such a pitch of persuasion.

On to football, which is no less important than what we just touched on. To each his own. And speaking of philosophers, let us dwell a moment on the words of the Norwegian coach Nils Johan Semb, whose team go into action tomorrow.

"What I'm aiming to do is win," he said, trying to distinguish himself from all the coaches in the world who, as we know, go out to lose. He went on: "Results come first and aesthetics after" - as if you had not guessed. Fortunately he concluded: "I have established that the most direct and simple way to win is with long balls." (Would he say that in Brazil?)

Nils, fleshing out his anthology of primitive play, even confessed that he was planning to defend with nine men behind the ball. Plus the goalkeeper, let me remind him, and that makes 10. A single man up front, then, and one it is easy to spot because he is 6ft 4in tall and easy to name because he is called Flo. That is where all the long balls will be heading while a few players (very few) will come up from the back to support and the rest (many) will watch unruffled from a distance. Nothing against Nils (to each his own again), except to point out a couple of little fibs.

F irst, that neither this method nor any other has been shown to be reliably effective, because football is not a science where you can do controlled experiments in the laboratory. Second, those long balls are more a means of defence than of attack (while the ball is far away, those at the back have time to sort themselves out). In theory it sounds primitive and boring but in practice it is insupportable.

The Flos of this world will be a constant in this tournament - towering forwards, with great power to battle for the ball and in the air. The most famous is Oliver Bierhoff (6ft 3in) who made it to Milan and the German side (that is, to the top) on his heading. Sweden's Flo is called Kennet Andersson (6ft 1in), a heavy and ungainly forward who has 75 caps; Turkey's is Hakan Sukur (6ft 3in), another member of the awkward squad. The Czech Republic have two good examples: Jan Koller (6ft 7in) and Vratislav Lokvenc (6ft 3in).

As football tries to make the creative midfielder extinct there is no longer any intermediate stop for the ball to rest a little. All that is left is the long punt from the back . . . Suffice it to say that the less brains there are in the middle the more inches there are up front.

Jorge Valdano won the World Cup with Argentina in 1986 and coached Real Madrid to the Spanish title in 1994.
