fields.headline: England 2 - 3 Portugal
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Portugal: Baia, Costa, Vidigal, Couto, Figo, Pinto, Rui Costa, Dimas, Xavier, Bento, Gomes. Subs: Espinha, Quim, Jorge, Sousa, Sa Pinto, Conceicao, Costinha, Beto, Capucho, Secretario.

England: Seaman, G. Neville, Adams, Campbell, P. Neville, Beckham, Scholes, Ince, McManaman, Shearer, Owen. Subs: Martyn, Wright, Keown, Southgate, Barry, Gerrard, Wise, Barmby, Heskey, Fowler, Phillips.

Referee: Anders Frisk (Sweden)

1 So here we go for England's opener in Eindhoven. England kick-off and everyone scampers about as Scholes boots it upfield towards Shearer. G Neville takes England's first throw and Shearer gets a header on target but straight at 'keeper Baia.
3 GOAL! England 1 - 0 Portugal P Neville launches a probing ball down the left towards Shearer. The ball gets knocked out to Beckham on the right, he crosses, Scholes rises and heads down to Baia's left to open the scoring. Text book stuff.
6 England fans in full voice as Portugal attempt to regroup and recover fromm the sucker-punch opening to this game. Portugal win a corner. It is played deep and cleared for another corner.
7 Shearer clears the corner as far as Dimas. England regain possession and break, but immediatley lose the ball.
9 Rui Costa tries to get on the end of a centre but is ruled offside as he strikes.
11 Portugal push up but are unable to get a shot on goal as England hold tight at the back. They win a corner, Adams clears but Portugal remain in England's half. Rui Costa squeezes in a cross from deep on the right and beats Seaman, but Jaiao Pinto's header carves out a trough directly beneath him rather than in the goal-mouth
15 Portugal have got themselves together and Figo and Rui Costa are looking the part, trying to get an equaliser. Rui Costa shoots from the edge of the area and forces Seaman down to his left to make the save.
17 Portugal win a free-kick, Figo takes from 25 yards and fires over the bar.
18 GOAL! England 2 - 0 Portugal Now we're talking. Beckham again the man of the moment when he crosses from the right; the ball goes behind Scholes and lands at McManaman's feet for him to rifle in a half-volley.
21 Rui Costa gets in behind the England midfield, centres for Joao Pinto but Seaman clears from his feet.
22 GOAL! England 2 - 1 Portugal Portugal get back in the game when Figo unleashes a shot from 25 yards that leaves Seaman a spectator as it cruises into the top right-hand corner of the net.
25 McManaman shimmies his way into a position deep on the left but is dispossessed for a Portugal throw when he should perhaps have had a free-kick.
26 McManaman again down the left, cuts inside, finds Shearer just inside the area, Shearer turns and crosses but the ball runs in front of Owen who is unmarked on the far post.
28 Rui Costa finds the unnaturally blonde Xavier on the right after exchanging passes with Gomes through midfield and his cross is palmed away from the advancing Joaio Pinto by Seaman.
32 Neville crosses from the left, but Portugal clear for a corner; Beckham takes but it comes to nothing.
35 Owen goes down after taking a clumsy hack on the side of his knee. Thankfully he is up and running soon enough.
38 GOAL! England 2 - 2 Portugal Rui Costa delivers a perfect cross from the right and Joaio Pinto brings the scores level with a superb glancing header that beats Seaman at the far post.
40 Owen tries a volley; it goes over the bar after taking a deflection for a corner. Shearer takes but Portugal clear after a bout of scrappy passing in their area as England try to regain the initiative.
42 Rui Costa runs right through England on the left, cuts inside and wastes an intended pass to Figo.
43 Portugal in the ascendancy as Rui Costa shoots from fully 35 yards out.
44 Booking Ince for a crunching tackle, one of those where the ball is won but nine out of ten refs would still see yellow
45 Half-time.

46 Substitution Heskey on for Owen. Portugal win two corners in quick succession and the second has Seaman struggling and unsighted, but Joaio Pinto fires over.
49 Beckham delivers a deep cross to McManaman on the left and England end up with a corner. Beckham takes from the right and Adams gets up to head just wide of the far post; the whistle goes for an unidentifible infringement.
51 Ince finds McManaman deep on the left. After getting away from the attentions of Xavier, he back-heels for Neville to reach the by-line and cross for Shearer, but his header goes wide with 'keeper Baia beaten.
53 McManaman goes down after taking an inocuous-looking knock on the knee when trying to tackle Rui Costa.
55 McManaman back on the field.
56 Scholes almost gets on the end of a Heskey knock-on from Neville's long throw into the Portugal area.
57 Portugal break and try to take up residence in the England half. England clear and break; Heskey chases upfield but Baia beats him to it.
58 Substitution Wise on for McManaman.
59 GOAL! England 2 - 3 Portugal Nightmare! Rui Costa gets away in midfield, threads the ball through to Gomes just inside the area and, under pressure, he lifts the ball over the sprawling Seaman.
61 England win a free-kick, Beckham takes from 30 yards out and attempts to find Adams but Portugal clear. England win a corner, again he aims for Adams but Xavier gets up to clear.
66 England appear to have reverted to their former ways - hopeful long balls towards the centre forwards with no discernable buld-up. Portugal must be laughing.
67 Scholes has half a chance in front of goal, but Vidigal clears.
68 England win a free-kick, Beckham takes and Heskey makes a meal of a shooting chance in the six-yard box before losing possession.
70 Scholes drills in a shot from just inside the area and floors the blocking Jorge Costa.
71 England putting the Portugal goal under pressure but leaving themselves wide open at the back as Portugal look to break.
73 Wise and Scholes exchange passes on the edge of the area, but Scholes's final pass is too long for the dinky Wise to get in a shot.
75 The game has settled into a pattern of England pushing up with Portugal sitting back and waiting to break.
76 Substitution Conceicao for Joaio Pinto.
77 Beckham delivers perhaps the worst shot of his career when he picks up possession on the left, cuts inside and then sends the ball to Amsterdam.
78 Neville's throw from deep on the right is knocked on by Adams for Scholes to shoot, only to see his effort blocked. Agonising stuff for England.
80 Figo has a crack from distance - wide of the left-hand upright.
82 Portugal have a corner, Rui Costa takes but England clear. England now looking as if they have given up the ghost. All too familiar unfortunately.Substitution: Keown on for Adams.
83Scholes, battling to the last, has another pop from just outside the area, but yet again it is blocked well.
84 Xavier gets away down the right and feeds Figo, but Campbell tackles well on the edge of the area.
85 Substitution Beto on for Rui Costa.
88 Conceicao plays in Beto deep on the right but his cross is poor. Time is running out for England as Portugal make them chase the ball.
89 Booking A bemused 'keeper Baia for what could only be time-wasting.
90 Substitution Capucho on for Gomes. Three minutes of time added on to play. Scrappy play sees out the half before referee Frisk blows for full-time. England 2 - 3 Portugal. All very deflating after England's dream start.

Germany: Kahn, Linke, Nowotny,
Babbel, Matthaus, Rink,
Jeremies, Haessler, Ziege, Scholl,
Bierhoff.
Subs: Lehmann, Butt, Rehmer, Bode,
Kirsten, Ballack, Hamann,
Wosz, Deisler, Ramelow, Jancker.

Babbel, Matthaus, Rink,
Jeremies, Haessler, Ziege, Scholl,
Bierhoff.

Kirsten, Ballack, Hamann,
Wosz, Deisler, Ramelow, Jancker.

Romania: Stelea, Petrescu, Ciobotariu,
Popescu, Galca, Munteanu, Chivu,
Filipescu, Hagi, Moldovan, Ilie.
Subs: Lobont, Prunea, Mutu, Petre,
Lupescu, Rosu, Belodedici,
Ganea, Lincar, Contra, Hildan.

Referee: K Nielsen (Denmark)

1 min Germany kick off. An early near-suicidal back pass leads to Bierhoof nicking a corner for the Germans. A second is won from the cross but this is cleared slightly more convincingly by Romania.
4 GOAL! Germany 0 - 1 Romania Linke's slip lets in Ilie who squares it across the goal for Moldovan who pelts it high into the roof of the net.

fields.headline: Dutch snatch penalty prize
fields.standfirst: Click here for full Euro 2000 coverage
fields.trailText: Holland looked ready to put their clog in it and the sense of despondency and anti-climax was palpable before a late and hotly disputed penalty from Frank de Boer salvaged this poor performance by the co-hosts.
fields.body:
Holland looked ready to put their clog in it and the sense of despondency and anti-climax was palpable before a late and hotly disputed penalty from Frank de Boer, after his twin brother had his shirt pulled by Jiri Nemec, salvaged this poor performance by the co-hosts.

Twice the woodwork saved Holland in the second half as the Czechs recovered from a shaky start to dominate. From the 19th minute Frank Rijkaard's team managed only one shot on target. Short of ideas and fluency, this was not the stuff of champions.

The Czech coach Jozef Chovanec was outraged at the penalty decision. "It's a scandal. Several players are crying in the dressing room right now, and it doesn't surprise me."

Frank de Boer admitted his team had been lucky. "You need to have luck in a tourna ment so I hope we have had our luck and we can just start playing football."

Holland knew nothing short of victory would do. Long before kick-off all but the Czech end of the stadium had been transformed into an sea of orange, giving it the look of a huge Jaffa plantation. Everything from inflatable clogs to hats and shirts were on show. The pre-match renditions of "We are the champions" left no doubt what was required from the Dutch, who started with Marc Overmars on the bench and Barcelona's Boudewijn Zenden on the left flank.

The Czechs had clearly come with the intention of stifling in midfield, pulling men behind the ball and hitting on the counter-attack, deploying the huge Jan Koller alone up front. Tomas Rosicky stuck close to Clarence Seedorf; Pavel Nedved tried to keep an eye on Edgar Davids.

Davids, though, proved too slippery to be held down by the Lazio man, a more natural offensive player. Inside 25 minutes Nedved had been booked for a foul on his opposite number. And taking their lead from Davids' bursts and passing, and Patrick Kluivert's mobility in attack, Holland poured forward.

They might have been three goals up within 20 minutes but for Pavel Srnicek's agility and one near miss. Srnicek first got down low to deny Dennis Bergkamp after Tomas Repka had blocked a Kluivert shot. Then the Sheffield Wednesday goalkeeper palmed aside a Kluivert effort and recovered to block Zenden's follow-up. When finally he was beaten by Bergkamp the ball flashed inches wide.

The Czech team hardly looked the third best in the world as the Fifa rankings suggest. Initially they were restricted to scraps of possession but, typically, Holland went off the boil as the half progressed. The Czechs, now using Karel Poborsky to shadow Davids, came more into the match with Nedved shooting over from long range.

The Dutch clearly failed to digest the importance of that warning. Within two minutes of the start of the second half they should have fallen behind. Nedved, free to roam at last, was the creator, outwitting Michael Reiziger down the left flank and crossing to Poborksy at the far post. But in a replay of Paul Gascoigne's famous miss against Germany at Euro 96, the former Manchester United player slid the ball wide from a yard out.

Before long, whistles of derision were pouring down on the Dutch from the stands as the Czechs, showing more ambition, took control. Nedved was now running the game, first pulling the ball back for Koller, whose shot was well saved by Edwin van der Sar, and then bursting through and forcing the keeper to save at his near post. Only the opposite upright denied him a goal in the 57th minute as he outjumped Davids to meet Nemec's cross with a fine header.

This was not what Frank Rijkaard had hoped for in his first competitive match in charge of Holland. But his players seemed to have lost all rhythm and looked too predictable in attack. The woodwork again saved them just after the hour, Koller heading a Poborksy free-kick against the bar. At that stage the Dutch might have settled for a draw.

webTitle: Zidane the usual suspect as Danes suffer blue murder

fields.headline: Zidane the usual suspect as Danes suffer blue murder
fields.standfirst: Click here for full Euro 2000 coverage
fields.trailText: In football certain things can be guaranteed and it was no different here. Zinedine Zidane was at the hub of everything, Nicolas Anelka loitered with intent and Laurent Blanc sought out Fabien Barthez to plant the obligatory kiss on his shiny pate.
fields.body:
If the French wanted to make a statement of intent here last night, the message came across loud and clear. Only Germany - who else? - can claim to have been World Cup and European Championship winners at the same time but do not bet your mortgage against Roger Lemerre's team matching them.

In football certain things can be guaranteed and it was no different here. Zinedine Zidane was at the hub of everything, Nicolas Anelka loitered with intent and Laurent Blanc sought out Fabien Barthez to plant the obligatory kiss on his shiny pate. As for Denmark, Peter Schmeichel screamed blue murder at his defenders, the referee, anyone really who was within earshot. Even an unsuspecting ball-boy felt the sharp end of his tongue.

In the end, however, it was not a matter for the Danes to apportion blame but a time to marvel at the French artistry. "Magnifique," purred Lemerre.

Only Anelka could have the season he has had and still end up with a couple of gongs for the sideboard. But here he was, clearly enjoying himself alongside Thierry Henry, past and present Arsenal strikers with enough pace to expose the most steely defence.

It was Anelka's considerable threat that manoeuvred the opening goal after 16 minutes. Only a couple of minutes earlier the Real Madrid striker had rounded Schmeichel but angled his shot into the side-netting. This time the Danish goalkeeper got his hands to the ball as Anelka surged into the penalty area but was caught in no-man's-land as it popped out for Blanc to stroke into an open goal.

The remainder of the first 45 minutes saw near-incessant pressure from the French - which is just as well considering the mayhem that had reigned in their defence during the opening exchanges.

It needed Barthez to charge off his goalline to deny Jon Dahl Tomasson after Marcel Desailly had got into a terrible mess. Then it was Lilian Thuram's turn to get in a tangle, scuffing a straightforward clearance to present Ebbe Sand with a chance that he seemed too bewildered to accept. If the French continue to offer so much in the way of charity, they may find other opponents are more receptive.

"There were a few early problems," said Lemerre. "The first 10 minutes was not very good at all but after that everything was OK. This is a hard group and I'm relieved we have got three points because the burden of being world champions can be hard to accept."

The relentless pace slowed after the interval but the suspicion remained that France were toying with the opposition. When it took their fancy they seemed able to move effortlessly on to a new plateau.

So it was in the 64th minute. Almost inevitably Zidane was the architect, applying the back-spin of a sand wedge to drop an exquisite ball behind Denmark's defence. Henry was on it in an instant and who was going to catch him? With Schmeichel exposed, Henry streamed almost half the length of the pitch before expertly picking his spot.

For Denmark, it was too much to comprehend, let alone counter. "There are times when you must give the credit to the opposition," offered their coach Bo Johansson. "We were playing a team that could be the eventual winners. It is wrong to say they are a team just with pace because they have brains as well. In fact, they have everything. And Zidane, he is very special.

"This is a very hard group, possibly the hardest, and we have everything to do now."

The final minutes were seen out by France showboating and Johansson attempting to add some virility to their attack by replacing Tomasson with Mikkel Beck.

Anelka was also substituted and his replacement, Sylvain Wiltord of Bordeaux, wasted no time in pilfering a third goal deep into stoppage time after being teed up by the Arsenal pair of Henry and the substitute Patrick Vieira.

All the Danes had offered in the second half was a couple of long-range efforts and a half-hearted penalty appeal when Desailly turned his left shoulder towards the ball. Had it been given, there really would have been a story: Schmeichel versus Barthez from 12 yards.

fields.trailText: For a team normally expected to leave the sanctuary of the starting gate smitten by lethargy, Italy, in relative terms at least, were positively sprightly in the sunshine here yesterday.
fields.body:
For a team normally expected to leave the sanctuary of the starting gate smitten by lethargy, Italy, in relative terms at least, were positively sprightly in the sunshine here yesterday.

True, it did take a stroke of good fortune in the shape of a debatable penalty award to help them negotiate safe passage through a commendably robust Turkish challenge but even taking into account their fondness for pratfalls it will be a major surprise if they do not emerge as Group B winners.

They may have an insecure goalkeeper in Francesco Toldo and a defence often so generous it betrays a glorious tradition, but much of the old swagger remains and at the end of a malice-free afternoon it had proved too much for Turkey.

The Turkish defence that de lights in living on its nerves was surprisingly matched by the child-like qualities of an Italian forward line that seemed to shiver in apprehension each and every time a half-chance presented itself.

That is to say a game so wildly open it would not have looked out of place in a local park should really have been decided in the Azzurri's favour long before midway through an absorbing first half when Turkey began - slowly, it must be said - to wake up to the possibilities.

Having opted to use the flamboyance of the infuriatingly erratic Francesco Totti, the Italian coach Dino Zoff will presumably have been horrified, if hardly surprised, to see all the attractive openings fall to the feet of his strike-partner, Filippo Inzaghi. It was ever thus.

Sadly, Inzaghi seemed to believe he was playing in a park and as his mind began to wander, the shots began to drift wide of what was quite often a woefully unprotected target.

Certainly the Juventus forward should have transformed base metal into precious gold after 18 minutes but after leaping enthusiastically to reach first a Stefano Fiore cross from the right he could do no more than steer his header well wide of the goalkeeper Rustu Recber's far post.

Turkey tend to wear an inferiority complex like a favoured overcoat on the big occasion and at times they played as if they knew their fate had been sealed long before it actually was.

But they do have players capable of transforming games, most notably Galatasaray's Sergen Yalcin, a central midfielder of some expertise and pedigree.

It was his marvellous raking drive from 20 or so yards just before Inzaghi's dreadful miss which rekindled hope among the predominantly Turkish audience and while the shot fell fractionally wide, it did constitute an alarm call which the Italian defence wisely heeded.

Turkey deserve much credit, for after Antonio Conte had moved Italy in front with a clever hooked volley on 52 minutes, they would have been forgiven had they hoisted the white flag.

They did not and 10 minutes later they were level, Okan Buruk arriving unannounced to head home Sergen's nicely flighted free-kick.

After failing to score during Euro 96, the celebrations were vociferous and understandably sustained.

It was all to no avail, however. Twenty minutes from the end the Scottish referee Hugh Dallas was one of only a handful inside the Gelredome who believed Ogun Temizkenoglu's shoulder charge on Inzaghi to be illegal.

After much bottle-throwing and rancour, Inzaghi steered home from the spot to finally crush Turkish spirit. He conceded Italy had been lucky to win the penalty and said that converting the kick had been a test of his resolve. "You have to just cut yourself off, but of course there were so many things going through my head. It's terrible. I just hit it hard because I thought he knew where I was going to put it."

"We should have scored more goals," said Zoff with a Keatonesque stare. He remains a hard man to please.

Turkey ( 4-1-3-2) Rustu; Fatih, Temizkenoglu, Alpay, Abdullah; Tayfur; ,Korkut, Okan (Ergun, 89min), Sergen (Arif, 80) ; Sukur, Umit (Tugay, 75).

Italy ( 3-5-2) : Toldo; Cannavaro, Nesta, Maldini; Zambrotta, Conte, Albertini, Fiore (Del Piero, 74), Pessotto (Iuliano, 62 ); Inzaghi, Totti (Di Livio, 83).

Referee: H Dallas (Scotland).

Attendance: 28,000

fields.headline: Hunting the hunters
fields.standfirst: The debate about fox hunting has been hijacked by extremists and the issue is much more complex than both sides would have us believe, writes Guardian journalist Stephen Moss
fields.trailText: The debate about fox hunting has been hijacked by extremists and the issue is much more complex than both sides would have us believe, writes Guardian journalist Stephen Moss.
fields.body:
Should people in expensive pink coats be allowed to hunt with hounds? How odd that what seems, on the surface, such a recondite question has come to dominate the political agenda - the litmus test of Labour radicalism, the moral core of the government's programme, the great issue dividing the country.

As sports minister Kate Hoey remarked over the weekend, there are half a dozen more pressing issues, but Downing Street wants this fight now. The hunters are about to become the hunted.

Almost all the arguments deployed on both sides in the debate are nonsense. Hunting will cost rural jobs but not as many as the Countryside Alliance claims; compared with the crisis that continues to dog UK manufacturing, the numbers are a drop in the ocean: rural life will go on.

The conservation arguments are also largely bogus: the numbers of foxes killed by hunts is relatively low and hunting an inefficient way of controlling the fox population. As we learned recently, the Beaufort hunt has to encourage foxes by feeding them and protecting their earths before it kills them: hunts want to claim a socially useful function and set themselves up as the farmer's friend, but don't believe them. Hunters hunt because they enjoy it. But they don't, as the anti-hunters world have it, do it for the pleasure of the kill. Ignore talk of all those blood-smearing rituals.

They do it for the thrill of the chase, the camaraderie among hunters, the love of the hounds, the pleasure of the countryside. Most of them couldn't care less whether the fox is caught or, as it frequently does, escapes, though they would like it to be a good couple of hours before the hounds lose the scent.

In any case, when a fox is caught and killed there are likely to be very few of the hunt present. A hunt comprises an elite group - comprising the master of foxhounds, his professional staff and the odd distinguished visitor - and everyone else, usually called "the field", who trail behind trying to keep up, jumping what fences they can and frequently falling off. Following a long chase, the hunting field can resemble the Grand National after a particularly dramatic race. The kill is neither here nor there; the game, the chase, is the thing.

Just as blood lust should be discounted, so should the idea of hunting being exclusively for toffs. Lots of toffs hunt, the royal family and aristos hunt, keeping horses (and to hunt regularly you need several) is expensive, but farmers hunt, solicitors hunt, insurance salesmen hunt, and lots of less wealthy people follow the hunt on foot. It is a rural day out, a chance to meet, talk, gossip, socialise. The fox is just an excuse for a get-together.

The hunting debate has been hijacked by extremes on both sides: the animal cruelty mob who will happily hit a hunter on the head with a pole to make their point (their idea of humane treatment does not seem to extend to mammals without fur) and the ultra-conservatives who argue that all rural life will end if a ban is passed.

I am somewhere in between, an agnostic about hunting. I believe that its ancient traditions cannot be lightly cast aside, that it is not the brutal, bloody, elitist activity berated by the animal rights brigade, that is does have an important function. But I also believe that the fox feels fear in the course of the hunt, that it recognises it is running for its life, that we are making sport of its suffering.

The issue is desperately difficult and none of the practical arguments alluded to above - jobs, conservation, rural stability - really helps. It is a moral issue.

A couple of years ago, to get an insight into this thorniest of subjects, I went hunting with the Beaufort on a lovely, crisp December day down in Gloucestershire. Prince Charles was out with the hunt that day, though he joined the elite group up front and you caught only the occasional glimpse of him. I had borrowed a horse and was looked after by a marvellous man, a former master of foxhounds and excellent rider. At one point he noticed that another member of the field had fallen off and her horse had bolted; he excused himself and rode off in pursuit, reining the horse in and returning it to its bruised rider. (The number of injuries and deaths among participants is high: any true anti-toff agitator would campaign for the retention of hunting as a way of reducing the old landed elite.)

My escort's main interest was in watching the hounds work. After 40 years of hunting (his father had also been mad-keen), he could understand what the dogs were telling each other as they combed copses sniffing for the scent. He took an aesthetic pleasure in the hunt, and that ultimately is the crux of the argument. Are we willing to foreclose on an activity that has been a central element in rural life, the heart of National Hunt racing, and a contributor to our literature (Siegfried Sassoon, the great poet and pacifist, was an obsessive, four-days-a-week hunter, hardly bearing out the blood-lust linkage)?

Hunting is part of the fabric of British life, and has been for centuries. It is where much of sport began. It has contributed greatly to our language, to a particular way of seeing the world. Critics will say that, in their time, bear-baiting and cock-fighting played the same cultural role, but hunting is more deeply entrenched, less obviously vicious (bears were baited, cocks torn apart, in combat, for pleasure and as a gambling medium).

My day with the Beaufort left me with a higher estimation of huntsmen and a realisation of the social and cultural value of hunting. I am still left sitting uncomfortably on the fence, wary of the committed on both sides, but what I do know is that if hunting is banned something important will have been silenced, a slice of life lost, a way of seeing erased.

A little humility among those claiming the moral high ground and demanding an end to barbarism would be in order.

webTitle: Swaying Millennium Bridge to close after two days

fields.headline: Swaying Millennium Bridge to close after two days
fields.trailText: Central London's swaying £18.2m Millennium Bridge is to close just two days after it opened to the public, its builders announced today.
fields.body:
Central London's swaying £18.2m Millennium Bridge is to close just two days after it opened to the public, its builders announced today.

The 320m-long Thames crossing, which links St Paul's Cathedral in the City with the Tate Modern gallery in Southwark, will close from 10pm tonight. It could be shut for weeks.

The suspension bridge swayed alarmingly under the weight of thousands of people at its official opening on Saturday. Tonight, the Millennium Bridge Trust, which organised its building, said the bridge would close to allow engineers to continue their investigation "into the cause of excessive movement of the bridge in certain conditions and to carry out work to correct the problem".

It is understood that the closure of the pedestrians-only bridge could last for weeks. Its closure will be a huge disappointment to Londoners and to the tens of thousands of tourists heading for the capital this summer. Designed by the highly-acclaimed Foster and Partners, the bridge was inaugurated by the Queen last month.

The company said the bridge was intended to have some movement, but those crossing it this weekend spoke of considerable sway.

The first new river crossing in central London since Tower Bridge opened in 1894, the bridge was officially opened to the public on Saturday by the former model Heather Mills, who led schoolchildren on a sponsored walk.

The large number of people on the bridge - 160,000 visited over the weekend - exposed a fault on the structure. It closed for 10 minutes on Saturday because of excessive swaying and stewards have limited the numbers allowed on it since.

A team from the bridge's engineers, Arup, were inspecting the bridge today in an attempt to locate the problem. The bridge remained open to pedestrians but the trust said it would close at 10pm. David Bell, chairman of the trust, apologised to people who might have felt discomfort or "unease" crossing the bridge on Saturday. "The current problem, which involves excessive movement on the bridge in certain conditions, is something that we will overcome," he said.

Millennium projects appear jinxed. The £758m Millennium Dome has endured a cash and visitor crisis which has led to the ousting of both its chairman and chief executive. And the opening of the Millennium Wheel, officially known as the British Airways London Eye, was postponed after a problem with the passenger pods.

fields.headline: Man critical after 'racist' attack
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: An Englishman was critically ill in a Dublin hospital last night after he suffered multiple stab wounds in a suspected racist attack as he made his way home early yesterday with his black wife and their son.
fields.body:
An Englishman was critically ill in a Dublin hospital last night after he suffered multiple stab wounds in a suspected racist attack as he made his way home early yesterday with his black wife and their son.

The victim, a 46-year-old from Bristol, needed 18 pints of blood after he was stabbed in the chest, face and arms in Dublin city centre. He had been celebrating his wedding anniversary and his son's 24th birthday.

He was on a life-support machine in intensive care at St James's hospital in Dublin. His wife and son were keeping vigil at his bedside.

Garda arrested three men. They were being questioned at Pearse Street station, which is close to the scene of the attack. Police spokesmen were making no comment, except to say it was an unprovoked assault. But sources close to the investigation said there was little doubt that the attack was racially motivated.

The Bristol man and his wife were making their way with their son to his home in the suburb of Ringsend after the family celebration. The son moved to Dublin to work some time ago.

They were unofficially named last night as David Richardson, his wife, Laverna, and son, Christian. The victim, who is white, intervened when a group of youths outside a fast food shop taunted his son and wife.

Members of the gang followed him, stabbing him several times shortly after 1am in what was described as a frenzied assault. Police appealed for witnesses to come forward. They wanted to hear from a taxi driver in the area, and from the occupants of a van, who doubled back to take a second look as the attack was going on.

The development comes as racism in the Irish Republic appears to be dramatically on the increase, fuelled by the rise in refugees.

There have been numerous demonstrations this year against refugees arriving in several towns throughout the country.

Police say they keep no records specifically of racist violence. But counsellors say that there is no doubt it is burgeoning, and they have long feared such an attack would end in murder.

fields.headline: Combinations, Challenges and Continua
fields.trailText: A REASONABLY BIG GAME
fields.body:
A REASONABLY BIG GAME

If Kelvin Koogan was starring in a film about an immortal Scotsman with a French accent who has a Spanish friend with a Scottish accent (played by Sean Connery), then this evening somebody would try to chop his head off with a claymore in a turf hut. Yes, after months of hyperbole, positive thought, and wishful thinking, it's the moment of truth for Kelvin Koogan's England. They're up against Portugal, the tournament's dark horses, and the Fiver can envisage three possible scenarios.

1. England lose terribly
In this scenario the wheels come off the Koogan jalopy completely: Luis Figo runs Phil Neville ragged, Steve McManaman gives the ball away before he gets it, Alan Shearer is sent off for use of the elbow and Paul Ince plays a blinder.

2. England scrape a draw
Outplayed for 70 minutes and 1-0 down, a combination of last-ditch tackling by Tony Adams, long balls a-go-go from David Beckham and a lucky shin from Paul Scholes get England a late equaliser. The country breathes again.

3. England romp a draw
Sol Campbell is back to his assertive best, McManaman is in the game from the start and Portugal's ageing back line is made nauseous by Michael Owen. A great result for Team England, and all cynical email updates are forced to eat their cheap words.

We'll get the ketchup ready.

The likely line-up: Seaman, G Neville, Adams, Campbell, P Neville, Beckham, Ince, Scholes, McManaman, Shearer, Owen.

THE NEW O'NEILL: THE NEW O'NEILL?

Peter Taylor is the new King Fox. He's got the lower-league pedigree (apart from a tricky spell at Southend, which we won't mention). He's got the international pedigree (apart from the odd run-in with the FA's technical director) He's also got a penchant for wearing jogging pants. But no matter how hard Mr Taylor may try, he's no Irish nutter.

"It was a hard challenge at Gillingham following Tony Pulis and it's an even greater challenge following Martin O'Neill here but I'm up here for the challenge," rumbled Mr Taylor today, in an attempt to impress the Foxy crowd. "My style might be a bit different to Martin's but I hope to have the same success as him. If I can do as well as he has done over the last four years I'll be happy. It's a wonderful challenge," he continued, while the assembled ranks waited for him to insult Robbie Williams.

"The last four years have been lovely for me in terms of results and progression," Taylor went on in far too dull a fashion. Then he pretended to run up and down the touchline in an agitated fashion while insisting: "I'll be looking to bring some players in." But to no avail. Then, just as everyone was about to leave, Mr Taylor looked up with a tear in his eye and said: "I've just left Gillingham so I'm a little bit sad." What's that? A sentimental attachment to a small provincial club? Why, that's more like it Mr Taylor!

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"My priority remains Real Madrid. Nicolas convinced me. What he likes the most is the atmosphere and the passion put into football" - Last month Robert Pires said he was joining Arsenal. This month he's taking the advice of Lonely Nic Anelka. What's happened to the poor lad?

LOVE UNITED DO

Manchester United may have spent the last ten years winning leagues, cups, doubles, trebles and friends in the City, but all they really want is to be loved. How do we know? Because deputy chief executive Peter Kenyon today told United's shareholders that they need to improve their PR. Telling the shareholders before your actual fans may not be the best of starts, but you can't run before you can walk.

United are desperate to avoid a repeat of their curmudgeonly behaviour at the World Club Championship, where they gained a lot of money but lost a lot of friends. "We have learned from all our overseas forays, and the thing is we have got to get better at communication," Kenyon announced in a low-profile shareholder's newsletter. He then outlined plans for one of those lip-service Fans Forums that never seem to work. "It's a continuum," he continuumed, "the fans forum at one end and press conferences on foreign soil at the other." Eh? Whatever you say.

All this nonsense is Kenyon's "number one priority for 2000", so you can be sure, like anybody else in the United boardroom, he means business. But exactly how can United regain the popularity they enjoyed in the good old days? The Fiver thinks it has the answer. fields.bodyText: A REASONABLY BIG GAME If Kelvin Koogan was starring in a film about an immortal Scotsman with a French accent who has a Spanish friend with a Scottish accent (played by Sean Connery), then this evening somebody would try to chop his head off with a claymore in a turf hut. Yes, after months of hyperbole, positive thought, and wishful thinking, it's the moment of truth for Kelvin Koogan's England. They're up against Portugal, the tournament's dark horses, and the Fiver can envisage three possible scenarios. 1. England lose terribly In this scenario the wheels come off the Koogan jalopy completely: Luis Figo runs Phil Neville ragged, Steve McManaman gives the ball away before he gets it, Alan Shearer is sent off for use of the elbow and Paul Ince plays a blinder. 2. The country breathes again. 3. England romp a draw Sol Campbell is back to his assertive best, McManaman is in the game from the start and Portugal's ageing back line is made nauseous by Michael Owen. A great result for Team England, and all cynical email updates are forced to eat their cheap words. We'll get the ketchup ready. It's a wonderful challenge," he continued, while the assembled ranks waited for him to insult Robbie Williams. fields.headline: No 4: Emile Mpenza
fields.trailText: Status? Belgium's answer to Michael Owen.
fields.body:
Status? Belgium's answer to Michael Owen.

Really? Well he's fast, he scores a lot of goals, and he played for Belgium at the 1998 World Cup while he was still a teenager. And he's just captured the Belgian nation's heart with that wonder goal against Sweden

Oh come on! It was clearly handball! Not according to Mpenza, who insists that "The ref was only five metres away and was better placed to judge than the people who say I handled the ball."

But wasn't his performance on Saturday just a flash in the pan? Not according to Jaap Stam. "He's a very quick boy, he is skilful, and he can see the game," he says. "Mpenza is already good and I can see him becoming a big mister in Europe."

A big mister? That sounds very impressive. But what's the Football Unlimited view? As if you care. Let's just say he's good enough to keep Gilles De Bilde out of the team.

So how does he compare with England's Emile - Emile Heskey? He's much smaller (only 5ft 9in), and much more prolific too. In Belgium he starred for Standard de Liège, with whom he notched up 16 goals in 26 matches before leaving for FC Schalke 04 for a Belgian record fee earlier this year.

How has he done in Germany? Everyone agrees the move - to join Belgian teammates Marc Wilmots and Nico Van Kerckhoven - has been the making of him. "I've really improved playing alongside Marc at Schalke," said Mpenza yesterday. "Everyone said the Bundesliga wouldn't suit me. But that's just not true at all. I've learnt that you shouldn't always listen to what other people tell you."

Hasn't he got an older brother too? He certainly has. 23 year-old Mbo has just helped Sporting Lisbon win the Portuguese title for the first time since 1982, but he's only good enough for a place on the Belgian bench.

All very interesting, but I bet you can't tell me something about interesting about BelgiumThey have made it to the last five FIFA World Cups, a feat only six other countries out of 197 can boast. Will that do?

webTitle: The Qayyum report is released, Malik and Ata-ur-Rehman given life bans

fields.headline: The Qayyum report is released, Malik and Ata-ur-Rehman given life bans
fields.standfirst: Day-by-day diary of the scandal that shocked the cricket world
fields.trailText:
Tuesday May 9
Jagmohan Dalmiya, ICC president, says he will sue the Sunday Telegraph over an article in which he was said to have been voted off the ICC finance and marketing committee.
fields.body:
Tuesday May 9
Jagmohan Dalmiya, ICC president, says he will sue the Sunday Telegraph over an article in which he was said to have been voted off the ICC finance and marketing committee.

Viv Richards describes Kapil Dev as "one of the last true great competitors". But if former Indian Board president IS Bindra's allegations (that Kapil offered Manoj Prabhakar $25,000 to underperform in a one-dayer against Sri Lanka in 1994) are true, "it will take away everything I have always felt and still feel for Kapil".

Wednesday May 10
Lt-Gen. Tauqir Zia, chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board, says their judicial enquiry has found "no planned match-fixing" by any Pakistan players, but that Judge Qayyum has proposed bans and fines for some for their "non-co-operation with the enquiry".

India's captain Sourav Ganguly defends Kapil Dev, demanding that his accusers "come out with proof".

Thursday May 11
The Guardian suggests that England's winter tour of Pakistan may be cancelled if the summary of Judge Qayyum's report is "significantly different from that which Qayyum intended". Lord MacLaurin says: "It seems very odd. But at the moment we have to wait and see the report before commenting on it further."

Saturday May 13
Confusion reigns as Qayyum contradicts Tauqir Zia: "There are members of the current team against whom punishment has been recommended."

Sunday May 14
The Sunday Telegraph suggests that Qayyum has confirmed that Pakistan players were definitely involved in match-fixing, that life bans have been recommended against Salim Malik and Mushtaq Ahmed, and that Wasim Akram has "not got off scot-free".

Bob Woolmer tells Australia's ABC Radio that he definitely reported an approach to his South Africa side to throw a one-day match at Bombay four years ago to Ali Bacher, who has always claimed ignorance of the incident.

IS Bindra admits to having no concrete evidence against Kapil Dev, and says he was working on infor-mation given to him by Prabhakar. He also says he has compiled a report showing that "the real corruption lies in the grant of telecast rights". An angry Kapil Dev says: "I am not going to let Bindra get away with his allegations: he will be sued for defamation."

In Mumbai, ex-BCCI chief PM Rungta makes allegations about Bindra's time as president in 1993-96. He says: "Only a probe by a high-powered committee can bring out the extent of financial damage."

Monday May 15
Dalmiya calls for positive steps, rather than "baseless accusations", to be taken to tackle match-fixing. Referring to Kapil Dev, he says, "If it is proved that he is innocent ... will he recover from the trauma he is going through?"

It is announced that the King Commission, into corruption in South African cricket, will start its hearings on June 7.

IS Bindra deposits his 360-page report with Central Bureau of Investigation officials in New Delhi.

Tuesday May 16
Judge Qayyum says not all his recommendations may be seen through. "They [the PCB] can be choosy. They can implement any recommendations they like, but if they are not all going to be implemented, what's the use of the entire drill?" He also denies speaking to the Sunday Telegraph (May 14).

Indian CBI officials issue IS Bindra with a questionnaire, which includes requests for details of the allocation of telecast rights and payments of unreasonable amounts to players.

Wednesday May 17
A South African judicial enquiry requests the Indian police tapes containing the alleged conversation between Cronje and a bookmaker, "to avoid having to recall witnesses unnecessarily".

AC Muthiah, president of the Indian Board, announces that any Indian player found guilty in a federal match-fixing investigation will be banned for life and have his name erased from the record books.

Thursday May 18
Muthiah appeals for Indian officials to stop mud-slinging: "I would remind them that if members are found guilty of endangering the harmony or affecting the reputation, stability or interest of the Board, they shall be liable for expulsion."

Friday May 19
Replying to Kapil Dev's solicitors, Bindra's lawyers deny defamation, and say their client "would have done the game of cricket and the cricket-loving people a great disservice had he concealed the fact of what Prabhakar had conveyed".

Dalmiya files three defamation suits, against the Sunday Telegraph and Indian magazines Outlook and India Today.

Sunday May 21
The News of the World splashes a claim that Salim Malik has boasted of being involved in systematic match-fixing, and that he could provide players and an ICC official to fix almost any match - including England's forthcoming fixtures in Pakistan. Malik is quoted as saying: "When you've got the main players in your hand, you'll have to be really unlucky to lose. You'll have four or five players in hand and they'll be playing just for you." Malik is also alleged to have said that a Test on Australia's 1994-95 tour of Pakistan was a "double fix", with both sides trying to lose.

Hansie Cronje is described in the Sunday Telegraph as "a virtual recluse" who does not return friends' calls. An ex-team-mate is quoted as saying: "How can he ever look another South African in the eye again? If I was him I'd emigrate." Three other former team-mates agree that "We have no doubt that what Hansie did was ball-tampering [in a one-day game at Sydney in 1997, when pictures showed him rubbing his spikes over one side of the ball] and therefore cheating."

Monday May 22
The ECB announces plans to draw up a "clear and easy-to-understand" anti-betting code for county cricketers.

David Graveney rejects allegations that England's 1997 Sharjah tournament victory was rigged (Salim Malik is alleged to have said that Pakistan threw their group game against England): "I believe we won the tournament fairly ... it would be shattering to all of us if that wasn't the case."

Manoj Prabhakar accuses the Indian Board of exerting undue pressure on him to apologise. "Say sorry for what? I have done no wrong." Prabhakar says he intends to make everything public "very soon".

Salim Malik rejects the News of the World's allegations as "baseless", and promises to tell his story soon as well.

Tuesday May 23
The ICC pledges to investigate the News of the World tapes.

Former Pakistan captain Rashid Latif speculates that some past officials of the Pakistan Board were also involved in match-fixing with Salim Malik, and that "four or five Pakistani players are [still] involved".

Wednesday May 24
Ashley Mallett airs his belief that the Australia-South Africa Test at Sydney in Jan 1998 may have been fixed. Mallett, a former Australia offspinner, was an advisor to the South African team at the time. He says "there were concerns about the game", which Australia won by an innings, and casts aspersions at the defensive line that Pat Symcox was instructed to bowl by Hansie Cronje. Steve Waugh, whose 100th Test that was, rejects the suggestion, saying: "If that [game] wasn't played at 100%, then I'm a real bad judge ... if Mallett has evidence to suggest otherwise, he should bring it forward. If not, he should keep his mouth shut." Waugh also rubbishes the News of the World's "double fix" claim.

The Qayyum Report is finally released. It recommends life bans for Salim Malik and Ata-ur-Rehman, and a fine of a million rupees (around £10,000) for Malik. (Rehman, who gave varying evidence to the enquiry, is now playing league cricket in England.) Mushtaq Ahmed and Wasim Akram are given the benefit of reasonable doubt, although Qayyum recommends that neither be allowed to captain Pakistan again, and that they be fined 300,000 rupees (£3000). He also recommends smaller fines for Waqar Younis, Inzamam-ul-Haq, Akram Raza and Saeed Anwar, for failing to co-operate with the enquiry.

Salim Malik says he has been made a scapegoat: "Why me alone when others have been let off with minor fines? Whether my cricket is finished or not, I have to live a life and I have been subjected to such tortuous allegations for a long time now, it is unjust."

In Delhi, Manoj Prabhakar publicly names Kapil Dev as the man who offered him money to underperform in Sri Lanka in 1994, saying "Kapil knows, and so does God". He adds that Navjot Sidhu, then-coach Ajit Wadekar, Ravi Shastri and Sunil Gavaskar were all informed of the incident, and that he is willing to undergo a lie-detector test.

Ravi Shastri confirms that he was informed by Prabhakar of Kapil's alleged bribe, and that he told him to report it to the team management immediately.

Thursday May 25
Speaking of the recommended life bans, Rashid Latif, one of the chief whistle-blowers, calls for other countries to administer similar punishments: "Pakistan has set an example, and other countries must follow suit."

Greg Melick, a former National Crime Authority member, is appointed as the Australian Board's special investigator into match-fixing. His first brief is to investigate Salim Malik's claim that Australia were involved in a "double fix" with Pakistan in 1994-95.

Bob Woolmer rejects Ashley Mallett's allegations, saying "We were beaten fair and square in that Test, and the reason we lost was Shane Warne, not Pat Symcox."

Friday May 26
In The Sun, Ian Botham describes cricket as "rotten to the core", and calls for an independent enquiry from a non-cricket nation "like the United States" to get to the bottom of the problem.

In Lahore, Salim Malik outlines plans to appeal to General Pervaz Musharraf, Pakistan's military leader, against his life ban. Malik says that, once he has received formal confirmation of the ban, he will go to court to clear his name.

Saturday May 27
In New Delhi, Prabhakar unveils a secret 45-minute video showing players and administrators making various match-fixing assertions to a hidden camera. The names of Kapil Dev, Mohammad Azharuddin, Ajay Sharma and Ajay Jadeja crop up repeatedly. Prabhakar promises to hand the complete recording to the police, saying "I know I will be friendless in cricket circles after this ... [but] I owed it to the game."

Fresh allegations on an Australian radio station, apparently based on the News of the World's tapes, suggest that Asif Iqbal, the former Pakistan captain who is now one of ICC's "special ambassadors for cricket", acted as a go-between for Salim Malik.

Sunday May 28
Indian police say they have identified "seven to eight prominent bookies" who laid odds on the five one-day internationals South Africa played in India in March, from which the original Cronje allegations arose.

Monday May 29
Indian police ask Interpol to help them gain voice samples of Hansie Cronje: "Once we have all that, we will start thinking of extraditing Cronje and the others charged in this case."

Tuesday May 30
Maite Nkoana Mashabane, the South African High Commissioner in India, is quoted as saying that SA will allow Indian detectives to question Cronje, so long as the request is "need-based and issue-based".

John Bacon, secretary of the King Commission, says they are to call between 35 and 45 witnesses when the hearing begins on June 7; these may include England captain Nasser Hussain.

(Rehman, who gave varying evidence to the enquiry, is now playing league cricket in England.) Mushtaq Ahmed and Wasim Akram are given the benefit of reasonable doubt, although Qayyum recommends that neither be allowed to captain Pakistan again, and that they be fined 300,000 rupees (£3000). He also recommends smaller fines for Waqar Younis, Inzamam-ul-Haq, Akram Raza and Saeed Anwar, for failing to co-operate with the enquiry. Salim Malik says he has been made a scapegoat: "Why me alone when others have been let off with minor fines? Whether my cricket is finished or not, I have to live a life and I have been subjected to such tortuous allegations for a long time now, it is unjust." In Delhi, Manoj Prabhakar publicly names Kapil Dev as the man who offered him money to underperform in Sri Lanka in 1994, saying "Kapil knows, and so does God". He adds that Navjot Sidhu, then-coach Ajit Wadekar, Ravi Shastri and Sunil Gavaskar were all informed of the incident, and that he is willing to undergo a lie-detector test. Ravi Shastri confirms that he was informed by Prabhakar of Kapil's alleged bribe, and that he told him to report it to the team management immediately. Thursday May 25 Speaking of the recommended life bans, Rashid Latif, one of the chief whistle-blowers, calls for other countries to administer similar punishments: "Pakistan has set an example, and other countries must follow suit." Greg Melick, a former National Crime Authority member, is appointed as the Australian Board's special investigator into match-fixing. His first brief is to investigate Salim Malik's claim that Australia were involved in a "double fix" with Pakistan in 1994-95. Bob Woolmer rejects Ashley Mallett's allegations, saying "We were beaten fair and square in that Test, and the reason we lost was Shane Warne, not Pat Symcox." Friday May 26 In The Sun, Ian Botham describes cricket as "rotten to the core", and calls for an independent enquiry from a non-cricket nation "like the United States" to get to the bottom of the problem. In Lahore, Salim Malik outlines plans to appeal to General Pervaz Musharraf, Pakistan's military leader, against his life ban. Malik says that, once he has received formal confirmation of the ban, he will go to court to clear his name. Saturday May 27 In New Delhi, Prabhakar unveils a secret 45-minute video showing players and administrators making various match-fixing assertions to a hidden camera. The names of Kapil Dev, Mohammad Azharuddin, Ajay Sharma and Ajay Jadeja crop up repeatedly. Prabhakar promises to hand the complete recording to the police, saying "I know I will be friendless in cricket circles after this ... [but] I owed it to the game." Fresh allegations on an Australian radio station, apparently based on the News of the World's tapes, suggest that Asif Iqbal, the former Pakistan captain who is now one of ICC's "special ambassadors for cricket", acted as a go-between for Salim Malik. Sunday May 28 Indian police say they have identified "seven to eight prominent bookies" who laid odds on the five one-day internationals South Africa played in India in March, from which the original Cronje allegations arose. Monday May 29 Indian police ask Interpol to help them gain voice samples of Hansie Cronje: "Once we have all that, we will start thinking of extraditing Cronje and the others charged in this case." Tuesday May 30 Maite Nkoana Mashabane, the South African High Commissioner in India, is quoted as saying that SA will allow Indian detectives to question Cronje, so long as the request is "need-based and issue-based". John Bacon, secretary of the King Commission, says they are to call between 35 and 45 witnesses when the hearing begins on June 7; these may include England captain Nasser Hussain.

webTitle: Inquiry prompts free vote on hunting

fields.headline: Inquiry prompts free vote on hunting
fields.standfirst: Government 'neither for nor against' ban, says Straw
fields.trailText: MPs will be given a free vote on whether to ban hunting, the home secretary, Jack Straw, announced today.
fields.body:
MPs will be given a free vote on whether to ban hunting, the home secretary, Jack Straw, announced today.

According to the report, between 6,000 and 8,000 full-time jobs depend on hunting, although the inquiry said it was impossible to predict exactly how many would be lost if a ban were implemented. It added that the losses could be "offset in the long term, say seven to ten years". The report concluded that any ban should apply nationwide.

The Burns report has revealed a higher level of support for hunting in certain rural communities than was previously thought, Mr Straw told the Commons. He said he recognised the "strength of feeling" on the matter, and added: "It is only right that all sides of the debate should be given the opportunity to have their point of view considered fairly" and that parliament should have the chance to "come to a proper conclusion."

The government bill will contain a series of legislative options for MPs to choose from, and should be introduced in early autumn.

To Tory jeers, Mr Straw insisted the government would press neither for nor against a ban on hunting with dogs. "The government is, and remains, neutral on the merits of whether hunting with hounds should be banned, but we do have an obligation to ensure that the decisions of this House can have an effect."

Labour promised in its last general election manifesto that there would be a free vote on hunting and had planned to move the issue forward through a private members' bill, which would stand little chance of clearing the Lords. "I now, however, believe that it would be better for the convenience of the House if there was a government bill in government time, which contained a series of legislative options on the merits of which there would be free votes." Mr Straw pledged to consult with the main interest groups, police and local authorities before drawing up the options. They seem certain to cover an outright ban and other options between this and the status quo.

Tory home affairs spokesman David Liddington told MPs that the fact that the government was bringing forward a bill on hunting showed that it had allowed itself to be distracted from the important issues facing voters.
