webTitle: The scandal breaks, the world reacts

fields.headline: The scandal breaks, the world reacts
fields.standfirst: Day-by-day diary of the scandal that shocked the cricket world
fields.trailText:
Friday April 7
The allegations break. Hansie Cronje, Pieter Strydom, Nicky Boje and Herschelle Gibbs are charged by Indian police with "cheating, fraud and criminal conspiracy relating to match-fixing and betting".
fields.body:
Friday April 7
The allegations break. Hansie Cronje, Pieter Strydom, Nicky Boje and Herschelle Gibbs are charged by Indian police with "cheating, fraud and criminal conspiracy relating to match-fixing and betting".

New Delhi police release transcripts of a conversation thought to be between Cronje and a businessman, Sanjeev Chawla. Strydom, Gibbs and Boje are explicitly mentioned, and "Cronje" goes on to say that he cannot "get" any more players as "The other guys are already angry with me because I have not received their money."

Ali Bacher, managing director of the United Cricket Board of South Africa (UCBSA), defends Cronje's integrity. Cronje says he is innocent of the charges: "I am stunned. The allegations are completely without substance." Jagmohan Dalmiya, the ICC president, announces: "If there is any grey side to it, we [ICC] will take care of it. We have our own way of working."

Kepler Wessels (Cronje's predecessor as captain) calls for "A fully independent and impartial enquiry".

Saturday April 8
Rajesh Kalra, the Indian bookmaker at the centre of the allegations, admits to India Today that he offered players $4-500,000 to fix the one-day series between India and South Africa in March.

Krishan Kumar, a former Bollywood actor, is interrogated by Indian police and then admitted to hospital suffering from an angina attack.

Sunday April 9
Cronje, Gibbs and Boje hold a press conference. Cronje says he never received money "during the one-day series in India" nor spoke to any member of his team about "throwing a game". Gibbs says: "We weren't approached by anybody and Hansie didn't speak to us about the subject." Boje adds: "Hansie never spoke to us about anything to help him in throwing a game."

The UBCSA president Percy Sonn dismisses the allegations as "spurious". A Foreign Ministry spokesman expresses disgust at the tapping of Cronje's phone: "This goes against all diplomatic norms and is a major invasion of privacy." India continues to deny access to the tapes.

Trevor Chesterfield, a cricket journalist for the Pretoria Star, says he overheard the tape while waiting to be interviewed on Indian radio, and that it doesn't sound like Cronje. It is later claimed that he heard a reconstruction of the tape, voiced by Indian actors.

The Sunday Times reports an experienced Indian crime journalist as saying that KK Paul, the New Delhi police commissioner, was being "as straight-forward as a police officer can be".

Monday April 10
New Delhi crime branch chief Pradeep Srivastava says he has new "clinching" evidence to prove Cronje and Chawla were in contact during the ODIs in India.

Interpol confirms that Scotland Yard will be asked to investigate the alleged payments; Indian police want to know Chawla's bank-account details.

Kalra tells police that the Kochin ODI was fixed for $300,000, but that the bookies had suffered a big loss when South Africa made over 300.

Cronje withdraws from the two upcoming benefit games in aid of Sachin Tendulkar. Bob Woolmer, former SA coach, and Australia's Justin Langer express their support for Cronje. Australian captain Steve Waugh calls for all cheats to be banned from the game.

Tuesday April 11
Cronje is sacked from the South African captaincy after he phones Bacher at 3am to admit "dishonesty". He is said to have broken down uncontrollably when a friend rang to ask how he was feeling.

At a 1pm press conference, Bacher says Cronje admits receiving money during the ODI series with India, but that he denies match-fixing: "During the England-Zimbabwe triangular series, contact was made with him by a local South African and a bookmaker of Indian origin based in London ... the result was that Cronje was given $10-15,000 which he took home." He adds that Cronje had denied being party to match-fixing, but that the UCBSA are "shattered ... we have been deceived". Shaun Pollock, who also appears at the press conference, is appointed captain.

Simultaneously, Cronje issues a statement through Balfour Ngconde, the sports minister. He denies speaking to any other players about match-fixing, confusingly saying he "received no financial rewards". Again he protests that "the allegations are devoid of all truth".

The ICC call for an "immediate and thorough investigation", while Indian police claim they have been vindicated. KK Paul says Kalra has given "more names", none Indian, but admits that the police caught Cronje by accident, after he borrowed Kalra's mobile phone.

Wednesday April 12
Bacher says he doesn't think any other South African players are involved: "We have been let down once, and I hope to God we are not let down again."

Wessels says the damage to SA's cricket is irreparable: "It is not enough to take the word of the players as the UCB appear to have done." Allan Donald admits the affair makes a "big dent" in South Africa's achievements.

Maite Nkoane-Mashabane, SA's high commissioner to India, says her country is now willing to co-operate with the Indian police "in any way".

Dalmiya promises a full-scale ICC enquiry, saying "any attempt to interfere with the fair conduct of sport is totally unacceptable". The South African findings will go before ICC's Code of Conduct Commission, chaired by Lord Griffiths.

Worrying new allegations emerge. Tony Greig, the former England captain, claims there is more to come: "There are other players involved, Indians as well." The Delhi police are investigating a "much bigger affair", writes Vinod Mehta in India's Outlook magazine.

Inderjit Singh Bindra (former president of the Indian Board) says the Board is hiding important information about Indian players. He claims that three players have been consistently involved in betting since 1996, and that the Board knows who they are. The Board responds by pledging that any player found guilty of match-fixing will be banned for life.

England's fifth-Test victory at Centurion in January comes under suspicion. Was Cronje really such a good sport? The fact that a draw was avoided saved the bookies a fortune.

Thursday April 13
Match referee Barry Jarman denies that the Centurion Test was fixed. "There was nothing there to suggest anything had been manufactured," he says. He is backed up by Sporting Index, whose chairman insists that it was "the least likely game ever played" to have been manipulated, as there was simply "no time for anything to be contrived between players and bookmakers".

It emerges that the sum Cronje took was $8200. His wife Bertha counted it for the first time in front of lawyers. Bacher says Cronje has not told him what he did to earn the money.

Hamid "Banjo" Cassim is alleged to be the go-between for Cronje and Chawla. He is also said to know India's recent captains Mohammad Azharuddin and Sachin Tendulkar.

In a prepared statement, Cronje says he can't respond fully to the allegations, since the authorities had not yet made clear the basis of the charges. He again denies match-fixing, and says "speculation and criticism directed against other members of the team is wrong and unjustified".

Indian police announce a hotel link between Cronje, Chawla and Kumar. In February, while Cronje was in Room 811 of Bombay's Taj Hotel, a Sanjeev Chawla stayed in Room 631. His bill was later paid by Kumar.

Indian revenue detectives begin a 48-hour interrogation of Kalra. They ask where the "huge funds" involved in the match-fixing charges came from, and details of overseas bank accounts.

Lance Klusener vehemently denies being the man who tipped off the Delhi police, who confirm he had nothing to do with it.

New transcripts throw suspicion on the last game of the five-match ODI series against India at Nagpur in March. The tape has "Cronje" saying that he will open the bowling with offspinner Derek Crookes. He did. He also predicts that "we will be bowling our non-regular bowlers". Part-time left-armer Strydom bowls a full ten overs.

SS Dhindsa, India's sports minister, calls for a report on India's recent poor Test performances (they lost 2-0 at home to South Africa, shortly after being whitewashed 3-0 in Australia). A high-level meeting is arranged for April 27: Azhar, Tendulkar, Kapil Dev and Sourav Ganguly are all summoned.

Ray Illingworth reveals that he was approached by a Pakistani book-maker to throw a match during the 1996 World Cup. He was England's manager (and chairman of selectors) at the time.

ECB chairman Lord MacLaurin calls for an urgent ICC conference: "If this were a business, we'd have an emergency board meeting." He says that any player in breach of the ICC Code of Conduct should be banned for life.

Cronje's sponsors desert him, and a Reserve Bank official tells SA's Citizen newspaper that he could face a $38,000 fine possessing foreign currency.

A poll for the Cape Times reveals that 94% of South Africans want Cronje to play international cricket again.

Friday April 14
New captain Shaun Pollock dedicates South Africa's victory over Australia in the ODI in Durban (the first game since the scandal broke) to Cronje.

Saturday April 15
It emerges that South Africa needed three team meetings before rejecting $250,000 to fix an ODI in India in 1996. It is alleged that only Jonty Rhodes, Andrew Hudson and Dave Richardson were against the idea. "No-one really wanted to play," said Richardson.

Gibbs again denies the allegations. He tells the Cape Argus: "Nothing would make me do something so irresponsible. Nobody approached us. When we were told about it we were terribly shocked."

Suspicions grow about the Centurion Test. Daryll Cullinan says: "I would like to think that Hansie was acting in the interest of the game and doing something for the public, but it totally went against the guy I know."

Derek Crookes admits he was very surprised when Cronje asked him to open the bowling in Nagpur. Cronje had earlier told him he wouldn't open in the series.

Sunday April 16
Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum, the judge who investigated match-fixing allegations in Pakistan, says he "found rock-solid evidence ... which confirmed some Pakistan players accepted bribes to tamper with the results of international matches." He recommended life bans for those players. The ICC is yet to see the report.

Azharuddin is implicated. He is named by Kalra, and it emerges that he also knows Cassim. His wife protests his innocence. V Gupta, an income-tax commissioner, says that two months ago an Indian player declared an inexplicably large income of £2million.

Chris Lewis claims in the News of the World that when he was approached last summer by Ashim Kheterpal, a sports promoter, he was told that three senior England players were involved in match-fixing.

Monday April 17
ICC calls an emergency meeting for May 2-3: "A summit meeting must be held to consider what further actions must be taken to rid our sport of this major problem," says Dalmiya.

Michael Parkinson writes in the Daily Telegraph: "It is time for the ICC to start acting like a governing body instead of a seedy public-relations agency."

Tuesday April 18
Lewis meets ECB officials to give them the names of the three players he'd been told were involved. The ECB pass the information on to the police for thorough investigation, although Gareth James, Lewis's agent, says the names were given to the police last September.

Azharuddin and Tendulkar both emphatically deny any match-fixing. Azhar says all the allegations are "false, untrue, baseless and of no substance"; Tendulkar says he has followed his "conscience and duty" and "stayed clear from all undesirable elements".

Andy Flower, Zimbabwe's captain, says he has long suspected "shenanigans" in some competitions. He says: "There have been instances I thought the opposition did not quite look themselves."

Wednesday April 19
Lewis claims that the ECB were "not interested" when he offered to pass on players' names last summer.

IS Bindra says "Hansie Cronje has emerged as the biggest hero in this episode. It is Hansie who is going to save world cricket and nobody else." He then claims that "virtually every game in international cricket is fixed". Kapil Dev, now India's coach, calls for cricket to "stop" until the allegations have been dealt with.

Bacher claims that two of last year's World Cup matches were fixed, and that he has been told that an international umpire was involved with bookmakers.

Thursday April 20
Ashim Kheterpal rejects Lewis's claims and dismisses him as a "fraud".

Bombay police reveal they have more tape-recordings of phone conversations between bookies and Test cricketers: it is claimed that they further incriminate Azharuddin and also Ajay Jadeja. The police are reportedly under pressure not to hand over the tapes, but are "standing firm".

Javed Akhtar, the Pakistani umpire who made several controversial decisions in the 1998 England-South Africa Test at Headingley and England's World Cup '99 defeat by India, protests his innocence.

Two South African umpires disclose they were offered money to match-fix. Cyril Mitchley claims he was offered $50,000 to ensure Pakistan did not lose the last of a three-Test series against Australia in 1996. Rudi Koertzen says he was approached during a triangular tournament between India, West Indies and Zimbabwe in in Singapore last year.

Saturday April 22
Unsubstantiated reports suggest that senior Delhi cricketer Ajay Sharma acted as a go-between for Azharuddin and bookmakers in Delhi.

Bacher tells a magazine that the South African judicial commission's report into match-fixing charges against Cronje and others will be submitted by the end of May. He says: "This thing must not linger on. There must be a finality to it."

Sunday April 23
ICC instruct the Pakistan Board to submit Judge Qayyum's match-fixing report in time for their emergency meeting at Lord's on May 2.

The Afrikaans-language newspaper Rapport claims that every senior South African player was to sign a contract compelling them to advise the cricket authorities of any approaches made by bookmakers. Bacher is quoted as saying that over the years there have been "too many allegations, too many innuendos about irregularities in the game. We must nip it in the bud."

Judge Qayyum claims his enquiry into Pakistan's defeat to Bangladesh in last year's World Cup was halted by the president of Pakistan. He says "Initially I was told I should look at the match-fixing without any restrictions ... then I was asked to withdraw. This was very unusual and I was very surprised - anyone would be if you were asked to do something and then told not to three days later."

Tuesday April 25
Former Pakistan captain Imran Khan reveals that an Indian bookmaker told him 23 years ago that Indian players were involved in fixing matches. He says: "He was always at cricket grounds. I never took him seriously. He named a few players. I think he talked about players from another international team - he said they were involved in match-fixing too."

Wednesday April 26
The Pakistan Cricket Board lodges a protest with the UCBSA over comments allegedly made by Bacher. PCB director Yawar Saeed says: "If he [Bacher] accused Pakistan, I will not level a counter-allegation. I will simply ask him to substantiate the allegations."

Thursday April 27
The ECB release a statement from Gerard Elias QC, chairman of their discipline committee: "I conclude that there is no evidence whatsoever to justify the bringing of disciplinary charges in relation to betting and/or match-fixing against any member of the England squad, past or present."

Arun Agarwal, a financial expert who conducted an enquiry into TV deals in India, accuses Dalmiya of a "telecast rights scam" during TV negotiations for a 1998 one-day tournament in Bangladesh.

Indian police issue a warrant for the arrest of Ajay Sharma. They claim to have evidence that he made numerous phone calls to bookmakers during South Africa's recent tour of India. Sharma, who played 31 ODIs and one Test for India, is currently playing club cricket in Lancashire.

Friday April 28
India's government orders a "broad-based enquiry" into all allegations of match-fixing. Lewis responds to the ECB's decision to take no further action by suggesting that other players "might think twice about coming forward".

Saturday April 29
Craig Smith, the South African team physio, says that Hansie Cronje put "undue pressure" on him to declare Henry Williams fit before the final match of the ODI series with India. This piles further suspicion on the game at Nagpur in which, as "Cronje" is alleged to have predicted to Chawla, Williams opened the bowling with offspinner Derek Crookes. Williams broke down in his second over.

Don Topley, who claimed (in 1994) that the 1991 Championship and Sunday League games between Essex and Lancashire were manipulated, agrees to meet the ECB. At the time, the TCCB refused to listen to Topley's story, and he remains sceptical: "My concern is that there are some poachers-turned-gamekeepers in cricket, in the media or administration. Whatever happens, it can't be brushed under the carpet."

Sunday April 30
Dalmiya files for defamation against Arun Agarwal, who alleged that Dalmiya exploited his position for financial gain while president of the Indian Board. Dalmiya's solicitor, UN Banerjee, describes the comments as "a conspiracy to tarnish the image and reputation of my client".

The Sunday Times alleges that three Sri Lankans were approached by bookmakers during the home series against Australia in 1992. Roshan Mahanama, Asanka Gurusinha and Sanath Jayasuriya were allegedly offered money for information and forecasting. They refused the money, as did Dean Jones of Australia, who says he was offered $50,000 in a biscuit tin.

Allan Donald tells the Sunday Telegraph: "Personally I'd be really annoyed if I find out that I played in a game where Hansie accepted cash. I'll stick with Hansie until he's proven innocent or guilty. But if he's proved guilty, he's going to have no sympathy; he will have to start running miles."

Monday May 1
Manoj Prabhakar, the former Indian allrounder, claims to have told "a big gun in the government" the name of the team-mate who offered him money to throw a match during the 1994 Singer Cup series in Sri Lanka.

Tuesday May 2
The ICC's emergency executive-board meeting begins at Lord's. Speaking beforehand, Lord MacLaurin promises that the investigation will be "from the president down".

All 18 members of the executive board are made to sign a declaration stating that they have no financial interest in cricket, other than what is already public knowledge. Dalmiya is cleared of malpractice by the ICC.

David Richards, the ICC chief executive, calls on IS Bindra to make a formal written submission to the governing body's solicitors outlining his match-fixing allegations. Bindra claims to have 100 pages of information and names relating to corruption.

Wednesday May 3
ICC announces a number of measures aimed at tackling corruption, including possible life bans for anyone found guilty of match-fixing. Also:

 Any country failing to co-operate with the Code of Conduct Commission, under Lord Griffiths, will be suspended; Judge Qayyum's investigation into Pakistani match-fixing must be released within five weeks.

 Every international player, umpire, referee, team official, administrator and employee will have to sign a declaration stating whether they have been encour-aged to engage in corrupt behaviour.

 Registration systems are to be standardised to ensure players are made aware of the ICC's code of conduct and what it deems "unacceptable behaviour".

 An independent anti-corruption investigation will be set up in time for the full ICC meeting in July. It will be led by a "senior experienced" legal figure and will be granted wide-ranging powers.

Lord MacLaurin admits that he believes corruption has infiltrated the international arena, and reiterates the authorities' commitment to "root it out". He promises to make an example of anyone found guilty of corruption by "kicking them out of the game for good".

Thursday May 4
Judge Edwin King is named to lead South Africa's investi-gation into the Cronje affair. King, 71, was born in London and describes himself as a "cricket nut".

In a televised interview with CNN, IS Bindra alleges that Kapil Dev offered Manoj Prabhakar $25,000 to underperform in an ODI against Sri Lanka in 1994.

Friday May 5
Kapil Dev denies Bindra's allegations and instructs his lawyers to take action. He also calls for India to withdraw from the Asia Cup in Bangladesh (starts May 28). This is rejected by the Indian Board.

Salim Malik rejects reports that he is to flee Pakistan before Qayyum's report is published: "I will remain in Pakistan until all the enquires clear me."

Sanjeev Chawla, the British businessman alleged to be at the centre of the Cronje scandal, breaks his silence: "I have never met Hansie Cronje and certainly never given him any money ... My whole life is being ruined." Police in Delhi have already arrested two men thought to have been working with Chawla, and are keen to examine his bank accounts in Britain.

Saturday May 6
The ACB announce that they will appoint an independent investigator to examine the allegations of match-fixing and bribery, but rule out a review of the Shane Warne and Mark Waugh case.

Kapil Dev serves a legal notice on Bindra for naming him as the player who tried to bribe Prabhakar: "[My] reputation built up over 25 years has been tarnished by one irresponsible statement."

Sunday May 7
Kapil Dev weeps during a BBC interview, in which he says he would rather commit suicide than take a bribe.

Imran Khan criticises ICC for pressurising the Pakistan Board to release their report on match-fixing, while letting the ACB get away with concealing facts about the Warne-Waugh affair.

Monday May 8
Edwin King, head of the South African government-appointed enquiry, tells the press that his is not a criminal investigation, but seeks only to discover the truth. But, King adds, he will subpoena witnesses if necessary.

Compiled by Alistair Rycroft, Catherine Hanley and Simon Byrne

Cronje withdraws from the two upcoming benefit games in aid of Sachin Tendulkar. Bob Woolmer, former SA coach, and Australia's Justin Langer express their support for Cronje. Australian captain Steve Waugh calls for all cheats to be banned from the game. Tuesday April 11 Cronje is sacked from the South African captaincy after he phones Bacher at 3am to admit "dishonesty". He is said to have broken down uncontrollably when a friend rang to ask how he was feeling. At a 1pm press conference, Bacher says Cronje admits receiving money during the ODI series with India, but that he denies match-fixing: "During the England-Zimbabwe triangular series, contact was made with him by a local South African and a bookmaker of Indian origin based in London ... the result was that Cronje was given $10-15,000 which he took home." He adds that Cronje had denied being party to match-fixing, but that the UCBSA are "shattered ... we have been deceived". Shaun Pollock, who also appears at the press conference, is appointed captain. Simultaneously, Cronje issues a statement through Balfour Ngconde, the sports minister. He denies speaking to any other players about match-fixing, confusingly saying he "received no financial rewards". Again he protests that "the allegations are devoid of all truth". The ICC call for an "immediate and thorough investigation", while Indian police claim they have been vindicated. KK Paul says Kalra has given "more names", none Indian, but admits that the police caught Cronje by accident, after he borrowed Kalra's mobile phone. Wednesday April 12 Bacher says he doesn't think any other South African players are involved: "We have been let down once, and I hope to God we are not let down again." Wessels says the damage to SA's cricket is irreparable: "It is not enough to take the word of the players as the UCB appear to have done." Allan Donald admits the affair makes a "big dent" in South Africa's achievements. Maite Nkoane-Mashabane, SA's high commissioner to India, says her country is now willing to co-operate with the Indian police "in any way". Dalmiya promises a full-scale ICC enquiry, saying "any attempt to interfere with the fair conduct of sport is totally unacceptable". The South African findings will go before ICC's Code of Conduct Commission, chaired by Lord Griffiths. Worrying new allegations emerge. Tony Greig, the former England captain, claims there is more to come: "There are other players involved, Indians as well." The Delhi police are investigating a "much bigger affair", writes Vinod Mehta in India's Outlook magazine. Inderjit Singh Bindra (former president of the Indian Board) says the Board is hiding important information about Indian players. He claims that three players have been consistently involved in betting since 1996, and that the Board knows who they are. The Board responds by pledging that any player found guilty of match-fixing will be banned for life. England's fifth-Test victory at Centurion in January comes under suspicion. Was Cronje really such a good sport? The fact that a draw was avoided saved the bookies a fortune. Thursday April 13 Match referee Barry Jarman denies that the Centurion Test was fixed. "There was nothing there to suggest anything had been manufactured," he says. He is backed up by Sporting Index, whose chairman insists that it was "the least likely game ever played" to have been manipulated, as there was simply "no time for anything to be contrived between players and bookmakers". It emerges that the sum Cronje took was $8200. His wife Bertha counted it for the first time in front of lawyers. Bacher says Cronje has not told him what he did to earn the money. Hamid "Banjo" Cassim is alleged to be the go-between for Cronje and Chawla. He is also said to know India's recent captains Mohammad Azharuddin and Sachin Tendulkar. In a prepared statement, Cronje says he can't respond fully to the allegations, since the authorities had not yet made clear the basis of the charges. He again denies match-fixing, and says "speculation and criticism directed against other members of the team is wrong and unjustified". Indian police announce a hotel link between Cronje, Chawla and Kumar. In February, while Cronje was in Room 811 of Bombay's Taj Hotel, a Sanjeev Chawla stayed in Room 631. His bill was later paid by Kumar. Indian revenue detectives begin a 48-hour interrogation of Kalra. They ask where the "huge funds" involved in the match-fixing charges came from, and details of overseas bank accounts. Lance Klusener vehemently denies being the man who tipped off the Delhi police, who confirm he had nothing to do with it. New transcripts throw suspicion on the last game of the five-match ODI series against India at Nagpur in March. The tape has "Cronje" saying that he will open the bowling with offspinner Derek Crookes. He did. He also predicts that "we will be bowling our non-regular bowlers". Part-time left-armer Strydom bowls a full ten overs. SS Dhindsa, India's sports minister, calls for a report on India's recent poor Test performances (they lost 2-0 at home to South Africa, shortly after being whitewashed 3-0 in Australia). A high-level meeting is arranged for April 27: Azhar, Tendulkar, Kapil Dev and Sourav Ganguly are all summoned. Ray Illingworth reveals that he was approached by a Pakistani book-maker to throw a match during the 1996 World Cup. He was England's manager (and chairman of selectors) at the time. ECB chairman Lord MacLaurin calls for an urgent ICC conference: "If this were a business, we'd have an emergency board meeting." He says that any player in breach of the ICC Code of Conduct should be banned for life. Cronje's sponsors desert him, and a Reserve Bank official tells SA's Citizen newspaper that he could face a $38,000 fine possessing foreign currency. A poll for the Cape Times reveals that 94% of South Africans want Cronje to play international cricket again. Friday April 14 New captain Shaun Pollock dedicates South Africa's victory over Australia in the ODI in Durban (the first game since the scandal broke) to Cronje. Saturday April 15 It emerges that South Africa needed three team meetings before rejecting $250,000 to fix an ODI in India in 1996. It is alleged that only Jonty Rhodes, Andrew Hudson and Dave Richardson were against the idea. "No-one really wanted to play," said Richardson. Gibbs again denies the allegations. He tells the Cape Argus: "Nothing would make me do something so irresponsible. Nobody approached us. When we were told about it we were terribly shocked." Suspicions grow about the Centurion Test. Daryll Cullinan says: "I would like to think that Hansie was acting in the interest of the game and doing something for the public, but it totally went against the guy I know." Derek Crookes admits he was very surprised when Cronje asked him to open the bowling in Nagpur. Cronje had earlier told him he wouldn't open in the series. Sunday April 16 Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum, the judge who investigated match-fixing allegations in Pakistan, says he "found rock-solid evidence ... which confirmed some Pakistan players accepted bribes to tamper with the results of international matches." He recommended life bans for those players. The ICC is yet to see the report. Azharuddin is implicated. He is named by Kalra, and it emerges that he also knows Cassim. His wife protests his innocence. V Gupta, an income-tax commissioner, says that two months ago an Indian player declared an inexplicably large income of £2million. Chris Lewis claims in the News of the World that when he was approached last summer by Ashim Kheterpal, a sports promoter, he was told that three senior England players were involved in match-fixing. Monday April 17 ICC calls an emergency meeting for May 2-3: "A summit meeting must be held to consider what further actions must be taken to rid our sport of this major problem," says Dalmiya. Michael Parkinson writes in the Daily Telegraph: "It is time for the ICC to start acting like a governing body instead of a seedy public-relations agency." Tuesday April 18 Lewis meets ECB officials to give them the names of the three players he'd been told were involved. The ECB pass the information on to the police for thorough investigation, although Gareth James, Lewis's agent, says the names were given to the police last September. Azharuddin and Tendulkar both emphatically deny any match-fixing. Azhar says all the allegations are "false, untrue, baseless and of no substance"; Tendulkar says he has followed his "conscience and duty" and "stayed clear from all undesirable elements". Andy Flower, Zimbabwe's captain, says he has long suspected "shenanigans" in some competitions. He says: "There have been instances I thought the opposition did not quite look themselves." Wednesday April 19 Lewis claims that the ECB were "not interested" when he offered to pass on players' names last summer. IS Bindra says "Hansie Cronje has emerged as the biggest hero in this episode. It is Hansie who is going to save world cricket and nobody else." He then claims that "virtually every game in international cricket is fixed". Kapil Dev, now India's coach, calls for cricket to "stop" until the allegations have been dealt with. Bacher claims that two of last year's World Cup matches were fixed, and that he has been told that an international umpire was involved with bookmakers. Thursday April 20 Ashim Kheterpal rejects Lewis's claims and dismisses him as a "fraud". Bombay police reveal they have more tape-recordings of phone conversations between bookies and Test cricketers: it is claimed that they further incriminate Azharuddin and also Ajay Jadeja. The police are reportedly under pressure not to hand over the tapes, but are "standing firm". Javed Akhtar, the Pakistani umpire who made several controversial decisions in the 1998 England-South Africa Test at Headingley and England's World Cup '99 defeat by India, protests his innocence. Two South African umpires disclose they were offered money to match-fix. Cyril Mitchley claims he was offered $50,000 to ensure Pakistan did not lose the last of a three-Test series against Australia in 1996. Rudi Koertzen says he was approached during a triangular tournament between India, West Indies and Zimbabwe in in Singapore last year. Saturday April 22 Unsubstantiated reports suggest that senior Delhi cricketer Ajay Sharma acted as a go-between for Azharuddin and bookmakers in Delhi. Bacher tells a magazine that the South African judicial commission's report into match-fixing charges against Cronje and others will be submitted by the end of May. He says: "This thing must not linger on. There must be a finality to it." Sunday April 23 ICC instruct the Pakistan Board to submit Judge Qayyum's match-fixing report in time for their emergency meeting at Lord's on May 2. The Afrikaans-language newspaper Rapport claims that every senior South African player was to sign a contract compelling them to advise the cricket authorities of any approaches made by bookmakers. Bacher is quoted as saying that over the years there have been "too many allegations, too many innuendos about irregularities in the game. We must nip it in the bud." Judge Qayyum claims his enquiry into Pakistan's defeat to Bangladesh in last year's World Cup was halted by the president of Pakistan. He says "Initially I was told I should look at the match-fixing without any restrictions ... then I was asked to withdraw. This was very unusual and I was very surprised - anyone would be if you were asked to do something and then told not to three days later." Tuesday April 25 Former Pakistan captain Imran Khan reveals that an Indian bookmaker told him 23 years ago that Indian players were involved in fixing matches. He says: "He was always at cricket grounds. I never took him seriously. He named a few players. I think he talked about players from another international team - he said they were involved in match-fixing too." Wednesday April 26 The Pakistan Cricket Board lodges a protest with the UCBSA over comments allegedly made by Bacher. PCB director Yawar Saeed says: "If he [Bacher] accused Pakistan, I will not level a counter-allegation. I will simply ask him to substantiate the allegations." Thursday April 27 The ECB release a statement from Gerard Elias QC, chairman of their discipline committee: "I conclude that there is no evidence whatsoever to justify the bringing of disciplinary charges in relation to betting and/or match-fixing against any member of the England squad, past or present." Arun Agarwal, a financial expert who conducted an enquiry into TV deals in India, accuses Dalmiya of a "telecast rights scam" during TV negotiations for a 1998 one-day tournament in Bangladesh. Indian police issue a warrant for the arrest of Ajay Sharma. They claim to have evidence that he made numerous phone calls to bookmakers during South Africa's recent tour of India. Sharma, who played 31 ODIs and one Test for India, is currently playing club cricket in Lancashire. Friday April 28 India's government orders a "broad-based enquiry" into all allegations of match-fixing. Lewis responds to the ECB's decision to take no further action by suggesting that other players "might think twice about coming forward". Saturday April 29 Craig Smith, the South African team physio, says that Hansie Cronje put "undue pressure" on him to declare Henry Williams fit before the final match of the ODI series with India. This piles further suspicion on the game at Nagpur in which, as "Cronje" is alleged to have predicted to Chawla, Williams opened the bowling with offspinner Derek Crookes. Williams broke down in his second over. Don Topley, who claimed (in 1994) that the 1991 Championship and Sunday League games between Essex and Lancashire were manipulated, agrees to meet the ECB. At the time, the TCCB refused to listen to Topley's story, and he remains sceptical: "My concern is that there are some poachers-turned-gamekeepers in cricket, in the media or administration. Whatever happens, it can't be brushed under the carpet." Sunday April 30 Dalmiya files for defamation against Arun Agarwal, who alleged that Dalmiya exploited his position for financial gain while president of the Indian Board. Dalmiya's solicitor, UN Banerjee, describes the comments as "a conspiracy to tarnish the image and reputation of my client". The Sunday Times alleges that three Sri Lankans were approached by bookmakers during the home series against Australia in 1992. Roshan Mahanama, Asanka Gurusinha and Sanath Jayasuriya were allegedly offered money for information and forecasting. They refused the money, as did Dean Jones of Australia, who says he was offered $50,000 in a biscuit tin. Allan Donald tells the Sunday Telegraph: "Personally I'd be really annoyed if I find out that I played in a game where Hansie accepted cash. I'll stick with Hansie until he's proven innocent or guilty. But if he's proved guilty, he's going to have no sympathy; he will have to start running miles." Monday May 1 Manoj Prabhakar, the former Indian allrounder, claims to have told "a big gun in the government" the name of the team-mate who offered him money to throw a match during the 1994 Singer Cup series in Sri Lanka. Tuesday May 2 The ICC's emergency executive-board meeting begins at Lord's. Speaking beforehand, Lord MacLaurin promises that the investigation will be "from the president down". All 18 members of the executive board are made to sign a declaration stating that they have no financial interest in cricket, other than what is already public knowledge. Dalmiya is cleared of malpractice by the ICC. David Richards, the ICC chief executive, calls on IS Bindra to make a formal written submission to the governing body's solicitors outlining his match-fixing allegations. Bindra claims to have 100 pages of information and names relating to corruption. Wednesday May 3 ICC announces a number of measures aimed at tackling corruption, including possible life bans for anyone found guilty of match-fixing. Also:  Any country failing to co-operate with the Code of Conduct Commission, under Lord Griffiths, will be suspended; Judge Qayyum's investigation into Pakistani match-fixing must be released within five weeks.  Every international player, umpire, referee, team official, administrator and employee will have to sign a declaration stating whether they have been encour-aged to engage in corrupt behaviour.  Registration systems are to be standardised to ensure players are made aware of the ICC's code of conduct and what it deems "unacceptable behaviour".  An independent anti-corruption investigation will be set up in time for the full ICC meeting in July. It will be led by a "senior experienced" legal figure and will be granted wide-ranging powers. Lord MacLaurin admits that he believes corruption has infiltrated the international arena, and reiterates the authorities' commitment to "root it out". He promises to make an example of anyone found guilty of corruption by "kicking them out of the game for good". Thursday May 4 Judge Edwin King is named to lead South Africa's investi-gation into the Cronje affair. King, 71, was born in London and describes himself as a "cricket nut". In a televised interview with CNN, IS Bindra alleges that Kapil Dev offered Manoj Prabhakar $25,000 to underperform in an ODI against Sri Lanka in 1994. Friday May 5 Kapil Dev denies Bindra's allegations and instructs his lawyers to take action. He also calls for India to withdraw from the Asia Cup in Bangladesh (starts May 28). This is rejected by the Indian Board. Salim Malik rejects reports that he is to flee Pakistan before Qayyum's report is published: "I will remain in Pakistan until all the enquires clear me." Sanjeev Chawla, the British businessman alleged to be at the centre of the Cronje scandal, breaks his silence: "I have never met Hansie Cronje and certainly never given him any money ... My whole life is being ruined." Police in Delhi have already arrested two men thought to have been working with Chawla, and are keen to examine his bank accounts in Britain. Saturday May 6 The ACB announce that they will appoint an independent investigator to examine the allegations of match-fixing and bribery, but rule out a review of the Shane Warne and Mark Waugh case. Kapil Dev serves a legal notice on Bindra for naming him as the player who tried to bribe Prabhakar: "[My] reputation built up over 25 years has been tarnished by one irresponsible statement." Sunday May 7 Kapil Dev weeps during a BBC interview, in which he says he would rather commit suicide than take a bribe. Imran Khan criticises ICC for pressurising the Pakistan Board to release their report on match-fixing, while letting the ACB get away with concealing facts about the Warne-Waugh affair. Monday May 8 Edwin King, head of the South African government-appointed enquiry, tells the press that his is not a criminal investigation, but seeks only to discover the truth. But, King adds, he will subpoena witnesses if necessary. Compiled by Alistair Rycroft, Catherine Hanley and Simon Byrne

fields.headline: A guide to Eindhoven
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Eindhoven on the web
fields.trailText: 1. Tonight's Euro 2000 match between England and Portugal is possibly the most exciting thing ever to have happened in Eindhoven, at least in peacetime.
fields.body:
1. Tonight's Euro 2000 match between England and Portugal is possibly the most exciting thing ever to have happened in Eindhoven, at least in peacetime.

2. Eindhoven has a long proud history as one of the main cities of the ancient Duchy of Brabant. Unfortunately, there is little to show of that history, following the ravages of the second world war.

3. The southern Dutch city is chiefly known, by those who know it at all, as the headquarters of the giant electronics company Philips. The company has dominated the local economy for more than 70 years.

4. Philips is closely associated with the city's other main product, the football club PSV Eindhoven. It has a worldwide following, not least on the internet.

5. Eindhoven prides itself on being a digital city, and is home to an unusual number of unusual websites, including one which will keenly interest collectors of rubber stamps.

6. Other minority interests are well catered for. Model enthusiasts will find much to entertain them at WillieS, while vintage aeroplane buffs will doubtless enjoy the eclectic joys of the Philips symphony orchestra, which bills itself as the most downloaded music site in Europe.

7. Oddly enough, the Odd Fellows also flourish in Eindhoven.

8. Visitors with more conventional tastes are sure to be entertained at the Cafe Sante.

9. England fans are unlikely to have language problems, given that most Dutch people speak rather better English than we do. And decyphering Dutch is not that difficult, as you will find by browsing the latest news in Eindhovens Dagblat.

10. Over the moon or sick as a parrot, footie followers can be assured that Eindhoven offers a quick way home.

webTitle: Prince's visit offers something for everyone

fields.headline: Prince's visit offers something for everyone
fields.standfirst: Charles's visit to Ballymena indicates how royal visits have become part of the currency of the peace process
fields.trailText: As Charles visits Ballymena, Guardian columnist John O'Farrell argues that royal visits, like IRA guns and the release of prisoners, have become part of the currency of the peace process.
fields.body:
Confidence-building measures are all the rage in Northern Ireland these days. Like children at a birthday party, where every kid must be handed a goodie bag so they won¹t feel left out, the competing ideologies of Ulster must all get surprises.

Today's big surprise is the visit to the province of the Prince of Wales. Prince Charles's presence will act as a boost for the hurt feelings of unionists who are unsure about the new power dispensation in Stormont.

Nationalists got their symbolic treat last week when the Irish president, Mary McAleese, made a whistlestop visit across the border. Some nationalists will attend the royal events, as elected representatives. The moderate nationalists of the SDLP will happily share the same space as the prince as he opens the new theatre in Armagh city, and will attend tomorrow's garden party in Hillsborough Castle for victims of the conflict.

The SDLP still hold on to their policy of refusing royal honours, such as the OBE. Sinn Fein are less forgiving. They will boycott tomorrow's garden party, in protest at Charles's honorary rank as Colonel-in-Chief of the Parachute Regiment, which killed 14 unarmed Roman Catholics in Londonderry in 1972.

In turn, some victims of the IRA who were invited to share tea and canapes with not only the prince, but also Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, have returned their invitations. It is unclear if there will be boycotts or protests from other invitees, relatives of victims of the security forces.

This is the problem with confidence-building measures. Recognition of one side's hurt is often perceived as a snub the pain of the other side. In Charles's case, nationalists will point to the incongruity of Prince Para sympathising with victims of state violence, while loyalists will object to nationalist victims being invited at all. They argue that some victims (i.e. the victims of the IRA) are more "innocent" than others.

Generally forgotten is that Charles has been touched by the conflict too. His godfather and guru, Lord Louis Mountbatten, was killed when the IRA blew up his boat in 1979. On the same day, 18 Paras were blown to smithereens near Warrenpoint. The graffitti on republican areas could have been a specific sneer at the Prince: "14 dead and not forgotten"; "We got 18 and Mountbatten."

Due to the sensitivity over the prince's role with the Paras, a planned visit to Londonderry was cancelled, much to the ire of the Rev Ian Paisley, who demanded (unsuccessfully) a debate in Stormont. It is unclear who actually cancelled the prince's planned launch of an e-commerce waste-management bureau in Londonderry's Magee college. Most local politicians did not know he was coming; nor did the Bloody Sunday Campaign. But someone in either the Palace or Magee college began to add two and two together, and a nightmare scenario emerged of the likely reaction to the Colonel-in-Chief of the Parachute Regiment enthusing about waste recycling, while less than one mile down the road, on the Guild Hall, evidence was being read aloud about Paras shooting unarmed Catholics as they lay injured on the ground.

Royal visits are changing in character. There is a more conscious attempt to include (or not to offend) nationalists. The obligatory visit to the security forces will now avoid images of royalty reviewing heavily-armed British troops. This time, the prince will call on the beleaguered RUC, a visit mitigated by solely concentrating on the drug squad in Ballymena. Isn't everyone supposed to be concerned about drugs?

The long-term agenda is really about Charles's mum. Both governments are convinced that the big symbolic seal on the Good Friday Agreement will be a visit by the Queen to Dublin. Three years ago, the Prince of Wales made his first steps along Grafton Street and Trinity college. During a lunch at Buckingham Palace last November, President McAleese publicly expressed her wish to host the Queen.

Royal visits, like IRA guns and the release of prisoners, have become part of the currency of the peace process.

fields.headline: Tinker, tailor, soldier, journalist
fields.standfirst: Has Fleet Street been over-run by the intelligence agencies?  David Leigh  unravels the hidden network of spooks at the heart of the British press.
fields.trailText: Has Fleet Street been over-run by the intelligence agencies? David Leigh unravels the hidden network of spooks at the heart of the British press.
fields.body:
British journalists - and British journals - are being manipulated by the secret intelligence agencies, and I think we ought to try and put a stop to it.

The manipulation takes three forms. The first is the attempt to recruit journalists to spy on other people, or to go themselves under journalistic "cover". This occurs today and it has gone on for years. It is dangerous, not only for the journalist concerned, but for other journalists who get tarred with the espionage brush. Farzad Bazoft was a colleague of mine on the Observer when he was executed by Saddam Hussein for espionage. In a sense it didn't matter whether he was really a spy or not. Either way, he ended up dead.

The second form of manipulation that worries me is when intelligence officers are allowed to pose as journalists in order to write tendentious articles under false names. Evidence of this only rarely comes to light, but two examples have surfaced recently, mainly because of the whistleblowing activities of a couple of renegade officers - David Shayler from MI5 and Richard Tomlinson from MI6.

The third sort of manipulation is the most insidious - when intelligence agency propaganda stories are planted on willing journalists, who disguise their origin from their readers. There is - or has been until recently - a very active programme by the secret agencies to colour what appears in the British press, called, if publications by various defectors can be believed, information operations, or "I/Ops". I am - unusually - in a position to provide some information about its operations.

Let us take the third allegation first. Black propaganda - false material where the source is disguised - has been a tool of British intelligence agencies since the days of the second world war, when the Special Operations Executive (SOE) got up to all kinds of tricks with clandestine radio stations, to drip pornography and pessimism into the ears of impressionable German soldiers. Post-war, this unwholesome game mutated into the anti-Soviet Information Research Department (IRD). Its task was ostensibly to plant anti-communist stories in the developing-world press, but its lurid tales of Marxist drunkenness and corruption sometimes leaked back to confuse the readers of the British media.

A colourful example of the way these techniques expanded to meet the exigencies of the hour came in the early 70s, when the readers of the News of the World were treated to a front-page splash, "Russian sub in IRA plot sensation", complete with aerial photograph of the conning tower of a Soviet sub awash off the coast of Donegal. That was the work of Hugh Mooney of the IRD, which was eventually closed down in 1977.

Its spirit did not die, however. Nearly 25 years later, readers of the Sunday Telegraph were regaled with with the dramatic story of the son of Libya's Colonel Gadafy and his alleged connection to a currency counterfeiting plan. The story was written by Con Coughlin, the paper's chief foreign correspondent and it was falsely attributed to a "British banking official". In fact, it had been given to him by officers of MI6, who, it transpired, had been supplying Coughlin with material for years.

Shayler had worked on MI5's Libya desk at the time, in liaison with his counterparts in the foreign espionage service, MI6, and had come away with a detailed knowledge of events, and a bundle of secret documents to back them up.

Although Coughlin asked for evidence, and was shown purported bank statements, the pleadings make clear that he was dependent on MI6 for the discreditable details about the alleged counterfeiting scam. He was required to keep the source strictly confidential.

But this veil of coyness was blown away by City solicitor David Hooper in his book on libel published last month, Reputations Under Fire, in which he says: "In reality [they were] members of MI6."

So, unusually, an MI6 exercise in planting a story has been laid bare. Now, there is no suggestion that Con Coughlin is dishonest in his work. He is a perfectly conscientious journalist who I expect did his best to substantiate his facts and undoubtedly believed in their truth. But nevertheless, those facts may not have been true. And I believe he made a serious mistake in falsely attributing his story to a "British banking official". His readers ought to know where his material is coming from. This was not an isolated example of recent MI6 I/Ops. I know, because I became involved in an MI6-inspired story as a result. Doyle's MI6 contact supplied him with intelligence information about an Iranian exile who, while running a pizza business in Glasgow, was also attempting to lay hands on a sophisticated mass spectrometer which could be used for measuring uranium enrichment - a key stage in acquiring components for a nuclear bomb.

We were supplied with a mass of apparently high-quality intelligence from MI6, including surveillance details of a meeting in an Istanbul hotel between our pizza merchant and men involved in Iranian nuclear procurement.

I should make clear that we did not publish merely on the say-so of MI6. We travelled to Glasgow, confronted the pizza merchant, and only when he admitted that he had been dealing with representatives of the nuclear industry in Iran did we publish an article. In that story we made it plain that our target had been watched by Western intelligence.

Nevertheless, I felt uneasy, and vowed never to take part in such an exercise again. Although all parties, from the foreign editor down, behaved scrupulously, we had been obliged to conceal from our readers the full facts and had ended up, in effect, acting as government agents.

Now, after the Tomlinson/Shayler defections and the subsequent revelation of MI6's continuing I/Ops programme of which my Iranian experience was plainly a part, I think the cause of honest journalism is best served by candour. We all ought to come clean about these approaches, and devise some ethics to deal with them. In our vanity, we imagine that we control these sources. But the truth is that they are very deliberately seeking to control us.

The second intelligence tactic of manipulation which gives concern is the habit of allowing spies to write under false names. It was Tomlinson, I suspect, who, having worked in the area, first blew the whistle on this one. And it was a recently published book - MI6 by Stephen Dorril - which once again added the final piece of the jigsaw.

Two articles appeared in the Spectator in early 1994 under the byline Kenneth Roberts. They were datelined Sarajevo, and Roberts was described as having been working with the UN in Bosnia as an adviser. In fact, he was MI6 officer Keith Robert Craig (the pseudonym was a simple one), whose local cover was as a civilian "attached" to the British military unit's Balkan secretariat.

At the time, Bosnia was the site of attacks and atrocities from neighbouring Serbia, and also the focus of some passionate reporting from British journalists. The British military was there in a UN peacekeeping role, but anyone who read Roberts's articles might have begun to wonder whether it was not a better policy for British troops to go home and leave the Serbs a free hand.

The first article on February 5 rehearsed arguments for a UN withdrawal, pointing out that all sides committed atrocities. The second piece complained, baselessly, about "warped" and inaccurate reporting by journalists, including the BBC's Kate Adie.

It is possible, of course, that Craig was merely overcome with private literary urges whilst marooned in the Balkans, and thought it more politic to express his own opinions under a nom de plume . But one of the traditional roles of I/Ops is to plant stories. What is not clear is how the introduction to the Spectator was made, or whether Craig confided his real trade to the then editor of the Spectator, Dominic Lawson. In his recent book about MI6, Stephen Dorril points out that Dominic Lawson's brother-in-law, Anthony Monckton, was himself a serving MI6 officer, who was to take over the Zagreb station in the Balkans in 1996. (Rosa Monckton, his sister and Dominic Lawson's wife, was the late Princess Diana's close friend.)

These relationships - which the disenchanted Tomlinson knew all about because he had himself served undercover in the Balkans in the same time-frame - have only slowly emerged into the public domain. There is no reason to believe the then editor of the Spectator did anything improper at all, and certainly no reason to think that he was acting as an agent of MI6, whether paid or unpaid. But, as an editor, wittingly or not, it must be a bad idea to end up in a position where an MI6 officer is writing for your publication on matters of political controversy, under a false name.

The final malpractice which the Tomlinson/Shayler defections have brought to light is the continuing deliberate blurring by MI6 of the line between journalist and spy. This is an old crime - Kim Philby, former foreign correspondent of the Observer would have had plenty of stories to tell about that. But it should be exposed and stopped. Tomlinson himself, by his own account, spent six months in 1993 travelling around Croatia and Serbia trying to recruit informants, under the guise of a British journalist. Dorril, in his book, publishes the further assertion that the Spectator itself was unknowingly used as cover by no fewer than three MI6 officers working in Bosnia, Belgrade and Moldova.

The most dismaying allegation floated by Tomlinson was that he had heard within MI6 of a "national newspaper editor" who was used as an agent, and had received up to £100,000 in covert payments, accessed at an offshore bank, via a false passport obligingly supplied by MI6 itself. This claim set off a hue and cry, during which the hapless Dominic Lawson, now editor of the Sunday Telegraph, issued his denial, and other editors came under suspicious scrutiny.

In fact, I believe Tomlinson has been wrongly reported. Those who have talked to him in detail say that he has no first-hand knowledge, but merely knew of something a colleague obliquely mentioned. Hearing the words "editor" and "national newspaper", Tomlinson jumped to the wrong conclusion, and then started guessing. Spies are, after all, very like journalists in their methods - but merely less reliable. What those in the newspaper business know is that there is all the difference in the world between "the editor" and "an editor". Newspapers have, for example, education editors, environment editors and defence editors (not, I should say, that I have any evidence against any individual members of these categories).

And a senior journalist at that level - who could travel, see things, report back - would be of more practical use in the business of espionage than, say, the editor of any national newspaper. So the hunt is still on for the miscreant. And, make no mistake, this kind of behaviour by journalists is dangerous and wrong.

Our first task as practitioners is to document what goes on in this very furtive field. Our second task ought to be to hold an open debate on what the proper relations between the intelligence agencies and the media ought to be. And our final task must then be to find ways of actually behaving more sensibly.

fields.headline: The prince and the paper
fields.standfirst:
Roy Greenslade on the tangled tale of the prince, the photographer and the disgraced press secretary

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade on the tangled tale of the prince, the photographer and the disgraced press secretary
fields.body:
As a certain Sun columnist would say: "You couldn't make it up". One of the most experienced royal press officers, handling a delicate - but, let's be honest, fairly routine - photographic deal goes about it in the most ham-fisted way imaginable.

On the other side is Fleet Street's greatest champion of journalistic ethics and lecturer to tabloids about the dangers of turning the royal family into a commodity, trying to make a commercial killing from a set of pictures.

Add to that the fact that it all came to light just days before the chairman of the press complaints commission (PCC) was to make a public statement praising editors for their sensitive treatment of Prince William in the past and urging yet more tolerance in future, and you have a public relations cock-up of memorable proportions.

By Friday, the Prince of Wales's press secretary, Sandy Henney, had departed in ignominy from her post, Daily Telegraph editor Charles Moore had lost his exclusive, rival editors were still steaming, and PCC chairman Lord Wakeham had postponed his setpiece speech indefinitely.

First, the facts. Henney and her press team at St James's Palace decided to ensure that newspapers would have a set of pictures of Prince William to mark his 18th birthday, on June 21. As usual, to avoid packs of cameramen surrounding the prince, a single photographer was selected on the understanding that two sets of his resulting pictures, once approved by William and his advisers, would be pooled. One set was destined, under embargo, for the dailies and another for the Sundays.

For reasons she has yet to explain in public, Henney gave this assignment, with its unprecedented access to the prince at Eton, to Ian Jones, a freelance photographer contracted to the Daily Telegraph. There were two other oddities in the agreement. First, Jones would retain the copyright to all the approved pictures. Second, there would be extra approved pictures quite separate from those chosen for the two pooled sets.

Rival photographers, though unaware of the detailed arrangements, are used to the pooling system. But they were unhappy at what they believed to be yet another example of favouritism shown to the Telegraph by St James's Palace. Just two weeks ago, during the Dunkirk commemoration, journalists were told there was space only for two of them aboard the prince's aircraft for a flight to Caen. Telegraph writer Robert Hardman and photographer Jones got the seats.

Delighted that Jones was taking the William pictures, Telegraph editor Moore quickly realised that he might be able to exploit the situation for his paper's benefit. So, on May 2, Henney agreed with Jones that he could give his pictures to the Telegraph weeks before their release to other papers in order that they could be published in the paper's glossy Saturday magazine on June 17.

Better still for Moore, with Jones holding the copyright to a number of approved pictures which wouldn't be available to his rivals, he would be able to publish exclusive shots. Saturday is already the Telegraph's best-selling day. Here was a chance to increase his circulation still further with a genuine scoop. Remarkably, none of this complex deal, with perhaps as much as £1m at stake, was enshrined in a written contract. But nothing ever remains secret for long in Fleet Street.

By last week the Daily Mail got wind of what was happening and, soon after, so did News International's papers at Wapping. Editors were furious at Henney's extraordinary decision-making. At best they thought her guilty of naivety; at worst, they accused her of duplicity. Most were also furious with Moore. Though they conceded that they too might have acted in a similar fashion given half the chance, they were amazed that Moore, of all people, should seek to take commercial advantage of Prince William. In the wake of Princess Diana's death, it was Moore who demanded that the tabloids be brought to heel, castigating them in public and doing all he could in private to amend the editors' code of practice to an acceptable level.

But Moore, even if somewhat embarrassed, was not going to give in easily. As Henney's bosses realised what she had done and demanded that Jones's pictures be released to the complaining Mail and News International, to allow them to compete with the Telegraph, Moore threatened to issue a writ. Later, after diplomacy involving the PCC, he withdrew the threat and then reluctantly agreed that he wouldn't publish pictures which were not available to his rivals. He had lost, and he issued an angry statement laying all the blame at the door of St James's Palace and accusing the Prince's private secretary, Stephen Lamport, of reneging on previous agreements. In fact, Lamport could not have done otherwise. Offending the Telegraph was the lesser of two evils. He knew the result of holding fast to the Henney-Jones deal would be wrecking the good relationship built up over the past four years with the rest of Fleet Street.

There remained the outstanding problem of copyright being vested in Jones, who markets his pictures through Frank Spooner's agency. On Friday afternoon, its managing director, Michael Soulsby, said unequivocally: "As far as we are concerned, we have obtained permission from the Palace to sell these pictures."

His agency considered that the agreement made between Jones and Henney was still valid. But with Henney having resigned - in the words of a Palace spokesman, "having done the honourable thing"- Jones followed suit. He handed back to the Prince of Wales the copyright in his pictures, foregoing considerable profits.

There are many lessons to learn from this sorry saga. The most obvious, of course, is that St James's Palace needs to create a totally new approach to press relations on behalf of Prince William. Newspapers are so competitive, each one vying for advantage over the other, that they must have complete confidence that the Palace will operate on a level playing field. Just because the Daily Telegraph is the preferred reading of princes and generally behaves with due deference, it cannot enjoy either commercial or operational favouritism.

Agreements made with photographers and papers, especially when copyright is involved, should be in the form of legal contracts.

But the greatest lesson of all is the realisation that William is going to be, whether he likes it or not, a subject of intense media fascination for the rest of his life. He is his mother's son in more ways than one. If the Daily Telegraph of all papers thought it could sell extra copies by using his image, imagine what the Daily Mail, Sun and Mirror are thinking. Desperate to replace Diana as a guaranteed sales winner, newspapers and magazines are sure that they can reverse their circulations' slides by publishing pictures of the prince. The market has no morality.

Knowing that, Wakeham was undoubtedly going to offer practical and ethical advice to editors in his now-deferred speech. His central problem is to assure the prince a measure of privacy while allowing the press to exercise its freedom. It was relatively easy to find that balance while William was at Eton because all school children, irrespective of their parentage, are protected from intrusion under the editors' code of practice.

As the pictures fiasco illustrates, now comes the really difficult, and potentially fraught, period when newspapers will be asked to act responsibly. They must avoid treating the prince as "fair game" while, for his part, Prince William must understand that he cannot be wrapped in cotton wool. To this end, Wakeham will need to remind editors that they must obey the code both in letter and spirit. Perhaps the most obvious, but most overlooked, point is the need for accuracy. Stories about the royal family are notorious for their factual errors, reliance on quotes from anonymous sources and wildly speculative flights of fancy.

William has already suffered that kind of nonsense. By coincidence, the Sunday Express yesterday published a PCC adjudication upholding a complaint by the father of a 19-year-old blonde girl "tipped to be Prince William's wife". Though the paper quoted "royal insiders" as saying the couple had "formed a close bond" the prince had never met Isabella Anstruther-Gough-Calthorpe. Sadly, given that truth is supposed to form the cornerstone of journalism, Wakeham will need to reinforce that basic tenet in his speech because inaccuracy all too often leads to intrusion.

That takes us on to the more subjective problem of defining what should and should not be private. Since, in a recent ruling, the PCC decided that Moors murderer Ian Brady was entitled to privacy, then the prince must enjoy the same privilege.

Finally, and here surely is the real test, Wakeham must reinforce the clause about harassment which was drawn up following Diana's death. Most importantly, editors must not publish pictures obtained by persistent pursuit.

What will be truly fascinating is public reaction. Will readers flock to buy any paper which preys on William as they did Diana?

In the wake of Princess Diana's death, it was Moore who demanded that the tabloids be brought to heel, castigating them in public and doing all he could in private to amend the editors' code of practice to an acceptable level. But Moore, even if somewhat embarrassed, was not going to give in easily. As Henney's bosses realised what she had done and demanded that Jones's pictures be released to the complaining Mail and News International, to allow them to compete with the Telegraph, Moore threatened to issue a writ. Later, after diplomacy involving the PCC, he withdrew the threat and then reluctantly agreed that he wouldn't publish pictures which were not available to his rivals. He had lost, and he issued an angry statement laying all the blame at the door of St James's Palace and accusing the Prince's private secretary, Stephen Lamport, of reneging on previous agreements. In fact, Lamport could not have done otherwise. Offending the Telegraph was the lesser of two evils. He knew the result of holding fast to the Henney-Jones deal would be wrecking the good relationship built up over the past four years with the rest of Fleet Street. There remained the outstanding problem of copyright being vested in Jones, who markets his pictures through Frank Spooner's agency. On Friday afternoon, its managing director, Michael Soulsby, said unequivocally: "As far as we are concerned, we have obtained permission from the Palace to sell these pictures." His agency considered that the agreement made between Jones and Henney was still valid. But with Henney having resigned - in the words of a Palace spokesman, "having done the honourable thing"- Jones followed suit. He handed back to the Prince of Wales the copyright in his pictures, foregoing considerable profits. There are many lessons to learn from this sorry saga. The most obvious, of course, is that St James's Palace needs to create a totally new approach to press relations on behalf of Prince William. Newspapers are so competitive, each one vying for advantage over the other, that they must have complete confidence that the Palace will operate on a level playing field. Just because the Daily Telegraph is the preferred reading of princes and generally behaves with due deference, it cannot enjoy either commercial or operational favouritism. Agreements made with photographers and papers, especially when copyright is involved, should be in the form of legal contracts. But the greatest lesson of all is the realisation that William is going to be, whether he likes it or not, a subject of intense media fascination for the rest of his life. He is his mother's son in more ways than one. If the Daily Telegraph of all papers thought it could sell extra copies by using his image, imagine what the Daily Mail, Sun and Mirror are thinking. Desperate to replace Diana as a guaranteed sales winner, newspapers and magazines are sure that they can reverse their circulations' slides by publishing pictures of the prince. The market has no morality. Knowing that, Wakeham was undoubtedly going to offer practical and ethical advice to editors in his now-deferred speech. His central problem is to assure the prince a measure of privacy while allowing the press to exercise its freedom. It was relatively easy to find that balance while William was at Eton because all school children, irrespective of their parentage, are protected from intrusion under the editors' code of practice. As the pictures fiasco illustrates, now comes the really difficult, and potentially fraught, period when newspapers will be asked to act responsibly. They must avoid treating the prince as "fair game" while, for his part, Prince William must understand that he cannot be wrapped in cotton wool. To this end, Wakeham will need to remind editors that they must obey the code both in letter and spirit. Perhaps the most obvious, but most overlooked, point is the need for accuracy. Stories about the royal family are notorious for their factual errors, reliance on quotes from anonymous sources and wildly speculative flights of fancy. William has already suffered that kind of nonsense. By coincidence, the Sunday Express yesterday published a PCC adjudication upholding a complaint by the father of a 19-year-old blonde girl "tipped to be Prince William's wife". Though the paper quoted "royal insiders" as saying the couple had "formed a close bond" the prince had never met Isabella Anstruther-Gough-Calthorpe. Sadly, given that truth is supposed to form the cornerstone of journalism, Wakeham will need to reinforce that basic tenet in his speech because inaccuracy all too often leads to intrusion. That takes us on to the more subjective problem of defining what should and should not be private. Since, in a recent ruling, the PCC decided that Moors murderer Ian Brady was entitled to privacy, then the prince must enjoy the same privilege. Finally, and here surely is the real test, Wakeham must reinforce the clause about harassment which was drawn up following Diana's death. Most importantly, editors must not publish pictures obtained by persistent pursuit. What will be truly fascinating is public reaction. Will readers flock to buy any paper which preys on William as they did Diana?

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: * Good Housekeeping's Lindsay Nicholson retains her title of Labour's magazine editor of choice despite suspicions that her organ is favoured by WI members. A GH do at the Lords last week was hosted by Baroness Jay and thronged with No 10 apparatchiks. Brave, then, of the hacks present to note that when Tony Blair made a speech to editors and publishers at their annual conference last month, he made a big policy statement, when they wanted to hear his views on the media. Happily the magazine folk were too polite to boo.
fields.body:
* Good Housekeeping's Lindsay Nicholson retains her title of Labour's magazine editor of choice despite suspicions that her organ is favoured by WI members. A GH do at the Lords last week was hosted by Baroness Jay and thronged with No 10 apparatchiks. Brave, then, of the hacks present to note that when Tony Blair made a speech to editors and publishers at their annual conference last month, he made a big policy statement, when they wanted to hear his views on the media. Happily the magazine folk were too polite to boo.

*More fun and games over OK!TV's return to ITV in August. The story so far: OK! publisher Richard Desmond has broken off contact with Carlton, which made series one, and is paired with GMTV. But no one can agree on presenters. GMTV's Fiona Phillips was a hit last time. But a root cause of the falling out with Carlton is said by GMTV moles to be her fee - a rumoured £7,000 a programme. Desmond apparently thinks Sky's Tania Bryer would be as good, and cheaper (apparently Tania charges £3,000). Sadly ITV wants Fiona. Perhaps Desmond could get two for the price of one with a fly-on-the-wall docu-soap?

*With Greg Dyke's BBC recruiting an ITV man to restore children's programmes, the rumour mill is in overdrive about the biggest job, head of drama. One version has Alan Yentob, as overall director, with the heads of series, serials and films working to him. But that's not what Dyke wants. Another has Granada's drama controller Simon Lewis and deputy Sue Hogg moving across: but as the team behind such popular ITV series as Grafters and Always and Everyone they're in demand. Maybe it's time for the BBC to kiss and make up with Jo Wright, LWT's controller of drama, who stole Ross Kemp. Except she's worked at the BBC before and knows the score.

*As many newspapers gleefully reported last week, Channel 4's achingly hip cricket coverage this summer includes a Caribbean season of live music. But despite the reported culture clash, it turns out the MCC is happy to have bands on the pitch at lunch, according to Terry Blake of the England & Wales Cricket Board. The real criticism at the launch came from black journalists who said the musical range was too narrow: too much Bob Marley, more bands from Jamaica than Barbados, and the worst sin: no women cricket commentators. "It's meant to be inclusive and multi-cultural and most of the audience will be white," snapped C4 deputy director of programmes Karen Brown. You can please some of the people . . .
