fields.headline: Not just kids' play
fields.standfirst: Children are turning off BBC in favour of ITV. But now the BBC has poached the commercial station's best weapon and the fight is on.  Maggie Brown reports
fields.trailText: Children are turning off BBC in favour of ITV. But now the BBC has poached the commercial station's best weapon and the fight is on. Maggie Brown reports
fields.body:
Over the past two years ITV has performed a minor miracle. It has revived its children's programmes, an area traditionally dominated by the BBC. Rather than resorting to wall-to-wall cartoons, it's done it by creating an eclectic mix: buzzy live presentation, puppets, comedy, dramas such as Worst Witch and My Parents are Aliens, and twice-weekly episodes of its enduring hit, Art Attack.

Above all, it has wrested control of Saturday mornings from the BBC, thanks to Ant & Dec's fizzy live show, SMTV Live, which, crucially, runs throughout the year. Last year it gave Live & Kicking a kicking. Now it's pulverising FBI, the limp replacement from BBC Scotland.

Ratings for its weekday CITV zone are up roughly 10% on a year ago, while those for Children's BBC (CBBC) are faltering. This is no mean feat in the face of ferocious competition: Sky One runs Pokémon cartoons from 3.30-5pm every weekday, directly against the terrestrial channels' kids' zones.

ITV's turnaround has been orchestrated by Nigel Pickard, who joined the ITV Network Centre in 1998 and took forceful command of CITV's £45m budget and 11 hours of weekly programming. Cynics told him the job would be short-term: ITV would be ditching TV for kids as fast as it could and courting "yoof" instead. Domestic production would be swamped by global forces, led by the $2.1bn invested annually in American children's programming.

Instead, with just two assistants, but strong backing from ITV programme director David Liddiment, Pickard proved the power of positive thinking, providing a rallying-point for children's TV producers. He introduced a stripped schedule boasting long runs of original, exclusive-to-ITV programming, only partly copying cable and satellite. He devised a long-term strategy for winning Saturdays, accepting that SMTV Live would take a year to bed in, and launched a fistful of new shows, including British animation made with partners.

"He is very good news. Before he arrived, CITV was in the doldrums," says a key official. And now Pickard, 48, who has spent all his life in commercial TV, has been poached by the BBC, to repeat his ITV feats and more. He is Greg Dyke's first major signing, installed in the reorganised BBC's new tier of powerful "budget- holder" commissioners, who are as capable of commissioning programmes as channel controllers.

He has been handed the best job in children's TV - controller of CBBC, a newly integrated children's department (reuniting 220 production staff with schedulers) responsible for 30 hours of output each week on BBC1 and BBC2. Part of his remit is "developing the proposition" of a public service BBC channel for the under-12s, a project on the launch pad awaiting a green light. If it gets Department of Culture approval, it could be on air late this year or early next. Pickard is said to think the BBC should launch two networks, not dissimilar to the Nickelodeon/Nick Jr model - one for pre-school children, another for the 6-to-12s.

In the context of the vociferous debate about public service broadcasting, the role of children's TV is key - especially to the BBC. Children's TV is a defining element of a public service mix and it's become axiomatic that children should have access to programmes which are made specifically for them and do not exploit them.

Though Pickard, a shrewd, genial figure who attributes much of his success to common sense, is lying low at his home in Kent, the clues to what he brings to CBBC are clear. The basic analysis is that CBBC is not punching its weight. It could be a global force. Blue Peter is performing as well as ever, but as a brand it is hardly exploited: no books or clubs. Its dramas, such as last year's Pig Heart Boy and the Bafta winner See How They Run, remain challenging and of the highest quality. But other opportunities are missed: Microsoap, a breakthrough portrayal of dysfunctional family life which influenced Granada's My Parents are Aliens, has been allowed to die.

Presentation has become laboured: everyone knew Zoë Ball and Jamie Theakston were quitting Live & Kicking, for example, but their departure still left a glaring gap. More generally, there has been drift and a lack of leadership since the extraordinary success of Teletubbies. "What you need is someone to champion CBBC," says a key source.

Greg Dyke first crossed paths with Pickard when he became director of programmes at TVS in 1984, after performing his famous rescue act at TV-am. Based in Southampton, TVS had built on what it inherited from Southern, the previous licence-holder, to become ITV's biggest supplier of children's programming. Many of the biggest talents in British children's TV worked there. To his surprise, Pickard was promoted by Dyke over several more senior producers to become controller of children's programming in 1986, when Anna Home left TVS to run children's television . . . for the BBC.

His roots go deep: he worked as an assistant producer on Worzel Gummidge in the 1970s, and was involved in a long list of other hits - Art Attack, Motor Mouth, How To . . ., What's Up Doc?, Mr Majeika, Street Wise. But when TVS lost its franchise to Meridian, he eventually ended up in the nascent but growing cable and satellite world, running the Maidstone-based Family Channel.

When it was taken over by Flextech, he became vice-president of production for Bravo, UK Living and Challenge TV. His one regret is the way Flextech failed to develop the Children's Channel, retreating in the face of the Cartoon Network and Nickelodeon and then opting to turn it into the teenage Trouble channel.

Married with three grown-up children, Pickard is praised by Alan Yentob, the BBC's bizarrely titled director of drama, entertainment and children, for having "a profound understanding of the needs and aspirations of children in the UK today". The truth is he's a mix of enthusiasm - "he loves the crunchy stuff, mixing with producers," says a key supplier - with a strong commercial streak.

His business sense is typified by CITV's switch to making long runs of drama and animation series - rather than old-fashioned sets of six - because it's the only way to attract international sales and co-production funds for expensive projects. Worst Witch is getting a third run and a Christmas special, so there will be 40 episodes in all. Pickard ordered 52 episodes of SMTV from the start. CITV's monthly magazine and website also testify to his commercial nous. Why is it thought that children's programmes are dying, Pickard has asked, when everyone in the new media world is targeting them?

He is well-equipped to deal with the BBC's new realism, where strong links with its commercial wing Worldwide count. What's unproven is how far he understands the special nature of the BBC's purer brand of public service broadcasting and the management challenges of getting results at the corporation. But now he has a really big train set to play with.

fields.headline: Basest instincts
fields.standfirst: English rivalry with the French and Germans is alive and well in Sega's new ad campaign.  It chose the charged air of Euro 2000 to kick off.  Emma Hall reports
fields.trailText: English rivalry with the French and Germans is alive and well in Sega's new ad campaign. It chose the charged air of Euro 2000 to kick off. Emma Hall reports
fields.body:
An obnoxious German, complete with mullet haircut and shell suit, turns to a gang of beered-up Brits and leers: "Come and have a go if you think you're hard enough."

This incendiary scenario will be played out over and over again during the three weeks of Euro 2000, and not just on the terraces. It is Sega's new ad campaign for the Dreamcast console, and it will be broadcast in pubs and homes all over Europe, despite rising concerns about the possibility of violence at the tournament.

Consumers are used to seeing cheap stunts from advertisers whose budgets don't match their ambitions, but Sega's venture doesn't come cheap - 30 seconds' television airtime costs £80,000 during the bigger games - and the campaign, which began with the opening match between Belgium and Sweden on Saturday, will cost £10m. At the heart of Sega's efforts is ChuChu Rocket, a game which allows up to four players to compete in a live, online game across Europe. For the first time, it claims, players will be able to take on European rivals from the comfort of their own bedrooms.

So Sega and its advertising agency, Bartle Bogle Hegarty (BBH), have created three different ads announcing the launch of online console gaming between England, Germany, Spain, France and Ireland. The first has the shell-suited German putting us straight on a few facts, such as "Germany always wins". The statement is accompanied by images of towels neatly arranged on a row of sun loungers and crowds of Germans celebrating a footballing triumph.

Next up is the English version. "There's no need to tell you England is superior," announces an upper-class narrator, while pictures of Winston Churchill, Margaret Thatcher and a bulldog appear on screen.

The voice continues: "You beg us to join your precious Europe, but why? We come and see you every summer." This last line is delivered to images of drunken Brits abroad walking around with their trousers down or turning lobster pink in the hot sun. The challenge is issued: "Play me head-to-head on your Dreamcast and let's see who's the daddy."

The French version is set in the Café de Ponce . A philosopher in a black polo neck explains that the French are not just intelligent, "but also so cultured and stylish and artistic. And all your women want us." The narrator warms to his theme: "You think you can defeat La France. You who are so stupid, like a peasant."

In the right context, the ads are hilarious. But impassioned international football matches are not necessarily the right context.

A Sega spokesman says: "If they do cause offence, it's because of a lack of sense of humour, and we can't be held responsible for that."

But only last week in Cornwall, English schoolchildren - encouraged by their parents - attacked a group of German youngsters, throwing stones and calling them Nazis. If this sort of incident is replayed among adult football fans in Charleroi, where England play Germany on Saturday, viewers may not be able to see the funny side of Sega's ads.

Alison Turner, marketing director of Sega UK, claims not to have considered the possibility of the ads backfiring. Nor is she worried about viewers finding them offensive.

"People are entitled to their opinions, but we haven't created ads that are antagonistic," Turner says. "They are a light-hearted look at European rivalry. They poke fun at national stereotypes."

Insiders admit, however, that Sega has a fallback position should trouble erupt. Softer copies of the ads will be sent to broadcasters if violence flares up, but there is no guarantee that Sega will be able to react quickly enough.

Paul Bradbury from BBH acknowledges the ads could cause offence: "We would be naive to think that there would be no reaction to them. But they will make the brand famous and they hit the mark," he says. "Probably people will be offended but I hope not - the jokes are cheap and obvious, they don't delve back into Nazi history."

Bradbury says the ads were originally even tougher, before cuts were made to persuade the advertising watchdog to approve the campaign. Overt violence and provocative language had to be toned down, and the German ad was amended to make it less "dark" than the original script intended.

Uisdean Maclean, director of the broadcast advertising clearance centre, believes the humour mitigates any possible offence. "We could defend our approval because the ads are not hard-edged," says Maclean. "They are funny."

But British consumers aren't always good at seeing the funny side of things. When Ikea ran a series of ads in which Swedes urged viewers to "Stop being so English", the independent television commission received 175 complaints from people who thought the ads were racist. Carling was also accused of racism when it ran a series of ads mocking the French and the Germans.

The most offensive aspect of the Sega campaign, it might be argued, is the reliance on tired jokes about Johnny Foreigner. Robert Saville, a partner at ad agency Mother, researched the lure of patriotism when planning the strategy for the launch of Whitbread's new lager, GB.

"Patriotism is old-fashioned," says Saville. "It appeals to the older generation. And xenophobia is incredibly limiting. Taking the piss out of foreigners to make the British look good has been done. There are new ways of doing things."

Sega might deny accusations of sensationalism, but clearly the brand needs to make maximum impact as quickly as possible.

Sony launches online gaming for its rival platform, PlayStation 2, in 2001, so Sega has only a small window in which to make Dreamcast a household name. The console has been selling well, but has found it hard to match the buzz about the new PlayStation model. The campaign is a shameless attempt to tap in to the patriotic hype that surrounds Euro 2000.

"Offence is in the eye of the beholder," reasons Alfredo Marcantonio, the European creative director of ad agency D'Arcy. Sega will be hoping that the right people are watching their ads over the coming weeks.

If this sort of incident is replayed among adult football fans in Charleroi, where England play Germany on Saturday, viewers may not be able to see the funny side of Sega's ads. "People are entitled to their opinions, but we haven't created ads that are antagonistic," Turner says. "They are a light-hearted look at European rivalry. They poke fun at national stereotypes." Insiders admit, however, that Sega has a fallback position should trouble erupt. Softer copies of the ads will be sent to broadcasters if violence flares up, but there is no guarantee that Sega will be able to react quickly enough. Paul Bradbury from BBH acknowledges the ads could cause offence: "We would be naive to think that there would be no reaction to them. Carling was also accused of racism when it ran a series of ads mocking the French and the Germans. Robert Saville, a partner at ad agency Mother, researched the lure of patriotism when planning the strategy for the launch of Whitbread's new lager, GB. "Patriotism is old-fashioned," says Saville. "It appeals to the older generation. And xenophobia is incredibly limiting. Taking the piss out of foreigners to make the British look good has been done. There are new ways of doing things." Sega might deny accusations of sensationalism, but clearly the brand needs to make maximum impact as quickly as possible. Sony launches online gaming for its rival platform, PlayStation 2, in 2001, so Sega has only a small window in which to make Dreamcast a household name. The console has been selling well, but has found it hard to match the buzz about the new PlayStation model. The campaign is a shameless attempt to tap in to the patriotic hype that surrounds Euro 2000. "Offence is in the eye of the beholder," reasons Alfredo Marcantonio, the European creative director of ad agency D'Arcy. Sega will be hoping that the right people are watching their ads over the coming weeks.

fields.headline: The firing line
fields.standfirst: It's called the 'fresh blood' policy. Critics call it racist and reckless.  Emma Hartley  on the World Service's  new hiring policy
fields.trailText: It's called the 'fresh blood' policy. Critics call it racist and reckless. Emma Hartley on the World Service's new hiring policy
fields.body:
The BBC World Service is often held up as a beacon of enlightened values and journalistic integrity around the globe, but it now stands accused of recklessness and institutional racism over its policy for recruiting foreign journalists.

The broadcasting union Bectu and the National Union of Journalists have been joined by Imran Khan, the Lawrence family's campaigning solicitor, and political comedians Mark Thomas and Mark Steel, in condemning the corporation's carnivorous-sounding "fresh blood" policy.

It is a policy which is intended to provide the BBC at Bush House with journalists of the highest calibre, but its critics say it will also create a climate of fear among staff and even expose some to physical danger.

Bush House attracts foreign journalists to work in its language section, which broadcasts international news in 43 languages, including English. They come, for what many regard as the opportunity of a lifetime, from every part of the globe to take up contracts which, by the Home Office definition, must be unfulfillable by anyone already living in Britain.

Until last July the norm was to get a two- or three-year deal initially, which in all probability would then be extended or renewed. But a recent change in policy, apparently under pressure from the Home Office, has meant that three-year fixed-term contracts are now given out with the proviso that at the end of that period recipients will have to compete openly with other applicants.

Fair enough in the cutthroat London media world, some might say. Except that the name of the policy - "fresh blood" - implies that the decision will be weighted against those who have been away from their homeland for some years. Loss of contact with up-to-date culture and idioms is the justification for this.

The initial three-year contract falls short of the four-year requirement for residency in Britain and, it is alleged, is designed to prevent the creation of a pool of foreign journalists at the World Service whose skills are too specialised to be useful anywhere else.

As a result the broadcasters, many of whom arrive in Britain with their spouses and children, are forced to choose between seeking another niche job that they, uniquely, can fill in order to satisfy the Home Office; returning to a regime which may no longer welcome them; or applying for political asylum.

A Bectu spokesman says: "Many of the countries they come from have regimes which are not keen on journalists - the majority of the languages are African and central Asian. Quite frequently they were political dissidents to some degree before they arrived. Some broadcast under pseudonyms in order to conceal their identities, but it is well known that the BBC is riddled with spooks, so anyone who has been critical of a totalitarian regime would have good reason to worry about their personal safety if they return.

"The policy supposes that these journalists can go stale, like a piece of meat. But these days the internet, international phone lines and email make it less likely than ever before that this will happen. And anyway, since when was it BBC policy to use street slang in broadcasts?

"White journalists such as John Simpson and Ben Brown are sent by the same organisation to countries where they don't even speak the language. The least the BBC can do is offer these people a sabbatical if they feel they are beginning to lose touch.

"The fresh blood policy only applies to the language section. We think under the race relations act this policy is racist and we have brought it to the attention of the commission for racial equality, who are investigating."

Joseph Naghdi, 40, worked at the BBC's Persian desk broadcasting to Iran for three years, until 1999. Married with two children, he is now taking computer a engineering course while awaiting a decision on his application for political asylum. In not having his contract renewed, he was unlucky, but his experience may now become the norm.

"In Iran journalists are under extreme pressure, especially if they work with radio like the BBC," he says. "It is not accepted as a friendly medium by the Iranian conservatives. If I went back I would be in a very bad situation - I might be prosecuted by the government.

"I know three people who were recruited for the section who were affiliated to the reformist movement in Iran and working for newspapers which were closed down. If they decide to go back they will definitely have problems.

The position of many language section journalists is made more difficult because the criteria for recruitment in the first instance do not include fluency in English.

"They mainly concentrate on the ability of the person to translate from English," says Naghdi. "Some are fluent anyway, but for those from regions where there were no British colonies - places such as Iran, Afghanistan, Tadzhikistan - it is not so easy."

Such countries are also among those that are least sympathetic to the western media. The same central Asian journalists who may be hindered by poor English while seeking new work in London are the very ones who are unlikely to get a hero's welcome on their return. "It is very cruel," says Naghdi.

In a statement, the BBC defended the "fresh blood" policy, saying: "the World Service operates in a fast-moving media environment and employs people using a mix of permanent and fixed-term contracts.

"Residency is a matter for the Home Office and not the employer. Staff who are engaged on fixed-term contracts are not precluded from applying for a permanent contract, and therefore staff are not prevented from applying to the Home Office for indefinite leave to remain in the UK."

But while the termination of a contract after three years may be a blow to anyone, it can only be much worse for these foreign nationals who stand to lose not only a job, but their right to remain in the country.

fields.headline: I'm listening
fields.standfirst: Phone-in psychiatry isn't just performing a social function - it also makes for compelling radio.  Stephen Armstrong  meets Britain's answer to Frasier Crane
fields.trailText: Phone-in psychiatry isn't just performing a social function - it also makes for compelling radio. Stephen Armstrong meets Britain's answer to Frasier Crane
fields.body:
It had been a pretty normal night on Dr Pam's show. Nigel had problems maintaining his erection, Sharon was worried her husband was having an affair, and Paul phoned in because he had the same problem as Nigel, although halfway through the call he revealed that he was gay. That changed things a little: Dr Pam wanted to check if he had problems coming out as well as simply coming. Then the researchers outside the studio window got terribly excited. They had Claire on the line, and she was radio gold dust.

Claire had been a porn star, met a guy, got him some porn work, married him, had a kid and wanted him to give up the movies. The trouble was, his career was taking off and he didn't want to give it up. And after a hard day's work on a hot bed, the last thing he felt like was a repeat performance for his wife.

"Jerry Springer," I thought through my blushes, "eat your heart out."

Welcome to the strangest media launch of the year - where sitcom becomes fact. Dr Pam Spurr is London's very own Frasier Crane, an on-air psychiatrist with a phone-in show. Previously a psychologist at Guy's hospital, she even has an American accent. She started a two-hour emotional and sexual problems programme called Heart to Heart on soft-rock station Heart FM on Sunday nights from 10pm at the end of May, and she's getting calls that make Trisha look like a kids' TV programme.

I first heard Dr Pam in her previous incarnation as sit-in doctor on Nigel Williams's late night love-songs programme. I was driving into London on Sunday night and Louise phoned in, complaining that her boyfriend didn't satisfy her. Dr Pam started with pretty direct suggestions as to what she should say until the girl explained that on Friday her female best friend had popped round, they'd messed about a bit and her mate had been better than her boyfriend. Now she wasn't sure if she preferred boys or girls. From then on, I was hooked.

"This new show's format is modelled a bit on the Frasier Crane show," admits Jana Rangoni, Heart's programme director. "We originally had Dr Pam on Monday nights with Nigel Williams, but it worked so well we put her on Sundays and Tuesdays as well and then we found that the other elements of Nigel's show were getting between her and the listeners so we gave her a show of her own."

The best call Dr Pam received in her Williams period was from a man - called David on air - who preferred porn to his wife. Halfway through the call his mobile rang. It was his wife. She'd been listening to him on the show and had recognised his voice. David went to pieces on air, repeating, 'This is a nightmare' again and again at increasing volume until finally he agreed to talk it all out with his wife. As they say in the US, don't touch that dial.

"Most people go on air with an assumed name but sometimes people recognise the caller's voice and phone the station or worse," Dr Pam explains. "Once we had a woman on the line whose husband abused her and during the call it became clear he'd been listening to the radio - he burst into the room and was about to attack her. She just said, 'Oh my God' and hung up. We didn't really have time to do anything else so we sent for the police. We always ask callers for their name and phone number even if they plan to go on anonymously, and we've kept in touch with her and now she's doing OK."

The show itself is highly staffed for a commercial radio station. Heart's studios normally contain just the DJ without even a producer. Dr Pam has three researchers, Rory the producer and someone to drive the desk, playing the records that pepper the show.

"I've been here for 20 years and I've seen the English change emotionally so much," Dr Pam says. "Twenty years ago, you wouldn't get a male caller to a show like mine. Now you can do an entire show and realise that every caller was a man. It's different from TV because the TV problem shows are usually about people getting their 15 minutes. With us, it's usually that people just want a couple of minutes to talk and get some impartial advice."

Of course, some trained psychiatrists might bemoan the brevity of the counselling. Others, such as Dr Deenesh Khoosal - a psychiatrist who performs a similar service on BBC Midlands local radio every Friday - think that airing these topics is good for the nation's soul. For the rest of us, yelling in delighted outrage at our car stereos when Dr Pam describes female masturbation techniques, the rights and wrongs don't enter into it. We've finally got our own Dr Ruth. Except she's called Pam.

fields.headline: Syria: a family business
fields.standfirst: The succession of Bashar al-Assad to the Syrian presidency may help the prospects of peace in the Middle East
fields.trailText: The succession of Bashar al-Assad to the Syrian presidency may help the prospects of peace in the Middle East, argues Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Syria's ruling clique has moved swiftly to fill the power vacuum created by the death of Hafez al-Assad.

On Saturday, when the old dictator died, the country's complaisant parliament rushed through a constitutional amendment reducing the minimum age required of a president from 40 to 34. That, conveniently enough, is the age of Assad's oldest surviving son, Bashar.

Bashar al-Assad has also been declared head of Syria's armed forces. He is, effectively, acting president.

But the succession cannot be taken for granted. Bashar's exiled uncle, Rifaad, still has powerful friends in Damascus, and must be calculating his chances of a successful comeback. And there are strong currents of dissent flowing beneath the surface of Syria's orchestrated display of national mourning.

The 30-year dictatorship of Hafez al-Assad rested on more than just his ruthlessness - though that was a major factor, and his anointed son has yet to show whether he has inherited it.

There are three other pillars of the system: the military, the Ba'ath party, and the small but powerful Alawite Muslim sect, to which the Assads belong.

Resentment of the Alawites runs deep in Syria, but for more than a generation nobody has dared to express it. Bashar's presidency will largely depend on whether he can stifle or divert criticism of the chronic cronyism of the present system.

He has already signalled his wish to modernise the creaking institutions of state, having launched last year a determined drive against rampant corruption. That is a popular cause in Syria, and it carries the added advantage of allowing him to remove potential rivals in the name of clean government.

Bashar is an opthalmologist by profession, who is keen to guide his country into the information technology age. His background is more international than that of most Arab leaders. He speaks fluent English and French, and has conducted important diplomatic missions for the regime.

Against all that, is the desperate brevity of his training for the top job. He was catapulted into the heir-apparent role when his elder brother, Basil, was killed in a road accident in 1994.

Basil had been groomed for the succession virtually from birth. Bashar seemed apolitical until his brother died, and has since had relatively little time to learn the intricate ropes of Middle East state-craft.

He starts with the advantage of being in a country long cowed into submissiveness by a regime which is brutishly intolerant, even by the standards of the region. Last year, Hafez al-Assad retained the presidency with a preposterous popular majority of 99.98%.

Yet even under Assad, there were signals of change. The economy has been partially freed from stifling state controls and is experiencing modest growth. Without the support of the Soviet Union, Syria has slowly softened its hostile attitude to the west.

Washington has an unprecedented opportunity to cajole its closest ally, Israel, into a long-sought accommodation with the new regime in Damascus.

There is little doubt that Israel, having come to terms with Egypt and Jordan, would love to complete the so-called circle of peace by signing a treaty with Syria. (Lebanon, Israel's only other neighbour, is little more than a Syrian client state.)

But an Israeli-Syrian peace accord can only come when there is a settlement of the fiendishly intractable issue of the Golan Heights.

The countries have twice fought bitter wars for possession of the strategically vital territory. In the six-day war of 1967, Israeli forces stormed the Heights. They were driven back to the Galilee plain at the outset of the Yom Kippur war in 1973, but within weeks they had pushed the Syrians out again.

Damascus insists that it must be given back all its lost lands, including Mount Hermon - where Israel has established a surveillance station overlooking Damascus - and part of the sea of Galilee as the price of peace. Israel insists that it must retain control of at least the Galilee shoreline and Mount Hermon, and that the rest of the Golan must be verifiably demilitarised to prevent Syrian artillery attacks on the coastal strip.

There is a vocal movement in Israel for retention of the Golan Heights, where settlers have established thriving tourist, wine-making, and agricultural industries. But for the non-Jewish majority of Golan residents, both Arab and Druze, there is a growing sense that the future is Syrian.

webTitle: Councillors reject Prescott's new homes plan

fields.headline: Councillors reject Prescott's new homes plan
fields.standfirst: Interactive: where the houses will be built
fields.trailText:
Government plans for hundreds of thousands of new homes in
the South East were today rejected by councillors.
fields.body:
Government plans for hundreds of thousands of new homes in the South East were today rejected by councillors.

They voted in favour of a Tory proposal to keep to an original target of 33,000 new homes a year for the next five years.

The decision came after a tense two-hour meeting of the South East Regional Planning Authority in London (Serplan). Conservatives argued that Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott's move to allow 43,000 new properties every year for the next five years in the South East would harm the environment and there was insufficient cash to pay for vital infrastructure, roads and schools.

Serplan had said that no more than 33,400 homes could be built annually between 1996 and 2016 without wrecking green fields.

Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, leader of Kent County Council, said after the vote: "The Government's total is far too high and we are delighted by this result."

A spokesman for the Tory group on the Local Government Association said: "We are obviously delighted with this result. It is backed not just by rural people but by the whole population in the South East."

fields.headline: Time for truly ethical policies
fields.standfirst:
Labour is firmly embarked on its road to the manifesto - and so is the Guardian. In this, the fifth week of a unique experiment in British journalism, we set out the latest part of our vision for Labour's second term. Today: Britain's place in the world

Road to the manifesto
fields.trailText: The government, in its first term, clung too closely to past perceptions of how Britain should protect its interests and influence the outside world. There are different ways to "fly the flag" and "punch above our weight".
fields.body:
The government, in its first term, clung too closely to past perceptions of how Britain should protect its interests and influence the outside world. There are different ways to "fly the flag" and "punch above our weight".

A more imaginative and radical approach is desirable during a second term. This should involve a fundamental rethink of Britain's traditional political and strategic alliances and how it can really achieve the foreign secretary Robin Cook's objective, set out in 1997, "to make Britain once again a force for good in the world".

Defence

The government should make unilateral moves towards nuclear disarmament, at the very least by stating it will not seek a successor to the Trident missile system. It should also press Nato to agree to a "no first use" policy on nuclear weapons and oppose any further Nato enlargement. Next, Britain should press for the abolition of Nato. That organisation is a relic of the cold war: it served a purpose then, but has now outlived its usefulness. The eventual aim should be to close all Nato and US military and security or intelligence-related bases in Britain.

Instead, the UK should move to strengthen the role of the organisation for security and cooperation in Europe (OSCE) of which Russia and the US are members.

The government should build up the European security and defence identity (ESDI), with a permanent professional military force and command at its heart, and with a mandate for "out-of-area" assignments under UN auspices. In the longer term, the government should support closer military and security cooperation, under ESDI and the OSCE, with a democratically-led Russia.

The government should gradually seek to reduce British industry's dependence on the arms trade and arms exports, especially relating to offensive weapons and equipment. It makes a mockery of Mr Cook's much-vaunted "ethical dimension" that the buyers of British arms include some of the world's most oppressive regimes, including Saudi Arabia.

Europe

To maximise Britain's influence, it is time to end the perennial debate about whether the UK's principal overseas ally and collaborator is North America or Europe. We believe Britain's destiny lies within Europe. This means acceptance of the principle of a more coherent EU, but on the basis of a confederation governed ultimately by the council of ministers, representing national governments, and not the European commission.

Logically, we believe this entails UK entry into the euro-zone and the replacement of the pound by the euro. We know colleagues may take a different view, but we think the government should hold a referendum on the single currency within six months of the election, enthusiastically recommending its adoption.

The government should support the gradual and staged enlargement of the EU to embrace principally east European countries formerly belonging to the Soviet bloc. Inclusion should depend on the acceptance of common business and trading practices - as well as values based on social justice and human rights. These ought to be under pinned by a new, binding charter of fundamental citizens' rights.

The UK must retain control of its defence and security forces, its domestic taxation system, and its national borders. But while progress by consensus would be preferable, more use of majority voting will be inevitable over issues which are not related to Britain's - or any other country's - vital national interest.

At the top of the UK's European agenda during the next parliament should be the reform of the EU and commission institutions themselves, to assure greater accountability, transparency, and less waste, inefficiency and fraud. One necessary reform is the creation of a single home for the European parliament and a reform of its finances. The government should propose a British city as the parliament's new, permanent home.

The United States

For 50 years our principal overseas ally, the US has had fundamental interests in common with Britain. But in several areas, our close alliance with the US is at odds with our defence and foreign policy identity and priorities.

This can be seen, for example, in American plans for a national missile defence shield and in diverging environmental and trade standards and practices.

While maintaining a close bilateral relationship with the US, we would seek to reorientate UK defence and foreign policy towards Europe.

The United Nations

The UN remains the sole, truly inclusive international forum. The government should double the UK's financial contribution, with special emphasis on the training and equipping of UN peacekeeping forces.

Britain should second to the UN a brigade of British troops to be part of a standing army at the disposal of the security council.

Labour should support the reform of the security council and the abolition of the permanent seats for the US, Russia, China, Britain and France, to be replaced by one, permanent seat representing the EU and other permanent places allocated on a regional basis - to include North America, Central America and the Caribbean, South America, Africa, the Middle East, South Asia, East Asia, and the Pacific.

The government should encourage the UN secretary general to reform the organisation and to take a more proactive role in crisis prevention, and in worldwide problems such as the lack of educational provision in many developing countries, combating Aids and other pandemics, taking a global approach to fighting terrorism, and preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction through the non-proliferation treaty and other tools.

The World Trade Organisation should be brought under the aegis of the UN, to ensure that the many concerns expressed about its activities by developing countries (and by many groups in the developed world) are fully reflected in its future policies.

Bilateral relationships

The government should end government-supported and funded trade missions and business ventures in China and other countries which serially abuse the human rights of their citizens.

Respect for human rights should become a fundamental criterion upon which the government judges its relationships with other states.

The next Labour government should also:

 Take the lead in setting up the long-promised permanent international criminal court, the treaty for which it has still not been ratified, and oppose attempts by the US to limit the court's mandate.

 Unilaterally withdraw from the sanctions regime against Iraq if no solution to the current impasse is found within six months of the election.

Defence pledges

1 Eliminate British nuclear weapons unilaterally

2 Work for abolition of Nato and accelerate European defence cooperation

3 Join the euro and fully embrace the European Union

4 Give the UN a brigade of British troops

5 Make human rights a priority

What happens next

Have we got it right - or should more be done in the second term? Write to our letters page, marking the envelope Manifesto, or join the debate at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/manifesto

webTitle: Scholars caught up in long-winded debate over 17-syllable verse form

fields.headline: Scholars caught up in long-winded debate over 17-syllable verse form
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited

Enter the Books Unlimited topical haiku competition
fields.trailText: A ferment in the world of the haiku - the 17-syllable verse seen as the simplest and most perfect form of poetry - will reach a head at a festival of 100 worldwide scholars in London and Oxford in August.
fields.body:
A ferment in the world of the haiku - the 17-syllable verse seen as the simplest and most perfect form of poetry - will reach a head at a festival of 100 worldwide scholars in London and Oxford in August.

More prosaically, the controversy will reach down to touch the classroom lives of tens of thousands of British schoolchildren.They are encouraged to write haikus as part of key stage three of the national curriculum.

The form has broken free from its origins in classical Japan to be widely used in education, as well as by amateur and professional poets.

At stake in the controversy - argued over in documents thousands of words long - is whether the brief poems should emulate the rural calm of Mensuo Basho, 17th century Japanese father of the genre:

Waterjar cracks:
I lie awake
This icy night

or reflect modern realities, like a new haiku composed in Slovenia:

spring evening -
the wheel of a troop carrier
crushes a lizard

or one written by a computer games-playing US teenager:

Today I own you.
Tomorrow I will be ruled
The bloody wheel turns

The experts will also debate whether contemporary haikus should stick to the 17 syllable rule or be restricted in their number of lines.

The British Haiku Society has already begun rewriting guidelines in its 2,000-word pack for teachers.

Its president, David Cobb, reportedly said yesterday that the aim was to breathe fresh life into the form without trivialising it.

"One walks a very sticky path between elitism and populism. I would be very unhappy if we were the cause of the dumbing-down of the haiku," he said.

The present guidelines show how far English haikus have departed from their origins. A verse by Mr Cobb sticks closely to them:

the frost holds:
Friesians in the byre
chew steam

but another has only four syllables:

puddles
bubble.

The ferment began last September with the 4,000-word Matsuyama Declaration in Japan urging poets to "broaden the possibilities of a rich array" of diversified national versions for the haiku.

The declaration said even the traditional line arrangement - a single vertical line in Japanese calligraphy, three lines in the west - could be varied.

One of the poets who engineered the declaration is Susumu Takiguchi, organiser of the British festival. Mr Takiguchi, chairman of the World Haiku Club, writes sometimes traditional haikus from the peace of a farmhouse near Bicester, Oxfordshire:

spade splits the Earth
into two worlds -
earthworm in between

Yesterday he was enthusiastic about the "strong haiku movement" in the whole of former Yugoslavia, which wrote about violence and ethnic cleansing.

But he said the festival would challenge an American influenced "minimalist" trend towards single-line haikus which groped for "a moment of enlightenment" in the style of Zen Buddhism.

Replying to purists who insist on strict adherence to ancient Japanese rules, he added, "Diversity and difference do need to be encouraged."

webTitle: A not so merry month of May

fields.headline: A not so merry month of May
fields.trailText: When he was at the Sunday Times, Andrew Neil was perpetually under attack from the rest of the media. But Neil merely pointed to increasing sales. History appears to be repeating itself in his new empire. Last month I remarked that the Scotsman was beset by internal turmoil and Scotland on Sunday was suffering a dramatic sales reverse after a one-week price-cutting manoeuvre. The (Glasgow) Herald is even running a poster campaign with Neil's picture and a quote from him - out of context, but so what? - urging people to "Buy the Herald".
fields.body:
When he was at the Sunday Times, Andrew Neil was perpetually under attack from the rest of the media. But Neil merely pointed to increasing sales. History appears to be repeating itself in his new empire. Last month I remarked that the Scotsman was beset by internal turmoil and Scotland on Sunday was suffering a dramatic sales reverse after a one-week price-cutting manoeuvre. The (Glasgow) Herald is even running a poster campaign with Neil's picture and a quote from him - out of context, but so what? - urging people to "Buy the Herald".

But Neil has reason to smile this week. The Scotsman has hit more than 94,000, a 19% rise on the previous month. In fact, for the final three weeks of the month it sold 105,000 - a 31% increase. As with most headline circulation figures, it isn't as good as it seems. Relaunched on May 8, the 45p Scotsman has since been selling for 20p, so it's impossible to say which new readers will stick with the paper. If price is the sole factor, many will do so for a long time yet because the cut is for an indefinite period. Some executives believe it may last until autumn, depending on how much profit the Barclay brothers are willing to sacrifice to build the Scotsman habit.

Scotland on Sunday has also bounced back well after its technical hitch to record a sale of 107,000. That puts the pressure back on the rival Sunday Herald, thought to have full-rate sales of just 45,000.

Outside the Scottish arena, the month of May wasn't too merry. A series of bank holidays didn't help, particularly among Sundays. The most notable figure is the News of the World's, at a surprisingly low 3.8m, which makes it understandable that News International decided to replace Phil Hall with Rebekah Wade. Last month the paper sold 6% fewer copies than in May last year. Its six-monthly average is more than 4% down on the same period in the previous year. Hall could point to the fact that his rivals have performed just as badly. But Rupert Murdoch likes to win, even in a falling market.

It will be fascinating to see if Wade can turn around a relentlessly downward trend. She may take heart from the way the Sunday Mirror has slowed its decline through a clever marketing initiative without noticeably changing or improving editorial content.

There is a similar difference in fortunes between the leading daily red-tops. The Mirror, at 32p, continues to slow the rate of decrease affecting the whole market while the 30p Sun falls further from its perch. How low will Murdoch let his beloved Sun reach before he contemplates replacing its editor, too? With sales below 3.5m, the paper is selling fewer copies than at any stage in recent history. The other alternative is to introduce yet another price cut, but that would rekindle the interest of the office of fair trading. Even so, it must be on Murdoch's mind and he may just take the risk.

His price-cutting strategy has been more successful at the Times. But the ballyhoo of the revamp and the addition of a tabloid second section has made little impact. When Times 2 was launched in March, sales stood at 720,000. Last month they were 3,000 more, hardly a vote of confidence.

The Times's six-monthly average is down by 3%, compared to the Guardian's loss of less than 1% and the Independent's slight rise, due to bulk sales. The Daily Telegraph's high-wire act to keep itself above the magic 1m continues to amaze, but its 46,000 freebies to a variety of hotels and airlines help maintain the illusion of success.

Perhaps the most interesting arena is the middle market, with the Mail titles having reached, for the first time since the early 1990s, a plateau. Both have rock-solid sales, but they have, perhaps momentarily, lost the impetus that has seen them add circulation effortlessly in recent years.

Could this have anything to do with the fact that the Express titles have begun to stabilise? The Daily Express has turned things around, recording its third successive monthly rise, and there are even signs that the Sunday Express is on the verge of consistently selling 1m once more.

webTitle: Shots fired at coup leader's car, say Fiji rebels

fields.headline: Shots fired at coup leader's car, say Fiji rebels
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Rebel supporters in Fiji today accused the military of plotting an assassination attempt after soldiers fired on a car carrying coup leader George Speight.
fields.body:
Rebel supporters in Fiji today accused the military of plotting an assassination attempt after soldiers fired on a car carrying coup leader George Speight.

However, an army spokesman blamed bad judgment by soldiers who opened fire as Mr Speight's car sped through a checkpoint. Several Speight supporters were arrested after a second car was shot near the roadblock and stopped. But they were quickly released after rebels threatened to harm the hostages they have been holding for more than three weeks, the military said.

The incident brought relations between Mr Speight and the military to a new low after Mr Speight seized the entire cabinet hostage in protest at the appointment of an ethnic Indian, Mahendra Chaudhry, as prime minister for the first time in Fiji's history. Commodore Frank Bainimarama, who declared martial law 10 days in the crisis, has shown increasing impatience with the coup perpetrators.

Lieutenant colonel Filipo Tarakinikini, the military's spokesman, insisted the shooting did not represent an escalation of the conflict, adding that the soldiers would be disciplined for using excessive force.

But Mr Speight's spokesman, Jo Nata, said: "We believe it was an assassination attempt by the military. The soldiers who fired the shots could not have fired the shots without orders," he said. "What they did was an extreme act of provocation."

The soldiers shot at Mr Speight's car as he was returning from drinking tea with a Methodist church leader, leaving Mr Speight uninjured but a bit shaken. "I am alive and well," Mr Speight later said. His car, a dark green Hyundai sedan, was hit at least twice with a bullet hole in the right rear passenger door and one in the right rear panel. Both rear passenger windows were smashed.

Lt Col Tarakinikini said Mr Speight's car was one of two that sped through a military roadblock. Soldiers first fired warning shots in the air, and when the cars failed to stop, they fired at the cars. One car stopped, and soldiers arrested the rebels inside. But officials quickly freed them after a Speight supporter, Ratu Timoci Silatolu, phoned and threatened that the hostages would be harmed, a military statement said.

fields.headline: Foxes acquire new Taylor
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor is the new manager of Leicester City. He was introduced to the public at a Filbert Street press conference this afternoon and immediately spoke of the "wonderful challenge" of carrying on the success enjoyed during Martin O'Neill's time at the club.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor is the new manager of Leicester City. He was introduced to the public at a Filbert Street press conference this afternoon and immediately spoke of the "wonderful challenge" of carrying on the success enjoyed during Martin O'Neill's time at the club.

"It was a hard challenge at Gillingham following Tony Pulis," said Taylor who has signed a three-year contract with the Foxes, "and it's an even greater challenge following Martin O'Neill here but I'm up for the challenge. If I can do as well as he has done over the last four years I'll be happy."

Taylor was the club's first choice for the post and chairman John Elsom said of the appointment: "Personally I'm quite sure we made the right choice and I'm looking forward to working with him."

Taylor comes with an impressive recent record in management. As coach of the England Under-21s he was unbeaten in qualification for the recent Euro 2000 tournament, and only last month helped Gillingham gain promotion to the First Division.

Speaking of his time at Gillingham, Taylor said: "I fully enjoyed my last 12 months so I'm a little bit sad. It was a nice opportunity, I appreciate them giving me the job and it was nice to finish off with some reward. But it's progress for me and I'm sure they'll [Gillingham] understand."

Taylor will now turn his attention to emulating O'Neill's enviable record, and strengthening the squad will be one of his top priorities. Asked if he knew how much he would be given to spend, Taylor replied: "The chairman has given me some idea [of money] and I'll be looking to bring some players in."

fields.headline: Gynaecologist faces 37 misconduct charges
fields.trailText: A gynaecologist appeared before the General Medical Council today to face 37 charges relating to operations on 14 women over a 17-year period.
fields.body:
A gynaecologist appeared before the General Medical Council today to face 37 charges relating to operations on 14 women over a 17-year period.

Richard Neale is accused of performing operations without consent, sub-standard surgery, unnecessary procedures and failing to inform his patients' GPs of complications following surgery he performed.

He is also accused of making false claims on his CV when he applied to the GMC in March 1997 to become an assessor for its performance procedures.

Mr Neale, who has worked in London, the Isle of Wight, and Leicester, was suspended by the GMC last year while working in a private clinic in Leeds.

Appearing before the GMC's professional conduct committee this morning, Mr Neale admitted three of the 37 charges.

He admitted failing to perform a pre-operative x-ray or a post-operative mammogram on a patient known as Mrs A at the Friarage Hospital in Northallerton, North Yorkshire, in 1986.

He also admitted failing to provide the GP of a patient known as Mrs D with a letter about complications after an operation in 1991 and failing to inform another patient's doctor of possible damage to her bladder after a 1996 operation.

Mr Neale, 52, is also being sued by 60 women for allegedly performing unnecessary surgery that left them in agony and some with organ damage and unable to have children.

North Yorkshire Police are investigating claims that Mr Neale, from Leeds, falsified his qualifications to work in this country.

The British-born consultant began his career in Canada in the 1970s after training in England.

But he was barred from practice in two provinces in the mid-1980s after a series of mistakes which left two patients dead. He came back to the UK in 1985 and until 1995 worked at the Friarage Hospital in Northallerton, North Yorkshire.

Mr Neale left the hospital because of "concerns about the extent of his commitment" but received £100,000 severance pay and a good reference before going on to work in Leicester, London and the Isle of Wight.

He was suspended by the GMC "to protect public safety" while working in a private clinic in Leeds last year. The GMC has been criticised for allowing the consultant to work in the UK, despite knowing that he had been struck off in Canada.

When a date was set for the hearing, Mr Neale issued a statement saying: "I continue to regret those instances in which any of my patients suffered post-operative complications but I have always maintained this: that I am both a competent and caring surgeon.

"The allegations that have been made against me have been extremely distressing and the many months in which I have not worked as a doctor have been traumatic for me and my family.

"I hope the GMC hearing will bring this matter to a conclusion."

The case is expected to last three weeks.

 His case comes a week after a damning report was published on gynaecologist Rodney Ledward, who was struck off by the GMC last year after being found guilty of botching surgery on 10 women. Hundreds more former patients of Ledward have since come forward saying they were left maimed and scarred by the Kent surgeon.

A proposed shake-up of the GMC is expected to lead to a speeding up in disciplinary cases and harsher punishment for doctors found guilty of serious professional misconduct.

fields.headline: RIP bill and civil liberties
fields.standfirst: The regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill, which updates surveillance for the internet age, is running into difficulties. We explain why.
fields.trailText: The regulation of investigatory powers bill, which updates surveillance for the internet age, is running into difficulties. Mark Tran explains why.
fields.body:
What is the RIP bill?
The bill gives the government new powers to intercept emails and decode encrypted data. It allows law enforcement agencies to demand encryption keys to coded information from individuals or companies with a ministerial warrant. Failure to comply carries a two-year prison sentence.

What is the government's justification for the bill?
The home secretary, Jack Straw, says the government needs the power to examine emails in the fight against terrorism, child pornography and organised crime on the net. The government also claims it is simply updating existing powers to tap telephone and postal services.

So what's wrong with the argument?
Say the government demands that a suspected paedophile hand over the encryption keys that scramble communications. The suspect is hardly likely to comply, because a two-year sentence is much more preferable than a heavier sentence for admitted paedophiles. The same will apply to terrorists and other hardened criminals.

Why are civil rights groups up in arms?
Because the burden of proof is placed on defendants to show they are not withholding information. Defendants must prove they do not have the key. Misplacing the encryption key or forgetting it will not be a defence. Worse, if defendants complain about their treatment in public, they face another five years. Tim Berners-Lee, the British inventor of the world wide web, has said that the bill gives the government great power to abuse personal liberties, adding that it would have been thrown out in the US "in a second".

Is it just civil libertarians who are upset?
No. Companies are also worried. The Institute of Directors is anxious about the data governments could collect, jeopardising the confidentiality of commercial communications. It has warned that businesses will shun Britain and invest in countries such as Ireland, where the law is not so draconian. Section 20 of the bill says electronic snooping is acceptable to safeguard the economic wellbeing of the UK, something that will not go down well with foreign companies thinking of setting up shop in the UK.

How does the government propose to make the bill work?
Every internet service provider (ISP) will have to install a black box with a direct link to an MI5 building. The intelligence services can monitor the pattern of all emails (including who sent them), visits to chat rooms and every website visited - all this without a warrant. ISPs will have to spend £17m on black boxes in the first year alone.

How does the government respond to such concerns?
The Home Office denies that warrants could be issued on spurious grounds, saying safeguards have been built into the bill to prevent this. But few critics have been satisfied by such assurances.

What happens to the bill now?
The bill is at committee stage in the Lords and ministers have been told they have about 10 days to head off peers' concerns or risk defeat on a number of opposition amendments. Peers claim they have sufficient numbers to defeat the measure unless ministers offer substantial concessions.

fields.headline: North delays Korean summit
fields.standfirst: The South insists that after 55 years of waiting it is unconcerned that the historic meeting is delayed by one day
fields.trailText: North Korea has postponed the summit with the South scheduled for today by 24 hours, in a bizarre last-minute move which has left Seoul making desperate apologies on Pyongyang's behalf.
fields.body:
North Korea has postponed the summit with the South scheduled for today by 24 hours, in a bizarre last-minute move which has left Seoul making desperate apologies on Pyongyang's behalf.

"There is no reason not to wait one more day," said the South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, yesterday, putting the best face on the postponement, "since we have been waiting for this meeting for 55 years!"

The telephone call from Pyongyang came late on Saturday as Mr Kim was being given last minute briefings on life across the 38th parallel. It has given him an unexpected early lesson in the art of fathoming what the North is up to.

The South's minister of culture and tourism, Park Jie-won, did his best to persuade journalists last night that everything was perfectly in order. He insisted that the postponement was not "because of political issues or problems of the itinerary, but because Pyongyang wants to be better prepared for the summit". Another official blamed unspecified "minor technical reasons" for the delay.

"It's bizarre, but then so is everything else in North Korea," said a senior official in the information agency.

Well-informed observers of the North Korean scene last night offered two probable reasons for the delay, both of which might be correct.

First it may genuinely be taking more time than expected for all the details of the visit to be cleared at the highest level, where decisions always have to be reached in North Korea.

"It is not just that the supreme leader Kim Jong-il must approve everything," said the editor of a Seoul newspaper. "He may have to refer it to an inner core which includes senior army generals, and they have been difficult in the past."

The second theory is that by imposing a delay of 24 hours, Pyongyang has reminded everyone - including its own people - who is calling the shots in this affair.

"It is after all the southern president who is going to the North," commented a Western diplomat, "and not the other way around." It is still taken for granted that the summit will go ahead and that Seoul has received private assurances from Pyongyang which justify its confidence.

Mr Park, who played a key role in secret negotiations leading up to the summit agreement, insisted there were no grounds for suspicion. But he also discounted expectations of any great results from the first-ever meeting between the leaders of North and South.

"We do not have high expectations, this is only the beginning," he said. "Just the mere photograph of the two leaders smiling and shaking hands will provide momentum for the new millennium."

His warning followed earlier attempts from the Blue House (South Korea's presidential office) to dispel excessive optimism about the prospects for reunification.

President Kim was said to believe it was "improper to talk about reunification" while a million troops are still deployed across the 38th parallel.

On a more practical note the Blue House said that unification would be far too expensive for South Korea's still shaky economy. Presidential estimates put the cost at up to $1,000bn (£660bn) - twice the South's annual GDP. Some agreements on investment to revive the North's moribund economy are still expected from the summit. But the South hopes to be an intermediary for western funds rather than having to dig deeply into its own pocket.

While older South Koreans with relatives across the border still hanker after reunification, many younger people care much less. Cynical teenagers have been quoted in the press saying they don't want unification because "it would make South Korea poor".

"I don't want to give my computer games to North Korean children," insisted one 13-year-old boy.

A Seoul journalist in her late 20s says that "South Korean families have many layers," citing her own as an example: "My grandmother came from a bourgeois family in the North. My grandfather came from the countryside in the south. My father was a student activist in the struggle against military dictatorship. And I grew up only interested in hip-hop, rap and MTV."

Last night South Korea's information service admitted that Seoul had been "embarrassed" by the North Korean postponement.

Officials cited a theory that Pyongyang might need the extra time to ensure Kim Dae-jung's security, since details of the president's itinerary had been published in the South Korean press.

But those who have visited the North say that it is the last place on earth where security could be breached without the consent of the authorities.

fields.headline: Here come the party poopers
fields.standfirst: Jamie Rainbow will be watching all of Euro 2000. Every last second of it. Appreciate him now before his inevitable descent into madness.
fields.trailText: Jamie Rainbow will be watching all of Euro 2000. Every last second of it. Appreciate him now before his inevitable descent into madness.
fields.body:
So far so good. Some decent football played, some exciting matches, some excitement courtesy of a last-minute penalty and some drama courtesy of Scotland's lone representative, referee Hugh Dallas. The perfect time then for England to come along and spoil the party.

Even the opening ceremony was bearable, although Des - clearly forgetting the embarrassing George and the Dragon sequence at Euro 96 - was content to mock feebly throughout. He was ably assisted by Ally McCoist, a likeable man, if you like your men to behave like schoolboys.

True, the ceremony was a somewhat confusing spectacle; lots of floaty footballs and people on stilts wearing swirly outfits; an Oliver Twist lookalike frolicking around in red pyjamas; and an enormous inflatable footballer wheeled onto the pitch to launch a ball and the tournament into orbit. The ball was never seen again but the giant later appeared up front for the Czech Republic - and very well he did too.

Over on the BBC, Gary Lineker continues to cope adequately with the non-too-onerous task of filling Des's boots. Alongside him sat the comical sideshow of Alan Hansen and Martin O'Neill. The pair, it seems, have been encouraged to contrive an antipathy for the duration of the tournament with Hansen attempting to recreate a similar relationship to that he enjoyed - or should that be endured? - with Jimmy Hill.

So, what of the party poopers? Well, judging by England's final warm-up game when gaps the size of Daniella Westbrook's nasal passage began appearing in their defence, there is reason to be concerned. Against a proper side, or at least one containing full-time professional footballers, one dreads to think how big those gaps could become. Suffice to say, Stevie Nicks or even John Belushi could be getting a name-check in the next couple of days.

Equally worrying is the change in Kevin Keegan in recent days. The Norman Wisdom persona has vanished, replaced by an altogether more serious character: melancholic Kev. At one point over the weekend during an interview with Des Lynam, there were times when I thought he might make it through a whole sentence without cracking a lame gag.

Worrying times indeed.

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Christina Ricci in Mermaids (Richard Benjamin, 1990)

Who? One of that rare breed - a child star who's made it as an adult actress - Ricci attended the Professional Children's School in New York alongside Macaulay Culkin - who didn't make the transition quite so smoothly. Mermaids was her first feature, at the ripe old age of nine, but it was as mini-goth Wednesday in The Addams Family that she really came to prominence. The dark, brooding and downright moody role seemed to possess Ricci in real life, too - she admits to having eating disorders and cutting herself in her teens. Now 20, and after superb coming-of-age appearances in Buffalo 66 and Pecker, she's still walking on the dark side - she recently appeared in Tim Burton's gothic horror Sleepy Hollow and her next project is an adaptation of Elizabeth Wurtzel's Prozac Nation. Cheery stuff.

The role: Kate Flax, a swimming-obsessed nine-year-old who lives with her slatternly mother (Cher) and her pious, aspirant nun sister (Winona Ryder).

Best line: Not a line so much as a strange screaming/ gurgling sound as she walks around the house with a pumpkin on her head trying to scare her mother.

Cringe factor: See above.

Other wannabes: The startlingly named Dossy Peabody, who plays Coach Parker, also turns up in a later Winona Ryder vehicle, The Crucible, as Goody Sibber.

Critical judgement: Desson Howe in the Washington Post said the film "doesn't come of age so much as die of it. It's awash in mediocrity, waterlogged with innocuousness".

Also not starring in: James Woods and Michael J Fox comedy buddy movie, The Hard Way, as Annabella Sciorra's daughter.

Mermaids, Carlton Cinema, Friday June 16, 9pm

fields.headline: Laughter in the dark
fields.trailText: "I asked a rabbi for the meaning of life. He told me, but he told me in Hebrew - and I don't understand Hebrew. What's more, he wanted to charge me $800 for Hebrew lessons." It's Joke One from the Woody Allen Book of Augustinian Misery, which has every gag from every film since the early 60s, a new stab at getting the message through, of telling the same old existential joke.
fields.body:
"I asked a rabbi for the meaning of life. He told me, but he told me in Hebrew - and I don't understand Hebrew. What's more, he wanted to charge me $800 for Hebrew lessons." It's Joke One from the Woody Allen Book of Augustinian Misery, which has every gag from every film since the early 60s, a new stab at getting the message through, of telling the same old existential joke.

In Scene By Scene: Woody Allen (BBC2), Allen explained that you never get through. That's life's pay-off, or the punchline. A reassuringly depressing conclusion about the nature of human communication from the master of the sour gag.

Even as a child, Allen explained, you never get the answers you deserve: "So why were there Nazis, daddy?" "How the hell should I know? I don't even know how the can-opener works."

I say he explained, but the movie clips did all the real talking. Allen was happy enough giving off-pat agnostic epigrams about the Big Questions, but disappointingly guarded about ordinary life (aka "reality").

The sex scandal and Mia Farrow were off-limits - understandable, but it somewhat undermined any claims to intellectual candour about the morality of domestic life. Mark Cousins was a splendid host and interviewer, louche and intellectually fleet-of-foot. I imagine men and women across the country falling in love with the way he EMPHASISES arbitrary words in sentences: "a panel of psychologists CONCURRED". A trick Alan Whicker once used to keep the viewers AWAKE.

Allen was raised under the mythological rollercoaster at Coney Island by women whose values were "God and carpeting". His mother said he "didn't show any early talent, except in sports".

The hawk-like Cousins, who engages with subjects by trapping them in his tractor-beam, just couldn't click with Allen. While Roman Polanski, a week before, had initially been prickly, but opened up under Cousins' glare, Allen wouldn't break. He wasn't fun, but, more importantly, he wasn't serious either.

Billy Wilder once said that a film is never funnier than the script. Allen agreed: "I've never made one that lived up to my expectations of it." The truck of fresh compromises pulls up each day, and by the end of the film you look at the finished print and think unutterable thoughts. What did Allen think of Billy Wilder's observation that Allen doesn't make great films, but "great episodes" (ouch). "I think Billy Wilder is a great master," he said.

In Husbands And Wives, Max Von Sydow, a mono-syllabic north European painter, stares in horror at a TV. "What kind of human being watches wrestling?"

Somebody like Daniel W Blaustein, a quiet forty-something US film-maker, whose superb documentary about the WWF, Beyond The Mat, opens next week. As a primer you could have done no worse than watch WWF: Heat (C4, Sun). All the Federation's heroes were on the bill: Joey Abs (whose enemies call him Joey Ass); Harry Saturn; Stone Cold Steve Austen aka The Rattlesnake, and reigning world champ, The Rock.

By way of greeting, the wrestlers trade Stooges-style punches and throw each other out of the ring with the kind of glee usually reserved for obese schoolboys who've overdosed on a packet of Frazzles.

Bout One. A man in lime-green leotard and bleached Bon Jovi hair clamps his legs round the head of a bald giant in leather thong and bin-liner chaps (Bronco Buster to his mum). "Nice press!" (he's not). The man in the leotard lies squashed to the canvas. Bronco is standing on his chest, bal ancing like a ballerina. "Very proficient," says the commentator. "He won't be getting up from that. Bag 'im up and send 'im out!"

The crowd, chanting "Bag 'im up and send 'im out!" in between Chicken McNuggets, awaits the arrival of main attraction, Joey Abs and Rodney in tag-team showdown with Too Cool Posse (Scotty Too Hotty and Grandmaster Sex Thing). Too Cool annihilate Rodney in a matter of seconds, hitting him with a step-ladder and wet towel combo (the clowning props of WWF). Joey Abs wisely stays outside the ring.

As Scotty Too Hotty breaks into a victory song and dance, I think of the shuddering Woody Allen and his love of European cinema. No wonder Allen's films don't sell in The States. He hates the country (or at least anything after Django Reinhardt). More to the point, how could existential angst compete with WWF? Bag 'im up and send 'im out.

fields.headline: You bet your life!
fields.standfirst: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you in association with BlueSq
fields.trailText: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting.
fields.body:
The first bets were placed at the weekend (read the first column here) and the current standings look like this:

Sean Ingle £73.01
Scott Murray £51.67
Paul MacInnes £40
Mike Hodgkinson £35

Now for today's bets...

Sean Ingle

England v Portugal: 0-1 Correct score 7-1 (£3)

So far, so good, so what? Thanks to the sharp-eyed refereeing of Pierluigi Collina I am now a stomping £23.01 up. But I'm not giving it large (or even small) just yet, because there are plenty of pitfalls in tonight's games.

You'd usually expect Germany to overpower an ageing Romania side, but with Bierhoff, Jancker and Kirsten all doubtful the result isn't as clear-cut. Meanwhile England are so hopelessly unpredictable - or should that be predictably hopeless? - that I normally hesitate on gambling on them as well. But Portugal are on a good run, while Keegan's England haven't yet impressed, which makes me think Luis Figo's boys might just nick it.

Scott Murray

Draw double: Germany v Romania and England v Portugal 15/8 each (£5)

Four games gone and even the poorest match has been an enthralling spectacle, despite the Dutch team's best efforts. So it's about time the tournament took its inevitable turn for the worse before we all start enjoying ourselves too much... oh look, here come England and Germany.

Both countries are talking themselves up at the moment, but secretly they'll be living in fear of an early exit. A disastrous start for either team today and the big showdown in Charleroi will become unbearably tense, so expect both teams to play a steady game tonight. They'll also be subconsciously saving themselves for Saturday, when they start beating seven bells of jingoism out of each other. Two draws, then.

Paul MacInnes

England v Portugal: Draw 15-8 (£6)

What a great start. Predict a scoreless draw, get three goals. Suggest that a top striker might be the last goalscorer, then find Holland's penalty taker is a defender. Mug behaviour if ever there was such a thing.

But today will be different. Today it's a safe bet, one that cannot fail... £6 on a draw between England and Portugal at the luvverly odds of 15/8. I'll make my money back instantly, won't I?

Mike Hodgkinson

Germany v Romania: Draw 15-8 (£10)

It's about time there was a draw in the tournament, and these sides look like they might well provide it. The ageing Romanians must fancy themselves against the roundly-dissed and fairly-average Germans, but the reigning champions know exactly what it takes to pace a campaign and there shouldn't be too much first-match madness here. At 15/8 the sensible stalemate looks value.
