fields.headline: One step beyond
fields.standfirst: McCready & Daughter is more than just another detective drama with a twist. It marks the post-EastEnders debut for Patsy 'Bianca' Palmer.  Jacques Peretti is impressed
fields.trailText: McCready & Daughter is more than just another detective drama with a twist. It marks the post-EastEnders debut for Patsy 'Bianca' Palmer. Jacques Peretti is impressed
fields.body:
Following Dirty Den's spectacular departure from EastEnders, Leslie Grantham appeared in a commercial. Lying in a sud-filled bath, Grantham asked if there was life after soap. He wore a nervous smile, a smell of desperation to his nonchalance. That's because, even as recently as the mid-80s, leaving a soap opera was a risky business. For every Nick Berry, there'd be an Anita Dobson or a Leslie Grantham.

Now, the post-soap path to glory seems more assured. On Thursday, Patsy Palmer makes her post-EastEnders debut in McCready & Daughter, a one-off detective drama written by Robert Jones, co-creator of award-winning BBC2 series, The Cops.

Palmer plays the wayward daughter of a down-at-heel private eye (Lorcan Cranitch from Ballykissangel), gumshoeing his way round the crisp packets of Kilburn. She makes an explosive entrance, setting fire to her landlady's flat. In a bizarre continuation of the EastEnders storyline on which she left, Palmer escapes her old life by going to college (though her new character, Clare, has none of the enthusiasm for the project, the animus that fired Bianca on to a better life).

Palmer is a fantastically good actress, as her sustained wail of pain in EastEnders testified. And there can be little doubt that the BBC will use her fame to promote what could otherwise be just another bog-standard detective drama. A trick previously pulled off with another ex-Ender, Michelle Collins, in Real Women.

Palmer's co-star, Cranitch, has his own soap demons to live down, graduating from Ballykissangel (or Cosykissangel as unkind critics dubbed it). BallyK took a darker turn with the arrival of Cranitch, who played a married man with a permanently furrowed brow, weighed down by a doomed affair. Cranitch is burnt into my memory from an earlier role, brilliantly playing a weak, corruptible and just-this-side-of-psychotic detective in Cracker.

Coincidentally, Robert Jones originally devised the part of McCready for another actor: Tony Doyle, who played alongside Cranitch in BallyK, and who died suddenly at the beginning of production. The baton was passed to Cranitch - not an obvious choice for lead, but all the more interesting for that.

Together, Cranitch and Palmer make a formidable double-act. There's a bruised quality to both performances which, sadly, the script doesn't take full advantage of. Not least because it leans uncomfortably towards comedy when it could have gone darker.

Nowadays it seems inconceivable that there are any permutations of the detective double-act left to try out: Man/Man; Woman/Woman; Man/Woman; Man/Dog; Woman/ Cat; Man/Car; Dead Man/Live Man; Mystic/Hippie, and spoofs of all of the above.

McCready & Daughter concentrates on the domestic complexities of the modern family: resoldering broken relationships; making peace with the ex; scratching a living from a business that happens to be a room above a shop in Kilburn, not a dot.com co in London's overly trendy Clerkenwell district.

It's a paradox that writers of middle-brow dramas, detective or otherwise, have taken over the role once played by soap operas. Namely, that of reflecting a kind of truth about minor as well as tectonic shifts in British society.

Soaps, meanwhile, have become antechambers to a bigger, more serious acting career. Once, they were a job for life. Now they're just a staging post, the next thing you do after leaving the Anna Scher School. This social fluidity probably makes modern soaps a reflection of the breakdown in traditional class barriers - but then again, maybe not.

For popular drama, the tackling of uncomfortable subject matter is really no more than a return to the early 1960s, when police procedurals like Z Cars tackled taboo areas like child abuse, divorce and domestic violence. Modern drama isn't afraid to confront such subjects - on the contrary, it often relishes in confronting them. But the great temptation now is to avoid tackling the low-key and humdrum, the inherent drama of simply surviving, which is the great strength of a series like McCready & Daughter.

In a couple of weeks' time, Ross Kemp makes his ITV debut in a legal drama. The departure of Grant Mitchell from EastEnders was kept ambiguous in order to leave Kemp with a window, should he wish to return. The only hitch is that he doesn't look he'll need it.

While so-called boomerang characters like Sam (played by Danniella Westbrook) return each year like a bad smell, an actor of the stature and popularity of Kemp can take his pick of roles. Who knows, in 20 years' time, a writer may even devise a comedic reunion of Grant and Sharon à la Bobby and Sheila in The Royle Family. But I doubt it. He'll probably be in Hollywood, remaking The Rock with Guy Ritchie.

 McCready & Daughter, BBC1, Thursday June 15, 8.10pm

fields.headline: No nose for the truth
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The question of the day is who has Pinocchio's nose, the one that grows longer with every lie he tells. Jim Nicholson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, is trying to graft the nose on Al Gore and Rupert Murdoch's New York Post has been foremost in obliging. More or less every day, it runs a caricature of Al with Nose in a sequence of scoreboxes, each purporting to document "Al's Lies". By Saturday, they were up to No 14.
fields.body:
The question of the day is who has Pinocchio's nose, the one that grows longer with every lie he tells. Jim Nicholson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, is trying to graft the nose on Al Gore and Rupert Murdoch's New York Post has been foremost in obliging. More or less every day, it runs a caricature of Al with Nose in a sequence of scoreboxes, each purporting to document "Al's Lies". By Saturday, they were up to No 14.

Nicholson's rhinoplasty is as deft as a blindfold party kid trying to pin a tail on a donkey. You would not expect a Bush campaigner to be fastidious about fib and fact, and the New York Post makes no pretence of being impartial, but what is surprising is how Nicholson's faxes have infiltrated coverage in mainstream press and television. Its editors and writers would blanch at the suggestion that they are recycling Republican propaganda. That is how it seems to the Democrats, but the paranoia is misplaced. What is happening is professional deformation.

The American press gets locked into Story Mode Syndrome (SMS) much more than the more varied, more cantankerous British press; and then awkward facts that would spoil a story line are flotsam on a surging tide. Now everyone is busy parsing Gore as a self-aggrandising liar. With the speed and proliferation of media in the electronic age, the old standards of checking have lapsed. By three or four news cycles, a minor piece of misreporting can incrementally morph into a monster, and checking its genealogy is like trekking back to the source of the Zambesi. Bring the snake bite serum for the following four.

1. The internet.
Everyone in America knows that Gore claimed to have invented the internet. Only he never did make that claim. "Invention" suggests a solo effort in a laboratory. What Gore said was different: "During my service in the United States Congress I took the initiative in creating the internet". Gore was indeed in the forefront of legislative initiatives to create the internet. Columbia University's James Traub, who chaired the computer science and telecommunications board, says: "Al Gore was perhaps the first political leader to grasp the importance of networking the country . . . At the time he was a senator from a fairly small south-eastern state and I was amazed at his national vision." Gore followed through in eight years as vice-president; back then, the mockery was for talking about some nonsense called "an information superhighway". Those who reported Gore as claiming invention might argue they were paraphrasing. But the media echo chamber guarantees further distortion. "Vice-President Gore tells a reporter the internet was his idea. Nice try, Al." (Wired magazine)

2. Love Story.
The Boston Globe's Walter Robinson and Ann Scales attacked Gore's veracity: "He has also said that he and his wife, Tipper, were the models for the movie Love Story, only to be contradicted by the author, Erich Segal." Their source was Time magazine. Trouble is, Gore never made that claim and Segal never contradicted him. Chatting on the press plane about movies for a couple of hours, Gore had simply remarked to two Time magazine writers on a newspaper interview in which Segal had described Al and Tipper as his models for the movie. True. The Tennessean did so report, but it misquoted Segal, who had told the reporter he based only the male in the movie on Gore. So Segal's "contradiction" was a correction for a newspaper, not Gore. Segal noted: "Al attributed it to a newspaper. Time thought it was more piquant to leave that out." End of story? Not a bit. Heavyweight commentators seized on Love Story to lash Gore for "inflating his past", "bragging" and "prevaricating".

3. The farm boy.
"My father taught me how to clear land with a doubleheaded axe . . . how to plough a steep hillside with a team of mules." Nicholson faxed the celebrity press corps that Gore was lying because he was really brought up in the posh Fairfax Hotel in Washington. Visiting Concord High School in New Hampshire, Gore urged the students not to be cynical about politics. He said he had been stimulated to hold hearings on toxic waste at Toone, Tennessee, and the Love Canal, New York, by a letter from a high school student. fields.bodyText: The question of the day is who has Pinocchio's nose, the one that grows longer with every lie he tells. Jim Nicholson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, is trying to graft the nose on Al Gore and Rupert Murdoch's New York Post has been foremost in obliging. More or less every day, it runs a caricature of Al with Nose in a sequence of scoreboxes, each purporting to document "Al's Lies". By Saturday, they were up to No 14. Nicholson's rhinoplasty is as deft as a blindfold party kid trying to pin a tail on a donkey. You would not expect a Bush campaigner to be fastidious about fib and fact, and the New York Post makes no pretence of being impartial, but what is surprising is how Nicholson's faxes have infiltrated coverage in mainstream press and television. Its editors and writers would blanch at the suggestion that they are recycling Republican propaganda. That is how it seems to the Democrats, but the paranoia is misplaced. What is happening is professional deformation. The American press gets locked into Story Mode Syndrome (SMS) much more than the more varied, more cantankerous British press; and then awkward facts that would spoil a story line are flotsam on a surging tide. Now everyone is busy parsing Gore as a self-aggrandising liar. With the speed and proliferation of media in the electronic age, the old standards of checking have lapsed. By three or four news cycles, a minor piece of misreporting can incrementally morph into a monster, and checking its genealogy is like trekking back to the source of the Zambesi. Bring the snake bite serum for the following four. 1. The internet. Everyone in America knows that Gore claimed to have invented the internet. Only he never did make that claim. "Invention" suggests a solo effort in a laboratory. What Gore said was different: "During my service in the United States Congress I took the initiative in creating the internet". Gore was indeed in the forefront of legislative initiatives to create the internet. Columbia University's James Traub, who chaired the computer science and telecommunications board, says: "Al Gore was perhaps the first political leader to grasp the importance of networking the country . . . At the time he was a senator from a fairly small south-eastern state and I was amazed at his national vision." Gore followed through in eight years as vice-president; back then, the mockery was for talking about some nonsense called "an information superhighway". Those who reported Gore as claiming invention might argue they were paraphrasing. But the media echo chamber guarantees further distortion. "Vice-President Gore tells a reporter the internet was his idea. Nice try, Al." (Wired magazine) 2. Love Story. Their source was Time magazine. Trouble is, Gore never made that claim and Segal never contradicted him. Chatting on the press plane about movies for a couple of hours, Gore had simply remarked to two Time magazine writers on a newspaper interview in which Segal had described Al and Tipper as his models for the movie. True. The Tennessean did so report, but it misquoted Segal, who had told the reporter he based only the male in the movie on Gore. So Segal's "contradiction" was a correction for a newspaper, not Gore. Segal noted: "Al attributed it to a newspaper. Time thought it was more piquant to leave that out." End of story? Not a bit. webTitle: June 12: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 12: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Nic Cage rejects Superman, Sam Mendes has designs on Dali, Stallone perseveres with Planet Hollywood, and, on the casting couch, Gwyneth Paltrow, Julia Roberts, Mark Wahlberg, Gary Oldman, Tony Robinson, and James van der Beek
fields.body:
 Nic Cage (pictured) has washed his hands of the long-planned, never-realised superhero revival, Superman Lives. "Superman I've decided I'm not going to do," says the balding Captain Corelli star. "It's just been too long. At first it seemed like a good idea and would've been a lot of fun, but just too much time has passed and I wanted to part company with it."

 Oscar-guzzling Sam Mendes is said to be interested in adapting Clifford Thurlow's new book to the big screen. Just released last week, Sex, Surrealism, Dali and Me is the memoirs of Carlos Lozano, partner and friend of artist Salvador Dali.

 Sylvester Stallone has vowed to continue backing the beleaguered Planet Hollywood theme restaurant chain. Stallone compares the dodgy eaterie's ailing fortunes with his own. "My own life is about comebacks and redemptions," he tells the New York Daily News, "so I love this stuff."

 Gwyneth Paltrow, Julia Roberts and Julianne Moore are vying for the lead role in Neil Jordan's historical epic Lucrezia Borgia. Can you see either of the first two as the notorious 16th-century Cardinal's daughter and serial poisoner? No, neither can we. But then, Jordan apparently has Friends star Matthew Perry pencilled in as Lucretia's husband, so what would we know?

 Mark Wahlberg is negotiating to star in Criminal Conversation for director Iain (The Wings of the Dove) Softley. Based on the 1994 novel by Evan Hunter, Criminal Conversation is about a teacher who has an affair with a mob leader whom her attorney husband is trying to put away.

 Blockbusting director Paul Verhoeven is planning a Rasputin biopic. The Dutch filmmaker plans to film his Mad Monk movie in Moscow and St Petersberg next spring, while rumours are flying that Gary Oldman, Ralph Fiennes and - wait for it - Val Kilmer are vying for the role of the demonic beardie in question.

 Juliette Binoche will star in The Assumption of a Virgin, the next film from Central Station director Walter Salles. Anthony Minghella will produce.

 Blackadder star and New Labour apparatchik Tony Robinson has ousted Maybe Baby star Hugh Laurie for the part of Cruella De Vil's henchman in the new £60m doggy yarn 102 Dalmatians.

 James van der Beek will star in Todd (Happiness) Solondz's latest sour dispatch from adolescence's front line. The Welcome to the Dollhouse director's latest is described as focusing on a group of youngsters picking their way through the treacherous terrain of high school and college. Selma Blair and loveable Dollhouse geek Heather Matarazzo co-star.

fields.headline: Unhappy shoppers
fields.standfirst: Consuming passions, one man and his cheese, flooded felons and bovine celibacy
fields.trailText: Pioneering research from Sussex has at last confirmed what most of us already suspected but have never been able to prove scientifically - that shopping is bad for your health.
fields.body:
Shop till you drop

Pioneering research from Sussex has at last confirmed what most of us already suspected but have never been able to prove scientifically - that shopping is bad for your health.

The research, conducted by psychologist Dr David Lewis, of East Dean, reveals how the increasing discourtesy and aggression of shop staff and fellow shoppers has turned modern consumerism into a nightmare of stress and physical danger.

"Our whole lifestyle has become stressful," explained Dr Lewis, "with the result that people no longer have time to shop or to serve shoppers properly. It's shocking how many people now consider rudeness to be part of the whole consumer experience."

In the course of his research Dr Lewis provided subjects with miniature video cameras and asked them to film what went on when they visited the shops. They were also hooked up to sensors which measured their heart rates.

One man's heart rate rose to more than 250 beats per minute as he battled the crowds on Oxford Street, central London, in search of knickers for his girlfriend. In another instance, an assistant at a Bradford electrical store joked with a man about how stupid his wife was as she stood beside him clutching their broken toaster.

Dr Lewis's report, titled The Soul of the New Consumer: Authenticity, What We Buy and Why in the New Economy, is available at all good bookshops. "I have to have a copy," said one student. "And woe betide any bastard that tries to stop me."
Eastbourne Evening Argus

Dairy of a nobody

Another exciting addition to Britain's bookshelves comes this week in the form of a biography of Yorkshireman Fred Taylor, the resident cheese expert at West Marton dairy.

Most people will probably never have heard of West Marton dairy, or, indeed, Mr Taylor. But biographer Bill Mitchell insists this should not in any way interfere with their enjoyment of his book, which provides a fascinating insight into the world of cheese-making in an obscure Yorkshire village.

The volume begins with an account of Mr Taylor's early life on a small hill-farm in the Yorkshire Dales in the 1930s, and charts his growing infatuation with all-things cheese.

Like any good life-story it contains moments of reversal and tragedy before Mr Taylor eventually rises to the giddy heights of chief cheese grader, en route collecting more than 150 items of traditional cheese-making equipment.

Particular highlights include a lengthy description of Mr Taylor mending a gap in a dry stone wall, and a dramatic confrontation between a young Mr Taylor and his father on the subject of pocket money.

"It's a real page-turner," enthused one satisfied reader. "A cross between Cider with Rosie and Shogun ... with extra cheese."

Fred Taylor, Yorkshire Cheesemaker is published by Castleburg Books at £4.99.
Craven Herald

Rising damp

One of the least successful, not to mention one of the wettest robberies of the new millennium took place in Barnsley this week when a crack team of thieves endeavoured to purloin all the copper piping from an empty house.

The thieves, described as "a highly professional outfit with previous plumbing experience," had, it seems, been staking out the house for several days to ensure that it was genuinely empty.

Once they had convinced themselves that it was, they skilfully gained entry via the roof and began removing the piping, using the latest plumbing equipment to aid them in their dastardly enterprise.

It all went like clockwork until they started cutting the piping, whereupon their otherwise foolproof scheme was found wanting - they had forgotten to turn the water off.

"It was the middle of the night," recalled one neighbour, "And we heard someone scream. Then we saw these men come running out of the house, all soaking wet. You could hear them squelching all the way down the street."

Any members of the public who saw three men in wet shell suits running through the middle of Barnsley clutching a bag full of monkey-wrenches have been urged to contact the police.
Barnsley Chronicle

A bit of the udder

A new crisis looks set to rock our beleaguered farming industry - a dramatic decline in bovine sex drive.

The problem centres on East Halton, near Scunthorpe, where local beef-farmers have noticed a marked reluctance on the part of breeding bulls to get down to business with their cows.

"They just don't seem to have the energy," said one exasperated farmer. "They just wander off to the other side of the field and stand eating grass. You can almost hear them saying 'Sorry, dear, I've got a headache.' I've got one bull, Errol, who used to go like the clappers. Now he just can't be bothered."

Various theories have been put forward to explain this sudden sexual reticence on the part of Scunthorpe's bullocks. The most likely is a marked reduction in their blood copper levels as a result of sulphur pollution from local factories.

But one farmer's wife has a different explanation. "They take their lead from their owners," she explained. "And with a husband like mine, you're lucky if they're going to perform more than once a year, and then only for a few minutes."
Scunthorpe Evening Telegraph

Letter of the week

Dear Sir, I woke up to find a large tame rabbit on my front lawn at my house in Hawtonville. It had eaten two rows of petunias and also wreaked havoc in a neighbour's garden. I phoned up the RSPCA.

"We can't do anything unless you catch it," I was told. "Then we can come and take it away."

I asked how I was to catch it.

"I don't know, but that's how we operate," said the woman, apparently assuming that everyone knew how to catch and handle animals.

I subsequently phoned Newark and Sherwood district council for help, and in a very short time the council dog-catcher arrived with his mate, caught the rabbit and took it away. My grateful thanks go to them for their prompt action.

Apparently they care more for the plight of people and animals than a supposedly caring institution which is bequeathed such vast sums of money from a caring public that it can afford to let other people do its job.
Mr B Harrison, Newark Advertiser

fields.headline: Kick this legislation out
fields.standfirst:
It should be RIP for the Big Brother bill

Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was given a mild drubbing by the Women's Institute last week. But that is nothing to what ought to happen this week as the RIP (regulation of investigatory powers) bill enters its committee stage in the Lords. People and industry are only just waking up to the enormity of what is proposed and their lordships would do us all a favour if they used their delaying powers to throw this disgraceful bill back to the Commons for a complete rewrite. The bill has only got as far as it has because no one believes that it means what it says. It does. If it becomes law every internet service provider will have to install a black box with a direct link to an MI5 building. That means they can monitor the patterns of all our emails (including who sent them), our visits to chat rooms and every website we click into. All that can be done continuously without a warrant. On production of a warrant, the authorities can force us to surrender any keys, simple or complicated, used to encrypt our emails, so they can read them.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was given a mild drubbing by the Women's Institute last week. But that is nothing to what ought to happen this week as the RIP (regulation of investigatory powers) bill enters its committee stage in the Lords. People and industry are only just waking up to the enormity of what is proposed and their lordships would do us all a favour if they used their delaying powers to throw this disgraceful bill back to the Commons for a complete rewrite. The bill has only got as far as it has because no one believes that it means what it says. It does. If it becomes law every internet service provider will have to install a black box with a direct link to an MI5 building. That means they can monitor the patterns of all our emails (including who sent them), our visits to chat rooms and every website we click into. All that can be done continuously without a warrant. On production of a warrant, the authorities can force us to surrender any keys, simple or complicated, used to encrypt our emails, so they can read them.

Refusal could mean a prison sentence of two years . Drug smugglers and paedophiles will gladly settle for that rather than a much stiffer penalty for being found guilty. If ordinary citizens claim they have forgotten their password they will be presumed guilty by the courts unless they can prove their innocence.

It gets worse. If the authorities demand to see an encryption key so they can read your or your company's internet transactions and you tell your boss (or your spouse) then you are liable for imprisonment of five years for a criminal offence. The government says: "Trust us. We have to have these powers but we won't use them in a draconian way." The trouble is, no one trusts government any more. Safeguards for the citizen must be built into the legislation. In yesterday's Observer Tim Berners-Lee, the British inventor of the world wide web, warned that the bill gave government great power to abuse personal and commercial innovation. He said it would have been thrown out "in a second" in the US. This follows complaints by the Institute of Directors which is worried about the commercial data governments could collect without a warrant. This draconian bill will create a big double whammy. Civil liberties will be abused and industry will invest in friendlier places like Ireland instead. Is this the government that pledged to make the UK the best place in the world to do ecommerce?

webTitle: Cage and Bruckheimer storm US charts

fields.headline: Cage and Bruckheimer storm US charts
fields.trailText: Jerry Bruckheimer, Nic Cage and, er, Vinnie Jones's latest actioner, Gone in 60 Seconds, has roared past Mission: Impossible 2 to the top of the US box office chart
fields.body:
Jerry Bruckheimer, Nic Cage and, er, Vinnie Jones's latest actioner, Gone in 60 Seconds, has roared past Mission: Impossible 2 to the top of the US box office chart. The opening becomes Cage's most lucrative yet - at $25.5m it eclipses his previous Bruckheimer team-up, The Rock, which debuted with a piffling $25m.

Gone in 60 Seconds, it need hardly be added, features car crashes and explosions a-go-go. Starring Cage as a retired car thief returning to the job to save his kid brother from a grisly death at Christopher Eccleston's hands, the no-brainer has been described by US uber-critic Roger Ebert as "a prodigious use of money and human effort, to make a movie of no significance whatsoever."

On its third weekend, Mission: Impossible 2 earned $17.1m to settle for second place. The Tom Cruise starrer's total take, $157.9m, makes it the biggest earner of 2000. Martin Lawrence in Big Momma's House came in at third with another $16.8m. Dinosaur became the fourth film this year to pass the $100m mark, after accruing $8.8m this weekend. Gladiator finished in fifth place with an additional $7.1m, for a cumulative total of $150.2m.

webTitle: Samuel L Jackson confirms strife over Shaft

fields.headline: Samuel L Jackson confirms strife over Shaft
fields.trailText: Samuel L Jackson has been venting his spleen over his latest movie, Shaft, the remake of the 70s blaxploitation favourite
fields.body:
Samuel L Jackson has been venting his spleen over his latest movie, Shaft, the remake of the 70s blaxploitation favourite. Stories of strife between star Jackson and director John Singleton were abundant during filming and Jackson is now all too happy to confirm them. "John is like many young directors I've worked with recently," he said at an LA publicity junket last week. "They've done five or eight films. I've made close to 70. I know better than they do what works for Sam Jackson."

Jackson, who plays the nephew of the original John Shaft in the film, continued, "I'm the one who's up there on the screen, so I'll only do it my way, because I'm the one who ends up taking the blame for their silly choices." Aware that this line of attack may confirm his reputation as a 'difficult' actor, Jackson sought to justify his bolshiness: "I will voice my opinion. I wanted John to do it my way, and not shoot another scene his way. I know the more stuff a director shoots, the more he can change the movie his way. It wasn't about power with me, it was about common sense."

Singleton is playing the criticism with a straight bat. "Sam is opinionated, but I respect that," he comments, going on to attribute blame to a third party: "It was our producer, Scott Rudin, who was the big problem." Rudin is blamed for drafting in script doctor Richard Price to rewrite the Shaft dialogue. Jackson wasn't - and isn't - best pleased: "Richard Price tried to put certain words in my mouth. I told John point-blank that I refused to say that white man's lines."

fields.bodyText: Samuel L Jackson has been venting his spleen over his latest movie, Shaft, the remake of the 70s blaxploitation favourite. Stories of strife between star Jackson and director John Singleton were abundant during filming and Jackson is now all too happy to confirm them. "John is like many young directors I've worked with recently," he said at an LA publicity junket last week. "They've done five or eight films. I've made close to 70. I know better than they do what works for Sam Jackson." Jackson, who plays the nephew of the original John Shaft in the film, continued, "I'm the one who's up there on the screen, so I'll only do it my way, because I'm the one who ends up taking the blame for their silly choices." Aware that this line of attack may confirm his reputation as a 'difficult' actor, Jackson sought to justify his bolshiness: "I will voice my opinion. I wanted John to do it my way, and not shoot another scene his way. I know the more stuff a director shoots, the more he can change the movie his way. It wasn't about power with me, it was about common sense." Singleton is playing the criticism with a straight bat. "Sam is opinionated, but I respect that," he comments, going on to attribute blame to a third party: "It was our producer, Scott Rudin, who was the big problem." Rudin is blamed for drafting in script doctor Richard Price to rewrite the Shaft dialogue. Jackson wasn't - and isn't - best pleased: "Richard Price tried to put certain words in my mouth. I told John point-blank that I refused to say that white man's lines."  Shaft is released in the US next weekend.

webTitle: How I skittled the county champions

fields.headline: How I skittled the county champions
fields.standfirst: Every week we go behind the secenes to get the lowdown on one of the performances of the week. Today we talk to Tim Munton, one of the new veterans on the block at Derby, who upset the odds against Surrey
fields.trailText: Tim Munton, 34, is a right-arm, medium-pace bowler for Derbyshire. He made his debut for Warwickshire in 1985 and played for them until he signed a two-year contract with Derbyshire at the beginning of this year. He played two Tests for England in 1992 against Pakistan, taking four wickets, and was a Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1995. He was appointed Warwickshire captain after the retirement of Dermot Reeve in 1996, but missed the 1997 season through injury and was replaced by Brian Lara in 1998. This season, he had picked up only three first-class wickets for Derbyshire before June 7, the first day of the Championship match against the holders Surrey, when he took 7-34, a first-class best, as Surrey were bowled out for 138. Derbyshire went on to win, but were docked eight points for preparing a "poor" pitch. Munton takes up the story
fields.body:
Tim Munton, 34, is a right-arm, medium-pace bowler for Derbyshire. He made his debut for Warwickshire in 1985 and played for them until he signed a two-year contract with Derbyshire at the beginning of this year. He played two Tests for England in 1992 against Pakistan, taking four wickets, and was a Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1995. He was appointed Warwickshire captain after the retirement of Dermot Reeve in 1996, but missed the 1997 season through injury and was replaced by Brian Lara in 1998. This season, he had picked up only three first-class wickets for Derbyshire before June 7, the first day of the Championship match against the holders Surrey, when he took 7-34, a first-class best, as Surrey were bowled out for 138. Derbyshire went on to win, but were docked eight points for preparing a "poor" pitch. Munton takes up the story

"It had been quite a frustrating season for me. I'd gone to a new county and was keen to mark my arrival with a good performance. I felt I was bowling well and had done well in the B&H, but the County Championship hadn't been so fruitful. So it was a big relief to get wickets and to contribute to the win.

"It has been fantastic here at Derbyshire. It is, to a very large extent, a new side and there has been lots of getting to know each other - Colin Wells and Dominic Cork have made us all very welcome. Doing well against the county champions has given us the belief that we can go ahead and repeat the win in following weeks.

"I suppose playing against Surrey does make you up your game, in that you have to because you are playing against a very good side. When I was at Warwickshire I had the other side of it - we always had the feeling that everyone was trying especially hard against us. But, and in fact we were talking about this the other day, two divisions has made every game a big game. And that can only be good news.

"The pitch at Derby has come in for some comment. There was a lot of rain around, and a little bit of moisture. It helped the seam bowlers throughout the game but I wouldn't say it was a very poor pitch.

"I bowled from the pavilion end and it was one of those magic days when everything clicks. From over one, no maybe over two, I felt very pleased with my rhythm. I like bowling against left-handers [Mark Butcher and Ian Ward, Surrey's openers, are both left-handed] and to bowl to two of them is a real plus for me, though I know some bowlers have a mental block about it.

My first wicket was Butcher - it was a ball that pitched quite full and then swung back in, Mark got a little inside edge onto the stumps.

"Then it was Graham Thorpe. The first ball that I bowled to him went away, and the next one swung back in, he didn't play a shot and I had him lbw. It was nice to see him depart: I've had my days against him but I've also been on the receiving end of a couple of Thorpe hundreds.

"[Alec] Stewart was next, out to a ball that came back into him, went through the gate and got him off stump.

"Adam Hollioake fell just after lunch to a very good catch by Matthew Dowman. It was quite funny actually, I'd had a short leg [Dowman] in for a while, then he went to midwicket. But when we came back on, Matt asked me where I wanted him and I said, 'Oh go to short leg.' Hollioake hit, I think the first ball after lunch, off the full face of the bat straight into his hands. It was a very good catch.

"Then it was Jason Ratcliffe, my old Warwickshire team-mate. It was hard not to smile when he came to the crease. But to his credit he fell to my best ball. I bowled it from wide of the crease and the ball swung out, carried on off the seam, and hit off stump. I was very keen to do well against him, and we had a bit of friendly banter in the bar afterwards.

"Martin Bicknell got an inside edge and was caught behind by Karl Krikken. It was a very good catch. I have to give Karl credit. I knew when I joined Derbyshire that he was renowned for being under-rated and for being very, very consistent, and this year he has certainly added a different dimension to my bowling because he has been prepared to stand up to the stumps. I'm sure Keith Piper, who I consider the best keeper in the country, would have stood up to me at Warwickshire but it was a bit of a macho thing and I didn't want him to. But now I'm a bit older and longer in the tooth, I was prepared to take up Karl's offer.

"[Alex] Tudor was the final one - to an inswinging yorker. He and Saqlain [Mushtaq] had been having a bit of a go, trying to score quickly - so I tried a bit of variation and it just went straight through.

"You practise and you feel good, but until you get the results you always have some doubt in the back of your mind. These wickets mean that I am looking forward to the rest of the season a lot more, and to going to Grace Road for our next game and hopefully getting a few wickets there as well."

Tim Munton is also the global director of cricket for sportsnetglobal.com, an internet company which will be up and running in July. He was talking to Tanya Aldred. Other recent My Days In The Sun: Chris Taylor(Gloucs),Richard Logan(Northants), Vyvian Pike(Dorset)

fields.headline: Gung-ho in Groningen
fields.standfirst: Keegan's flexible formula; those god-awful headlines in full; and another morning of discomfort for Karel Poborsky.
fields.trailText: Keegan's flexible formula; those god-awful headlines in full; and another morning of discomfort for Karel Poborsky.
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"In my spare time I am reading Henry V. I certainly find it interesting, that's why I'm reading it" - Tony Adams on his new book. What's wrong with Michael Hardcastle?

THE EURO-TORIAL

Kevin Keegan has named his England team for tonight's match against Portugal - and according to every pundit in Christendom he has chosen Steve McManaman over Dennis Wise, and opted for a flexible formation: 3-5-2 in attack and 4-4-2 in defence.

Keegan's big idea is that England will play a tried and trusted 4-4-2 to stifle any pincer movements from Portuguese danger men Rui Costa and Luis Figo, and then transform into a continental style 3-5-2 formation when they come forward, with Phil Neville pushing into the left wing-back position, Gary Neville dropping into central defence and Steve McManaman slipping from left-midfield into a free role.

All of which, in the Euro's humble opinion, sounds quite promising. Even, dare we say it, exciting. In theory it will enable McManaman to drift off the left flank to link up with Scholes, Beckham and Owen and England will run riot (well, not rely solely on set-pieces to score). In practice of course, McManaman will at some point meander into the middle, the team will lose the ball and it'll be Figo one-on-one with Phil Neville. The Brylcreemed boy will ghost past him and blast the ball straight through a despairing David Seaman. England will lose 1-0 and Keegan will be slated for his tactical naivety.

Of course it's probably wise to point out that Keegan won't actually announce his team until an hour before kick-off, so all this is just harmless speculation/clever subterfuge/the truth (depending on your point of view). However speaking on Radio 5 earlier today, Peter Beardsley (who's in the England camp) claimed he hadn't yet heard the team, wouldn't tell anybody even if he did know and poured scorn on the whole idea of a dual formation. All of which suggests that the pundits are probably right

GUNG-HO WATCH

It's the morning before the big match, and the papers are so excited they're in need of a sit down. Here are our top five patriotic stirrings.

1 "The game's afoot: Follow your spirit; and, upon this charge cry 'God for Kevin!' England and St George!" Hurrah! The Daily Mirror leads the way with their patriotic front page

2 "Cry God for Harry, England and St George" But the Sun's back page is not far behind.

3 "God for England and St George" And the Star's on a similar wavelength too

4 "For England and Saint George." No surprises here from The Daily Mail.

5 "Earn our respect, England" Eh? The Express refuses to go along with the Henry V headlines, and decides to be sceptical instead. It'll never catch on.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

You'll get a wider view of the Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com. See how you score with fantasy share trading and you could win a 28" wide screen TV.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Feelings are running high in the Czech camp after the Dutch nicked a late win against them in Amsterdam last night. "Several players were crying in the dressing room and it doesn't surprise me," said an emotive Czech coach Jozef Chovanec. "I don't remember anything like this happening in my whole career." Mr Chovanec is a highly talented actor, with screen credits that include The Bill and Last of the Summer Wine. If you like what you read here and would like to offer him work, please fax all requests to the Czech FA.

Turkey coach Mustafa Denizli has described the decision by referee Hugh Dallas to award Italy a penalty in yesterday's 2-1 victory for the Azzurri as 'unforgiveable'. "The whole match turned on one bad decision by the referee. There's no way it was a penalty and my players later confirmed this to me," he said. "I repeat that there was no way it was a penalty and the consequences are serious." Denizli is today expected to call for Uefa to impose sanctions on the Italians, including a 10-metre "safety zone" around Fillippo Inzaghi's flailing limbs.

Uefa have been forced to withdraw 47,000 official match programmes because they didn't have the Belgian Prime Minister in them. An official photograph of Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt was supposed to appear in all programmes, but a photo of some random bloke turned up instead. To eliminate all confusion, the random bloke will be expected to perform Verhofstadt's official duties until the end of the tournament.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hi-aiiieeeee!

Pavel Nedved here. That was my close personal friend and chum Karel Poborsky being thrown out of a high window. I had to do it because today I must bring you a transfer rumour concerning myself, and there is nobody better placed to talk about myself than me. I'm sure you will agree.

"In Rome, Lazio fight constantly for the title and the Champions League, the pressure is much too heavy and there are greater difficulties with the supporters." That's me talking, by the way. "Therefore, I am thinking next about a transfer to England - there is quite an interest from Manchester United. It would be a dream to play at Old Trafford."

Take it from me, that's straight from the horse's mouth. Ciao.

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC 1: Match of the day live - Germany v Romania (4.35pm) This is not England v Portugal.

MOTD at Euro 2000: Portugal v England (11.30pm) This is.

ITV: England v Portugal (7pm) But it's not on until after this. Wonder how long Des has been practising his opening line. He's so professional though, he probably just thinks one up off the cuff.

British Eurosport: Portugal v England (7pm) They've got it live too you know.

Sky Sports One: World Football Show (11pm) Which is more than can be said for this mob.

webTitle: Pound at risk as long as Britain spurns euro

fields.headline: Pound at risk as long as Britain spurns euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The pound will be subject to wild fluctuations, buffeted by the dollar and the euro, as long as Britain stays out of the single currency, a group of pro-European economists claims today.
fields.body:
The pound will be subject to wild fluctuations, buffeted by the dollar and the euro, as long as Britain stays out of the single currency, a group of pro-European economists claims today.

The economists, who include Willem Buiter, a former member of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee and Robert Mundell, a Nobel Prize winner, warn that sterling is likely to continue the rollercoaster movements of the past five years which have seen it fall as low as DM 2.19 and then rise as far as DM 3.40.

"Those who are in favour of staying out have to accept that every so often the currency is going to go off to ludicrous levels," said Adair Turner, the former CBI director general and one of the pamphlet's authors.

Simon Buckby, campaign director of Britain in Europe, publisher of the pamphlet, said: "It would be irresponsible to ignore the damage that the overvalued pound is causing the British economy."

Mr Turner said foreign companies would be deterred from investing in Britain. "Somebody investing in Britain is facing a currency risk which somebody investing in Europe doesn't face. Where there is extra risk there will probably be lower investment."

As long as it is outside the single currency zone, Britain will not be able to benefit fully from the European single market and the lower prices which increased competition will bring, the economists claim. They add that staying out has long-term costs for Britain:

"The City could lose its role as Europe's leading financial centre if Britain is permanently excluded from the euro. Britain is already losing influence over important developments in Europe."

fields.trailText: Monday, 1pm: The trade union leader is the unofficial standard-bearer of the government's pro-euro campaign, says political correspondent Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
With a few carefully crafted remarks, Tony Blair's favourite trade union leader has managed to dominate the airwaves today with his warning that the government's stance on the euro is dangerously reminiscent of John Major's dithering.

The attack by Sir Ken Jackson, the general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union (AEEU), was initially interpreted as a rebuke to Tony Blair for failing to give a lead on the single currency.

But Sir Ken, Downing Street's favourite trade union leader who was knighted by the prime minister, rarely moves against his admirer. He is, after all, the man who fixed the AEEU's vote to block Ken Livingstone standing as Labour's London mayor candidate.

His aides made clear that Sir Ken's remarks were in fact aimed at Gordon Brown who is lukewarm about the euro. The chancellor is resisting pressure from pro-European cabinet ministers to sound more enthusiastic about the single currency, to the frustration of trade union and business leaders who want the government to set a timetable for membership.

Sir Ken's speech today has fuelled speculation that Downing Street is quietly orchestrating a campaign to allow pro-Europeans to start beating the drum for the currency, amid fears that the Tories have hijacked the issue with their Keep the Pound campaign.

The cross-party Britain in Europe group, which was set up to campaign in favour of the European Union with the blessing of Downing Street, has been "given the green light" to widen its campaign to include the euro.

As Sir Ken was speaking in Blackpool, the group launched a new pamphlet, called the Case for the Euro, which warns of the economic dangers of failing to join the currency.

There are, however, limits to Downing Street's enthusiasm for the euro. Stephen Byers, the pro-European trade and industry secretary, was believed to have been encouraged by Downing Street to make his keynote speech last Friday in which he said that businesses would gain from British membership. But by the weekend, Mr Byers had been reined in by Downing Street which penned a newspaper article in his name which merely spoke of the "potential benefits" of membership.

Sir Ken's speech does mark a significant shift in gear by pro-Europeans. However, until the prime minister emerges from his bunker and joins the pro-European chorus, William Hague will continue to set the agenda.

webTitle: Blair dithering like Major on euro says union chief

fields.headline: Blair dithering like Major on euro says union chief
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's favourite trade union leader will today launch a withering attack on the government for failing to take a lead on the European single currency, warning that the sense of drift is reminiscent of the John Major era.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's favourite trade union leader will today launch a withering attack on the government for failing to take a lead on the European single currency, warning that the sense of drift is reminiscent of the John Major era.

In a damaging intervention, Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, will claim that the government's "very unclear" position will crumble at the general election if ministers fail to outline a timetable for British membership of the euro.

"We can't afford to let this drift go by default," Sir Ken will tell an AEEU conference in Blackpool. "We will lose jobs and lose influence as we do."

The sense of disarray among ministers over the euro was heightened yesterday when the pro-European trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, rowed back on his keynote speech of last Friday in which he spoke up strongly in favour of the single currency.

In an article in yesterday's Independent on Sunday, said to have been drafted by the Downing Street strategic communications unit, which takes a cautious stance on the euro, Mr Byers merely spoke of the "potential benefits" to Britain of joining the currency. This contrasted with his strong endorsement of the euro last Friday in which he said that joining would allow businesses to take greater risks.

The confusing signals from Mr Byers highlighted the tensions among senior ministers over the euro. The Byers camp, supported by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, wants the government to take a more robust stance on the euro.

The pro-Europeans are opposed by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, who believe that the next election should be fought on the government's handling of the wider economy and on health and education.

In his carefully timed speech today, Sir Ken will seize on the divisions when he launches a guarded attack on the chancellor for stifling the pro-Europeans in cabinet. "Now is the time for the Treasury to make it clear that we have not buried the issue, that the perception of Euroscepticism is untrue," Sir Ken will say.

AEEU sources said Sir Ken believes the chancellor is in danger of allowing William Hague to dominate the debate over the euro with his Keep the Pound campaign.

"We cannot avoid the issue during the election," Sir Ken will say. "It is naive to assume it won't be the defining theme. Whether we like it or not, William Hague will make it his number one issue. Without a clear and credible policy, we will crumble at the first sign of real debate."

Sir Ken will call on the chancellor to announce when he will say whether Britain is meeting the government's five economic tests which must be passed before ministers call a referendum on the euro. "We should move on from this wait-and-see policy so reminiscent of John Major's government," he will say.

Pro-Europeans are keen to put pressure on the chancellor to spell out his position on the tests after the organisation for economic cooperation and development (OECD) reported last week that the UK economy is more in tune with euroland than some countries which are already signed up to the euro. This was echoed yesterday in a study by accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers, which said the economies of Britain and euroland have been growing closer together in the past 18 months.

Pro-European campaigners will today step up pressure for British membership of the euro with the publication of a pamphlet which warns of the dangers of staying outside. The Case for the Euro, published by the cross-party Britain in Europe pressure group, says sterling will face damaging fluctuations because it is "trapped between the euro and the US dollar".

The pamphlet signals that Britain in Europe has been given the "green light" by Downing Street to make the case for the euro.

webTitle: Syria promotes Assad son as power struggle begins

fields.headline: Syria promotes Assad son as power struggle begins
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The struggle for power in Syria began yesterday when the regime paved the way for Bashar al-Assad to become president in succession to his father who died on Saturday after ruling the country for almost 30 years.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  and Suzanne Goldenberg  on the Golan Heights
fields.body:
The struggle for power in Syria began yesterday when the regime paved the way for Bashar al-Assad to become president in succession to his father who died on Saturday after ruling the country for almost 30 years.

In a sign of nervousness, the regime made a series of frantic moves aimed at bolstering Bashar, who is only 34: the ruling Ba'ath party nominated him as president, the constitution was changed to allow him to take up the post, and he was promoted from a relatively lowly post to commander in chief of the armed forces.

The future of the Middle East peace process hangs on whether Bashar, a Western-educated moderniser, can achieve a peaceful transition in a country that has been marked by bloody political upheavals.

While diplomats based in the Middle East predicted he will succeed in taking over in the short-term, doubts were expressed about the longer term, given his lack of experience. A western diplomat said: "How much stomach does he have for it? He has to prove he is as hard and ruthless as the next man."

His father, Hafez al-Assad, who had been in power since 1970 was lying in state in Damascus yesterday. Government leaders from round the world, including the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, and the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will attend a funeral ceremony tomorrow on a hill overlooking the capital.

Bashar has been groomed for power since the death of his brother in 1994. His father's death from a heart attack at the age of 69 has forced responsibility on him faster than many of his supporters would have liked.

The Ba'ath party yesterday unanimously nominated him for president. The parliament will approve the nomination on June 25 and a referendum will be held.

Constitutional law was changed yesterday to lower the minimum age for becoming president from 40 to 34.

Bashar is an Anglophile, who studied in London for two years, and he is close to another young reformist leader, King Abdullah of Jordan. Diplomatic sources in Damascus said that in the past few months he had been leading an anti-corruption drive that had caught several senior political figures.

One threat to Bashar's takeover had been posed by Assad's younger brother, Rifaat, who is in exile in Paris where he uses an Arab radio station to broadcast reports aimed at annoying the regime in Damascus. Diplomats yesterday dismissed the threat, saying that a small outburst of support for Rifaat in recent months in Syria had ended with the leaders being rounded up. A more realistic threat could could be posed by a disenchanted or jealous army officer.

Hafez's death will stall the Syrian side of the peace negotiations with Israel. Syria, which has been Israel's most implacable foe, holds the key to peace. It has a large number of troops in Lebanon and holds sway over the Hizbullah guerrilla forces,

Although Bashar is a reformer, it will be difficult for him, at least initially, to go any further in making concessions than his father.

fields.headline: Wounded Blair orders attack
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Downing Street and Millbank spent the weekend drawing up plans for another government relaunch after Labour strategists admitted privately that senior ministers were caught off guard by the sudden drop in support for the party.
fields.body:
Downing Street and Millbank spent the weekend drawing up plans for another government relaunch after Labour strategists admitted privately that senior ministers were caught off guard by the sudden drop in support for the party.

Amid growing signs that the general election could be less than a year away, the prime minister and the chancellor will lead the cabinet's fiercest attack on the Tories since the general election in an attempt to halt the drop in support for Labour.

The fightback, which will be dismissed by Labour's opponents as a sign of desperation, was signalled after an opinion poll in the Mail on Sunday showed that Tony Blair's lead over the Tories has sunk to an all-time low of three points.

The Mori poll, which was carried out two days after the prime minister's disastrous speech to the Women's Institute on Wednesday, showed Labour on 41 points, with the Tories on 38. In the previous Mori poll, carried out last month after the birth of the prime minister's son, Labour was on 48 points, with the Tories on 32.

The poor showing was compounded by a leaked memo by Philip Gould, the prime minister's polling guru, in which he wrote that middle Britain believed that Mr Blair was out of touch and was failing to deliver on his key election promises. Mr Gould said the prime minister was believed by middle Britain to be "all spin and presentation".

The damning assessment of the prime minister was made by "switch voters" interviewed by Mr Gould in focus groups. They said, according to the memo leaked to the Sunday Times, that: "TB has not delivered. He said he would improve the NHS and public services, he said he would improve Britain, but instead things have got worse."

Mr Gould was also devastating about an early draft of Mr Blair's speech to the WI. In a note to Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, Mr Gould said: "This speech does not work because it does not feel authentic. It reads like TB reacting to criticism, rather than saying what he believes in."

Alarmed by the Gould note, the prime minister personally changed his speech. Despite his efforts, the speech still crashed, with embarrassing consequences.

Labour sources last night dismissed the significance of the Gould memo on "switch voters", saying that his missives often made uncomfortable reading and were a sign of the prime minister's determination to remain in touch with voters who are not natural Labour supporters.

However, there was more alarm at the drop in support. A senior Labour source said the party's own research showed that Labour has lost support over its handling of the NHS, though this is now returning, and on asylum. Support for the government on education and its handling of the economy is remaining firm.

However, strategists are in no doubt that Labour has a fight on its hands after the Tories' success in dominating the headlines in recent months. "Because things have been going so smoothly we have been caught slightly unawares by the fact it is possible to create an electoral atmosphere," one said.

The unease was voiced publicly by the environment minister, Michael Meacher. Speaking on GMTV, he said: "I think the government has done plenty of good things...[but] we are under pressure now and we have to [speak] in an unvarnished, straight, clear and honest manner."

Strategists say the fightback will highlight Labour's achievements in four key areas. They are:

 Reforms of the NHS, which contrast with the threat of private medical insurance promised by the Tories;

 One Nation policies, such as the New Deal and the working families tax credit, which compare with the "social division" offered by the Tories;

 Success on the world stage and in Europe as opposed to "an isolated Britain under the Tories";

 Economic stability against the uncertainty of a return to Tory boom and bust.

Senior ministers will also say that New Labour is still determined to appeal to the wide audience which flocked to the party in 1997, rather than simply appealing to core voters. "The big tent is what got us elected and it will move forward," one source said.

The Tories claimed that the polls showed that they were at last staging a recovery. The Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, said: "The New Labour bubble has burst. Fewer and fewer people believe Tony Blair's promises any more and more and more people are turning to the common sense solutions which William Hague is offering."

webTitle: Support for royal family falls to new low

fields.headline: Support for royal family falls to new low
fields.standfirst:
New low for royal family
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Support for the royal family has fallen to its lowest level in modern times, with only 44% of the public believing that Britain would be worse off without the monarchy, according to a Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.
fields.body:
Support for the royal family has fallen to its lowest level in modern times, with only 44% of the public believing that Britain would be worse off without the monarchy, according to a Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.

The survey suggests, however, that it is a growing indifference to the royal family rather than a rise in republicanism that is responsible for the spectacular slide in royal popularity since the late 1980s and early 1990s when repeated ICM polls showed more than 70% of the public believed Britain would be worse off without the royal family.

A comparison of the poll results with Guardian/ICM surveys over the last 13 years shows that the royal family is now held in less affection than the previous low point in their fortunes in August 1997 when their support fell below 50% for the first time, just before the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.

Although there was a modest revival in popularity in the year after Diana's death during which the Prince of Wales waged a quietly successful campaign to reclaim the hearts and minds of the British people, the ICM poll shows that those gains have melted away. Support for the royal family has fallen a further eight points in the last two years. The survey shows that despite the efforts of Buckingham Palace's "way ahead group" to try to reinvent and modernise the monarchy for the 21st century it is still in deep trouble.

The sharp rise in the proportion of those who say they "don't know" in answer to the question whether they think Britain would be better off or worse off without the royal family, from 20% in 1998 to 29% now, suggests that a growing minority believe that the monarchy is irrelevant to their lives. This increasing indifference is particularly striking when compared with the results in the early 1990s when everybody seemed to care one way or the other about the royals and only 5% to 10% said they did not have a view.

The ICM poll also shows that in time solid support for the royal family will "die out" with only the 55-and-over age group showing a clear majority who believe that Britain would be worse off without them.

The rise in hostility is sharpest among the young. Some 40% of 18-24 year olds, the highest ever, believe that Britain would be better off without the royals and only 24% say the country would be worse off if the monarchy were abolished. Perhaps even more worrying for Buckingham Palace is that a third of those under 44 are indifferent to the royal family. But the level of republicanism in Britain appears to have changed little in the six years, with between 25% and 30% of the population saying they think Britain would be better off without the royal family.

The poll shows there is not much variation in attitudes to the royal family across social classses or between the north, the midlands and the south.

The ICM survey also shows a continuing unhappiness among a significant minority at the idea of Prince Charles becoming king. Not quite a majority - 48% - say that when the Queen abdicates or dies the crown should pass to King Charles III, but one in three of the public rejects this view and believes the monarchy should skip a generation and Prince William should be crowned king. Support for this idea is particularly strong among women. They are almost evenly split - 43% to 41% - over whether Charles or his son, William, should become king, suggesting that women are less forgiving about his adultery confession in 1994 and reflecting the strength of the Diana legacy.

Hostility to the idea of King Charles is strongest among the DE social class - the unskilled working class and the poorest - 48% of whom want to see Prince William, whose 18th birthday is on June 21, the next king and who outnumber the 38% that want to see Charles enthroned.

The only positive results for the palace in the poll lie in the responses to the question whether people feel the royal family has become more in touch with ordinary people since the death of Princess Diana. Some 38% felt they were more in touch now, 7% less in touch and 51% felt there had been no change. The ICM findings seem to suggest that despite this positive finding they have failed to halt the erosion in their standing with the public.

ICM Research interviewed a random sample of 1,006 adults aged over 18 by telephone between May 26 and 28. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

Not quite a majority - 48% - say that when the Queen abdicates or dies the crown should pass to King Charles III, but one in three of the public rejects this view and believes the monarchy should skip a generation and Prince William should be crowned king. Support for this idea is particularly strong among women. They are almost evenly split - 43% to 41% - over whether Charles or his son, William, should become king, suggesting that women are less forgiving about his adultery confession in 1994 and reflecting the strength of the Diana legacy. Hostility to the idea of King Charles is strongest among the DE social class - the unskilled working class and the poorest - 48% of whom want to see Prince William, whose 18th birthday is on June 21, the next king and who outnumber the 38% that want to see Charles enthroned. The only positive results for the palace in the poll lie in the responses to the question whether people feel the royal family has become more in touch with ordinary people since the death of Princess Diana. Some 38% felt they were more in touch now, 7% less in touch and 51% felt there had been no change. The ICM findings seem to suggest that despite this positive finding they have failed to halt the erosion in their standing with the public. ICM Research interviewed a random sample of 1,006 adults aged over 18 by telephone between May 26 and 28. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Stricter bans urged for fans
fields.standfirst:
Plan for tougher measures against hooligans, while fraud officers target unemployed at Euro 2000
Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Football supporters convicted of even minor offences could be banned from travelling to English matches abroad under proposals being considered by the Home Office.
fields.body:
Football supporters convicted of even minor offences could be banned from travelling to English matches abroad under proposals being considered by the Home Office.

Senior officers at the National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS) football unit are to lobby for a strengthening of legislation that would require all convicted hooligans to surrender their passports during international tournaments involving the national side or English clubs.

Currently those convicted of football-related violence are subject to either domestic banning orders, preventing them from travelling to matches in England and Wales, or international banning orders which require the surrender of passports.

The NCIS would like to see a single banning order introduced so that all convicted hooligans, guilty of crimes either in England or abroad, would be required to surrender their passports during major England or club matches abroad.

The government, meanwhile, strengthened its stance by warning that unemployed hooligans will lose their welfare benefits if convicted. The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, said that unemployed fans who are traced to Euro 2000 will lose their income support and job seekers allowance if they cannot prove they are seeking work.

The NCIS and the Home Office are understood to be dismayed that magistrates have not imposed more international banning orders since the 1999 Football (Offences and Disorder) Act became law. Under the act the courts can augment fines or custodial sentences with the banning orders.

Since September last year just 20 international orders have been made compared with around 200 domestic orders. This has in effect left 180 more convicted hooligans free to attempt to attend Euro 2000 than might have been the case.

A Home Office source confirmed it would be considering the proposal: "The NCIS has a strong persuasive role and we will be looking carefully at ways of improving the handling of hooligans after Euro 2000."

An NCIS spokesman said: "Changing the legislation would send out a huge warning that a small offence can be punishable by a blanket ban.

"Make no mistake, these people [hooligans] like their football and imposing an international order is the punishment most likely to deter them; it would be like taking away their toys."

The NCIS believes a single order would simplify the sentencing process and remove from magistrates the question of which orders to impose.

"The magistrate or judge currently faces a difficult dilemma as to whether the person before them is a small-town thug or an international hooligan.

"Someone arrested at a lower division match is likely to be treated as a small-time offender and receive a domestic banning order. In fact these people are just as likely to travel abroad."

The NCIS has passed the names of around 1,000 convicted or suspected hooligans to Dutch and Belgian authorities in an attempt to stop them reaching the tournament.

Around 30 people have been refused entry to the low countries ahead of England's match against Portugal tonight, as a result of the information. Among them are several of England's most notorious hooligans.

"This shows the intelligence is working, and the publicity has deterred many from travelling," said the NCIS spokesman.

The NCIS has also passed "significant, specific" intelligence to the Dutch authorities ahead of tonight's England game in Eindhoven.

Social security recipients attending matches in the Netherlands and Belgium are being targeted by fraud officers. Under the job seekers allowance, beneficiaries are required to be actively seeking work to receive benefit.

"If you are languishing in the cells of the gendarmerie you are not available for work," said Mr Darling, who will today announce a crackdown on benefit fraud.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, described the move as "knee-jerk nonsense".

"Why unemployed people should be treated any differently from other members of society as to whether they can travel to football matches seems utterly ludicrous," he said.

fields.headline: City braced for English invasion
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Weak beer and a strong police presence greeted thousands of England fans arriving in Eindhoven for England's opening Euro 2000 match against Portugal tonight.
fields.body:
Weak beer and a strong police presence greeted thousands of England fans arriving in Eindhoven for England's opening Euro 2000 match against Portugal tonight.

Dutch police said yesterday they expect as many as 10,000 ticketless England fans to be in and around Eindhoven for the match and the city was mounting the biggest security operation in its history.

Around 3,000 police officers will be on duty for the game, 50% more than the number for other Euro 2000 matches in Eindhoven.

Dutch police also warned that any violence during Euro 2000 will be met with violence and all troublemakers will be prosecuted and forced to serve their sentence before being allowed home.

The bulk of England fans are expected to arrive today and police have ordered bars in the centre of Eindhoven to sell weak beer in an attempt to minimise any trouble. Festival Beer, as it has been called, went on sale in city centre bars yesterday costing four guilders per glass, almost double the price of normal strength Dutch beers.

Dutch authorities also confirmed yesterday that six England fans had been turned away from the country over the weekend because their names appeared on a list of troublemakers.

Five were turned back at Schipol airport, Amsterdam, while another was turned back at the Hook of Holland after arriving by ferry. The Dutch home office said that patrols along the border with Germany were being stepped up and the number of immigration officals at ports and airports in the country had been increased.

With up to 20,000 England fans expected for tonight's match, police have taken special precautions to ensure there is no trouble with Eindhoven's sizeable Turkish community. English and Turkish football fans have clashed recently following the killing of two Leeds United supporters before a match against Galatasaray, in Turkey, in April, sparking fears that the two groups might confront each other during Euro 2000.

Special routes have been set up to ensure that Turkish fans in Eindhoven can get in and out of the city without coming across English fans, and police have segregated parts of the city centre to ensure the groups remain apart.

Around 50 water cannons have been brought in as a precaution and the number of staff at local hospitals has been increased.

Yohan Beelan, spokesman for Eindhoven police, said: "This is the biggest security operation in the city's history and we expect most England fans to come here for a good time.

"We have put a lot of work into ensuring that things go smoothly. We have never had so many police officers on duty for a match and are well prepared for any problems that might happen."

While English fans arriving in the Netherlands were generally well behaved, police in Belgium made a number of arrests following skirmishes in central Brussels after Saturday's opening match between Belgium and Sweden.

Riot police fired tear gas following fears that rival fans would clash in the city's main square and 63 fans were detained with another 26 arrested and charged with violence offences. None of those arrested are believed to be English.

 The Football Association last night said it had expelled two people from the England Members' Club, the only official England supporters' organisation, over the violence in Copenhagen before last month's Uefa cup final between Arsenal and Galatasaray.

Two young men, one from Oxfordshire and one from Windsor, Berkshire, had been identified by officials as being involved in disturbances.

FA spokesman Adrian Bevington said: "Both these individuals have had their membership immediately cancelled on this information being brought to our attention.

"This should send out a clear message to all members travelling to Euro 2000 that violent behaviour will see instant expulsion from the England Members' Club. The EMC is currently operating a 'football yes, violence no' campaign, and these people have no place in such a positive organisation."

The club has confirmed that neither man had tickets for any Euro 2000 game. However the National Criminal Intelligence Service had forwarded their personal details to the Dutch and Belgian authorities.

No Violence Campaign
National Criminal Intelligence Agency

webTitle: Swaying Millennium Bridge to close after two days

fields.headline: Swaying Millennium Bridge to close after two days
fields.trailText: London's £18.2m Millennium Bridge is to close just two days after it opened to the public, its builders announced today.
fields.body:
London's £18.2m Millennium Bridge is to close just two days after it opened to the public, its builders announced today.

The 320m-long structure, which links St Paul's Cathedral in the City with the Tate Modern gallery in Southwark, will close from 10pm tonight. It could be shut for weeks.

The suspension bridge swayed alarmingly under the weight of thousands of people at its official opening on Saturday. Tonight, the Millennium Bridge Trust, which organised its building, said the bridge would close to allow engineers to continue their investigation "into the cause of excessive movement of the bridge in certain conditions and to carry out work to correct the problem".

It is understood that the closure of the pedestrians-only bridge could last for weeks. Its closure will be a huge disappointment to Londoners and to the tens of thousands of tourists heading for the capital this summer. Designed by the highly-acclaimed Foster and Partners, the bridge was inaugurated by the Queen last month.

The company said the bridge was intended to have some movement, but those crossing it this weekend spoke of considerable sway.

The first new river crossing in central London since Tower Bridge opened in 1894, the bridge was officially opened to the public on Saturday by the former model Heather Mills, who led schoolchildren on a sponsored walk.

The large number of people on the bridge - 160,000 visited over the weekend - exposed a fault on the structure. It closed for 10 minutes on Saturday because of excessive swaying and stewards have limited the numbers allowed on it since.

A team from the bridge's engineers, Arup, were inspecting the bridge today in an attempt to locate the problem. The bridge remained open to pedestrians but the trust said it would close at 10pm. David Bell, chairman of the trust, apologised to people who might have felt discomfort or "unease" crossing the bridge on Saturday. "The current problem, which involves excessive movement on the bridge in certain conditions, is something that we will overcome," he said.

Millennium projects appear jinxed. The £758m Millennium Dome has endured a cash and visitor crisis which has led to the ousting of both its chairman and chief executive. And the opening of the Millennium Wheel, officially known as the British Airways London Eye, was postponed after a problem with the passenger pods.
