fields.headline: The appeal of Camilla
fields.standfirst:
Throughout her relationship with Charles, she has been a model of discretion. If only the same were true of all royals

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Throughout her relationship with Charles, she has been a model of discretion. If only the same were true of all royals
fields.body:
Private. Intensely private. That, for a very long time, was as much as we were told about Camilla Parker-Bowles. True, the woman had more reason than most to be private, but love of privacy, her friends insisted, would have been a Parker-Bowles quality even if she hadn't got involved in a 25-year affair with her future sovereign and endured having their intensely private smutty telephone call transcribed as entertainment for the masses.

Since she was so private, not being officially acknowledged or generally liked seemed to suit Camilla just fine. "She is without personal ambition," revealed Ingrid Seward, one of her supporters, "and insists she will always be happier pruning the roses than planting them." "Camilla becomes nervous when the spotlight turns on her," said fellow sympathiser Stuart Higgins, a former editor of the Sun.

All she wanted, her friends said, was to be with Charles. "She's a very private person - I can't see her cutting ribbons," Patti Palmer-Tomkinson, a friend of the couple, told the New Yorker in 1997. "I've never heard them mention marriage. While they've got each other in private it's their romance; it belongs to them."

That summer, when everyone still expected the Diana v Camilla story to run for ever, a love of privacy was starting to look like rather an attractive quality. While the princess pranced around the Mediterranean in high-cut swimsuits, public opinion began to soften towards Camilla. It may even have helped when Diana's new boon companion, Mohamed al Fayed, whose son would become her lover, gave a press conference in which he boasted about their intimacy and declared that "Camilla's like something from a Dracula film compared with Diana, who is so full of life". In July 1997, just before her 50th birthday, 68% of those polled for the Daily Mirror said Charles should be free to marry Camilla. William Hill cut the odds of the couple marrying before the turn of the century from 6-1 to 3-1. Two months later, Diana was dead.

As Diana worshippers clamoured for vengeance, Camilla returned to her privacy. In fact, as reported by the kindly Higgins, she "temporarily vanished from view while she supported Prince Charles, giving him hope for the future". Business as usual, really. When she came to vulgar notice in 1992, with the publication of extracts from Andrew Morton's Diana: Her True Story, Camilla had been avoiding public notice and giving Prince Charles hope for the future for a good decade or two already.

The press only caught on when Morton transcribed Diana's charge that Camilla had haunted her marriage since her honeymoon, with the implication that the affair with Charles had resumed, and was now callously conducted in full view of staff, neighbours and friends. The day the extracts appeared, Camilla's home fell under siege. "It's fiction, it's fiction," said a helpless Andrew Parker-Bowles.

According to the rushed biographies that followed, Camilla Shand, the scantily educated daughter of a master of foxhounds, and great grand-daughter of Alice Keppel, mistress of Edward VII, had instantly appealed to Prince Charles when they met in 1972. Although not, as they say, photogenic, Camilla is reputed to have had many other charms, "animal magnetism" foremost among them. And crucially, as Jonathan Dimbleby recorded in his hagiography, "she was convulsed by the Goons".

Royal-watching mythology has it that, on their first encounter, Camilla propositioned Charles thus: "My great-grandmother and your great-great-grandfather were lovers. So how about it?" The animal magnetism did its bit. "It finally made him a man," one of Camilla's "friends" told Christopher Wilson, the author of A Greater Love, Charles and Camilla.

Which makes it all the more ungrateful that the newly virile Prince Charles promptly embarked on an eight-month cruise aboard HMS Minerva. By the time he returned, Camilla had married a cavalry officer called Andrew Parker-Bowles, a match that appeared, at the time, to have been made in animal magnetism heaven.

So the royal dalliance was put on hold. But after the Parker-Bowleses had had their two children, Camilla and Charles's feelings would no longer be denied. "To most of the population," Christopher Wilson remarks, "theirs was a passion which simply did not exist. But a privileged few were witness to an astonishing display of the almost animal attraction that the two now had for each other." At the Cirencester Polo Club Ball, he reports, the pair were seen "kissing each other, French kissing, dance after dance". On another occasion, a "trusted friend" reported, the heir to the throne was unable to resist the attractions of Camilla's favourite dress: "Charles took one look at it, plunged his hands down the front and grabbed her breasts. In mixed company, that is not the done thing." Indeed not.

Charles bought a new house, Highgrove, because it was close to Bolehyde Manor, the recently acquired seat of the Parker-Bowleses, and the magnetic twosome, now nicely settled, set about procuring the prince an official wife.

Once Diana had been installed, the affair temporarily ceased, only to be reignited as the royal marriage disintegrated. "Camilla was normal," contends Christopher Wilson. "She was grown up. She was womanly, with voluptuous curves, not a bag of bones. She was sexually adventurous. And she was, in all truth, a very nice woman." Who could ask for more?

As Charles later pointed out in a television interview, his marriage had "irretrievably broken down" by the time he and Camilla resumed extra-marital proceedings. Andrew Parker-Bowles was allegedly happy to try his luck elsewhere. Diana was enjoying riding lessons with James Hewitt. There was nothing - unless you count the princes and the Parker-Bowleses' children, and, perhaps, Charles's future as Defender of the Faith - to stand in the path of true love. Had Diana not told Morton about the arrangement, it might have gone on for years, even become the done thing. But in December 1992, six months after Morton's revelations, John Major announced a royal separation. Outside her house, Camilla gave a statement: "If something has gone wrong I'm very sorry for them," she said. "But I know nothing more than the average person in the street. I only know what I see on television."

Her fib was exposed just a few weeks later when newspapers published a taped conversation between the Prince and Mrs Parker-Bowles. Camilla was not, it made clear, "an average person in the street". Unless, that is, average persons in the street are in the habit of calling Charles at midnight, and telling him they miss him desperately, desperately, desperately. There was more. Loyal subjects were touched by a section in which the faithful Bowles beseeched the Prince to let her see his latest speech. Most of the tape, however, comprised complicated arrangements for future assignations and lustful declarations. Camilla: "I need you all the week, all the time." Charles: "Oh, God, I'll just live inside your trousers or something." It was suggested, to their shared amusement, that Charles be reincarnated as a Tampax. So this was what animal magnetism sounded like.

At the time, the tape seemed to constitute a blow from which the royal family - and Charles in particular - would never recover. How, after this, would the prince ever dare to lecture his subjects on aesthetics, on the English language, on spirituality? But the damage to the prince's reputation was short-lived. Within months of what could have been eternal disgrace, Prince Charles was droning away like 10 men, as if nothing had happened, on everything from the horrors of modern architecture to his role as "Defender of the Divine".

In fact, those who wish the royal family would keep their opinions to themselves owe a debt of gratitude to Camilla Parker-Bowles. One might go further. Until the dreadful day earlier this month when Camilla was formally conversed with by the Queen, she was the model royal: shy, opinion-free, almost invisible. If she has opinions on GM foods, she is to be congratulated on not sharing them with us. If she cares, like her boyfriend, about Shakespeare, Islam and organic carrots, she has done the decent thing of never mentioning it. It was too good too last. Sooner or later, Camilla would have to become a role model, like her ghastly future in-laws. Not long after Diana's death, Charles's spivs got to work. Camilla was seen out and about, she was reputed to be tolerated by the young princes, and now, less than three years since she seemed to be doomed to life as a Chippenham-based anchoress, Camilla is inches away from public acceptability. The archbishop of Canterbury offers consolation over tea. She entertains Scottish prelates with her prince. Last week 68% of Mirror readers said she and Charles should marry. William Hill's odds on the pair getting hitched within a year have dropped to 6-4. Tabloids that would once have rejoiced to see her hung, drawn and quartered now scream, "Marry her!"

If nothing is done, it is only a matter of time before Charles's privacy-loving helpmeet is up there beside him, planting trees, cutting ribbons, and preaching the joys of Islam, or reed-bed sanitation units, or whatever her partner's latest hobby happens to be. For however earthy, independent and sensible Camilla may be in other respects, when it comes to the massive folly of worshipping a twerp like Charles, she is peerless. Remember her "great achievement"? "Your great achievement is to love me," Charles said, unbelievably, on that tape. And even more unbelievably, Camilla took it as a compliment. If only we could attribute it to her Goonish sense of humour.

The press only caught on when Morton transcribed Diana's charge that Camilla had haunted her marriage since her honeymoon, with the implication that the affair with Charles had resumed, and was now callously conducted in full view of staff, neighbours and friends. The day the extracts appeared, Camilla's home fell under siege. "It's fiction, it's fiction," said a helpless Andrew Parker-Bowles. According to the rushed biographies that followed, Camilla Shand, the scantily educated daughter of a master of foxhounds, and great grand-daughter of Alice Keppel, mistress of Edward VII, had instantly appealed to Prince Charles when they met in 1972. Although not, as they say, photogenic, Camilla is reputed to have had many other charms, "animal magnetism" foremost among them. And crucially, as Jonathan Dimbleby recorded in his hagiography, "she was convulsed by the Goons". Royal-watching mythology has it that, on their first encounter, Camilla propositioned Charles thus: "My great-grandmother and your great-great-grandfather were lovers. So how about it?" The animal magnetism did its bit. "It finally made him a man," one of Camilla's "friends" told Christopher Wilson, the author of A Greater Love, Charles and Camilla. Which makes it all the more ungrateful that the newly virile Prince Charles promptly embarked on an eight-month cruise aboard HMS Minerva. By the time he returned, Camilla had married a cavalry officer called Andrew Parker-Bowles, a match that appeared, at the time, to have been made in animal magnetism heaven. So the royal dalliance was put on hold. But after the Parker-Bowleses had had their two children, Camilla and Charles's feelings would no longer be denied. "To most of the population," Christopher Wilson remarks, "theirs was a passion which simply did not exist. But a privileged few were witness to an astonishing display of the almost animal attraction that the two now had for each other." At the Cirencester Polo Club Ball, he reports, the pair were seen "kissing each other, French kissing, dance after dance". On another occasion, a "trusted friend" reported, the heir to the throne was unable to resist the attractions of Camilla's favourite dress: "Charles took one look at it, plunged his hands down the front and grabbed her breasts. In mixed company, that is not the done thing." Indeed not. Charles bought a new house, Highgrove, because it was close to Bolehyde Manor, the recently acquired seat of the Parker-Bowleses, and the magnetic twosome, now nicely settled, set about procuring the prince an official wife. Once Diana had been installed, the affair temporarily ceased, only to be reignited as the royal marriage disintegrated. "Camilla was normal," contends Christopher Wilson. "She was grown up. She was womanly, with voluptuous curves, not a bag of bones. She was sexually adventurous. And she was, in all truth, a very nice woman." Who could ask for more? As Charles later pointed out in a television interview, his marriage had "irretrievably broken down" by the time he and Camilla resumed extra-marital proceedings. Andrew Parker-Bowles was allegedly happy to try his luck elsewhere. Diana was enjoying riding lessons with James Hewitt. There was nothing - unless you count the princes and the Parker-Bowleses' children, and, perhaps, Charles's future as Defender of the Faith - to stand in the path of true love. Had Diana not told Morton about the arrangement, it might have gone on for years, even become the done thing. But in December 1992, six months after Morton's revelations, John Major announced a royal separation. Outside her house, Camilla gave a statement: "If something has gone wrong I'm very sorry for them," she said. "But I know nothing more than the average person in the street. I only know what I see on television." Her fib was exposed just a few weeks later when newspapers published a taped conversation between the Prince and Mrs Parker-Bowles. Camilla was not, it made clear, "an average person in the street". Unless, that is, average persons in the street are in the habit of calling Charles at midnight, and telling him they miss him desperately, desperately, desperately. There was more. Loyal subjects were touched by a section in which the faithful Bowles beseeched the Prince to let her see his latest speech. Most of the tape, however, comprised complicated arrangements for future assignations and lustful declarations. Camilla: "I need you all the week, all the time." Charles: "Oh, God, I'll just live inside your trousers or something." It was suggested, to their shared amusement, that Charles be reincarnated as a Tampax. So this was what animal magnetism sounded like. At the time, the tape seemed to constitute a blow from which the royal family - and Charles in particular - would never recover. How, after this, would the prince ever dare to lecture his subjects on aesthetics, on the English language, on spirituality? But the damage to the prince's reputation was short-lived. Within months of what could have been eternal disgrace, Prince Charles was droning away like 10 men, as if nothing had happened, on everything from the horrors of modern architecture to his role as "Defender of the Divine". In fact, those who wish the royal family would keep their opinions to themselves owe a debt of gratitude to Camilla Parker-Bowles. One might go further. Until the dreadful day earlier this month when Camilla was formally conversed with by the Queen, she was the model royal: shy, opinion-free, almost invisible. If she has opinions on GM foods, she is to be congratulated on not sharing them with us. If she cares, like her boyfriend, about Shakespeare, Islam and organic carrots, she has done the decent thing of never mentioning it. It was too good too last. Sooner or later, Camilla would have to become a role model, like her ghastly future in-laws. Not long after Diana's death, Charles's spivs got to work. Camilla was seen out and about, she was reputed to be tolerated by the young princes, and now, less than three years since she seemed to be doomed to life as a Chippenham-based anchoress, Camilla is inches away from public acceptability. The archbishop of Canterbury offers consolation over tea. She entertains Scottish prelates with her prince. Last week 68% of Mirror readers said she and Charles should marry. William Hill's odds on the pair getting hitched within a year have dropped to 6-4. Tabloids that would once have rejoiced to see her hung, drawn and quartered now scream, "Marry her!" If nothing is done, it is only a matter of time before Charles's privacy-loving helpmeet is up there beside him, planting trees, cutting ribbons, and preaching the joys of Islam, or reed-bed sanitation units, or whatever her partner's latest hobby happens to be. For however earthy, independent and sensible Camilla may be in other respects, when it comes to the massive folly of worshipping a twerp like Charles, she is peerless. Remember her "great achievement"? "Your great achievement is to love me," Charles said, unbelievably, on that tape. And even more unbelievably, Camilla took it as a compliment. If only we could attribute it to her Goonish sense of humour.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: Ordering stationery can be a goodie-filled office task, or a threatening vice that needs careful monitoring.
fields.body:
Ordering stationery can be a goodie-filled office task, or a threatening vice that needs careful monitoring. Antonia Frances, 30, PA to a firm of reinsurers in the City of London is a woman who is unfazed by fuchsia coloured Post-it Notes and sleek, sexy staplers. "No one has ever told me what I can and can't order, but I'm naturally quite careful. I'm the kind of girl who likes hunting for a bargain," she says.

Although she finds the requisite browse through the glossy stationery catalogue very enticing, she manages to remain a woman of considerable restraint. "I was almost tempted the other day - there was this pen that you fill up with water and then run over the glued part of envelopes so that you don't have to lick them and I thought what a good idea. But then I decided to order self-seal envelopes instead," she says.

Proud of her frugality, she continues: "If someone were to ask me for staples I would always give them a handful rather than a box." Her stationery orders are always modest and her seniors have never questioned her purchases. In fact, her most extravagant purchase to date was a Collins English Dictionary at the grand price of £16.99.

Stationery wholesalers often supply goods in large numbers that can prove problematic when making room for storage in the workplace. "There is a big problem of space in our offices - I don't have much room to play around with - so often it means ordering things at the last minute." Stock is kept in a cupboard, which Frances admits is due for a good tidy up. The cupboard is part of her territory which she guards vigilantly, locking it each evening before heading home. "I keep the key at my desk and although people can help themselves, they tend to ask me first," she says.

"One of the problems with ordering stationery from suppliers is that you only find out if they are out of stock of something when the rest of the order is delivered to the office. If it's an emergency, I would have to go around the corner to the shops and pay with some petty cash money."

But her main complaint is that finding one's way around stationery catalogues is no easy task. "They are not always very clear. For example, if you want to look for staples you won't always find them under "S" in the index, you'll find them under the name of the make. Equally, my dictionary was under "C" for Collins. They do have a page colour-coding system, which groups things under types of products, such as paper and pens, but it takes some getting used to."

Since stationery is so often seen as one of the few perks of the office, does Frances notice much going walkabout?

"Some of our staff work from home and they order things specifically for home use so they don't need really need to pinch them," she says. But she is aware how easily one good idea can catch on like an office contagion: "I finally got round to ordering a "received" stamp for myself - and now everyone wants one!"

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: Fat cats' slim pickings
fields.body:
Fat cats' slim pickings

Is the day of the fat cat coming to an end? Maybe so, according to new figures which show the rise in big bosses' salaries to be the lowest for several years. The Institute of Management annual pay survey suggests the brakes are being put on bosses' salaries, with increases in pay and bonuses for senior execs well down on last year. Managers received a 5.7% pay rise - down on last year's 6.9% and the lowest in four years. Directors, meanwhile, found 6.2% less cash in their pay packets, a whopping 9% less than in 1999, and the lowest in six years. Despite falling slightly, though, they're still doing better than most of us - the average earnings index for the same period was a more modest 4.8%.

Women only

A training concept developed specifically for women has celebrated its 10th birthday. The Springboard women's development programme was started in 1990 to encourage women to take control of their lives, and to equip them with a positive attitude and the skills to develop to their full potential. To mark the anniversary, an international conference was held at the weekend, bringing together trainers from nine countries, who between them have delivered courses to 130,000 women during the past decade. For more info on the organisation, call 01453 878540.

Being the boss

Being promoted is exciting, but it can be tricky if you find yourself in authority over your previous peers. In Managing for the First Time (Institute of Personnel and Development, £5.95), Cherry Mill offers practical advice on how to survive promotion without alienating your old colleagues. She recommends being open with friends from the outset, and building an agreement of how you will work together. She says it helps to establish your credibility early on, and do things that have needed doing for some time. The book offers a five-point plan for your first 100 days covering what you need to learn, who you need to meet and what you need to achieve. From Plymbridge Distributors on 01752 202301.

The value of Wales

If you need to organise a conference or event in the UK, but want to avoid London prices, try Wales. A report by the British Association of Conference Destinations into 40 popular regions and cities found that north Wales offers excellent value. The average rate is £17.50 per delegate per day - in some places you can pay nearer £150. Events can be co-ordinated by North Wales Conference, a one-stop bureau of specialists who offer free help with planning, itineraries, leisure activities, and bed booking. For details on what north Wales has to offer call 01492 574009.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 23: Drawing pins
fields.trailText: Bombay duck is really a fish. Plus-fours have nothing to do with sums. And drawing pins are really useless for drawing with. It is sadly not recorded how many unwitting PAs have sat down to sketch the Serpentine at dusk only to open the box and wish they had ordered a 2B pencil instead of a box of brass tacks.
fields.body:
Bombay duck is really a fish. Plus-fours have nothing to do with sums. And drawing pins are really useless for drawing with. It is sadly not recorded how many unwitting PAs have sat down to sketch the Serpentine at dusk only to open the box and wish they had ordered a 2B pencil instead of a box of brass tacks.

What drawing pins are great for however, as any cartoon character will tell you, is impeding the progress of Wile E Coyete, the Anthill Mob or the Mystery Mobile in a high-speed jalopy chase. Scatter a box on the road and before you can say "ACME", your pursuer will promptly disappear over a cliff, with only a small protruding twig between him and oblivion.

This is not to be advised in the office, however. Within a work environment, it is fair to say that drawing-pin enthusiasts should confine themselves to the implements' proper purpose, which is - rather dully - to hold little bits of paper on the wall. Hirings, firings and this week's menu in the canteen would be lost without little brass tacks to attach them to notice boards. Well, they wouldn't be lost, they would be on the floor below the board, but who is going to read them there? Noticeboard habitues will of course be familiar with the first rule of drawing pins, which is that there is always one pin less than you need to hold upthose important staff notices.

Drawing pins are also known as thumb tacks, which is another misnomer, since if anything it is the heel which they attack. This may have developed as an evolutionary defence against office workers defying dress code and going barefoot.

But any temptation to scatter a couple on your boss's chair is to be avoided at all costs. Humorous cartoon-like yelping might ensue, but it is likely to be accompanied by less than amusing swift dismissal.

webTitle: Don't be fooled by the fog of war

fields.headline: Don't be fooled by the fog of war
fields.trailText: In the aftermath of the prime minister's brush with the WI, a poll yesterday showed Labour's lead over the Tories down to 3%. For the first time since he was elected leader of the Conservative party almost three years ago, it is now conceivable that William Hague will win the next election. Of course, the odds are still against it, but six months ago bookmakers weren't even taking bets.
fields.body:
In the aftermath of the prime minister's brush with the WI, a poll yesterday showed Labour's lead over the Tories down to 3%. For the first time since he was elected leader of the Conservative party almost three years ago, it is now conceivable that William Hague will win the next election. Of course, the odds are still against it, but six months ago bookmakers weren't even taking bets.

This should give the government and its supporters pause for thought. Labour needs to work out whether its strategy from here to polling day is to be for the prime minister to stand above politics and try to pull together a big-tent coalition or if it is prepared to make some enemies. Both avenues have been explored over the past month - by Gordon Brown in his attack on Oxbridge elitism and the prime minister with his WI speech - but neither has been conspicuously successful. However, the government runs the risk of appearing totally confused and rudderless if it tries to face both ways at once, so it has to choose between the two strategies.

The strength of the economy remains Labour's most potent electoral weapon, and the Conservative party's biggest problem. So far, all we know about Hague's intentions is that he wants to match Labour's spending commitments on health and education but also give a guarantee that taxes will be cut. This is unlikely to stand up to the scrutiny of an election campaign, particularly if inflation remains low, unemployment is still falling and real incomes continue to rise. There should be a powerful feel-good factor working in the government's favour but, as John Major found in 1997, the old rule that parties are not turfed out when the economy is doing well no longer applies. Voters are more cynical and capricious than they were, and the government will be vulnerable unless it clarifies what its message is going to be.

Labour has been in this position before. As Neal Lawson, the impeccably Blairite editor of Renewal, said recently, the prime minister's "forces of conservatism" speech at last year's party conference got under the skin of the right by giving them something to fear, but the government quickly rowed back."Instead of finally chucking someone out of the bloody tent, we backed down. We did not want to define the enemy."

Lawson's conclusion is that the landslide of 1997 did not empower the government but rather imposed severe limits on what it could hope to achieve. "Our challenge is to deepen our political roots, not to herd a flock of nervous sheep within the tent of 'one nation'. Satisfying no one for fear of offending anyone is unsustainable. We cannot continue being all things to all people."

Brown's remarks certainly offended some people, not just on the right, which reacted with ferocity to the idea that the dice should stop being loaded in favour of the already privileged, but from the metropolitan left which, after whingeing for three years about New Labour's lack of radicalism, turned and fled at the first whiff of grapeshot. The chancellor, if we are to believe some of the hyperbolic guff written in the past couple of weeks, seized on the Laura Spence affair to relaunch the class war.

In class-war terms, the notion that if state-school children account for two-thirds of those getting three As at A level they should get more than half the places at Oxbridge is hardly revolutionary. It is the equivalent of a bit of guerilla action behind enemy lines. But it was portrayed as the first day of the Somme, with Field Marshal Brown sending the flower of Britain's privately educated officer corps over the top to be impaled on the barbed wire of egalitarianism and mown down by the machine gun fire of class envy.

That the right should promulgate this tosh is par for the course. However, when the chancellor looked around for reinforcements from his friends on the left they were a bit thin on the ground.

Brown believes that the debate about elitism in education looks a lot different from outside the M25 than it does from Hampstead and he is probably right. In the real world, Labour supporters, members and voters are rather more likely - either through inclination or lack of money - to send their children to state schools. Moreover, it makes no sense for the government to devote more resources to state schools and insist that they improve standards if the end product is children from lessadvantaged backgrounds getting a worse deal. All of the main players - Blair, Brown and David Blunkett - are committed to "opportunities for all" but the narrative only makes sense if there is opportunity from top to bottom.

The rejoinder, much heard in the aftermath of the Laura Spence affair, that the government could do more by increasing spending on state education or by depriving the private sector of its financial privileges, is fair enough. One of the benefits of the row is that the political ground has now been cleared for higher spending on schools, and that will duly be delivered next month. Sadly, the removal of charitable status or the imposition of VAT on school fees are not on the government's agenda.

None of this adds up to class war. Some of the things that happened under the Conservatives might justly be classified as such - the increase in claimant count unemployment to three million (twice), the widening of income differentials, the cut in state education spending as a proportion of GDP, the abolition of the metropolitan authorities, the curbs on trade unions, the rate-capping of local authorities. But the notion that university admissions should be based on fairness and merit rather than the ability to pay? That the government should lean into the wind and stand up for the 93% who send their children to state schools rather than the 7% who don't? This is class war? Do me a favour.

Like all governments, Labour is finding that you cannot please all the people all the time. Government is about choosing between priorities - such as whether the dividend for economic growth is higher spending rather than tax cuts, whether to use fiscal policy to redistribute money from rich to poor. Labour's actions have shown where its priorities lie: the big surpluses built up since 1997 will come down over the next few years, not because taxes are being cut but because public capital expenditure is being doubled (albeit from a low base), child benefit has been increased, the minimum wage has been introduced and those on low incomes are seeing real improvements in their living standards as a result of the working families tax credit.

Critics of the government argue that huge problems of inequality and poverty remain. They are right. Britain is a country in which class still matters and a sense of powerlessness runs deep. As Robert Pollin points out in the latest New Left Review, there has been no real trickle-down effect in America's so-called miracle economy. The earnings of the lowest-paid workers are lower than they were in the Reagan-Bush years and wage inequality has increased under Clinton.

There is a message in this, for the government and for its supporters. It is possible for Labour to pursue policies that are popular across the whole country, but it should not be afraid of showing that its first concern is for those who have least. Labour's supporters should think a bit harder about what happened between 1979 and 1997 before falling for the line that there is no difference between a vote for Blair and a vote for Hague. There is. The Tories and their friends in the press never forget that Labour is the enemy and that the real object of politics is power, not opposition.

Moreover, it makes no sense for the government to devote more resources to state schools and insist that they improve standards if the end product is children from lessadvantaged backgrounds getting a worse deal. All of the main players - Blair, Brown and David Blunkett - are committed to "opportunities for all" but the narrative only makes sense if there is opportunity from top to bottom. The rejoinder, much heard in the aftermath of the Laura Spence affair, that the government could do more by increasing spending on state education or by depriving the private sector of its financial privileges, is fair enough. One of the benefits of the row is that the political ground has now been cleared for higher spending on schools, and that will duly be delivered next month. Sadly, the removal of charitable status or the imposition of VAT on school fees are not on the government's agenda. None of this adds up to class war. Some of the things that happened under the Conservatives might justly be classified as such - the increase in claimant count unemployment to three million (twice), the widening of income differentials, the cut in state education spending as a proportion of GDP, the abolition of the metropolitan authorities, the curbs on trade unions, the rate-capping of local authorities. But the notion that university admissions should be based on fairness and merit rather than the ability to pay? That the government should lean into the wind and stand up for the 93% who send their children to state schools rather than the 7% who don't? This is class war? Do me a favour. Like all governments, Labour is finding that you cannot please all the people all the time. Government is about choosing between priorities - such as whether the dividend for economic growth is higher spending rather than tax cuts, whether to use fiscal policy to redistribute money from rich to poor. Labour's actions have shown where its priorities lie: the big surpluses built up since 1997 will come down over the next few years, not because taxes are being cut but because public capital expenditure is being doubled (albeit from a low base), child benefit has been increased, the minimum wage has been introduced and those on low incomes are seeing real improvements in their living standards as a result of the working families tax credit. Critics of the government argue that huge problems of inequality and poverty remain. They are right. Britain is a country in which class still matters and a sense of powerlessness runs deep. As Robert Pollin points out in the latest New Left Review, there has been no real trickle-down effect in America's so-called miracle economy. The earnings of the lowest-paid workers are lower than they were in the Reagan-Bush years and wage inequality has increased under Clinton. There is a message in this, for the government and for its supporters. It is possible for Labour to pursue policies that are popular across the whole country, but it should not be afraid of showing that its first concern is for those who have least. Labour's supporters should think a bit harder about what happened between 1979 and 1997 before falling for the line that there is no difference between a vote for Blair and a vote for Hague. There is. The Tories and their friends in the press never forget that Labour is the enemy and that the real object of politics is power, not opposition. larry.elliott@theguardian.com

webTitle: MoD denies abducting injured Kosovo gunman

fields.headline: MoD denies abducting injured Kosovo gunman
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence yesterday denied that British soldiers who snatched an injured gunman from a hospital bed in Kosovo during a night-time operation had been guilty of abduction and brutality.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence yesterday denied that British soldiers who snatched an injured gunman from a hospital bed in Kosovo during a night-time operation had been guilty of abduction and brutality.

Nebojsa Stojanovic, who is accused of threatening to shoot Brigadier Richard Shirreff, the highest ranking British soldier in the region, was taken from a Kosovan clinic to a British field hospital in Pristina in the early hours of Thursday morning because of fears he would abscond.

The man had been shot in the shoulder during a riot by Serbs angry at an Albanian drive-by grenade attack in the town of Gracanica on Tuesday morning. Five people, including a woman and a child, were injured when a grenade exploded under a car in the crowded market square.

Brig Shirreff rushed to Gracanica in an attempt to placate the Serbs and to try to restore order, but was caught up in scuffles and surrounded by the crowd, estimated to be more than 300-strong, who were angry that Swedish troops stationed in the town had failed to stop the car that carried out the grenade attack.

As the brigadier's bodyguards drew their weapons to protect themselves, Stojanovic allegedly snatched a pistol from the brigadier's driver and fired the gun four times into the air before threatening the K-For troops with the weapon.

After warning shots fired by the British soldiers were ignored, Stojanovic and two other men were shot at a range of two or three feet.

He was taken to the Kosovan clinic in Gracanica, which is supported by the medical aid charity Medecins du Monde.

Serb doctors and Greek staff are reported to have claimed British troops threatened them with baseball bats before removing the man's intravenous drip and forcefully taking him away in the early hours of Thursday morning.

But a spokesman for the MOD said yesterday: "Soldiers had to force their way into the hospital because it was locked. None of the medical staff was threatened as there were none in the hospital at the time. We've checked with our people in Kosovo and no bats, truncheons or anything else were used.

"This was an operation which seemed to go very successfully so we believe there is no requirement for an investigation.

"The operation was conducted in the middle of the night to prevent anyone getting wind of what was going to happen.

"There had been various demonstrations by the local population during the day about the man being shot in the shoulder. He had to be guarded to avoid the possibility of further civil unrest. The soldiers took medical staff with them to ensure the man was in good health. Fortunately, he was and offered no resistance."

Stojanovic was taken to the British field hospital five miles away in Pristina, where he was questioned by UN police about the shooting.

The incident in Gracanica, five miles from Pristina, was the first serious clash this year between Serbs and international peacekeepers in Kosovo.

Eight Serbs have been killed by Albanians in Kosovo in the last week. The Serb national council said the grenade attack was the latest "wave of organised Albanian terrorist groups seeking to expel Serbs from Kosovo."

fields.headline: Welcome to Charlieville
fields.standfirst:
Wander round the neat streets and old-fashioned squares of Poundbury and you could be in an ancient Tuscan town - though nothing is more than 10 years old. There's an organic market, signs are hidden and ball games aren't allowed. Andy Beckett visits the village in Dorset which is fast becoming a metaphor for the man behind it

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Wander round the neat streets and old-fashioned squares of Poundbury and you could be in an ancient Tuscan town - though nothing is more than 10 years old. There's an organic market, signs are hidden and ball games aren't allowed.  Andy Beckett  visits the village in Dorset which is fast becoming a metaphor for the man behind it
fields.body:
In Poundbury, gravel is an issue. At first sight, raked across the wandering pavements of Prince Charles's ideal village in Dorset, the tiny stones give the streets an attractively dusty air. When the sun shines, the cottage shadows cut the roads into tourist-brochure triangles; you could almost be in Siena, the prince's favourite town in Tuscany. And when you walk in Poundbury, as you are much encouraged to, the pavements and old-fashioned squares and courtyards crunch beneath your feet. Every step seems a slightly formal public gesture. It feels like being at a royal garden party.

It is not quite as special for the residents. Some of them have been here for six years now, while the prince's town planning experiment has grown from a handful of houses to 200, enduring the builders and visiting dignitaries, the peering tourists and reporters. Yet, more than anything, they are tired of the gravel.

"That fucking stuff goes into the house," says an otherwise cheery retired man in cords and an anorak. The woman he is talking to gestures at her front door. "Everyone is doormat-obsessed," she says. "Because of the gravel." It spreads across the narrow roads, forms drifts in the gutters, gets stuck under people's shoes. A tide of small stones lies halfway up her doormat. A few rogue fragments have almost made it to the carpet.

The man interjects: "Of course, there's a security upside. It makes it difficult for burglars." The village has barely suffered a break-in in its history, he says. The woman, who is younger, perhaps in her 30s, interrupts in turn. "But you can't go round and sleep with your neighbour."

The preoccupations and peculiarities of Poundbury, like those of its patron, have long exercised a certain fascination. From its conception in the late 80s, to the planning battles and compromises of the early 90s, to its painstaking expansion since 1993, this tight hilltop maze of white walls and beige stone has become a steadily more vivid metaphor for Charles's approaching rule.

The local taxi drivers call it "Charlieville". To its critics, it is a royal vanity - social engineering driven by self-interest (Charles owns the land and profits from every house sale) and contradictory ideals (some properties are rented cheaply through a housing association, but the use of traditional building materials makes the others more expensive than the Dorset norm). Architectural authorities, in particular, point out that Poundbury is going up, fake antique brick by fake antique brick, just when public taste is finally turning to modernity. In the London Evening Standard last year, a panel of design writers chose Poundbury as one of "The 99 Worst Things This Century".

But its supporters are swelling in number. Last month, a government report praised its densely clustered homes, attention to detail and emphasis on pedestrians as a healthy alternative to the usual suburban sprawl. In 1998, John Prescott visited. "What is being done here," he said, "is very important work for this country's urban future." Poundbury's theme-park quality - its cosy reproduction of features from existing ancient villages and market towns - may actually fulfil the desires of English house-buyers. With millions of new dwellings needed, especially in southern counties like Dorset, the prince's little prototype kingdom is planned to expand far beyond its current 400 subjects. It could, to different degrees, be the future for all of us.

You approach it off a roundabout. Poundbury, like Charles, is not a self-contained entity but the latest addition to an ancient institution - in this case, the former Roman town of Dorchester. Poundbury is out by the bypass, beyond the genteel Georgian facades, the Victorian terraces and the 20s council houses. The weather on this side of town is locally described as "draughty".

Amid the crisp new walls and doorstep plant pots, along the roads free of dustbins and litter and modern traffic markings, whole minutes pass without a pedestrian. The odd builder's van or resident's Volvo squeezes round the blind corners, grumpily changing gear. Barely another sound carries across the rooftops. In the squares, the benches stand expectant and unused. The prince's saplings rustle in the breeze.

There is only one shop. A pub and cafe and corner shop are planned to open later this summer; until then, to gossip and get out of the rain, people have had to make do with an interior design showroom. The Stitchinghouse has no sign outside - Charles disapproves of gaudy shop fronts - and closes at four in the afternoon. At lunchtime, there are two people in the shop, discussing archery and Nigel Kennedy's failure to shave.

Sue McCarthy-Moore, the owner, is sewing a quilted curtain attachment. She is very keen on Poundbury. "I've lived here since the beginning," she says. "It's safe. It's friendly . . . I like the attention to detail. I think it's nice not to have TV aerials and telegraph poles." In a loud, well-informed voice, she takes issue with a recent newspaper letter from the architect Richard Rogers criticising Poundbury. "People here get interested in design. There's zero crime. People look out for each other." She picks up the cushion by one of its reproduction brass rings. "At least Charles was brave enough to have a go."

Her neighbours appear to agree. They are retired couples, many of them, who wear the country uniform of the prosperous: smart cardigans and cords, green quilted jackets and V-necked jumpers just like Charles's. For royalists, there are a reassuring number of Commonwealth citizens. A dapper man from Sydney is unloading books from a lorry. Is he worried about the wind? "They're supposed to be very fuel efficient houses."

Poundbury feels carefully worked out. There is a monthly organic market and an alternative medicine clinic. There is a business park, with factory buildings like Tuscan farm compounds, their ugly money-making ducts and pipes hidden behind red towers and pretty walls. There is a maker of "fine chocolates" and a cereal manufacturer promoting "healthy eating".

The prince's every crusade and polemic is represented here in picture-postcard form. A manifesto of sorts has been inscribed on the inside of the Millennium Belvedere Tower, a small stone pavilion in a field on the southern edge of the settlement, quoting Clough Williams-Ellis, the architect of the utopian Welsh village Portmeirion: "We must preserve what may be of our ancient heritage . . . that desolation be stayed, that standards of graciousness may here and there persist."

The Poundbury ideal took shape during that great decade of revivals, the 80s. In 1984, the prince began attacking modern architecture and praising the "eternal", "natural" forms and ways of life that had only really existed in Britain before the Industrial Revolution. By 1989, with his television documentary and polemical volume, A Vision of Britain, a programme for rescuing his future kingdom from concrete and alienation had been devised. "We do not have to live in surroundings that directly reflect the latest technology," he wrote. Instead, developments should be built "on a more intimate scale"; "a sense of hierarchy" should be restored to buildings; "good lettering must be taught and learned".

To illustrate these principles, he would "produce something of real beauty in the English countryside". Through the Duchy of Cornwall, which had provided an income for male heirs to the throne since the 14th century, the prince owned large pockets of south-west England. One piece of land was outside Dorchester; the local council wanted to see houses built on it. The result was Poundbury.

Its evolution has not been as natural as its royal overseer probably intended. Its Englishness, for one thing, was in question from the start: Leon Krier, the planner Charles chose, was from Luxembourg; and Krier's initial models imagined Poundbury as a perfect Italian town, with campaniles, rotundas and unlikely-looking trees from the Mediterranean. These grand designs had to be simplified and shrunk and made to reflect the settlement's cool, green surroundings. The property price slide of the early 90s slowed construction further.

Yet nowadays, at the small Duchy outpost in Poundbury, modest satisfaction is the order of the day. The houses are selling. "He's happy, I think - generally," says Simon Conibear, the development manager. Plans for buildings still go to the prince, but he consults before making his mind up. His exercise of power over the hilltop is "constitutional".

As Charles's ambassador in the village, Conibear has two ways of behaving. Out in the street, in his old-fashioned suit, he strides through endless tours, greets locals, and even borrows a phrase from the anti-capitalist protests: "We've reclaimed the streets from cars." But in his office, amid the bright lighting and decor that usually sits behind Poundbury facades, he is much more hard-headed. "This is the most profitable development per acre in Dorchester," he says. He shows the plans for the settlement's ultimate shape: over 2,000 buildings, over 6,000 inhabitants, the current "village" a mere thumbnail. "A few key houses with period detail," he says. "Fill in the gaps with a lot of concrete blocks and render."

Poundbury's air of quiet can deceive in other ways. It is, to an extent, an enforced calm: there are rules against ball games in public courtyards; rules against altering the outside of properties; a £70 annual charge for the upkeep of the roadside trees and flowerbeds. And there is the residents' association. Attendance at meetings is high. Warnings are given about talking to reporters. References in the minutes to "the Poundbury Concept" are in capital letters. A recent minor bit of vandalism is crossly attributed to culprits "not local to Poundbury".

Yet the place has its tensions. The social housing, to look at, is admirable: well built, no smaller than the rest, discreetly scattered. Young mothers and men with tattoos tend their flowers like everyone else. But the talk, in the clinic's pristine waiting room, is of "slight trouble". The two smartly dressed women murmur on: "You can't have someone who's paid £250,000 for a house living next to someone who . . ." They are both nodding before the end of the sentence.

Poundbury would like to attract fewer wealthy retired people, Conibear says. Then, perhaps, the curtains will stop twitching when its small population of children scamper over the gravel. Then the unfriendly little notices against parking too close will stop going up on front doors. And the contradictory experiment of the contradictory prince, environmentalist and sports-car collector, estate-dweller and advocate of terraced housing, will work more smoothly. Until then, after the builders have gone in the evenings, two small boys with golf clubs are determined, it seems, to use the prince's buildings for target practice.

webTitle: Young lion takes on the old guard

fields.headline: Young lion takes on the old guard
fields.standfirst:
With very little grooming, Bashar has been thrust into battle against his father's close, but seemingly corrupt, circle of loyalists
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Bashar Assad, formally designated as successor to the Syrian presidency in a rash of decrees designed to bolster his legitimacy, will need all of his father's toughness if he is to impose himself on the old guard of party, army and security services.
fields.body:
Bashar Assad, formally designated as successor to the Syrian presidency in a rash of decrees designed to bolster his legitimacy, will need all of his father's toughness if he is to impose himself on the old guard of party, army and security services.

They will resist him, not merely out of jealousy for their personal power and privileges, but out of a conviction that he risks undermining the whole existing order of which, as a "branch of the Assad tree", he was selected to uphold.

Only last week it began to look as though his anti-corruption drive was threatening to turn into an overt power struggle between the old guard and his new one. Its latest target was a true pillar of the system, General Hikmet Shehabi, a former chief of staff. He was said to have amassed millions in deals with the Russians, and to have concealed his own and others' embezzlements from the president. The old guard were reacting vigorously in the face of an on slaught which threatened them all.

If that could happen when his father was still alive to hold the ring, how much more serious could it become now?

Bashar Assad was not the original candidate for the presidency. That fell to his elder brother Basil. Only when, in 1994, Basil died at the wheel of his sports car did the father turn to the younger, more retiring and intellectually inclined sibling.

At the time, in a first unofficial hint at what was never officially admitted, a high-ranking officer said: "Al-Assad ['the lion'] bears cubs. The first has dropped out of sight, but God brings help along with woe. The same storm that broke the first branch brought the second one into the light of day."

The officer, now close to Bashar, was speaking of a remarkable phenomenon in the contemporary Arab world. This is the way in which republican regimes, in their maturity, emulate the traditional dynasties which, as former "revolutionaries", they were once bent on sweeping away. In a kind of republican primogeniture, autocratic leaders groom their sons to succeed them. The idea is that the installation of their nearest possible reincarnation will enable the narrow ruling elites to preserve themselves against popular pressure for new, and more representative, forms of government. It is happening in President Saddam's Iraq, Gadafi's Libya, possibly even in Mubarak's Egypt. But Syria is the first place where the concept will be put to the test.

Bashar was studying ophthalmology in London when, in a sudden change of destiny, he was summoned back to Syria. His grooming for supreme office began with a crash course of military training from which he emerged as a tank commander. This was clearly considered essential in a regime whose backbone is the army and security services; it also brought him into personal contact with some of the officers of his generation, with whom he would later be dealing as president.

At the same time, he was promoted as the embodiment of a new generation, in tune with the contemporary world in a way which the regime, a relic from the era of Soviet-style totalitarianism, was not; he stood for transparency, dynamism, efficiency, and the liberalisation of a creaking, command economy. He was enthusiastic about anything relating to science and technology. He pushed for the introduction of the internet, which the regime had strenuously resisted as a "threat to security". He assumed important foreign policy responsibilities; he was put in charge of the key "Lebanon file".

Within the Ba'ath party apparatus he was associated with an up-and-coming "camp of change" at loggerheads with an old guard of entrenched and privileged apparatchiks. Taking command of a "war on corruption", he made little secret of his ambition to target high-ranking people, within the his father's loyalist old guard, whom he saw as the chief culprits.

But, characteristically of Assad's Syria, his ascent was intended to be slow and steady. Till now he has held no formal position within the state or party hierarchy. And in so far as the completion of the process had a date on it, it was to be the year 2006, when his father would have ended his sixth seven-year term of office, at the age of 75. He himself would have reached the age of 40 which under the constitution was the minimum required for supreme office.

But now his father's un timely death has thrown this schedule to the winds. Within hours the parliament obligingly amended the constitution to accommodate a 34-year old successor. Next week the Ba'ath party will hold its ninth plenary congress at which it plans to nominate Bashar for the presidency, a one-man candidacy which will then be put to a referendum.

Will he be up to the job? He appears to have many good qualities. He is described as modest and thoughtful, intelligent, even brilliant. He knows the outside world; he speaks both French and English.

He will have to impose not only himself, but his ideas of reform and change on the old guard. It is the kind of challenge which Bashar will have to take on if he is to fulfil the minimum hopes - what semi-official rhetoric calls "change amid continuity" - which the people have been encouraged to invest in him. What their maximum hopes might be, with the opportunities that the sudden end to 30 years of one-man rule will surely throw up, is another matter.

fields.headline: Gloomy prospect for peace process
fields.standfirst:
A new key player means delays at best
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The future of the Middle East peace process hung in the balance yesterday following the death of President Assad. Only last week the Syrian track - stalled since January - appeared to be on the point of revival. But now, in the words of a US state department official, everything is "up in the air" again. Talcott Sealy, a former US ambassador to Damascus, put it more strongly, describing Assad's death as a menace to the peace process. "It's really a setback," he said.
fields.body:
The future of the Middle East peace process hung in the balance yesterday following the death of President Assad. Only last week the Syrian track - stalled since January - appeared to be on the point of revival. But now, in the words of a US state department official, everything is "up in the air" again. Talcott Sealy, a former US ambassador to Damascus, put it more strongly, describing Assad's death as a menace to the peace process. "It's really a setback," he said.

Although the president's 35-year-old son, Bashar, is regarded as modern and forward-looking, without his father's political and historical baggage, he may not have much room to manoeuvre - at least within the tight timetable set by the Americans and Israelis for the peace process.

Bashar is popular with younger Syrians but as yet he has no legitimacy. The hasty amendment of the constitution - just hours after his father's death - to reduce the qualifying age for the presidency from 40 to 34 and allow Bashar's nomination, shows how precarious his succession is.

If all goes according to plan, parliament will nominate him as the only candidate for the presidency on June 25. The people will then be asked to approve his appointment in a referendum, to be held within 90 days. Until his position is confirmed, it is unlikely that Bashar - or anyone else in Syria - will be able to make serious moves in the peace process. That in itself may well frustrate Washington's goal of striking a deal before the US presidential election.

The negotiations with Israel stalled over a few yards of land at the foot of the Golan Heights - occupied by Israel in 1967 - on the shores of Lake Galilee, with Syria insisting on access to the lake, though not the use of its waters. Various fudges have been proposed unofficially which might satisfy both parties, but Israel has been reluctant to consider them without a signal from Damascus that such a deal would bring "warm peace" between the two countries - something that Hafez Assad was probably incapable of delivering.

This view was echoed by the Palestinian peace negotiator Saeb Erekat, who said yesterday that it would be hard for any successor in Syria to be flexible in future peace talks with Israel because of Assad's uncompromising legacy.

"President Assad's legacy was that a full peace with Israel meant full withdrawal of Israel to the 1967 borders. I don't think anyone in Syria will come and accept anything less than this," Mr Erekat said in an interview.

"And therefore Israel has to realise that to make peace means it has to withdraw to the June 1967 borders on both the Syrian and Palestinian tracks," he said.

Bashar might be more amenable, but whether he is prepared to adopt a different approach will depend largely on how secure he feels back home.

The Israeli government argues that it will have difficulty selling a withdrawal from Golan to the public, but this would become easier if Syria were to make a dramatic ice-breaking gesture - something like the historic visit that the late Egyptian president, Anwar Sadat, paid to Israel.

But Assad, along with many other Arabs, regarded Sadat's visit to Jerusalem as a mistake and argued that successful negotiations should end with handshakes, not start with them. "I am not Anwar Sadat and it is not my ambition to become Yasser Arafat," he was quoted as telling President Clinton last March. The Syrians also suspected that they were being stampeded into a compromise by the US-Israeli timetable merely to help salvage President Clinton's reputation.

There are two alternative scenarios of how Bashar's succession might affect the present stalemate. One is that he will need more time to consolidate his power and that he will try to avoid any decisions that, in the eyes of the Syrian establishment, his father would have disagreed with. If that turns out to be the case, the Syrian track may remain on hold for a year or two.

The other scenario is that with his more open character, he may feel that the time has come to solve the problem that dogged his father's presidency for so many years. He would, however, have to secure favourable terms with the Israelis or his domestic position would be undermined.

There is also the question of Syria's Siamese twin: Lebanon, where Bashar's initial weakness will increase pressure from Israel, and perhaps more subtly from the Lebanese, to withdraw Syrian troops. Israel has been taunting Syria on this point ever since it withdrew its own troops from southern Lebanon last month. The Syrians are also unpopular with Lebanese citizens, many of whom would like to see the back of them but are reluctant to say so in public.

Syria can, however, claim to be a stabilising influence in Lebanon - pointing out that it helped to prevent the predicted turmoil following the Israeli withdrawal. President Assad generally judged the Lebanese situation shrewdly. Whether Bashar will be able to handle Lebanon so skilfully may depend on whether he is diverted by challenges at home.

webTitle: Cruel cut for footsoldiers of the Golan

fields.headline: Cruel cut for footsoldiers of the Golan
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Safadi Mahana's mission ended yesterday, or perhaps it was finally aborted. Thirty-three years after signing on as a partisan to liberate the Golan Heights from Israel in a brief audience with Hafez al-Assad that is forever seared in his memory, he finds himself alone, an aging foot soldier with no commander.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Majdal Shams, Golan Heights
fields.body:
Safadi Mahana's mission ended yesterday, or perhaps it was finally aborted. Thirty-three years after signing on as a partisan to liberate the Golan Heights from Israel in a brief audience with Hafez al-Assad that is forever seared in his memory, he finds himself alone, an aging foot soldier with no commander.

And so Mr Mahana and thousands of other Druze residents of the high, yellow-grassed plateau of the Golan yesterday began three days of mourning for Assad, clutching faded portraits of their dead leader to their chests.

Shops and schools were closed, and black flags fluttered from lampposts and rooftops. In the central square, they raised the Syrian tricolour - an offence punished with jail under normal circumstances.

It was a fitting tribute. For the people of Majdal Shams, the largest town in the heights that Israel has occupied since 1967, Assad is seen as a saviour who was just waiting for his moment to arrive.

His implacable opposition to the Zionist state, and his refusal to countenance a peace that would leave a single blade of the Golan under Israeli rule, comforted them during the long years of occupation.

But three decades passed, during which the Syrian bunkers on the upper stretches of the Golan have been turned into tourist attractions.

At last they must admit he will never arrive. "There is no more painful time for us. The Arab world has lost a great leader, but we in the Golan have lost a man who was the father of us all," Khatir Wasif, a local doctor, said. "We all prayed that we would meet him, that he would come to free us in the Golan. Now he is not coming, but we will continue to follow on his path, the path of Syria."

Today, Mr Wasif is to join a delegation of notables from Majdal Shams who will journey to Damascus for Assad's funeral. The village elders are hoping to meet his heir, Bashar.

He does not even dare to hope that Bashar Assad will turn his thoughts towards making a peace with Israel that could unite the people of Majdal Shams with friends and family across the barbed wire fence. However, he would like Bashar to know that he already commands the allegiance of the people of Majdal Shams. And they will wait for his instructions - just as Safadi Mahana did 33 years ago.

Three months after Syria's defeat in the war, the former maths teacher was summoned to a meeting the then-defence minister, Assad, in Damascus.

"He said: 'We have lost a war and a whole Arab nation is mourning, but I believe that we can recover if we are strong'," he recalls. "He asked me to go back to Majdal Shams and to work for Syria - not with weapons, but in a political way. He said I must fight for the soul of people living under the Jews. I was proud to follow him."

For his devotion, Mr Mahana spent more than five years in Israeli jails. He has not been able to work as a teacher since.

But he is a hero to a younger generation sunning themselves in the square after the procession of mourners passed. Although they switch between Hebrew and Syrian-accented Arabic with ease, and have a passing acquaintance with the club scene in Tel Aviv, the younger generation has no doubt where its loyalties lie.

"I was born here, in what is now Israel, but Assad was still my president, and this land is still Syria," a 25-year-old construction worker said. "Everything else is just an accident."

fields.headline: Waving? Or drowning?
fields.standfirst:
Today a Guardian poll reveals that, for the first time, less than half the population supports the royal family. But that doesn't seem to be dampening their spirits - next week they're all getting together to celebrate the birthdays of William and the Queen Mother. Beginning a special in-depth royal issue, Christopher Hitchens wonders what the future holds

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Today a Guardian poll reveals that, for the first time, less than half the population supports the royal family. But that doesn't seem to be dampening their spirits - next week they're all getting together to celebrate the birthdays of William and the Queen Mother. Beginning a special in-depth royal issue,  Christopher Hitchens  wonders what the future holds
fields.body:
I was being driven back from Hay-on-Wye to London one gorgeous morning in late May when, just as the motorway traffic began to thicken, we spotted a royal limousine immediately ahead. A crest and shield, and a flag or standard, and the opaque numberplate AEI were the only exterior clues to the occupant. The head in the rear window appeared to be female and white-haired, and I thought - because after all, my God, there are so many of them - is that Princess Alexandra? Or Princess Michael of Kent? Or some other noble pensioner (of the sort you often hear described as "the hangers-on")?

My driver, who I am pleased to say was perfectly indifferent, indulged my faint curiosity and so, until some turn-off near Windsor, we were sometimes right behind the royal progress, occasionally in front of it, and more than once cruising right alongside.

The experience of being a republican has, over the last decade or so, rather resembled that encounter. There have been moments - the revelations about tax-dodging, the horrors of Prince Philip's diplomacy in China, the endless matrimonial squalor and tedium - when one has thought, yes, we're finally leaving them behind. And there have been moments - the Blair-scripted Palace concession to the cortege of Princess Diana, for example - when it has seemed that populism and royalism are joined at the hip and cannot be put asunder.

Much of the time, though, the House of Windsor is only in society's peripheral vision; marginally relevant to the regional and constitutional metamorphosis through which we are passing, almost completely irrelevant to the European dimension, and fulfilling neither the "dignified" nor the "efficient" parts of the role that Walter Bagehot famously assigned to it.

Yet even the appearance of a slow decline into mediocrity may be deceptive. In the next two months, we will be subjected - we are, after all, subjects - to birthday celebrations of the only two "royals" who approach anything like the charismatic. One of them, as I cannot pretend not to know, will be 100 and the other, as I was actually quite startled to learn, will be 18. Of the old lady of Clarence House, I have nothing to say; literally nothing occurs to me. She appears to have had a goodish innings. Of the presumptive next king but one, I also lack an opinion. I have nothing to go on. He is, however, physically quite hauntingly reminiscent of his departed mama. I wonder what the gloomy old Balmoral faction thinks, and how the gloomy old Balmoral faction feels, when it surveys this blond and fluted and gentle-seeming reminder of the neurotic girl who was so ill-used, and whose name was struck out of the Church of England's prayers for the royal family a few weeks before she died, and who was stripped of her coveted title as a Royal Highness.

What it may think and feel, of course, is that God is in some way still on its side. What a piece of uncanny good fortune, that a Prince Charming should have survived what looked like an irretrievable moral and public relations wreck, to become a wholly-owned subsidiary of the very "Firm" which repudiated his mother. It's almost enough to make one superstitious. Just as the centenarian is making her final arrangements, and just as the thought of Charles remaining in waiting until he is 70 becomes a distinct possibility, a cherubic distraction is suddenly offered free, gratis and for nothing, and the encrusted old oil painting is cleaned to reveal a blithe and hitherto unsuspected figure.

What excellent timing, then, for the Prince of Wales to attempt another trial run with the only woman he's ever given a damn about. On the Sunday following my encounter with that shapely Daimler or Humber, my Sunday Times informed me of a high-level rapprochement at Highgrove between Her Majesty and Camilla Parker-Bowles. It informed me of this by the expedient of making it the splash front-page lead. (Whenever I even think of wavering in my republicanism, or of weakening in the long and unequal struggle, I am confirmed anew by this sort of thing. The monarchy should be abolished if only for the no-brainer effect it has on my profession, and the excruciating banality of the automatic "lead" stories that it dishes out.)

The dinner or luncheon at which this excitement occurred was in honour of the 60th birthday of one Constantine, falsely described as "the exiled King of Greece". He is not an exiled king but an ex-king, having been booted out in a democratic referendum in 1974, and having been lucky to escape heavier punishment for swearing in a fascist military dictatorship in 1967. His Nazi-loving aunt, the former Queen Frederika, was Prince Philip's favourite relative. They order these things better in Greece. Here, we have a succession crisis but don't have the fortitude or honesty to admit it; we hobble along with neither a serious monarchy, nor a self-respecting democracy, but in a quasi-presidential regime with silly royalist trappings.

We are not allowed a referendum on the future of our monarchy, but we are allowed the illusion of a say by means of the opinion poll. Voting in the passive voice is the best we can expect, as we consider the role and function of the only family in the country that still holds formal political power by right of birth. (An odd family to pick, one might say, except that we didn't pick it.) When asked in the recent Guardian poll whether they would prefer the Queen's son or grandson to succeed her in the certain event of her death or the improbable contingency of her abdication, an impressive number of respondents seem already prepared to skip the Charles experience altogether. (Not that they have been asked, or can hope to be consulted.) Even more interesting, the combined votes of the anti-monarchists and the don't care faction actually outweigh the opinion - held by only 44% - of those who feel that Britain would be worse off without the monarchy.

These figures fluctuate vertiginously. But the crucial point, the one to keep your eye on, is this: win or lose, up or down, the monarchy is now an issue. This may not seem so surprising to the 18-24 age group, which reports itself as 40% against the continuation of royalism (24% in favour) but to someone of my advanced years, there is something staggering about it.

As late as at least 1980, and possibly later, no such vulgar probe of public opinion was ever undertaken, or even thought of. The House of Windsor enjoyed the nirvana state of being the apex of our system, while remaining miraculously suspended "above politics". That dreamland has dissipated forever. In 1988, Tom Nairn and I made a TV documentary, eventually screened in the small hours, of his path-breaking republican book The Enchanted Glass. We seemed, to ourselves and others, as quixotic as the village atheist in some Bible Belt state. The monarchy was a given; a still centre in a turning world. Now, in Tom's beloved Scotland, it is at best a piece of obvious veneer. And I can barely remember the last time that my espousal of republican views got me into any kind of hot water.

So to the question we used to ask ourselves - will we live long enough to see them off? - the answer is, in one way, that we already have. The easy, natural, semi-automatic authority and affection have departed. They can no more be revived than the Church of England, or the reputation of Barings, or the letters page of the Times, or the Conservative and Unionist Party.

Which is why I fret about this lad William. With a part of myself, and with a son not far from him in age, I want to fold him in a manly embrace and beseech him not to waste his life mouldering in the ante-chambers to a hollow crown and a vestigial throne. See what it did to your parents? To your Great Aunt Margaret? To your Auntie Annie? Flee while there is yet time; dash the envenomed chalice to the flagstones; mount up and move to California!

With another part of myself, I dread him and I cringe away. If he becomes the unscripted agent of a royal revival, then we are in for the worst of all cultural worlds: the alliance of a discredited hereditary principle with showbiz values and celebrity style. The last time that happened, we got the swinging Edward VIII - a fiesta of narcissism and nastiness (cheered on as a "breath of fresh air", lest we forget, by many liberals) from which only the most dogged and feudal and obscurantist forces ultimately rescued us. We must be able to do better than that choice.

An old English radical slogan has it that the problem is not the will of some to power, but the will of others to obey. I think that it's literally true that many people can't imagine life without the Windsors. And my quarrel is with that very mentality, much more than it is with any actual or potential monarch. One doesn't wish to demolish people's household gods, or rip away their comfort blankets, but couldn't they be just as happy as Jacobites once were, cultivating nostalgia and illusion while leaving the rest of us to get on with it?

The experience of being a monarchist in a British republic, or should I say a federation of English and Scottish and Welsh and Irish republics, might be quite an agreeable one. The pictures of the beloved Queen Mum over the fireplace, the display of Coronation mugs, the tea towels from that cruelly phoney wedding service in 1981 - all these could retain their iconic status. They might even mean more, once they were cut free of a ridiculous feather-bedding subsidy. And they wouldn't have to be officially inflicted upon those who can't any longer bear the sight of them. Parliament could open itself, surely, without permission. Life in general would muddle on.

And what would we put in its place? People obviously need something transcendent; only a philistine denies it. My proposal has always been a reconfiguration of Westminster Abbey. Abolish the patronising name Poet's Corner, and make it into a shrine for our language and literature. Much but not all of this tradition of poetry and prose - Milton, Shelley, Burns, Byron, Wilde - is republican already, as well as reflecting the glories of the Scots and Irish and Welsh. That would be something to show the schoolchildren and (since monarchists always insist on this for some reason) the tourists, too.

Am I dreaming? Not as much as those who think that the Windsors can renew their depleted blood supply from the Spencers.
