fields.bodyText: I was being driven back from Hay-on-Wye to London one gorgeous morning in late May when, just as the motorway traffic began to thicken, we spotted a royal limousine immediately ahead. A crest and shield, and a flag or standard, and the opaque numberplate AEI were the only exterior clues to the occupant. The head in the rear window appeared to be female and white-haired, and I thought - because after all, my God, there are so many of them - is that Princess Alexandra? Or Princess Michael of Kent? Or some other noble pensioner (of the sort you often hear described as "the hangers-on")? My driver, who I am pleased to say was perfectly indifferent, indulged my faint curiosity and so, until some turn-off near Windsor, we were sometimes right behind the royal progress, occasionally in front of it, and more than once cruising right alongside. The experience of being a republican has, over the last decade or so, rather resembled that encounter. There have been moments - the revelations about tax-dodging, the horrors of Prince Philip's diplomacy in China, the endless matrimonial squalor and tedium - when one has thought, yes, we're finally leaving them behind. And there have been moments - the Blair-scripted Palace concession to the cortege of Princess Diana, for example - when it has seemed that populism and royalism are joined at the hip and cannot be put asunder. Much of the time, though, the House of Windsor is only in society's peripheral vision; marginally relevant to the regional and constitutional metamorphosis through which we are passing, almost completely irrelevant to the European dimension, and fulfilling neither the "dignified" nor the "efficient" parts of the role that Walter Bagehot famously assigned to it. Yet even the appearance of a slow decline into mediocrity may be deceptive. In the next two months, we will be subjected - we are, after all, subjects - to birthday celebrations of the only two "royals" who approach anything like the charismatic. One of them, as I cannot pretend not to know, will be 100 and the other, as I was actually quite startled to learn, will be 18. Of the old lady of Clarence House, I have nothing to say; literally nothing occurs to me. She appears to have had a goodish innings. Of the presumptive next king but one, I also lack an opinion. I have nothing to go on. He is, however, physically quite hauntingly reminiscent of his departed mama. I wonder what the gloomy old Balmoral faction thinks, and how the gloomy old Balmoral faction feels, when it surveys this blond and fluted and gentle-seeming reminder of the neurotic girl who was so ill-used, and whose name was struck out of the Church of England's prayers for the royal family a few weeks before she died, and who was stripped of her coveted title as a Royal Highness. What it may think and feel, of course, is that God is in some way still on its side. What a piece of uncanny good fortune, that a Prince Charming should have survived what looked like an irretrievable moral and public relations wreck, to become a wholly-owned subsidiary of the very "Firm" which repudiated his mother. It's almost enough to make one superstitious. Just as the centenarian is making her final arrangements, and just as the thought of Charles remaining in waiting until he is 70 becomes a distinct possibility, a cherubic distraction is suddenly offered free, gratis and for nothing, and the encrusted old oil painting is cleaned to reveal a blithe and hitherto unsuspected figure. What excellent timing, then, for the Prince of Wales to attempt another trial run with the only woman he's ever given a damn about. On the Sunday following my encounter with that shapely Daimler or Humber, my Sunday Times informed me of a high-level rapprochement at Highgrove between Her Majesty and Camilla Parker-Bowles. It informed me of this by the expedient of making it the splash front-page lead. (Whenever I even think of wavering in my republicanism, or of weakening in the long and unequal struggle, I am confirmed anew by this sort of thing. The monarchy should be abolished if only for the no-brainer effect it has on my profession, and the excruciating banality of the automatic "lead" stories that it dishes out.) The dinner or luncheon at which this excitement occurred was in honour of the 60th birthday of one Constantine, falsely described as "the exiled King of Greece". He is not an exiled king but an ex-king, having been booted out in a democratic referendum in 1974, and having been lucky to escape heavier punishment for swearing in a fascist military dictatorship in 1967. His Nazi-loving aunt, the former Queen Frederika, was Prince Philip's favourite relative. They order these things better in Greece. Here, we have a succession crisis but don't have the fortitude or honesty to admit it; we hobble along with neither a serious monarchy, nor a self-respecting democracy, but in a quasi-presidential regime with silly royalist trappings. We are not allowed a referendum on the future of our monarchy, but we are allowed the illusion of a say by means of the opinion poll. Voting in the passive voice is the best we can expect, as we consider the role and function of the only family in the country that still holds formal political power by right of birth. (An odd family to pick, one might say, except that we didn't pick it.) fields.headline: Debt relief stalled
fields.standfirst:
Only five countries have had any benefit

Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: It's nearly a year since the G8 summit in Cologne was hailed as a great victory for the debt campaigners. World leaders claimed to have cracked the problem, it was simply a matter of some number crunching back at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington. By last September, the final details were said to be in place, and Gordon Brown promised debt relief would be a matter of weeks. The campaigners congratulated themselves on a job well done and, ever since, the accepted wisdom has been that the developing world's debt crisis has been solved. Nothing could be further from the truth.
fields.body:
It's nearly a year since the G8 summit in Cologne was hailed as a great victory for the debt campaigners. World leaders claimed to have cracked the problem, it was simply a matter of some number crunching back at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington. By last September, the final details were said to be in place, and Gordon Brown promised debt relief would be a matter of weeks. The campaigners congratulated themselves on a job well done and, ever since, the accepted wisdom has been that the developing world's debt crisis has been solved. Nothing could be further from the truth.

Only five countries have had any debt relief at all (Uganda, Bolivia, Mozambique, Tanzania and Mauritania) and some of that has been pathetically inadequate - the worst case is Tanzania, which has had its debt payments cut by the princely sum of £12m, to £150m a year. No country has had any debt completely cancelled - Uganda has been repeatedly postponed. Yet Mr Brown had promised that by the end of 2000, 25 countries would have had their debts cancelled. As for Mr Brown's famous millennial gesture of 100% cancellation of debts owed to Britain, only Mauritania has so far benefited.

He was right to tie it into the IMF-World Bank debt relief process, but the result is that the relief process has got snarled up, too. There is no shortage of finger-pointing; the US Congress is being criticised for holding up the US pledge of $600m for debt relief while Japan is being blamed for its refusal to prioritise the issue at the G8 summit in Okinawa next month. Mr Brown is frustrated; he has expended considerable effort pushing the issue up the international agenda. Now there is a real danger that the momentum of the international campaign will fade away - and that Jubilee 2000 will close up shop in six months - before its objective has been reached in even one country.

fields.headline: Tobacco firm faces DTI inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: BAT
fields.trailText: British American Tobacco faces an official inquiry into allegations that it actively encouraged and profited from cigarette smuggling after a cross-party committee of MPs agreed to demand an investigation into the London-based company.
fields.body:
British American Tobacco faces an official inquiry into allegations that it actively encouraged and profited from cigarette smuggling after a cross-party committee of MPs agreed to demand an investigation into the London-based company.

A source close to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said he is likely to be "sympathetic" to the committee's call for DTI inspectors to be appointed for what could be an explosive investigation of the tobacco industry.

A unanimous report by the Commons health select committee, to be published on Wednesday, will ask Mr Byers to act under section 432 of the Companies Act.

Inspectors would have the power to go through BAT's books and quiz current and former staff under oath about accusations of suspected fraud and the withholding of information from shareholders by the world's second biggest tobacco company.

The report, endorsed without dissent by the committee's Labour, Liberal Democrat and Conservative members, also strongly criticises advertising by most tobacco firms, claiming that it tries to ensnare non-smokers - directly contradicting industry assurances that advertisements try only to persuade current smokers to switch brands.

Concern will be voiced about the harmful effect of tobacco additives and the government will be put under pressure to improve the industry's regulatory framework.

MPs on the committee, which is chaired by Labour's David Hinchliffe, took the unusual step of taking evidence in person from the tobacco company's chairman, Martin Broughton, three times.

The all-party group is believed to have been dissatisfied with alleged inconsistencies between his replies and those of Kenneth Clarke, the former Conservative chancellor of the exchequer, who is now BAT's vice chairman, about smuggling on the one hand and internal company documents on the other.

BAT papers disclosed in the Guardian earlier this year suggested that senior executives encouraged smuggling around the world, despite the com pany's insistence that it was opposed to the practice.

The company has already set up an internal inquiry into the allegations. A BAT spokesman said the company had consistently denied allegations that it promoted smuggling.

"We don't know what the committee will recommend until Wednesday," said the spokesman. "If [a DTI investigation] is among the recommendations then we do not believe it is either necessary nor appropriate."

But Clive Bates, director of the anti-smoking group, Ash, said: "The great thing about a DTI inquiry is they can question employees, former employees and associates of BAT under oath. They will have no choice but to answer the allegations in detail."

fields.headline: Death in Damascus
fields.standfirst:
Assad's successor will face big challenges

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The sudden death of the Lion of Damascus has brought forth many crocodile tears, as well as some genuine grief. Descriptions of President Hafez Assad as a "great Arab statesman", while appropriate perhaps to the solemnity of the moment, are hard to square with a 30-year record of missed opportunities, disputatiousness, and internal repression which has left Syria poor, weak, isolated, and lacking a clear way forward.
fields.body:
The sudden death of the Lion of Damascus has brought forth many crocodile tears, as well as some genuine grief. Descriptions of President Hafez Assad as a "great Arab statesman", while appropriate perhaps to the solemnity of the moment, are hard to square with a 30-year record of missed opportunities, disputatiousness, and internal repression which has left Syria poor, weak, isolated, and lacking a clear way forward.

In his dealings with his neighbours, Mr Assad, after he assumed dictatorial powers in 1970, lurched from one crisis to another. His 1973 attempt, with Egypt, to regain the Golan Heights (lost to Israel when he was Syria's defence minister in 1967) ended in an even greater humiliation. Then, in 1977, he fell out with Cairo over Anwar Sadat's decision to forge a separate peace. In 1980 Mr Assad broke with Iraq's Baathists, backing Iran in its war with Saddam Hussein and thereby shattering lingering dreams of a socialist, secular pan-Arabism. In 1982, Damascus proved powerless to prevent Israel's invasion of its close ally, Lebanon, and in 1987, lost the all-out military support of its main international sponsor, Mikhail Gorbachev's Soviet Union.

Out of enmity for Saddam, Mr Assad backed the US and others in helping reverse the 1990 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But after joining the 1991 US-initiated Middle East peace process, he failed to capitalise on resulting western goodwill. In 1993, he watched angrily as Yasser Arafat made unilateral peace with Israel; and again the following year, when Jordan's King Hussein broke ranks. Mr Assad's response - the funding of violent Palestinian rejectionists like Hamas - echoed his tactics in Lebanon, where (with Iran) he assisted Hizbullah militants fighting a proxy war with Israel. This earned him Washington's condem nation as a leading sponsor of global terrorism and, for example, almost brought conflict with Turkey in 1998 over his backing of Kurdish separatists. Even when, last year, Syria was finally coaxed back to the negotiating table, Mr Assad brought no new ideas. Hamstrung by his own history, he demanded a full, unconditional Israeli withdrawal to the 1967 borders. At the Geneva summit last March, he told Bill Clinton he wanted to go fishing again on Galilee before he died, as he had as a young man. He would not soften his uncompromising terms. It turned out to be Mr Assad's last chance. True to form, he missed the boat.

Syria's lack of credible, democratic institutions and basic civil rights, the parlous state of its economy, its army's lack of new equipment and weaponry, its increasingly untenable position in Lebanon, its sidelining in the peace process, and the uncertain future conduct of its clannish, corrupt political factions are other aspects of Mr Assad's precarious legacy. They are parts of the overall problem which now confronts his successor, likely to be his 34-year-old son, Bashar - although in the confusion Mr Assad bequeaths, even this is not certain.

It is a daunting challenge, but one not without opportunity. As we have long argued, a Syria which positively engages with Israel and its Arab neighbours to find workable solutions to common problems; a Syria which is confident enough to open up its fenced society to the free flow of information and to international business and investment; a Syria which, without forgetting the past, is ready to look forward - this is a Syria of limitless potential and true greatness. For all his famous steadfastness, Mr Assad lacked the toughest quality of all: the courage to change. And Syria must now begin to change its ways.

webTitle: So what exactly do you do for a living, Ma'am ?

fields.headline: So what exactly do you do for a living, Ma'am ?
fields.standfirst:
The Palace didn't want Simon Hattenstone to shadow Princess Anne at work. That didn't stop him

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Palace didn't want  Simon Hattenstone  to shadow Princess Anne at work. That didn't stop him
fields.body:
Thursday May 25, Medical Simulation Centre, St Bartholomew's Hospital

"Could you brush away the water?" says the senior anaesthetist. "I'm worried about the little depression collecting in the pavement." The hospital cleaner scrubs for all he's worth. Which, in money terms, isn't much. As the Bentley rolls through the front entrance, he vanishes to order.

"They're almost here," shouts an excitable doctor.

"Just as well. I'm freezing," says another senior bod, with a seditious rub of his hands.

We are waiting in two lines at the King George V entrance. One line is for the anaesthetists. The other sad, diminished line is for the journalists - the Press Association's royal correspondent, his photographer, and me. The Princess Royal doesn't like the hack pack. Never has done.

In 1962, when she was 12, Anne was on holiday and took an introverted turn for the worse. "Princess upset by overexuberance of French photographers" read one headline. The media may have been a less ferocious beast in those days, but as far as Anne was concerned it was still very much a beast. Every incident in her life was dutifully reported. In January 1964, we learned that "Princess Anne joined with other local youngsters in a paper chase on ponies in Sandringham woods". A year later "Princess Anne stayed indoors at Valduz castle with a slight cold".

It has to be said that the hack pack has never cared much for Anne, either. As a young woman she was considered aloof, abrupt, staid. As a woman approaching 50, she is respected as the hardest-working royal - close on 500 official engagements in Britain last year. Respected, but hardly liked.

The Guardian has put in a request to Buckingham Palace. We'd like to follow Anne for two or three days, snatch a few words between openings. Felicity Murdo-Smith, her PA, takes a week to reach a decision. No way. Perhaps I could observe her at the British Knitting and Clothing Export Council where, as president, she will attend the AGM? Felicity says that's up to the knitters. Sorry, say the knitters, private do. What about the preview of Christie's sporting art sale which she will attend as president of the Animal Health Trust? 'Fraid not, says Christie's; private. Surely the Worshipful Company of Farmers will allow me to attend lunch with Anne, their Junior Warden? Maybe not, but they promise to send on all the bumf.

Despair is setting in when St Bartholomew's say they'd be delighted to entertain me. Of course there's no chance of talking to Anne, but they're happy to let me share a room with her as she opens the simulation centre.

Anne steps out of the Bentley, a vision in yellow. We follow her past the Queen Elizabeth II wing. It must be strange, forever shadowing your heritage; there's Mum, Great Granddad, Great-Great-Great-Grandma. Every stop is punctuated by handshakes. Actually, only Anne shakes hands; the dignitaries are shaking a black glove. I ask Peter Archer, the Press Association's royal correspondent, whether she wears gloves because she doesn't want to be polluted by the masses. No, he says - if you had to shake as many hands as she does, your digits would get sore. He says the Queen goes through a pair a day. In his six years on the job, Anne has never uttered a word to Peter. Diana, of course, would often stroll over for a chat, and since her death Charles has learned to do the same. Anne's way of acknowledging him is to walk past, head buried in her chest. He admires her for it, says she is her father's daughter: no-nonsense, businesslike. What, though, is her business?

Anne became president of the Save the Children Fund at 19. Now she is patron of 222 organisations. She has said that her role is to make the most of her position; to burst into the offices of corporate bosses, grab them by the ears and demand what they can do for her starving children.

A handful of prize-winners are invited to shake Anne's glove. "How long have you been here?" she asks. Whenever Anne asks a question, she bounces on her feet. As she listens she clenches and unclenches her hand behind her back. Maybe the gloves irritate her.

The ceremony climaxes with the unveiling of a plaque. Anne draws back the curtain. "The Medical Simulation Centre, opened by HRH the Princess Royal, 25th May 2000." She stands to the side, proofreads and nods.

A crowd of patients has gathered in the drizzle to wave her off. Some are in pyjamas, and one has a drip attached. She doesn't seem to have seen them. They disperse, walk back to their wards, say it would have been nice if she'd waved back.

Friday May 26, Queen Anne's School, Reading

The palace laughs when I ask to attend the European Forum for Victim Services reception at Windsor Castle. But not even Felicity can banish me from the opening of the sports centre at Queen Anne's School. A sporting day for a sporting woman. In 1971 she won the European three-day event at Burghley. That year she was named Britain's sportswoman of the year, and was the subject of a series of profiles. Anne didn't fit an easy stereotype. Some said she was sullen, peeved that she wasn't going to be queen. Others said she was happy to be a maverick from the Hemingway school of adventurers.

On the train, I jot down questions, just in case. Which event has meant most to her in the past week? Does she ever wish she had a normal job? Does she prefer to be called Your Royal Highness, or Ma'am, or Annie? Are any of her friends republicans?

On the few occasions she does grant interviews, it is to advance her own agenda. Last week she talked to trade magazine The Grocer to say that GM foods are quite groovy, actually, and put one over on her elder brother. Interviewees have to submit questions beforehand, and the sheet is returned with all but the anodyne lashed out.

Queen Anne's is a girls' public school, £12,500 a year. After years of planning, the day has turned into a disaster. It's pissing down. The fireworks are cancelled; the parents, cooped up in the library, are trying to make the best of it. "This is bad luck for them. Dreadful. Every time I put on my boots the heavens open," says one man, flicking the rain from his face.

The sports centre is magnificent. In the gym, 14 girls are engaged in an abdominal workout. Anne is 15 minutes late, and by the time she arrives, they are exhausted. We move off to the basketball court, lacrosse, aerobics, the rockery. Anne occasionally pauses to ask that question: "How long have you been at this school?"

As Anne talks to the children, she bounces on her heels, clenching and unclenching her gloved hands. Many people say she can be funny and spiky and irreverent, yet she is loath to show it in public. As if it were beneath her dignity. As well as the horses, she's a fine lacrosse player, a crack shot on the shooting range. She once broke Patrick Lichfield's lap record on his private speedway circuit. How can she watch those girls chucking basketballs and not ask for a shot? Perhaps she worries that the girls will go home and say: "I met Princess Anne and she was a right good laugh."

I'm within hugging distance of her. Just as my mouth opens for the first question, a discreet security man ushers me back towards the stairs.

Anne starts her speech with a joke. "May I point out that the Princess Royal who visited here in 1929 was not me." She congratulates the school for the sports centre, then draws back the velvet curtain. The plaque tells her what she has just done. She stands to the side, reads and nods her approval.

"What's the point of her coming here?" says 18-year-old Rowena Barber. "If she was coming to raise some money, maybe. But she isn't." Her friend, Catherine Davison, agrees. "If this was a state school, fair enough. A visit from royalty could show them they are valued. But feeling undervalued isn't a problem here."

The two head girls are giving Anne an upbeat send-off. "Three cheers for the prin-" They stop, realising they have botched the protocol, and start again. "Three cheers for Her Royal Highness. Hip hip, hoorah!"

A rope divides the princess and sporting volunteers from the mass of pupils. Row after row bend an ear to listen. After her speech, she shakes gloves with the headmistress and leaves without a glance in their direction. Anne looks like she needs a good ironing.

Wednesday May 31, Hammersmith and Fulham Carers' Centre

Felicity gets quite unpleasant when I suggest asking Anne a few questions about her work with carers. "No, no, no! " she says. "I've already told your colleague you can't interview her. No! " I tell Felicity she is not allowing us to see the princess in her best light.

The carers' centre is a place where all ages come for respite - some look after elderly partners, some are kids looking after their families. A photographer in the waiting room is complaining about his treatment. "The policeman on the door said, 'How do I know you're a photographer?' and I said, 'Because I've got a press card that says photographer, issued by the Metropolitan police.'"

I ask the administrator how long they've been preparing for the big day. "Oh, months," she says. "It's been murder! We've had the whole of the outside painted, and that was just the start." It reminds me of the time when Rajiv Ghandi was visiting a rainy suburb of Delhi, and the local authority had the pavements raised for him.

In the corner, Albert the clown is teaching the children circus skills. Daniel Meekings is balancing on an iron globe. He's seven, the youngest carer at the centre, and looks after his deaf sister. Does he know who Anne is? He spreads his hand in baffled awe. "Her family rules the country."

It's four days since I last saw Anne. In the meantime she's changed her gloves and attended the Army Families Federation Conference and the commemoration of the new roof of the choir of Paisley Abbey in Scotland. She seems more animated today, and praises the kids' homework club. "It's not eashy to conshentrate on school. Care is about creating time for yourshelves." It's taken me a week to realise who that deep, slurred voice reminds me of: Bill Deedes. A girl presents her with a bouquet. It looks the same as the last one. What does she do with them all? Does she like flowers?

She smiles at a little girl and for a second I think she's going to swoop her up and drop a big sloppy kiss on her cheek. Instead, she bounces on her feet, flexes her hand and asks how long she has been coming to the centre. The trouble is that Anne refuses to acknowledge she is in the PR business - PR for her charities and, these days, PR for her family. The only way she can measure herself is by the money raised for her causes. And there is nothing the hospital or the public school or the carers' centre would like more than a soft-focus newspaper picture of a sunny princess fighting their corner.

A while ago, Anne was interviewed about her work for Save the Children. The interviewer, desperate for colour, asked for one memory that stood out, one anecdote. She refused to provide it, implying that it would be invidious. But perhaps it all begins to merge. Perhaps, like many of us, she lives a Groundhog Day existence. She was once asked what she would have done if she'd not been a princess. She said she'd like to have been a long-distance lorry driver.

It's time to leave. Another day's work done. The plaque is unveiled. She opens the velvet curtain. "To commemorate the visit of her Royal Highness the Princess Royal to the Hammersmith and Fulham Carers' Centre on Wednesday 31st May 2000." She stands to the side, reads , and nods her approval. "Smashing," she says.

fields.headline: What is globalisation?
fields.trailText: It is a word coined to describe the increasing integration of today's world so that trends or changes to the way we live seem to happen simultaneously in many countries. It is a result of a revolution in communications technology and of the increasing links between national economies through trade and investment. The most striking aspect of it for many people is the way big companies now seem to be international rather than national and to have more power than governments.
fields.body:
It is a word coined to describe the increasing integration of today's world so that trends or changes to the way we live seem to happen simultaneously in many countries. It is a result of a revolution in communications technology and of the increasing links between national economies through trade and investment. The most striking aspect of it for many people is the way big companies now seem to be international rather than national and to have more power than governments.

What has caused this?

Governments have progressively lowered the barriers to moving goods and capital across borders since the second world war. Today, $1.5 trillion is exchanged every day on the world's foreign exchanges and money can be transferred around the world in seconds. There has been a huge rise in trade volumes since the war. Trade now accounts for 30% of world output. The growth of cross-border investment has led to the rise of multinational corporations which account for about a fifth of world output and 70% of global trade.

Is it just about money?

It spills over into other aspects of our lives: for example, the global environment is affected by consumption patterns in other countries. Television, email, the internet, have all helped spread ideas and trends so that culture itself seems to be becoming globalised. Crime is globalised as well. The smuggling of people, drugs and arms across borders is a growing source of income for crime corporations which mirror legal corporations in their global reach.

Is globalisation a new thing?

Some people argue that we have been here before. In the late 19th century, many countries were as open to foreign trade as they are today. They were a lot more open to labour migration than are modern western economies. The largest migration flows in history occurred between 1815 and 1915. But the scale and speed of goods and capital flows today is of an entirely new order.

Is globalisation a good thing?

Globalisation has plenty of downsides - increasing environmental degradation, loss of distinctive cultures and habitats. Economists will argue, however, that it has brought undreamed of prosperity to much of the world. Many people and countries have missed out, however. The problem is how to manage the process so it is more inclusive and less destructive because there is a governance gap - nation states cannot control the process because it is happening at global level, and international bodies are weak.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
CBI reports services surge
Britain's service sector grew strongly over the past three months, with increases in activity, optimism, profits and jobs, the Confederation of British Industry reports today.
fields.body:
CBI reports services surge
Britain's service sector grew strongly over the past three months, with increases in activity, optimism, profits and jobs, the Confederation of British Industry reports today.

The latest survey conducted by the CBI and Deloitte & Touche shows firms in the business and professional sector were upbeat for the sixth successive quarter, while consumer services saw their first rise in confidence since last September.

Electrical jolt for retailers
Online electrical goods retailer the Helpful Home Shopping Company opens today, aiming to challenge established players with offers including a free three-year guarantee on all its products, free home delivery and installation, saving customers between £50 and £200.

Helpful has been set up by former Comet chairman Eddie Styring and Peter Hopper, Comet's former purchasing director.

The retailer, which is backed by Royal Bank of Scotland, will not have any shops but will accept orders through its website, www.helpful.co.uk, or a call centre.

Firms offered back pain relief
Small firms are to be offered expert help to prevent their workers suffering from back strain, a problem which costs industry millions of pounds a year in lost production.

A helpline will be set up in the autumn, staffed by experts who will advise smaller companies. Stan Mendham, chairman of the Forum of Private Business which is supporting the initiative, said: "Back pain is a major cause of absenteeism, causing loss to the business and the UK economy."

Small firms lose an estimated 1.2m working days a year because of back pain, costing them £100m.

Crest cuts cost of share trades
The share trading settlement group Crest said yesterday it was cutting its charges by up to 80% for cross-border share transactions in US and European securities.

The reduction will mean securities firms will pay about £1 for cross-border deals from July 1, compared with the present £5.

Crest's chief executive, Iain Saville, said the reduction meant cross-border settlement would no longer be such a high cost activity for securities firms. "Crest is now in an excellent position to offer low-cost automated settlement for the consolidating pan-European exchanges and markets."

Crest operates a real-time settlement system, settling British, Irish and international securities.

Bullying bill put at £2bn
Companies have been urged to root out bullying in the workplace after a report said yesterday the problem was costing industry £2bn a year.

Up to 19m working days are lost because workers suffer verbal and physical threats, offensive remarks and humiliation. Victims are more likely to make mistakes or have an accident and there is a negative effect on people who witness bullying incidents, according to the report by the London Chamber of Commerce.

The organisation published a guide urging firms to tackle bullying and identifying overworked managers as the most common workplace bullies.

webTitle: It's time to take the plunge with the mythical powers of Suit Guy

fields.headline: It's time to take the plunge with the mythical powers of Suit Guy
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: We are in the thick of our first major recruitment drive at the moment - and it is taking up a significant amount of our time, along with the technical development and discussions with potential partners. There has been a veritable procession of people through our offices in recent weeks. We have seen some very good people, some less good and some - well, a little bit different.
fields.body:
We are in the thick of our first major recruitment drive at the moment - and it is taking up a significant amount of our time, along with the technical development and discussions with potential partners. There has been a veritable procession of people through our offices in recent weeks. We have seen some very good people, some less good and some - well, a little bit different.

One candidate declined to shake hands with us. I think it made us more nervous about the interview than it did her until we were assured that it was for religious reasons rather than a personal disinclination. This did not put us off at all, and indeed of all the candidates we saw she was one of the strongest and made it down to the last two. Unfortunately for her, she was up against Suit Guy.

In a neat twist to the usual stereotypes about dot.com businesses, we found a candidate who was adamant that he would always wear a suit, even if all the team and everyone we met in a professional environment dressed casually. This strange belief in the mystical power of a suit has not put us off and, on the basis of the practical experience he has, Suit Guy will be joining us this week.

On the whole we have been reasonably successful in recruiting the staff we want.

Some roles - for example, operations - are more difficult to fill than others. But through hard work, the effective use of five specialist recruitment agencies and our personal networks we have managed to fill many of the key roles and are genuinely excited by the people whom we have found.

We are particularly pleased to have secured a very experienced non-executive director after a courtship lasting over a month. Patrick Boylan, previously the chief executive of NatWest Cards - a member of the Global Board of MasterCard and vice-chairman of Europay - joined the board last week.

He will make key contributions to the business through his 30 years within banking and payments. Patrick claims that he does not like wearing suits but we have not yet seen him out of one. Maybe Suit Guy has got to him.

There have also - inevitably - been disappointments. We had to reject an otherwise very promising candidate because of the lack of professionalism he demonstrated. He informed us by voice mail that he would not be able to attend a second interview on Saturday morning because he had forgotten he had a plane to catch. The lameness of the excuse itself was reason enough not to have taken his application any further.

But we have achieved quite a lot in a relatively short period of time. Importantly, we are no longer male-dominated, which is a bit of a relief, and have people from a number of different ethnic and social backgrounds. We are trying to assemble a well balanced team of people. If that means mixing suits with jeans, so be it.

 Adam Hamby and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools.com, a net service enabling consumers to buy online without credit

One candidate declined to shake hands with us. I think it made us more nervous about the interview than it did her until we were assured that it was for religious reasons rather than a personal disinclination. This did not put us off at all, and indeed of all the candidates we saw she was one of the strongest and made it down to the last two. Unfortunately for her, she was up against Suit Guy. In a neat twist to the usual stereotypes about dot.com businesses, we found a candidate who was adamant that he would always wear a suit, even if all the team and everyone we met in a professional environment dressed casually. This strange belief in the mystical power of a suit has not put us off and, on the basis of the practical experience he has, Suit Guy will be joining us this week. On the whole we have been reasonably successful in recruiting the staff we want. Some roles - for example, operations - are more difficult to fill than others. But through hard work, the effective use of five specialist recruitment agencies and our personal networks we have managed to fill many of the key roles and are genuinely excited by the people whom we have found. We are particularly pleased to have secured a very experienced non-executive director after a courtship lasting over a month. Patrick Boylan, previously the chief executive of NatWest Cards - a member of the Global Board of MasterCard and vice-chairman of Europay - joined the board last week. He will make key contributions to the business through his 30 years within banking and payments. Patrick claims that he does not like wearing suits but we have not yet seen him out of one. Maybe Suit Guy has got to him. There have also - inevitably - been disappointments. We had to reject an otherwise very promising candidate because of the lack of professionalism he demonstrated. He informed us by voice mail that he would not be able to attend a second interview on Saturday morning because he had forgotten he had a plane to catch. The lameness of the excuse itself was reason enough not to have taken his application any further. But we have achieved quite a lot in a relatively short period of time. Importantly, we are no longer male-dominated, which is a bit of a relief, and have people from a number of different ethnic and social backgrounds. We are trying to assemble a well balanced team of people. If that means mixing suits with jeans, so be it.  Adam Hamby and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools.com, a net service enabling consumers to buy online without credit

fields.headline: Clampdown on premium line fraud
fields.trailText: A fraudulent debt collection service tried to con nearly 1,000 people into calling a premium phone line on pain of court action, it has emerged.
fields.body:
A fraudulent debt collection service tried to con nearly 1,000 people into calling a premium phone line on pain of court action, it has emerged.

Intacc Group despatched hundreds of identical "demands" for £176.52 and warned failure to ring immediately to sort out the "debt" would result in a summons.

While Intacc was not trying falsely to claim the sums on the "debt collection" letters, it was trying to make thousands of pounds from the premium-cost phone number the "debtors" were ordered to call.

Within two hours of the line being opened last September, 500 complaints had poured in, and it was halted.

The telecommunications service provider, Telecom One, held on to the money earned and refunded the more than 750 people concerned.

The Intacc case was one of the most serious ever handled by Icstis, the agency that regulates premium phone services. Intacc has now been barred from all circuits and has been fined £5,000.

In addition, two individuals associated with Intacc have been banned from running or being associated with a premium telephone service until September 23 this year.

They cannot be named as both trading standards officers and police have inquiries under way.

Intacc, along with a second, less serious, case accounted for nearly a third of all complaints received last year by Icstis, its report disclosed today .

In the case of Allocation Hotline Group, millions of leaflets were sent to private homes last autumn telling occupants they had won a competition prize.

The "winners" then had to call a premium number, charged at £1 a minute, and listen to a nine-minute message. Icstis said just a small number of the available prizes were worthwhile. The vast majority was made up of 50,000 mobile telephones, each costing £17 a month.

Icstis received 1,250 complaints about Allocation, which was fined £2,000.

Icstis imposed fines totalling £140,000 against 94 firms during 1999, and bars on access to the telephone system were imposed against 54.

Icstis chairman Sir Peter North said that just a few firms had caused huge numbers of complaints. He urged any concerned subscriber to to call the Icstis help line on 0800 500212.

fields.headline: I met the Queen
fields.standfirst:
The Queen doesn't give interviews. So Carolyne Ellis spoke to some of the chosen few to find out what she's like

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Ekow Eshun, journalist
fields.body:
Ekow Eshun, journalist

I met the Queen two years ago at a Buckingham Palace reception for young achievers attended by most of the royal family. Unexpectedly, I found myself being introduced to her and, stuck for something to say, I told her she had a lovely home. She nodded. Rising to my theme, I gazed out of the palace windows at the vast acreage of lawn outside with its own private lake and complimented her on the grounds. "Yes, one is very lucky to have a garden in the centre of London," she replied. This struck me as a bit of an understatement. Before I could point this out, she'd moved on. She was very short with perfectly coiffured silver hair. There was something very slick, almost showbiz, about how polished she looked and the way she worked the room.

Russell Stannard, scientist and ex-professor of physics

I was invited to lunch with the Queen at Buckingham Palace last spring. I was on the Queen's left. Michael Atherton was on the other side. The corgis were at our feet. Throughout the meal, she dropped down pieces of toast. We spoke about the Uncle Albert books I write for children, and about science and religion, because she and Prince Philip listen to Thought For The Day, and I often give that. I asked her how many corgis she had, and she said they weren't all corgis, some of them were dorgis. She explained that that was a cross between a corgi and a dachshund.

Dickie Bird, ex-cricket commentator

I had lunch with the Queen at Buckingham Palace on November 27 1990. It was a marvellous occasion, because there were only three or four of us. She asked me if I had had a good journey down, and I said: "Yes, I have, your Majesty. I left at five this morning from Barnsley." And she laughed and said: "Oh dear, you definitely made sure you were going to be early." I said: "Yes, I would not have missed this for anything. I would have walked it from Barnsley to Buckingham Palace to have lunch with you." She had a good laugh over that. She asked me if I had enjoyed the lunch, and I said I had, it was a magnificent lunch. She asked had I enjoyed the day. I said: "Yes, I have, it's a day that I will cherish for the rest of my life." I've met the Queen about 28 times, but that time will stand out. I was there all day.

Larry Adler, harmonica player

It was at an event called The Great Event, like a royal variety show, at Earl's Court. After the show, the Queen came back to meet the cast. As she got to me I said: "I played for you when you were 12." And she said: "Oh, where was that?" I said: "Edinburgh. You sat on the floor with your sister and your parents sat behind you." There was a long pause and I think she was thinking of something regal to say. Then finally she said, "How kind of you to remember so far back", and went on to the next artist.

Andrew Festing, artist

I painted her twice. Each time there were six sittings of about an hour, in the yellow drawing room at Buckingham Palace. On one occasion, she was just about to go to America on a state visit, so she spent a certain amount of time talking about that. It was just after that mortar bomb attack on 10 Downing St. There was a certain amount of talk about that, and the security at Buckingham Palace. Then we had a long conversation about what sort of rifles the army had. I remember us peering out of the windows and having a long conversation about the large numbers of Japanese tourists there. I think that was just after the emperor of Japan had been here. We had a long conversation, too, about some virus which had got into the stables. All the horses were suffering from some sort of epidemic. The conversations were completely normal. She's incredibly easy to talk to. After the initial part, the conversation flows in a perfectly normal way, like it does with anybody else.

Tim Cunningham, TV producer

I was captain of the school at Eton in 1990. They had a big celebration for the 550th anniversary of the school and the Queen came. I had to give a speech in Latin. I was introduced to her before and we had a quick chat about the fact I was giving it in Latin. So she asked me about the speech and about how long it was going to be. And that was about it. It was one of those swift, move-along things.

Claire Brown, reflexologist

It was November 1997. I was running touchy-feely type courses in Oxfordshire: hand massage, reflexology. All the TV crew came in and put the lights on, and I remember saying: "No, you mustn't do this. She's coming to me to relax. It's not a show. She's coming to see how I normally operate." I remember her gliding in and going: "Oh, isn't it lovely, a beautiful atmosphere here." I said: "Excuse me ma'am, would you like me to show you what a little hand massage is?" She answered to the effect of: "Yes please, I'd love to." I made her an oil up of frankincense, rose and mandarin; rose because she was the Queen, the symbol of England; frankincense because it's a lovely, calming one; and mandarin because it's a lovely, uplifting one. I remember her saying: "How soothing, how relaxing. I'm having a lovely time." Halfway through working on her hands, I suddenly thought: "Oh my golly, this is the Queen!"

Ron Freeman, investment banker

I met the Queen in 1992 at the new European Bank of Reconstruction & Development (EBRD) headquarters in Broadgate. She came when it signed the new lease for the building. She asked if they were terribly busy with the EBRD. She made a point of speaking in French to Jacques Attali, the organisation's president, saying she was very pleased to have the EBRD in London. Her French was good but with an upper-class British accent. She was soft-spoken and polite. She said she hoped they were comfortable in the new headquarters. This turned out to be rather ironic as the FT criticised the EBRD for spending more on their lobby than on Europe, leading to Attali's departure.

Maureen Davies, primary school teacher

I met her at Buckingham Palace last February to receive the CBE for services to education. The sense of occasion overwhelms you. You have already been told the protocol, where you curtsey, move forward and she shakes your hand. So she shook my hand and said: "Very well done, well deserved, and congratulations." I said: "Oh, thank you very much. I feel very proud to be here."

webTitle: Early warning scheme to catch bad doctors

fields.headline: Early warning scheme to catch bad doctors
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, yesterday proposed an early warning system to pick up the mistakes and bad practice of rogue doctors following the scandals of the GP Harold Shipman and gynaecologist Rodney Ledward, who were both able to carry on damaging patients for many years without being unmasked.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, yesterday proposed an early warning system to pick up the mistakes and bad practice of rogue doctors following the scandals of the GP Harold Shipman and gynaecologist Rodney Ledward, who were both able to carry on damaging patients for many years without being unmasked.

The proposal, to be unveiled by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, tomorrow, is that every hospital trust and GP practice will have to keep a register of mistakes and untoward incidents. If any patient is harmed, or might have been harmed - by a wrong drugs dose, for instance - it will have to be recorded and notified to a central database.

"Overwhelmingly, doctors do a brilliant job for the NHS, but I am determined to learn a lesson from where things go wrong," Mr Milburn told the BBC's On the Record. "The chief medical officer has made proposals to set up an early warning system so we can make the alarm bells ring.

"Where there has been an adverse incident where the patient has been damaged or died, we do not have a national system for recording that or doing something about it. Things go wrong. Cases end up in the courts. We have not fully learned from those. We need to take all that data, analyse it and learn the lessons."

Mr Milburn believes Shipman and Ledward would have been picked up by such a system. Deaths in a GP's surgery would have to be recorded on the register, since they are normally very unusual. In Shipman's practice they were almost a regular occurrence.

Ledward's hysterectomies and bladder operations went wrong far more often than those of his colleagues, but no one at the William Harvey hospital in Kent or in other hospitals where he worked spoke out. Analysis of a register of mistakes would have brought his record to light.

Where the register throws up a pattern of bad practice as it would have done in these cases, inspectors from the government's commission for health improvement would be sent in. They are already trouble-shooting in trusts where problems have been detected.

The proposals emerge as a second gynaecologist, Richard Neale, today faces a disciplinary tribunal of the General Medical Council. He worked at a hospital in North Yorkshire for 10 years after his licence to practise in Canada was revoked. Eventually, in the mid-1990s, the hospital trust paid him £100,000 to go and gave him a clean reference. He was suspended by the GMC last year and now faces complaints relating to 14 patients.

The British Medical Association said yesterday that it had no problem with the idea of registers for adverse incidents. "The system exists in a number of hospitals and practices. It is part of risk management to identify incidents where patients may have been harmed," a spokesman said. "If he is saying all hospitals should do this and the register be centralised, that is worth discussing." The only problem the BMA had was with the spin about "dodgy doctors" attached by ministers to such pronouncements, the spokesman added.

Mr Milburn's announcement came as Labour councillors promised to fight reforms which they say strip local authorities of responsibility for social services in a power grab by the NHS.

Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association and member of Labour's national executive, said the plan to merge health and social care would put the welfare of thousands of vulnerable elderly people "at risk".

Last week Mr Milburn gave the first public indication that the government was preparing to loosen local authorities' grip on social services. His motive was to ensure that older people could be moved out of hospital as quickly as possible to free beds for other patients.

fields.headline: Bass to build hotels empire
fields.standfirst: Brewery cash unlikely to be spent on Whitbread
fields.trailText: Brewing and leisure group Bass will probably use the cash from selling its breweries to invest in international hotels rather than make a bid for the British businesses of Whitbread , analysts said yesterday.
fields.body:
Brewing and leisure group Bass will probably use the cash from selling its breweries to invest in international hotels rather than make a bid for the British businesses of Whitbread , analysts said yesterday.

Bass is set to announce the sale of its brewing division early this week to Belgium's Interbrew for £2.2bn, giving it money to expand its Holiday Inn, Crowne Plaza and Inter-Continental hotels business.

Reports at the weekend indicated that Bass executives have prepared strategy documents that include a £4bn takeover bid for rival Whitbread. But analysts said Bass was more likely to look abroad for a merger.

"Bass has always stated its aim to expand its hotels side. I don't see it selling its essentially UK beer business just to reinvest in another UK business like Whitbread," one ana lyst said. Market sources said Bass has held merger talks with US hotels group Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide, the operator of the Sheraton, Westin and other chains, but these broke down.

Other potential targets for Bass's hotel expansion could be French-based Accor, Hilton Group which runs Hiltons outside the US, and the American-based Hilton Hotels which operates in the US.

Bass is already the world's most international hotel group and the second biggest in the world overall after US company Cendant. Bass bought the Inter-Continental chain for £1.8bn in March 1998, and now the group runs 2,900-plus hotels with almost 500,000 worldwide beds.

"Bass is already the fifth largest hotel group in the UK, and its hands are full with its recently-acquired 550 Allied pubs, so I can not see it being interested in Whitbread for any other reason than its low share price," said another analyst.

The reports suggest Bass is working on a £4bn bid at 700p a share for Whitbread to become Britain's dominant pub operator. A deal would reinforce Bass's 3,000-strong managed pub estate which includes outlets such as All Bar One and O'Neills.

But analysts pointed out Bass would have to sell off Whitbread's leased pubs, many of its underperforming managed pubs, David Lloyd health and sports clubs and other retailing outlets just to acquire the bits it wants like Whitbread's Hogshead and Brewers Fayre pubs, Beefeater restaurants and its British hotels.

Relations have been strained between Bass and Whitbread since last summer when Bass joined with Punch Tavern to top Whitbread's agreed deal for 3,500 Allied Domecq pubs.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Telegraph
fields.body:
Sunday Telegraph

The former head of Radio 4, James Boyle , is to become a director of the independent television company Wark Clements , which is to produce programmes for the BBC. Boyle, who left the BBC in May, becomes the latest in a succession of senior BBC executives leaving for the private sector.

The US venture capital firm Apollo Management is holding secret talks with the board of Somerfield to agree a bid to take the struggling retailer private. A proposal to offer about 80p a share is being put together by Brooks Newmark, the head of Apollo's UK operations, valuing the company at £400m.

Sunday Times

The food and drinks group Diageo is offering a huge incentive package for an e-commerce supremo to look over its international business-to-business internet subsidiary. The deal involves a basic salary of £250,000 plus an option of more than 1% of the new company.

A £2bn merger proposal to acquire Liberty International and its 74%-owned subsidiary, Capital Shopping Centres , has been put forward by British Land property group chairman John Ritblat. The offer was made before Mr Ritblat acquired 29.9% of Liberty last weekend.

The Observer

The diamond mining company Oryx has axed its UK flotation plans after the Foreign Office stepped in against a backdrop of Britain's intervention in the Sierra Leone crisis. It is understood the government voiced concerns over the company's $1bn (£667m) mining concession in the Congo, formerly Zaire.

Virgin hopes to pip Orange at the post in the race to go global in mobile telephony with $2bn worth of international joint ventures. Sir Richard Branson's group plans to put £200m into new deals with German, Japanese and US mobile operators.

IoS

The French luxury goods tycoon Bernard Arnault may sell his 20.6% stake in Gucci to arch-rival François Pinault . This would mean that Giorgio Armani would be clear to sell his brand to Gucci for an estimated €1bn. He did not want to sell while Arnault, a personal friend, was embroiled in a dispute over Gucci with Pinault.

Gordon Brown will reveal a figure thought to be near £140bn in the Comprehensive Spending Review as part of a 10-year transport strategy. The chancellor wants the City to be closely involved with the drive, offering new business plans for tram services.

Rank Group is poised to sell its holiday camp operation Butlins . Despite an extensive revamp of the centres in Skegness, Minehead and Bognor Regis, sources at the company say that a buyer is being sought.

Mail on Sunday

Sainsbury is to axe its Reward card after it cost the company £100m last year. Sir Peter Davis, the new chief executive, thinks the cost is too great. The move is part of an attempt to buck up the company's falling performance. Safeway scrapped its ABC card in April and its share price subsequently rose 22%.

Britain's largest tour operator, Airtours, has started merger talks with Germany's C&N Touristic . Airtours is already in talks with LTU , Germany's third largest tour operator.

Sainsbury, Tesco and Budgens are competing to build stores in 2,500 suburban railway stations across Britain. The new shops, to be set up as part of the bidding for the next generation of train-operating franchises, are expected to have an internet function.

fields.headline: Mugabe accuses UN monitors
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe yesterday accused the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, of trying to "hijack the international monitoring" of Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections later this month.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe yesterday accused the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, of trying to "hijack the international monitoring" of Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections later this month.

Even as Mr Mugabe attacked the UN, state-sponsored political violence continued in Zimbabwe with one more opposition member killed, one tortured and others badly beaten.

Mr Mugabe reacted angrily to the UN's withdrawal on Friday from monitoring Zimbabwe's elections. Mr Mugabe said the world body had tried to assume "an illegitimate role" as co-ordinator of foreign election observers.

The secretary general decided to act when Mr Mugabe issued new restrictions on international monitors, including regulations on where they could go and a lengthy accreditation procedure.

The UN said the new regulations were contrary to standard international procedures and withdrew its offer to supervise and coordinate 300 international observers and 16,000 domestic monitors.

The European Union has taken on the role of coordinating other observer missions. EU, Commonwealth and other observer groups are livid about the new restrictions, which they believe are clearly attempts to make them less effective on the ground. But they have decided to carry on in the hope that their presence will help bring about better elections with less violence.

The presence of the international observers has reduced, but not halted, Zimbabwe's political violence. In the latest attack, a supporter of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change was killed in the troubled Mberengwa district while another is in intensive care after being tortured.

Finos Zhou, 21, died after being abducted and severely beaten by supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party. His brother is in hospital with numerous injuries and cigarette burns all over his body.

Although at least three prospective MDC candidates for parliament have been killed, the party has managed to field candidates in all 120 constituencies and is posing the biggest challenge to Mr Mugabe since he led the nation to independence from Britain in 1980. Despite widespread intimidation, support for the MDC appears to be growing.

"We are being ruled by thieves and murderers instead of leaders," said Prosper Katsaya Mapfumo at an MDC rally yesterday. "It is now or never. Now is the time for us to build a better Zimbabwe for our children."

He was speaking at a rally for the MDC candidate in Harare East, human rights lawyer Tendai Biti, attended by more than 3,000 Zimbabweans, black and white.

"The main issue in our campaign is the economy," said Mr Biti. The MDC would cut the budget deficit and withdraw troops from the Congo war, creating a new economic climate and delivering new jobs.

Most of Mr Biti's supporters arrived on foot, wearing jackets and jerseys but shed the outer layers to reveal MDC T-shirts. Just a few weeks ago an MDC supporter was beaten to death after being caught wearing such a shirt.

The enthusiasm of the MDC rally was in stark contrast to the lavish but subdued Zanu-PF rally in the same constituency for its candidate, Stalin Mau-Mau. It featured free refreshments, free T-shirts and caps, and music from one of Harare's most popular bands. It was also attended by about 3,000 people .

"There is no political violence in Zimbabwe," declared Border Gezi, a provincial governor, at the rally. "Those who create violence cannot expect Zanu-PF to go to bed and do nothing. We are not like Jesus. If you hit my cheek, I will hit back with a big fist," he said.

fields.headline: 3 held over 'rogue heroin' deaths
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Police yesterday arrested three men in connection with the death of a drug addict, as it emerged that the rogue heroin which has claimed the lives of addicts across Britain and Ireland may have killed three more people.
fields.body:
Police yesterday arrested three men in connection with the death of a drug addict, as it emerged that the rogue heroin which has claimed the lives of addicts across Britain and Ireland may have killed three more people.

At least 31 people in Scotland, Ireland and the North-west have died after injecting heroin contaminated with a bacterium found in soil. But over the weekend West Midlands police said they feared the contaminated narcotic could have claimed three more lives in the Wolverhampton area.

The body of Derek Anderson, 45, was discovered in Wolverhampton on Saturday. Detectives investigating the death were last night questioning two men on suspicion of murder and one on suspicion of supplying heroin.

Mr Anderson and the other two, who both died in hospital, showed similar symptoms to addicts who died after injecting the contaminated heroin into their muscles.

Last Friday, health officials from the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, Georgia, issued a global health warning on the dangers of the rogue narcotic.

Scientists from the American epidemiology centre were called in by Laurence Gruer, a senior public health consultant at Greater Glasgow health board, after intensive investigations in Britain failed to yield concrete results.

Health officials have still to isolate the bacterium they believe is causing the deaths. Their task is being made difficult by the fact that it is anaerobic and dies when it comes into contact with oxygen.

The outbreak was first discovered in early May when heroin addicts began showing up at the casualty departments of Glasgow hospitals with huge abscesses. Despite intensive doses of antibiotics, they died within hours.

Officials believe the deaths are caused by addicts missing veins and injecting into muscles or other tissue. The acid in which the heroin is dissolved burns a hole in the muscle which allows the bacterium to thrive. It then produces its own deadly toxin and multiple organ failure often ensues.

A spokesman for Greater Glasgow health board said it was too early to confirm that the three deaths in Wolverhampton were linked to the other rogue heroin deaths. "Those deaths are still being investigated to establish if they are linked to the Glasgow and Dublin outbreaks."

webTitle: News of the World pictures of William crank up row over press intrusion

fields.headline: News of the World pictures of William crank up row over press intrusion
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Photographs of Prince William provoked another row yesterday when St James's Palace announced it would report the News of the World for publishing unofficial pictures of the prince at school.
fields.body:
Photographs of Prince William provoked another row yesterday when St James's Palace announced it would report the News of the World for publishing unofficial pictures of the prince at school.

Senior aides to the Prince of Wales issued a statement saying they will refer the issue to the Press Complaints Commission this week for intrusion after the newspaper published a series of pictures taken by a paparazzo accused by Diana, Princess of Wales, of making her life "hell".

The photographs, showing the prince mixing with his friends and playing sport at Eton in the run up to his 18th birthday on June 21, were taken by freelance photographer Mark Saunders.

It is the second clash over photographs of the prince in a matter of days.

Last Friday, Prince Charles's press secretary of seven years, Sandy Henney, resigned following a dispute with the Daily Telegraph over the copyright of the official photographs marking the birthday.

Media experts said the News of the World's decision was a clear breach of the PCC code of conduct. The code was tightened following Diana's death in 1997 to restrict all intrusions into her sons' private lives until they were 18.

The pictures - published six days ahead of the scheduled publication this Saturday of the official set of photographs - were taken from a forthcoming book about the prince featuring pictures by Mr Saunders, a paparazzo who trailed Diana daily for the last six years of her life and was accused of regularly "hounding" her to tears.

The PCC chairman, Lord Wakeham, is likely to be sympathetic to the palace's concerns. He has in the past called for the code to be extended until the princes finish their full-time education around the age of 21.

A St James's Palace spokeswoman said in a statement yesterday: "The privacy of Prince William and Prince Harry at school has always been of paramount importance to us, and it is vital for us to reaffirm the principle that the two young princes, like all children, should be free to complete their time at school without interruption.

"This is of continuing importance to us because, even though Prince William himself will shortly be leaving school, Prince Harry remains at Eton."

Even before the palace announcement, the News of the World's new editor, Rebekah Wade, had issued a statement defending the publication of the "charming" and "inoffensive" pictures as a "tribute" to the young prince that involved "absolutely no intervention of privacy nor intrusion".

 Scotland Yard confirmed yesterday that a small number of cannabis leaves had been discovered in a staff kitchen at Buckingham Palace. Police raided the ground floor kitchen of the palace in the early hours of Saturday, after a member of staff tipped off the royalty protection squad. A police spokesman said: "There have been no arrests and it is uncertain whether there will any further action taken."

fields.headline: How much is she worth?
fields.standfirst:
Estimates of the Queen's wealth vary according to who you believe. Fortune magazine gives her a cool £5bn, the Palace denies it. Charlotte Denny does her sums

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: When you are a pensioner, every little counts. So Gordon Brown's decision to raise the universal state pension by a generous 75p a week must have been welcome news to the 74-year-old inhabitant of a modest little pile at SW1A 1AA, bringing her weekly income to an estimated £678,846.75.
fields.body:
When you are a pensioner, every little counts. So Gordon Brown's decision to raise the universal state pension by a generous 75p a week must have been welcome news to the 74-year-old inhabitant of a modest little pile at SW1A 1AA, bringing her weekly income to an estimated £678,846.75.

Or thereabouts. The real story behind the Queen's wealth is how successfully Buckingham Palace has managed to avoid embarrassing disclosures about the size of her loot. Somewhere in a tax office in Cardiff, where all the most sensitive returns are dealt with, there is a man or woman who knows more or less how much Elizabeth Alexandra Mary Windsor is worth. Everybody else is taking wild guesses, ranging from an estimate of £2.18bn, in Eurobusiness magazine last year, to Fortune magazine, which has her sitting pretty on a £5bn nest egg.

In fact, the Queen's dosh can be roughly divided into the bits we have no idea about - her private investment portfolio, where estimates range from £100m to £1.1bn - and the bits we know about but aren't really sure who owns: the Crown Estate, the Duchy of Lancaster, her jewels, stamp collection and the fabulous art collection which includes 9,000 paintings, 28,000 watercolours, and 20,000 pen-and-ink drawings, including sketches by Raphael and Da Vinci.

The Sunday Times used to include the value of the collection - valuations range from £600m to £4bn - in her fortune, but they caved in to pressure from the Palace and dropped the paintings on the rather shaky grounds that, as she can't sell them, she doesn't really own them.

It is an argument the Palace uses frequently to knock down some of the wilder estimates of her wealth. Thus, for example, the official Buckingham Palace website states that the jewellery, art and royal palaces belong to the Queen as sovereign, not as an individual, and thus should be excluded from estimates of her wealth. They must be handed down to the next monarch, and cannot be sold off to raise a quick bob or pay off the Queen Mum's overdraft - or so the Palace says.

In fact, it's not quite that clearcut. Some of the jewellery was bought by individual sovereigns; Queen Mary snapped up the Russian imperial family's baubles at bargain-basement prices during the Depression, which suggests that her granddaughter should be free to sell them. Estimates of the value of the jewellery range from £70-£130m, although if they were ever auctioned off the bidding would go much higher than the face value of the stones, simply because of who used to wear them.

Likewise, the palace was furious when the Eurobusiness survey included the Crown Estate in its estimate of the family's wealth. The estate consists of some 380,000 acres of prime land and buildings throughout the United Kingdom, valued at £1.1bn.

So who owns it? Under a settlement reached in 1760, the monarchy surrenders the Crown Estate to government at the start of each reign in exchange for payments to cover its expenses - the civil list. The Treasury pockets the revenues from the Crown Estate - £125.8m in 1998-99 - while the civil list has been set at £9.79m annually since 1990. It sounds like a sweetheart deal for the taxpayer and, every so often, the palace murmurs that perhaps it should take back the revenues from the Crown Estate in exchange for covering all its own costs. But if the royals think they are entitled to the income from the Crown Estate, that surely suggests they think they still own it, despite claiming not to?

Phillip Hall, historian and expert on the royal finances, says that the argument for giving the income from the Crown Estate back to the royals is disingenuous. Before George III handed over the Estate, the monarchy used the revenues to cover all the expenses of running the country apart from going to war. "The Crown Estate income has always been for paying the expenses of government," says Hall. "When the monarch was effectively the government, that is the basis on which he or she received the income. It was never private income. Now that the government is the state, the state receives it."

So if the Palace wants to take back the Crown Estate revenues, it should cough up the £200bn annual costs of running a modern government. Not such a good deal, perhaps.

The Duchy of Lancaster is another mysterious part of the royal port-folio: 51,150 acres of land and at least £35m worth of investments run like a government department, with a minister at its head, currently the Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam. But all the money it generates - £5.9m a year - goes to the Queen. "That she draws this revenue suggests that it is her private property, yet when the Palace calculates her private wealth they never include [it]," says Hall. Eurobusiness didn't include it in their estimate of the Windsors' wealth, either.

The one clear piece of the puzzle is the property that the Queen owns as an individual rather than a monarch: Sandringham and Balmoral, conservatively estimated as being worth around £100m.

The most shadowy part of the Queen's finances is her personal fortune. Since 1993, she has paid tax on her private income - the fruits of her investment portfolio and the income from her private estates - but aside from that anonymous tax official in Cardiff, it's anyone's guess how much the bill is because no one can be sure how large her investments are.

The most accurate figure - or at least, a figure that the Palace did not dispute at the time - was that, in 1971, her portfolio was worth around £21m. Conservatively invested, this would now be worth around £861m, according to investment bankers CSFB. Standard Life, meanwhile, values her portfolio at £1.25bn. However, the palace regularly denies that she is worth anything like this much, pointing out that she has drawn down on her capital at various times. Sources close to the palace suggest that the true value of the portfolio is more likely to be around £100m.

As well as the annual income from her investments and the Duchy of Lancaster, the government provides the Queen with a sum known as the civil list, which the Palace insists is not a salary but a grant to cover some of the costs of being royal. When the government and the Palace used to haggle each year about the size of the payment, it generated plenty of embarrassing headlines about pay rises for the royals.

To avoid that, the palace and the previous government agreed a deal in 1990 fixing the civil list at £9.79m a year for the rest of the decade. It was deliberately intended to be generous at the start of the period on the expectation that inflation would erode its value. In fact, inflation has been much lower than expected, so the Queen has been able to make savings from her £7.9m annual share and may even take a pay freeze for the next few years as a result.

The taxpayer also forks out £15m a year for the maintenance of the five royal palaces: Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle, Kensington Palace, the palace of Holyroodhouse and St James's Palace.

All of this adds up to a tidy annual income of perhaps as much as £35m a year, from which the Queen runs seven properties, employs 1,300 people and subsidises several of her relatives. Taken together, the Windsors are the most expensive bunch of royals in all of Europe - in fact, the cost to the state of running them is more than the expenses of all the other royal families combined.

Mr Brown's extra £39 a year for pensioners won't make a huge impression on the Queen; it might pay for an extra bunch of flowers, perhaps. In fact, the Palace says the Queen does not receive a state pension, even though, like anybody else over the age of 65, she is entitled to one.
