Somewhere in a tax office in Cardiff, where all the most sensitive returns are dealt with, there is a man or woman who knows more or less how much Elizabeth Alexandra Mary Windsor is worth. Everybody else is taking wild guesses, ranging from an estimate of £2.18bn, in Eurobusiness magazine last year, to Fortune magazine, which has her sitting pretty on a £5bn nest egg. In fact, the Queen's dosh can be roughly divided into the bits we have no idea about - her private investment portfolio, where estimates range from £100m to £1.1bn - and the bits we know about but aren't really sure who owns: the Crown Estate, the Duchy of Lancaster, her jewels, stamp collection and the fabulous art collection which includes 9,000 paintings, 28,000 watercolours, and 20,000 pen-and-ink drawings, including sketches by Raphael and Da Vinci. The Sunday Times used to include the value of the collection - valuations range from £600m to £4bn - in her fortune, but they caved in to pressure from the Palace and dropped the paintings on the rather shaky grounds that, as she can't sell them, she doesn't really own them. It is an argument the Palace uses frequently to knock down some of the wilder estimates of her wealth. Thus, for example, the official Buckingham Palace website states that the jewellery, art and royal palaces belong to the Queen as sovereign, not as an individual, and thus should be excluded from estimates of her wealth. They must be handed down to the next monarch, and cannot be sold off to raise a quick bob or pay off the Queen Mum's overdraft - or so the Palace says. In fact, it's not quite that clearcut. Some of the jewellery was bought by individual sovereigns; Queen Mary snapped up the Russian imperial family's baubles at bargain-basement prices during the Depression, which suggests that her granddaughter should be free to sell them. Estimates of the value of the jewellery range from £70-£130m, although if they were ever auctioned off the bidding would go much higher than the face value of the stones, simply because of who used to wear them. Likewise, the palace was furious when the Eurobusiness survey included the Crown Estate in its estimate of the family's wealth. The estate consists of some 380,000 acres of prime land and buildings throughout the United Kingdom, valued at £1.1bn. So who owns it? Under a settlement reached in 1760, the monarchy surrenders the Crown Estate to government at the start of each reign in exchange for payments to cover its expenses - the civil list. The Treasury pockets the revenues from the Crown Estate - £125.8m in 1998-99 - while the civil list has been set at £9.79m annually since 1990. It sounds like a sweetheart deal for the taxpayer and, every so often, the palace murmurs that perhaps it should take back the revenues from the Crown Estate in exchange for covering all its own costs. But if the royals think they are entitled to the income from the Crown Estate, that surely suggests they think they still own it, despite claiming not to? Phillip Hall, historian and expert on the royal finances, says that the argument for giving the income from the Crown Estate back to the royals is disingenuous. Before George III handed over the Estate, the monarchy used the revenues to cover all the expenses of running the country apart from going to war. "The Crown Estate income has always been for paying the expenses of government," says Hall. "When the monarch was effectively the government, that is the basis on which he or she received the income. It was never private income. Now that the government is the state, the state receives it." So if the Palace wants to take back the Crown Estate revenues, it should cough up the £200bn annual costs of running a modern government. Not such a good deal, perhaps. The Duchy of Lancaster is another mysterious part of the royal port-folio: 51,150 acres of land and at least £35m worth of investments run like a government department, with a minister at its head, currently the Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam. But all the money it generates - £5.9m a year - goes to the Queen. "That she draws this revenue suggests that it is her private property, yet when the Palace calculates her private wealth they never include [it]," says Hall. Eurobusiness didn't include it in their estimate of the Windsors' wealth, either. The one clear piece of the puzzle is the property that the Queen owns as an individual rather than a monarch: Sandringham and Balmoral, conservatively estimated as being worth around £100m. The most shadowy part of the Queen's finances is her personal fortune. Since 1993, she has paid tax on her private income - the fruits of her investment portfolio and the income from her private estates - but aside from that anonymous tax official in Cardiff, it's anyone's guess how much the bill is because no one can be sure how large her investments are. The most accurate figure - or at least, a figure that the Palace did not dispute at the time - was that, in 1971, her portfolio was worth around £21m. Conservatively invested, this would now be worth around £861m, according to investment bankers CSFB. Standard Life, meanwhile, values her portfolio at £1.25bn. However, the palace regularly denies that she is worth anything like this much, pointing out that she has drawn down on her capital at various times. Sources close to the palace suggest that the true value of the portfolio is more likely to be around £100m. As well as the annual income from her investments and the Duchy of Lancaster, the government provides the Queen with a sum known as the civil list, which the Palace insists is not a salary but a grant to cover some of the costs of being royal. When the government and the Palace used to haggle each year about the size of the payment, it generated plenty of embarrassing headlines about pay rises for the royals. To avoid that, the palace and the previous government agreed a deal in 1990 fixing the civil list at £9.79m a year for the rest of the decade. It was deliberately intended to be generous at the start of the period on the expectation that inflation would erode its value. In fact, inflation has been much lower than expected, so the Queen has been able to make savings from her £7.9m annual share and may even take a pay freeze for the next few years as a result. The taxpayer also forks out £15m a year for the maintenance of the five royal palaces: Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle, Kensington Palace, the palace of Holyroodhouse and St James's Palace. All of this adds up to a tidy annual income of perhaps as much as £35m a year, from which the Queen runs seven properties, employs 1,300 people and subsidises several of her relatives. Taken together, the Windsors are the most expensive bunch of royals in all of Europe - in fact, the cost to the state of running them is more than the expenses of all the other royal families combined. Mr Brown's extra £39 a year for pensioners won't make a huge impression on the Queen; it might pay for an extra bunch of flowers, perhaps. In fact, the Palace says the Queen does not receive a state pension, even though, like anybody else over the age of 65, she is entitled to one.

fields.headline: No home for Che
fields.standfirst:
Dome 'barred sculpture to please arms firm'
The Millennium Dome: special report
fields.trailText: Management at the Millennium Dome refused to display a sculpture of the revolutionary Che Guevara for fear that it might offend the struggling attraction's arms manufacturer sponsors, an artist has claimed.
fields.body:
Management at the Millennium Dome refused to display a sculpture of the revolutionary Che Guevara for fear that it might offend the struggling attraction's arms manufacturer sponsors, an artist has claimed.

Gavin Turk, a leading light of Britart, wanted to put a waxwork of Guevara in the Mind zone, which is sponsored by BAe/Marconi, the UK's largest manufacturer of military hardware.

But he claims the idea was blocked by the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome. "They thought it would not go down well with Marconi as they make missiles," said Turk. However, BAe/ Marconi said it would have had no objections to the sculpture.

"We certainly would not have stood in the way of it. We would never dream of telling artists what they could or could not do. The contents as such were decided by the NMEC and its advisers, many of whom we believe have moved on."

Turk has since shown a version of the sculpture, Dead Che, based on the famous 1967 photograph of Guevara's Christ-like corpse, riddled with bullets, to acclaim at the White Cube<+>2 gallery, in London.

A spokesman denied that the NMEC had banned the sculpture. "A lot of ideas fell away early on, as you would expect. There had to be a filtering out process."

fields.headline: Graphic detail
fields.standfirst:
Within hours of the media embargo being lifted on Prince William, Channel 4 will be testing royal patience with an irreverent cartoon. Meg Carter reports


The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Within hours of the media embargo being lifted on Prince William, Channel 4 will be testing royal patience with an irreverent cartoon.
fields.body:
If you don't have an invitation to the party of the year - William's 18th, of course - Channel 4 has the answer. It will be screening Will's World, an animated account of Will's coming of age on the big night itself, June 21. The five-minute cartoon, which goes out post-watershed, after Sex in the City, is a raunchy satire on life in the royal household and family expectations of the heir to the throne. It will also be the first TV comedy about the prince following the lifting of the media embargo earlier on the same day.

The action opens with a boozy Tara and Tamara trying to find their way to the party . . . and running over a country bumpkin along the way. At the palace, two events are under way - a boisterous rave, and a more sedate family gathering in the room next door. The Queen and Prince Philip - depicted as half man, half dalek - are in attendance, along with William's three uncles. Edward is going on about how he wants to be a TV presenter. Andrew, meanwhile, is careering across the room in a helicopter.

As Will flits between the two bashes, he is intermittently grilled by his family about what career he wants to pursue - they collapse in hysterics when he announces he wants to join the SAS - and propositioned by a panting Britney Spears. Away from the formality of the family function, Britney is eager to seduce the young prince who, sadly, fails to understand and panics. Events come to a head when Will tumbles into the wrong room in Y-fronts, his trousers round his ankles.

"This is not the behaviour of a royal prince," his grandmother barks as, in the background, we see images of his uncles pursuing other unsuitable pursuits - such as fox hunting. In despair at his family and confused by his new-found sexuality, Will flees the palace with his trusty dog, Widgin, climbs on to his bike and - in classic ET style - is last seen escaping the clutches of the royal circle in a moonlit flight across the night sky.

Humorous pastiche, or gross infringement of the young prince's privacy? There's little doubt the cartoon, made by independent production company Fireside Favourites and directed by veteran animator Bob (Rhubarb & Custard, Henry's Cat) Godfrey for Channel 4, will cause a stir. Its producer, Gavin Claxton, insists he'd be extremely disappointed if it didn't. "If I thought a Daily Mail reader wouldn't be offended by this, I wouldn't be doing my job properly," he observes. "We're not writing for them but first and foremost for ourselves, and secondly for people whose opinions and sense of humour we know and respect."

The idea for Will's World came from Channel 4. The broadcaster had initially planned a Prince William theme night with an evening of programmes to mark his 18th birthday. It subsequently shelved the idea, but Will's World survived. Fireside Favourites was approached to make it - only the title, transmission data and slot were specified. "With a post-10.30pm transmission we knew we could be as raunchy as we wanted to be," Claxton says, "within reason - if we didn't want to lose our head."

Given Fireside's track record, the style and tone was always going to be quirky. Fireside's is a brand of animated humour people either instantly love or loathe. The company was set up last year to make a one-off comedy pilot for Channel 4 called All Aboard the Cat Bus (the story of what happens when Gwyneth Paltrow loses her English accent and attempts to get it restored by the Queen). Claxton and his writing partners Richard Preddy and Gary Howe - whose extensive comedy writing credits include work for Harry Enfield, Mel & Griff and Smack the Pony - pride themselves on their company motto: "Is it a joke, or is it a mistake?"

Animation can provide greater creative freedom than live action, says Claxton. "Would our parents have let us watch Tom and Jerry if it had been a real cat and a real mouse?" he asks. "Animation means you can push the boundaries - which is its appeal to us as comedy writers."

In Will's World, however, the aim wasn't to lampoon everything - that would have been too easy. "William's young, sympathetic, good-looking - so why take the piss?" Claxton explains. "Instead, we wanted to ask: what's he going to do? Like all disappointed mums, the Queen's pinning her hopes on her grandson, but how will he respond?" The end result is undoubtedly funny. And in gloriously dubious taste. Channel 4 should brace itself for the inevitable fallout, however, from those who will surely ask whether its remit should extend to exposing the heir to the throne so soon into his 19th year.

Will's World goes out on June 21, on Channel 4 at 10.55pm

webTitle: Islamic makeover for beauty parade pageant

fields.headline: Islamic makeover for beauty parade pageant
fields.standfirst:
Indonesia's beauty is skin-deep
Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Viewers who tuned in to watch the first Miss Indonesia competition for four years hoping to feast their eyes on bikini-clad beauties were in for a rude awakening at the weekend.
fields.body:
Viewers who tuned in to watch the first Miss Indonesia competition for four years hoping to feast their eyes on bikini-clad beauties were in for a rude awakening at the weekend.

The organisers had come up with a fresh spin on the western-style pageant in an attempt to pacify the numerous government, feminist and conservative Islamic critics who had joined forces to get the contest banned after the 1996 parade.

Gone were the swimsuits and questions about hobbies. Instead, there were more sophisticated outfits, searching questions about ways to resolve Indonesia's economic, social and political crises and a theme that sought to divert attention from the traditional skin-deep nature of the event.

Putri Kuswisnurwardhani, the chairman of the judges, said: "We have focused on the three "Bs" - beauty, brain and behaviour. In this way it will not be a superficial competition and the girls' inner personalities will shine through."

She said the winner was not chosen solely on the basis of her performance on Saturday night, but on how well she acquitted herself in interviews, excursions and seminars during the previous three days. The winner will represent Indonesia as a tourism ambassador at international events.

The semi-finalists were asked questions ranging from their attitude to abortion to how they would boost Indonesia's bad image overseas, while the three finalists had to explain what their first act would be, if they became president, to end the national crisis.

The organisers, a leading cosmetics company, also tried to persuade their detractors, notably the government, that the country should be represented at the annual Miss Universe beauty pageant.

They flew in Miss Universe, 21-year-old Indian student Lara Dutta, to explain the benefits of participating in the global beauty contest. "It puts your country on the world map," she said. "It gives you the chance to represent and showcase your country as ideals, traditions and culture to the rest of the world."

Howevere, this veneer of respectability did not impress Indonesian orthodox Muslims, who voiced opposition to the event.

"It should still be banned. They have merely tinkered with the edges," said Hilmi Zani Shohir, the head of an Islamic boarding school in West Java. "It is still exploiting women and encouraging them to conform to western stereotypes. Where is our national diversity?"

He had a point. There was little evidence in the competition to indicate that Indonesia has hundreds of ethnic groups and cultures. Most of the contestants were remarkably similar in skin colour and height.

Women's groups were less outspoken in their opposition. "Personally, I think it is a waste of time," said Liang, an activist with Women's Solidarity

"It's not even worth discussing when we have so many more pressing problems in Indonesia. But there are also two sides to every coin. If we want to consider ourselves a mature society we should not prohibit this sort of event. People should be free to take part if they want."

Bernika Irnadianis Ifada, 23, from Jakarta, was certainly glad she had. Holding the trophy and diamond-studded sceptre after being crowned Miss Indonesia 2000, she said she didn't expect to win.

She added: "I will just try to do my best to boost the beauty of Indonesia around the world."

webTitle: How Greer and Peel became a cautionary couple in the sixties

fields.headline: How Greer and Peel became a cautionary couple in the sixties
fields.trailText: Germaine Greer forced John Peel to sleep with her, Beryl Bainbridge paid a woman to have sex with her husband so she could get a divorce, and Joan Bakewell, now doyenne of religious affairs broadcasting at the BBC, smoked marijuana and had affairs.
fields.body:
Germaine Greer forced John Peel to sleep with her, Beryl Bainbridge paid a woman to have sex with her husband so she could get a divorce, and Joan Bakewell, now doyenne of religious affairs broadcasting at the BBC, smoked marijuana and had affairs.

The frank revelations by some of the most influential media figures of the past 40 years were made last night in a new BBC series, My Generation, in which Ms Bakewell discussed life, love and politics during the swinging 1960s with her contemporaries.

John Peel, 60, a Radio1 DJ, told Ms Bakewell about how Germaine Greer, the academic and feminist icon, forced him to sleep with her. "All I thought about was getting my end away. Germaine taught me a valuable lesson. She was a friend, somebody I liked and admired, and then she decided to presume on friendship and push it a step too far. I actually found myself saying: 'Look, I like you too much. I don't want to do this'. And she just made me. I thought: 'Oh shit, that's what it's like'."

Speaking from his home in Suffolk yesterday, the disc jockey said of the encounter, which took place before he married his wife of 25 years: "I'm sure it's an incident she would rather forget, but it was all free love and that sort of thing. One of the tabloids phoned me up and asked for a blow by blow account, but I'm not doing that.

"I think we are still friends. We don't exchange Christmas cards or anything, but I am always really pleased when I do see her."

Ms Greer, who became a household name in the 1970s after the publication of her groundbreaking book, The Female Eunuch, which was considered the bible of feminism, was unavailable for comment yesterday.

Other revelations in the programme included those from Beryl Bainbridge telling Ms Bakewell about how she paid a woman to sleep with her husband, Austen Davies, at a party so that she could get a divorce, something the novelist claimed was common practice at the time.

"It was all arranged. I took the children up the road, with a cot. There was a girl who, for a certain sum of money, put herself forward as correspondent and that went down on my divorce petition."

In an interview with the Observer, Ms Bakewell said the programme, made by the BBC's religious department, aimed to show how the liberal left ideas of the 1960s gave way to the rise of the right.

Ms Bakewell, who admitted to having affairs and smoking marijuana, said that even she was surprised by some of the frank revelations, particularly Mr Peel's.

"When it came up I thought: 'We can't transmit that'. But the editor said it makes a very positive point. Women didn't come on in those days. When Germaine did, it was a shock to John. It showed him how women might feel when men did it to them."

fields.headline: Drumcree marchers raise the stakes
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Orangemen in Portadown yesterday raised the stakes ahead of next month's annual flashpoint at Drumcree, demanding permission for a second march down the nationalist Garvaghy Road in the County Armagh town.
fields.body:
Orangemen in Portadown yesterday raised the stakes ahead of next month's annual flashpoint at Drumcree, demanding permission for a second march down the nationalist Garvaghy Road in the County Armagh town.

They promised there will be no repeat of last year's low-key approach to defuse the threat of violence, when the Portadown lodge surprisingly marched away from police lines after attending the Church of Ascension, Drumcree. Those tactics were aimed at winning permission for a march later in the year, and the Orangemen now feel spurned.

Drumcree has sparked crisis in Northern Ireland every July since 1995. Orangemen have been barred from walking their traditional route down the Garvaghy Road for the past two years, and have maintained a constant vigil on Drumcree hill since the parade was halted in 1998.

Brian Currin, a human rights lawyer from South Africa, arrived in Northern Ireland last week in a last-ditch effort to broker a compromise between the Orangemen and the Garvaghy Road Residents' Coalition. But both sides believe he has left it too late.

The march usually takes place the Sunday before July 12, the most important date in the Orange Order's calender. It marks the victory of William of Orange, leader of the Protestants, over the Catholic forces of King James II at the Battle of the Boyne in 1690.

It has demanded the Grand Lodge of Ireland, the overall body, changes it policy of refusing to recognise the commission, set up three years ago, a move which would have brought the chances of a successful application closer.

fields.headline: Engineers admit problem over bridge
fields.trailText: The millennium curse struck again yesterday as engineers on the Millennium Bridge across the Thames in London announced that the structure had developed an unspecified "problem" following its temporary closure at the weekend.
fields.body:
The millennium curse struck again yesterday as engineers on the Millennium Bridge across the Thames in London announced that the structure had developed an unspecified "problem" following its temporary closure at the weekend.

The footbridge linking St Paul's Cathedral and the Tate Modern at Bankside thus joined the ill-fated dome and the London Eye among millennium projects that have suffered early setbacks.

Engineers spent yesterday examining ways of reducing the swaying that led to police closing the bridge briefly on Saturday, and restricting access throughout the weekend. A spokeswoman stressed that there was no risk to safety after an estimated 150,000 people crossed the bridge in the first two days. "There is a team of engineers looking very carefully at the bridge and assessing what the problem is. As soon as we know what the cause of the movement is, we will tell people what we are going to do about it," she said.

David Bell, chairman of the trust, apologised to people who might have felt discomfort crossing the bridge. "The current problem, which involves excessive movement on the bridge in certain conditions, is something that we will overcome," he said.

"We are in discussions with the engineers to find out the exact cause. It is something that we will put right."

Despite earlier statements indicating the crossing was "100% safe", engineers conceded that they will have to combat the movement which left some visitors complaining of sickness. "We know what we've got to do, and there are measures we can take to sort this out," said one senior member of the team.

Saturday's closure came when people, alarmed at the movement of the structure, alerted police. "We anticipated 10,000 people on Saturday, but we think we had about 100,000 over the bridge," the spokesman said.

"We are satisfied we have now come up with a system to deal with these crowds. We will have someone down at the bridge to monitor the crowds."

Access to the bridge was restricted yesterday as about 50,000 people queued for up to 30 minutes to cross in groups of 60 at two-minute intervals.

The footbridge is London's first new river crossing for over 100 years. A cooperative design by Foster and Partners, sculptor Sir Anthony Caro and engineers Ove Arup and Partners, the bridge is also the longest horizontal suspension bridge ever built. A spokesman for Foster and Partners said: "The bridge is intended to have some movement. It's a suspension bridge - if there isn't movement there can be a problem."

The swaying problem comes a month after the bridge was inaugurated by the Queen, who was unable to cross the bridge because it had not been completed, and stopped some way short of the south bank.

While organisers hope the problem is little more than a hiccup on a project that has been widely praised for its elegance and environmental credentials - Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London, has praised it for being pedestrian friendly - the setback is the latest to afflict the capital's millennium projects.

The dome at Greenwich has suffered from poor attendances while the opening of the London Eye, the giant observation wheel on the south bank of the Thames overlooking Westminster, was delayed after problems with the pods.

Visitors yesterday appeared untroubled by the swaying, which is most marked at the southern end where the central walkway forks into two ramps down to the river bank. Mark Munro of Edinburgh said that for his son Jamie the swaying had added to the fun.

"He thinks it's a fairground ride - it's a terrific looking thing but it feels quite safe."

webTitle: Eton, beagling, and history of art

fields.headline: Eton, beagling, and history of art
fields.standfirst:
Denis Lawton wonders if this is suitable preparation for the future head of state

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: How well has William been educated and trained for inheriting the crown? It is not possible to make a sensible assessment of that issue without asking a more fundamental question: what kind of king does the country need?
fields.body:
How well has William been educated and trained for inheriting the crown? It is not possible to make a sensible assessment of that issue without asking a more fundamental question: what kind of king does the country need?

While there is now, according to much of the evidence, no real enthusiasm for a republic, there is certainly a range of views about the monarchy and its future. There are large numbers of citizens who are very critical of the personal behaviour of some individual members of the royal family. They also criticise the present financial arrangements whereby the taxpayer pays about twice as much as other Europeans pay for their royal families. (Do the Windsors really need five palaces as well as Sandringham and Balmoral?) As a reaction to much unfavourable publicity in the 1990s, the royal "firm" set up a small working party - the Way Ahead Group - to improve their public image, but there is little indication that they seriously considered the preparation of William for his future role. What kind of role should it be?

In a recent book about royal education, Peter Gordon and I began by looking at the changes over time in the role of the monarch - from the almost absolute power of the Tudors, to limitations placed on their absolutism by parliaments in the 17th century (when one king, Charles I, was executed and another, James II, was thrown out). We looked at further moves towards a constitutional monarchy in the 18th and 19th centuries and finally to the present situation, where monarchs have virtually no power but retain some of the symbols of power. For example, the Queen's speech and the ability to dissolve parliaments remain as misleading impressions of real power. Part of the training of modern monarchs has to be how to cope with such ambiguities: how to take ceremonial occasions seriously without being confused by the difference between appearance and reality. (That was one of the mistakes of the Queen's uncle, Edward VIII, and one of the reasons why he abdicated and was replaced by his more compliant brother.)

The problem of preparing individuals for this strange role is complex. Yet little thought seems to have been given to the kind of education future kings or queens should have. The problem is that the monarchy as an institution inevitably conflicts with some of the principles of modern democracy, such as equality of opportunity. Our present Queen's education was left almost entirely to a young nanny - Crawfie - whose own education was extremely limited. The top priority for Elizabeth's parents was that she should have a happy childhood, and they interpreted this to mean no school, no university, nothing too demanding. When Crawfie later broke the rules and wrote a book about life with the royals, she said she was surprised that the King and Queen showed so little interest in their daughter's education.

Although Elizabeth has, superficially, coped reasonably well with her constitutional position, it is said that she finds the company of academics and intellectuals difficult. Compared with many of her predecessors - Elizabeth I, for example - she has made little contribution to the artistic or intellectual life of her country. But Elizabeth I's education had been carefully planned according to Renaissance theories of education; she had been given the best tutors available, including Roger Ascham - not only a great scholar but an excellent teacher who wrote one of the best books of the 16th century about education, The Schoolmaster. Queen Elizabeth I surprised a group of foreign ambassadors by her ability to converse in French, Latin and Italian, and she had a real grasp of the theological, political and other issues of the day.

A little more thought was given to the education of the present Prince of Wales. His education at Gordonstoun, inspired by the German educator Kurt Hahn, seems to have produced an individual who cares about society and the environment, but his lower-second Cambridge arts degree has left him confused, prejudiced against science and much too fond (for a future constitutional monarch) of putting forward personal views as facts rather than opinions. What kind of education was "planned" for William?

At age three, William became a pupil at Mrs Mynor's private nursery school in west London. He stayed there until 1987 when he transferred to Wetherby School in Kensington, an exclusive pre-preparatory school. After three years he became a boarder at a preparatory school - Ludgrove School in Wokingham. His curricular and extracurricular activities were typical for boys going on to an elite independent school and university. In 1995, when he was 13, William passed his Common Entrance examination and proceeded to Eton, the most exclusive school in England.

He followed the normal Eton curriculum and wore the distinctive Eton uniform designed to mark off the privileged pupils from the less privileged outsiders: black tailcoats, striped trousers, white ties. Having been taught in small classes compared with state schools, it was not surprising that William passed 12 subjects at GCSE; he went on to study geography, biology and history of art for A-levels. His university course has yet to be made public but it is likely to be history of art at a non-Oxbridge University, probably Edinburgh.

The arrangements for "preparing" William for kingship also included the appointment of Tiggy Legge-Bourke: following the official separation of Charles and Diana in 1992, Legge-Bourke was appointed as a companion/nanny to William and Harry whenever they stayed with Charles. Her official position was assistant to the Prince of Wales's private secretary, but her duties were recreational and social - for example, helping to teach the boys to shoot rabbits. Clearly she was chosen for her social rather than intellectual accomplishments, since her academic qualifications consisted of four passes at O-level and a Montessori teaching certificate, which would not have qualified her for employment in a state school.

There are three reasons for suggesting that William's education has not been an adequate preparation for a future king. First, Eton, although a "good school" in some respects, is an unsuitable environment for a future king. At a time when the monarchy needs to become more "democratic", William has been brought up in a privileged institution, where he was socialised into thinking of himself as a superior person. At Eton he also became identified with such upper-class pursuits as beagling (hunting hares with dogs) and other blood sports, which many find offensive. He has mixed throughout his schooling with a limited section of the population. His education and training should have broadened his social experience, but have restricted it instead.

Second, the choice of history of art at university will not be adequate unless supplemented by courses that will give him a thorough understanding of the British constitution and his future position within it. A constitutional monarch has to learn that it is not possible to accept all the privileges of the role while ignoring its responsibilities and limitations; a special kind of moral education is needed. And does he know enough about national finances and how the parliamentary system works? Does he understand the Commonwealth, the European Union, the United Nations and other international organisations?

Finally, William needed to learn not to abuse his privileged position to foist his views on the rest of the population. The country needs someone who will demonstrate that he can have a useful but limited role in a modern democratic society. One of the dangers of being "prepared" for monarchy is that the deference paid to royalty, plus the privileged lifestyle, may actually encourage royals to believe that they are superior. That is not the kind of king the country wants or needs.

The advantage of having a monarch rather than a presidential system is that it places the position of head of state outside politics. Some would add that a royal head of state preserves valuable historical traditions and serves to unify a kingdom by reinforcing our national heritage. That is a more controversial view, not least because it involves contradictions and tensions between the traditional role of monarch and the modern principles of democracy. Part of the education and training of a future king must be to encourage the dignified performance of the role of head of state while constantly reminding the role-player that he is a normal human being in no way superior as a person to any of his subjects. This is a difficult lesson to learn: Edward VIII never grasped the distinction and some suggest that Prince Charles has occasionally been guilty of the same delusion.

In our book, Peter Gordon and I pointed out that in recent years the position of private secretary to a monarch or future monarch has been important in providing educative advice on the role of a constitutional king or queen. Several constitutional disasters have been avoided by taking good advice. We suggested that this kind of advisory role could be extended for Prince William and combined with an explicitly educative one with the appointment of a private secretary who would act also as a kind of moral tutor. Such a position would have to be filled carefully. But without some such arrangement the future of the monarchy might be in doubt. It may already be too late.

Although among the population as a whole there may be royalist support of a kind, among young people - the decision-makers of the future - the picture is less comforting for those who wish to preserve the status quo. Only a few days ago it was reported that Barry Hale, an 18-year-old comprehensive school pupil from Liverpool, had written an open letter to "Dear William" condemning the monarchy as an outdated institution that should be abolished. The letter was the basis of a BBC TV programme which was to be shown to coincide with the Prince's 18th birthday. The BBC has now scrapped the plan, though it may be shown "later".

Denis Lawton is professor of education at the Institute of Education, University of London, and author, with Professor Peter Gordon, of Royal Education: Past, Present and Future (published by Frank Cass).

fields.headline: Ladies in waiting
fields.standfirst:
He's the world's most eligible bachelor, and rumours abound over who will bag him - another toff, a rock star, an ex-con's daughter? Or will Prince William look even further afield for a future queen? Oliver Burkeman studies the form

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: He's the world's most eligible bachelor, and rumours abound over who will bag him - another toff, a rock star, an ex-con's daughter? Or will Prince William look even further afield for a future queen?  Oliver Burkeman  studies the form
fields.body:
Victoria Aitken

Age: 19.

Pedigree: Daughter of perjury enthusiast Jonathan and his ex-wife Lolicia.

Assets: Friends of the family, in a way: Victoria's dad has already spent some months as a guest of William's grandmother.

Liabilities: One photograph at one party showing the two within a two-metre radius of each other is not, it has to be said, the basis for the kind of marriage of which the average Relate counsellor would approve. Wills had never met her before and probably hasn't since.

Prospects: They've only ever met for a few minutes. But then, royal marriages have been based on less.

Britney Spears

Age: 18.

Pedigree: The daughter of devout baptists Jamie and Lynne, a building contractor and teacher from the nondescript Louisiana trucking town of Kentwood.

Assets: Like many a teenage boy, Wills is rumoured to have walls plastered with Britney pin-ups.And there have been claims that he's actually exchanged emails and gifts with the child-woman.

Liabilities: A hectic touring schedule probably wouldn't be compatible with ribbon-cutting duties.

Prospects: According to reports, Britney recently purchased Battledown Manor, a quick chauffeur-assisted ride from Highgrove. This looks promising - unless it signifies that, in true royal style, she aims to move out of Wills's house and into her own within weeks of the wedding.

Isabella Anstruther-Gough-Calthorpe

Age: 20.

Pedigree: Granddaughter of pre-war racing star Earl Curzon and daughter of 1960s debutante Mary-Gaye.

Assets: Three barrels, which must count for something. The only aristocrats ever to have longer names than this died of exhaustion signing credit-card receipts.

Liabilities: Breathless revelations in the Sunday Express that the It-girl of Edinburgh University and the young prince had formed "a close bond" were slightly undermined by a press complaints commission ruling which noted that they had, in fact, never met.

Prospects: Better than you might think. Perhaps actually meeting is where most recent royal couplings have gone wrong.

Princess Theodora of Greece

Age: 17.

Pedigree: Fourth child of King Constantine and his wife Queen Anne Marie.

Assets: Greek, which will be a big help with the grandparents. And royal.

Liabilities: There's the small awkwardness that Theodora's parents currently reside in Hampstead Garden Suburb, because the Greek royal family is in exile.

Prospects: Diplomatically tricky.

Davina Duckworth-Chad

Age: 21.

Pedigree: Her mother Elizabeth is Diana's first cousin, so she and the prince are related. Her father, Anthony, is a Norfolk landowner.

Assets: Brains, breeding and looks are all on her side. Plus, she showed up with Wills and others on the April 1999 cruise on board John Latsis's "love boat".

Liabilities: Davina's famous appearance dressed in rubber on Country Life's website won her the soubriquet "Deb on the web" - amusing now; pretty embarrassing when you're queen.

Zara Simmons

Age: 19.

Pedigree: Top aristo credentials. Zara is the granddaughter of Countess Hermione Ranfurly.

Assets: When she was 14 and he 12, he wrote her love letters and sent her chocolates, and they had a sweet holiday romance as guests of friends in Greece. Only . . .

Liabilities: . . . she dumped him.

Prospects: She reportedly kissed him at a 1996 party. And if that isn't watertight evidence of impending nuptials, we'd like to know what is.

Laura Spence

Age: 18.

Educated: Monkseaton communiuty high school, Whitley Bay, and, soon, Harvard University.

Assets: "Monkey High" is an unlikely breeding-ground for royal escorts, but now she's been snapped up by those assiduous snapper-uppers at Harvard's Snapping-Up Department, Spence will exude Ivy League allure.
Liabilities: For someone whose name has become synonymous with a crusade against elitism, marrying the next king isn't a wholly obvious next move.
Prospects: Slim. Even the persuasive powers of Monkseaton head Paul Kelley won't stretch to bringing about a royal wedding.

Sarah Gore

Age: 21.

Pedigree: One of four children of Al Gore - presidential hopeful and self-styled inventor of the internet - and his curiously named wife Tipper.

Assets: The fathers of the bride and groom, Prince Charles and putative president Al, are equally environmentally minded and would get on like fossil fuels on fire.

Liabilities: The Gores - Tennessee democrats - and the Windsors - home counties aristocrats - might not see eye to eye on other political questions.

Prospects: It might work - but for a real Special Relationship, Sarah, currently a college senior, would be better off waiting for one of the Blair boys to reach adulthood.

Laura Fellowes

Age: 19.

Pedigree: A cousin of Wills's, Laura is also the daughter of Sir Robert Fellowes, the Queen's former private secretary.

Assets: As a cousin, Fellowes might provide a whiff of that arguably inadvisable genetic proximity that has made the members of our royal family - and those strange mountain people in the film Deliverance - what they are.

Liabilities: On second thoughts, maybe that's not such a good idea.

Prospects: Stranger things have happened. And quite a few of them have happened to members of the British royal family.

Holly Branson

Age: 18.

Pedigree: Daughter of Richard and his second wife Joan.

Assets: A sizeable inheritance. Sufficient beauty to have already been a Cosmo model. And a declared ideal man who is "about 6ft 2in, dark, with blue eyes and a chunky build," on which Wills scores two out of four.

Liabilities: New money. A mindbogglingly large amount - but new money, none the less.

Prospects: A Virgin Queen might be a rebranding too far for Britain's least self-made family. And things wouldn't bode well for the punctuality of the royal train.

Stephen Gately

Age: 24.

Pedigree: Son of cleaning lady Margaret and her husband Martin, Gately's childhood on Dublin's rock-hard Sheriff Street was a world away from Wills's.

Assets: A Gately-Windsor union would modernise the monarchy at a stroke, doing away with the need for all those troublesome committees and Highgrove handwringing.

Liabilities: Gately's longstanding boyfriend Eloy de Jong, a Dutch musician, is extremely big.

Prospects: Too little in common. The coming-out endured by Gateley was, after all, a little more nerve-wracking than those of William's debutante chums.

webTitle: Teens say parents give them support

fields.headline: Teens say parents give them support
fields.standfirst: Most young people are happy with the levels of emotional care they receive from the adults in their family, according to new research
fields.trailText: A stereotype of simmering conflict between teenagers and their parents is punctured by research published today which shows a remarkably high level of satisfaction among young people with the quality of support they get from the adults in their family.
fields.body:
A stereotype of simmering conflict between teenagers and their parents is punctured by research published today which shows a remarkably high level of satisfaction among young people with the quality of support they get from the adults in their family.

A representative poll of 2,345 children aged 11-16 showed that three-quarters said their parents were always there for them when needed, and two-thirds said that they felt loved and cared for.

In confidential questionnaires conducted by Mori, 59% said they got on well with their parents, whereas only 20% reported arguing a lot. Even lower proportions thought that they did not get the attention they needed (11%), or that their parents made them feel bad about themselves (7%).

The survey, commissioned by the national family and parenting institute, did not seek to downplay serious tensions between a minority of teenagers and adults. They were the main cause of anxiety among callers seeking help from parent helplines last year.

But officers of the independent institute said they were surprised at the general mood of harmony between the generations reported by most young people. "Contrary to the Harry Enfield picture of the monster in family life, the majority of teenagers get on well with their parents," said Mary MacLeod, the institute's director.

The survey found that the most difficult age for teenagers' family relationships is 13, when the proportion of children saying that they get on well with their parents sinks below 50% before climbing back to 56% by 15-16. "It seems that age 13 is a crunch point," the researchers said.

The dip coincides with reduced help from parents with homework and an increasing tendency for the young people to say they cannot talk about their problems.

Although girls were more likely than boys to say they felt loved and cared for, there was little difference between the low proportions of girls and boys saying they were not understood or felt unvalued.

The survey showed clear differences of view between the young people and their parents about how best to raise happy children. Nearly three-quarters of the teenagers said it was important that children felt listened to and understood, compared with 41% of adults questioned in an earlier poll by the institute. Almost two-thirds of the children said that clear guidelines from their parents on what is right and wrong were important to their happiness, while only 40% of adults shared that view.

Among the young people, 70% said that their parents' relationship affected their happiness and that they would be unhappy if their parents did not get on well together. Only a third of parents thought their relationship had an impact on their children's happiness.

The young people were more divided on whether "parents should try and stay together for the sake of the children, even if they don't get on well" - with 42% agreeing and nearly a third disagreeing. Girls and children from single-parent families divided almost equally for and against.The poll findings were released to coincide with publication of a "survival guide" for parents of teenagers by Parentline Plus, a charity that provides helplines for parents to discuss their problems anonymously. Last year it took nearly 10,000 calls from parents of teenagers.

Almost half the parents using the service used derogatory terms to describe their children and at least threequarters labelled them in potentially damaging ways - needing to vent anger before being able to address the problems.

Dorit Braun, chief executive of Parentline Plus, said the overwhelmingly positive poll findings were not inconsistent with the evidence of stress among callers to the help-lines. Parents expressing anxiety might not realise from the behaviour of their children that they felt loved. Or their children might be among the 20% reporting lots of arguments.

Tensions usually built up over a long time and the flash points were varied, often including school attendance, sexuality, possible drug use, or illegal/dubious behaviour.

"Parenting can feel difficult, isolated and lonely. The institute's survey is reassuring in terms of the number of children who feel loved, but that doesn't make the task of parenting any easier and people should not feel embarrassed to seek support," Ms Braun said.

'Worst error lay in lecturing him'

Frances is a single mother in her early 50s. She has lived in London with her son David, 17, since she split from his father when David was very young. Their names have been changed. She says:

"The problems started when David was just 11 years old - sooner than I had expected. At the time, I put it down to changing schools but it got worse over the next year and he became verbally abusive all the time.

The mood swings would come out of the blue and I would have to try to gauge when he could be spoken to or not. I wasn't ever scared that he would physically attack me, but I was scared of how little control I had.

I had gone on a parenting course when he was six so I thought we had the boundaries set up. He's very, very bright and a straight-A student, but they're the worst because they have an answer for everything.

We had huge screaming rows on a daily basis for a while and he would throw tantrums, trying to blackmail me into buying him the latest designer labels. When he was 13 and 14, he used to disappear with his friends and I never knew where he was.

He was arrested once for writing graffiti and he got handcuffed, but the worst moment for me was when he got into trouble for damaging some property at school and I saw his whole life going up the spout.

He smokes cannabis but he says he's too bright to drink, smoke tobacco, sniff glue or do any other drugs, so it could be a lot worse.

I felt very ashamed by the breakdown of our relationship and I didn't tell any friends or relatives what was going on. But then I did another parenting course, which taught me how to listen to him.

I think my biggest mistake was to lecture him because he just shuts down. My hot tip to other parents would be to make relationships with their friends - it's absolutely vital - and to keep the lines of communication open. We're through the worst now but there's still a long way to go."

Ten tips for parents with teenagers

Try a general chat with friends and relatives about their teenagers - you may pick up some useful ideas

Give yourself time to relax, enjoy yourself and recharge your batteries

Be caring and firm but be prepared to compromise sometimes

Really listen to what your teenager has to say

Show interest in what your teenagers are doing, but do not pry into their personal lives

Help teenagers set their own limits; it helps them take on more responsibility for themselves

Keep things in perspective. Is what you are disagreeing on really important?

Let them know there are other people they can talk to if they are not ready to talk to you - relatives, friends and helplines, for example

Enjoy them as young adults and praise their progress and achievements, big and small

Do not be afraid to seek help if it is necessary

Source - Parenting Teenagers: A Survival Guide for Mums and Dads, published by Parentline Plus
Additional reporting by Julia Hartley-Brewer

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A report headed Bombing strikes stepped up in 'secret war' against Iraq, page 2, June 8, mistakenly stated that two no-fly zones, policed by British and US planes, were agreed by the UN after the 1991 Gulf war. The Foreign Office says the no-fly zones were set up "in support of" UN security council resolution 688 (1991) which demands that the government of Iraq cease oppression of its civilian population, particularly in the northern Kurdish area. The British and US governments justify the no-fly zones on grounds of "overwhelming humanitarian   necessity" - the reasons given for Nato's bombing of Serbia. There is no basis for such intervention in international law. In the same piece we spoke of the Shia minority in Iraq. In fact more than 60% of the population is Shia.
fields.body:
A report headed Bombing strikes stepped up in 'secret war' against Iraq, page 2, June 8, mistakenly stated that two no-fly zones, policed by British and US planes, were agreed by the UN after the 1991 Gulf war. The Foreign Office says the no-fly zones were set up "in support of" UN security council resolution 688 (1991) which demands that the government of Iraq cease oppression of its civilian population, particularly in the northern Kurdish area. The British and US governments justify the no-fly zones on grounds of "overwhelming humanitarian necessity" - the reasons given for Nato's bombing of Serbia. There is no basis for such intervention in international law. In the same piece we spoke of the Shia minority in Iraq. In fact more than 60% of the population is Shia.

In a column, page 5, G2, June 9, on more relaxed attitudes towards dress at work, we said that the management consultants, Arthur Andersen, had initiated "dressing-down Friday" in January this year. In fact dressing-down Friday had already been running for a couple of years before it was extended, from January this year, through out the week and throughout the company. Arthur Andersen say they have left the response to individuals and never issued directives.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Some evidence of an unholy alliance with science

fields.headline: Some evidence of an unholy alliance with science
fields.trailText: Dr Mae-Wan Ho of the Open University stepped forward and identified herself (Letters, June 8) as the anti-GM university biologist whom I had written about (A misguided media swarm, June 6). She claims that she had answered my questions in full at the GM debate. She did not. They do indeed remain most emphatically unanswered.
fields.body:
Dr Mae-Wan Ho of the Open University stepped forward and identified herself (Letters, June 8) as the anti-GM university biologist whom I had written about (A misguided media swarm, June 6). She claims that she had answered my questions in full at the GM debate. She did not. They do indeed remain most emphatically unanswered.

What is the evidence that GM constructs "overcome natural processes that break down foreign genetic material"; and that "GM constructs are more unstable than natural genetic material as well as more invasive"?

In this third invitation, I ask Dr Ho to please cite the primary data, not reviews in books or articles but original research, published in internationally recognised refered scientific journals to support these statements.

I am a professional scientist with an open mind and I seek the truth whatever it is. I need supporting experimental evidence. That is how science works.

Prof Conrad Lichtenstein
School of biological sciences Queen Mary & Westfield College, University of London
c.p.lichtenstein@qmw.ac.uk

 Your photograph of the stricken nuclear power station (Chernobyl to close 14 years after disaster, June 6) is itself sufficient answer to Michael Rennie's question "Why is it that in Britain there is such a strong anti-scientific bias?' (Don't be afraid, June 6).

Most non-scientists are suspicious of science and with good cause. Scientists rightly value evidence and the public also values the evidence that events like Chernobyl, or for example the thalidomide tragedy and the CFC's generated hole in the ozone layer, present them with. Nor is confidence improved when we are assured in other cases that there is nothing to worry about and subsequently it becomes evident that there was a great deal - witness BSE. The inevitable conclusion is that scientists cannot be trusted with science.

Thirty years as a professional scientist and 10 as a parish minister have taught me that scientists are no more and no less wise, honest or ethical than the rest of the population. Science is exciting and worth pursuing but after more than a century and a half of its technological exploitation we should have learned a little respect for the things we only partly understand.
Rev Dr Stephen Hunt
Preston

 I contest Michael Rennie's assertion that the pharmaceutical industry is the "only truly vibrant research-led industry" left in the UK. In terms of research intensity, the UK aerospace industry is second only to the pharmaceutical industry, and well ahead of other UK manufacturing sectors in R&D activity. Public and private investment in R&D has ensured that the UK aerospace industry can hold its own in world markets, exporting nearly 70% of its turnover last year.
Keith Hayward
Head of research, Society of British Aerospace Companies

fields.trailText: I read with incredulity your story (Minister admits GM crop failings, June 9), which claimed that I had been "kept in the dark for six weeks by the Ministry of Agriculture over the unlawful spread of GM into crops". This is simply not the case. I was briefed on the situation very early on while the Department for Environment, Transport and Regions, the Ministry of Agriculture and the Foods Standards Agency were establishing all the facts.

fields.headline: Pokemon's winning hand
fields.trailText: My six-year-old son is a Pokemon fan, but luckily I live in Mexico City, unlike Hilary Cooper (Fleecing kids, June 10). My son has all the Pokemon cards that he will ever want and he also has the various Pokemon cassettes for his Gameboy machine. Does this mean that I am a wally? No, it does not.
fields.body:
My six-year-old son is a Pokemon fan, but luckily I live in Mexico City, unlike Hilary Cooper (Fleecing kids, June 10). My son has all the Pokemon cards that he will ever want and he also has the various Pokemon cassettes for his Gameboy machine. Does this mean that I am a wally? No, it does not.

In Mexico, everyone who has an off-set litho machine, or a colour scanner and printer, is churning out these cards to be sold for coppers on the street. The cassettes for the Gameboy, indeed the machine itself, are all pirated in small factories.

Only a wally would pay the prices Sony wants to charge.
Ken Bell
Col. Tlaltenco, Mexico kenbell@prodigy.net.mx

 One thing Hilary Cooper fails to mention about the marketing strategy used for the Pokemon card game is that it is nothing new. The whole apparatus of the collectable card game - starter packs, boosters containing one or two valuable cards and a lot of dross, different levels of rarity and so on - has been around for about 10 years.

The first (and perhaps best) game to employ this strategy was the hugely successful Magic: the Gathering, published by Wizards of the Coast, the same company responsible for Pokemon cards. They have certainly had plenty of experience in getting the formula right. In the early to mid 90s a large number of similar collectable card games came out. The only thing new about Pokemon is that it is being pitched at a younger audience than was the case for previous games of the genre.
Roger Musson
Edinburgh Roger@abaxial.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Surgeons on piecework
fields.trailText: I was surprised that, as an economics professor, Julian Le Grand could advocate that hospital consultants be paid per operation performed (Letters, June 9). This simply would not work.
fields.body:
I was surprised that, as an economics professor, Julian Le Grand could advocate that hospital consultants be paid per operation performed (Letters, June 9). This simply would not work.

Operative procedures are carried out by teams which include anaesthetists, surgeons, technicians, nurses, auxiliaries, porters, sterile supplies staff, engineers, pharmacists, administrators and managers. Each of these, and others, could help or hinder an operating list crucially. Most would consider it unfair to have their pay depend on the performance of others they work with. Far better if all staff work on a professional basis for a salary.

The perverse incentive does exist and I agree that it should be corrected. To do so by importing private sector practices into the NHS would be cripplingly expensive and would destroy the public service ethos which keeps many NHS staff working.

The better solution would be to remove the interdependence of the sectors and Polly Toynbee (How to fix the consultants, June 7) identified a way of doing it. Buying out the right to moonlight (or daylight) in the private sector would remove the criticism that those who benefit from the waiting lists control their lengths
Dr Mark Porter Burbage
Leicestershire
mark.porter@appleonline.net

 Prof Le Grand seems to think that the way forward is to pay consultants on a fee per item of service basis, but seems unaware that consultants have been trying to achieve such a system for many years. However, politicians will not agree to this because they know that the NHS exploits its consultants, not the other way around.

I retired from my NHS hospital consultant post nearly three years ago and at private rates, I would have had an income in the year before that of more than £3,250,000 for the completed cases I personally carried out, compared with an actual salary of less than £60,000.

The only reason any con sultant carries out private practice is because the NHS consultant salary scale is so poor (£48,000 to £63,000 per annum) for the very high qualifications required. Incidentally, most consultants are on call several nights per week and 20 weekends per year, for no extra remuneration, even if they are called into the hospital and are working all night. All consultants have been junior hospital doctors for many years and do not become consultants until their late 30s, on average.
Dr Bill Easson Buxton
Derbyshire

 Does Prof Le Grand not know of his many fellow academics who spend much of their time in well paid consultancies or as directors of technology companies, rather than in the teaching or research for which the public pays them? Years ago, when my son was at LSE, one of his professors was hardly ever to be seen. He was busy earning a living as a psephologist.
Cyril Cooper
Tonbridge, Kent

 Prof Le Grand has got it - surgeons on piecework! Think of the opportunities that opens up. We could install conveyor belts and get rid of all those moaners whose trolleys block the corridors.
Ian W Greig
Wigan, Lancashire
IanWGreig@cs.com

 Surely this particular argument was settled by the late Richard Titmuss when he said long ago that if any NHS administration was stupid enough to bring in such a payment system for doctors then, "there wouldn't be a foreskin left in the country by Christmas".
Tom Richardson
Oxford

webTitle: Nato and the laws of war

fields.headline: Nato and the laws of war
fields.trailText: Isabel Hilton (Nato's shame, June 8) not only expressed views I disagree with but more importantly attributed views to me that were totally inaccurate. She said, referring to the legitimacy of Nato's action in Kosovo, "you could take the robust view that a war crime committed by men with pure hearts and high moral purpose (ie our side) is not a war crime. George Robertson, indeed, has come perilously close to such a position."
fields.body:
Isabel Hilton (Nato's shame, June 8) not only expressed views I disagree with but more importantly attributed views to me that were totally inaccurate. She said, referring to the legitimacy of Nato's action in Kosovo, "you could take the robust view that a war crime committed by men with pure hearts and high moral purpose (ie our side) is not a war crime. George Robertson, indeed, has come perilously close to such a position."

I most certainly have not. My view has always been that Nato had sufficient legal basis to act in Kosovo. We followed the law to prevent others committing war crimes. Attempts to say Nato's action as a whole was illegal were rejected by the UN security council at the time. Claims that individual actions were war crimes have been rejected recently by Carla del Ponte, the chief prosecutor of the UN's International Criminal Tribunal for Yugoslavia, who said of Nato's actions: "I am very satisfied there was no deliberate targeting of civilians or unlawful military targets by Nato during the bombing campaign".

Nato was right to act last year and did so while working within the confines of the laws of war. Our action was moral and lawful. No one doubts our action was controversial and Isabel Hilton is entitled to her views, but not to distort mine.
Lord Robertson
Secretary general, Nato

 Congratulations to Isabel Hilton for exposing the illegality and immorality of Nato aggression in Kosovo. Tony Blair should call a halt to our participation in warlike acts carried out without the authority of the UN, as in Kosovo, Iraq and Sierra Leone. George Robertson's call last week for the re-arming of Nato should be rejected as it presages further interventions which are antagonistic to the search for world peace.
D Sheldon
Epsom

fields.headline: Andrew Meldrum@Harare
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Ordinary life continues in Zimbabwe even though this country is plunged in a profound political and economic crisis. People still go to work in the mornings, children go to school and people shop for food. But there are telling differences. Going to work is often delayed by two or three hours in order to queue for fuel, which has been at 50% of ordinary consumption since December.
fields.body:
Ordinary life continues in Zimbabwe even though this country is plunged in a profound political and economic crisis. People still go to work in the mornings, children go to school and people shop for food. But there are telling differences. Going to work is often delayed by two or three hours in order to queue for fuel, which has been at 50% of ordinary consumption since December.

Going to school has been disrupted by political violence which has shut nearly 300 schools across the country, particularly in the rural areas. President Robert Mugabe's supporters have barged into schools and beaten teachers suspected of supporting opposition parties. More schools are planning to close around the time of the June 24 and 25 elections.

Shopping, too, has been affected. The prices of basic foods like tomatoes and onions have tripled because of the disruption to farms caused when war veterans ransacked and trashed several large producers of those vegetables. A waiter explains that several items on the menu are not available because "of the mess our country is in". His comment produces rueful laughter at the table.

In other words, virtually every facet of daily life has been affected by Zimbabwe's crisis. Economists say Zimbabwe has "the world's fastest shrinking economy" with the GDP forecast to contract by 5% or even 10% this year.

For 20 years Zimbabwe has been a country full of hope and optimism. There have been considerable problems, but they have always been offset by the numerous people who could see the way out of the trouble and find solutions to the problem. But in the past few months that positive thinking has shrunk. Those who still have a sunny outlook for the country are dismissed as ostriches with their heads in the sand. Zimbabwe has rather quickly become a nation of worried and alarmed people.

I carry on, like everyone else. But in a crisis many ordinary tasks become casualties. I have not serviced my car, for example, nor have I replaced some burned out light bulbs in my home. I must wade through stacks of newspapers to get to my office desk. I have become accustomed to making do with not enough sleep, skipping meals and rushing to the country's next catastrophe.

Friends have confirmed they have a similar sense of anxiety. Normally tidy homes are now in disarray. Ordinarily cool, calm and collected people now seem more scatty and more emotional. This nervous edge has given social gatherings a new electricity. Parties have a "fin de regime" hilarity. People drink more and laugh more loudly. Conversations have become more intense. And there are many more goodbye parties. Last night I went to a party for a Yugoslavian friend who had sought refuge in Zimbabwe from her war-torn country. Now she is off to seek a new life in New Zealand.

"People say New Zealand is boring," she said. "But after Yugoslavia and now Zimbabwe, I want someplace boring. I don't want the heartbreak of seeing another country go to pieces."

Newspapers carry advertisements from "emigration experts" who, for a fee, will advise people on their chances of moving to Australia, Canada, Portugal and New Zealand. It is not just white flight that is affecting Zimbabwe. The audience at a recent seminar about moving to Australia was about 40% white, 30% Asian and 30% black. And the blacks were doctors, lawyers, architects and other well-educated, highly skilled people. At the bottom end of the social ladder, poor Zimbabweans are sneaking into neighbouring countries. South Africa is flooded with hundreds of illegal Zimbabweans every week.

Most people have grasped that the future of the country is at stake. I find I am driving my car faster, playing my radio louder and living just a bit closer to the edge.

fields.headline: Diving into the unknown
fields.standfirst:
Very soon we will hear of the most important scientific breakthrough of our lives and it's a frightening prospect

The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: It could be this week, it could be next. Any day now, we will hear of what will probably be the most significant scientific discovery of our lifetime. The publicly funded international Human Genome Project is promising a "working draft" of the human genome, while the US private company, Celera is racing to beat them with what it calls its "First Assembly".
fields.body:
It could be this week, it could be next. Any day now, we will hear of what will probably be the most significant scientific discovery of our lifetime. The publicly funded international Human Genome Project is promising a "working draft" of the human genome, while the US private company, Celera is racing to beat them with what it calls its "First Assembly".

Don't hold your breath. In the long run, these discoveries may promise to transform our understanding of how our bodies work, offer cures for all types of genetic diseases and open up a frightening Pandora's box of eugenic possibilities. (Do you want your daughter clever or long-legged or both, sir?) But all that still lies a few years off. What we will have, as John Maynard Smith (one of the world's greatest evolutionary biologists) said recently, will be "like wanting to learn Hungarian and being given lists of all the Hungarian words but without any of them defined". Not only will we not have a clue as to what any of First Assembly means, but neither will the scientists.

And that is just one of the many reasons why the human genome discoveries make people nervous - the sense that we are launching into a huge unknown territory which makes all we have so far discovered look puny in comparison. As geneticist Norton Zinder comments in this week's lead article in the New Yorker, The Genome Wars, "This is the beginning of the beginning." There's nothing more frightening than being in Year Zero.

Here we are facing a scientific breakthrough like Newton's laws of gravity or Darwin's theory of evolution, and the predominant emotion is fear. And it is not just the usual mixture of conservatives and reactionaries who are edgy. Many scientists are as well, even some of those at the heart of the whole enterprise, the Human Genome Project.

There are very good reasons for this. Craig Venter, who runs the private company, Celera, scares a lot of people. His methods of distributing the information his company discovers only to subscribers who in turn spew out applications for patents on genes, raises the prospect of this new territory being parcelled out to US pharmaceutical companies before anyone else has even got a map. What's more, the brave new world of genetic research could be stillborn, bogged into a quagmire of patent law in which the only beneficiaries will be teams of US corporate lawyers.

To old-fashioned public-spirited scientists, it is deeply repulsive that some thing as important as the human genome has become the plaything of a flamboyant entrepreneur who wants to use it to become the world's first bio-tech billionaire. And that it becomes an object of the vagaries of the stock market speculation; Celera's energetic PR division ensures a slew of hyperbolic media attention, which has had its share price yo-yoing up and down the Nasdaq - even at one point dragging the whole stock index with it. The result is a stream of abuse between Venter and the scientists in the international Human Genome Project - the British end of which is being carried out in the Sanger Centre, Cambridge. As a scientist concludes in the New Yorker: "It happens to be the most important project in science of our time, and it has all the character of a schoolyard brawl."

Perhaps all such scientific discoveries are marked by territorialism, money-making ambitions and squabbles, but these are writ-large in billions of dollars and they coincide with a period of growing distrust of scientists and what happens to their discoveries. Genetic modification may or may not have great advantages for human beings and the environment, but what the past few years has undoubtedly shown is how pernicious the discovery is in the hands of an unscrupulous corporation intent on maximum commercialisation. The point is that our capacity at an institutional and governmental level to regulate the exploitation of scientific discovery seems to be woefully inadequate.

Part of this lies in the globalisation of scientific research. The British government can do little to stop GM developments in the US and, as we have painfully discovered over the GM contaminated rape seed case, we can't isolate ourselves from it either. Part of this weak regulation also lies in the commercialisation of scientific research in this country and elsewhere, as successive governments have encouraged university laboratories into cosy relationships with the private sector, opting out of both funding research and directing it.

To have government as such a weak agent at this historic moment in science, exacerbates our fear about what kind of morality will we develop for this new era. Our generation will face huge moral dilemmas - what's wrong with cloning? What genetic disorders do we weed out? What kind of eugenics is acceptable? - and we are without any of the old moral compasses. There is a paradox here, about the huge power we have developed - the computer revealed last week with a capacity millions times that of a PC - and a sense of impotence over knowing how or what to control of our discoveries.

Beyond all these understandable, rational reasons for anxiety over the human genome project, lies an instinctive fear. We don't much like the idea that in 15 or so years, all the biological make-up of our bodies could be carried on a smart card: will we be reduced to a computer print-out. It's a shock to human psychology as far-reaching as Galileo's blow to the medieval mind when he put the sun not the earth at the centre of the universe, or when Darwin told us we were descended from apes. More than 500 or so years of western scientific thought, human egotism and self-importance has been repeatedly punctured: we are not God-made masters of creation, but share most of our genes with a vacantly staring cow.

Real and reasonable some of these anxieties may be. We must think what we want from the human genome project, scientifically and morally, and press government to regulate it to those ends. Citizenship will require some moral philosophy over the next decades. But we also need some sense of bravery to carry us into this new era, so that our anxieties don't blind us to the hope the human genome project could bring.

One of the most painful moments in my journalistic career was when I sat in the home of a Muslim woman whose husband had left her. In her lap lay an adorable sleeping child, dressed in pink satin; on the walls were photos of another child - who had died of an incurable genetic disorder. She told me, with the terrible clarity of someone in a state of traumatised shock, that the child in her lap was unlikely to live much longer and her husband had divorced her because she was the carrier. If genetic research can alleviate such suffering, then there is reason to celebrate the announcement of the first drafts of the human genome.
