In the long run, these discoveries may promise to transform our understanding of how our bodies work, offer cures for all types of genetic diseases and open up a frightening Pandora's box of eugenic possibilities. (Do you want your daughter clever or long-legged or both, sir?) But all that still lies a few years off. What we will have, as John Maynard Smith (one of the world's greatest evolutionary biologists) said recently, will be "like wanting to learn Hungarian and being given lists of all the Hungarian words but without any of them defined". Not only will we not have a clue as to what any of First Assembly means, but neither will the scientists. And that is just one of the many reasons why the human genome discoveries make people nervous - the sense that we are launching into a huge unknown territory which makes all we have so far discovered look puny in comparison. As geneticist Norton Zinder comments in this week's lead article in the New Yorker, The Genome Wars, "This is the beginning of the beginning." There's nothing more frightening than being in Year Zero. Here we are facing a scientific breakthrough like Newton's laws of gravity or Darwin's theory of evolution, and the predominant emotion is fear. And it is not just the usual mixture of conservatives and reactionaries who are edgy. Many scientists are as well, even some of those at the heart of the whole enterprise, the Human Genome Project. There are very good reasons for this. Craig Venter, who runs the private company, Celera, scares a lot of people. His methods of distributing the information his company discovers only to subscribers who in turn spew out applications for patents on genes, raises the prospect of this new territory being parcelled out to US pharmaceutical companies before anyone else has even got a map. What's more, the brave new world of genetic research could be stillborn, bogged into a quagmire of patent law in which the only beneficiaries will be teams of US corporate lawyers. To old-fashioned public-spirited scientists, it is deeply repulsive that some thing as important as the human genome has become the plaything of a flamboyant entrepreneur who wants to use it to become the world's first bio-tech billionaire. And that it becomes an object of the vagaries of the stock market speculation; Celera's energetic PR division ensures a slew of hyperbolic media attention, which has had its share price yo-yoing up and down the Nasdaq - even at one point dragging the whole stock index with it. The result is a stream of abuse between Venter and the scientists in the international Human Genome Project - the British end of which is being carried out in the Sanger Centre, Cambridge. As a scientist concludes in the New Yorker: "It happens to be the most important project in science of our time, and it has all the character of a schoolyard brawl." Perhaps all such scientific discoveries are marked by territorialism, money-making ambitions and squabbles, but these are writ-large in billions of dollars and they coincide with a period of growing distrust of scientists and what happens to their discoveries. Genetic modification may or may not have great advantages for human beings and the environment, but what the past few years has undoubtedly shown is how pernicious the discovery is in the hands of an unscrupulous corporation intent on maximum commercialisation. The point is that our capacity at an institutional and governmental level to regulate the exploitation of scientific discovery seems to be woefully inadequate. Part of this lies in the globalisation of scientific research. The British government can do little to stop GM developments in the US and, as we have painfully discovered over the GM contaminated rape seed case, we can't isolate ourselves from it either. Part of this weak regulation also lies in the commercialisation of scientific research in this country and elsewhere, as successive governments have encouraged university laboratories into cosy relationships with the private sector, opting out of both funding research and directing it. To have government as such a weak agent at this historic moment in science, exacerbates our fear about what kind of morality will we develop for this new era. Our generation will face huge moral dilemmas - what's wrong with cloning? What genetic disorders do we weed out? What kind of eugenics is acceptable? - and we are without any of the old moral compasses. There is a paradox here, about the huge power we have developed - the computer revealed last week with a capacity millions times that of a PC - and a sense of impotence over knowing how or what to control of our discoveries. Beyond all these understandable, rational reasons for anxiety over the human genome project, lies an instinctive fear. We don't much like the idea that in 15 or so years, all the biological make-up of our bodies could be carried on a smart card: will we be reduced to a computer print-out. It's a shock to human psychology as far-reaching as Galileo's blow to the medieval mind when he put the sun not the earth at the centre of the universe, or when Darwin told us we were descended from apes. More than 500 or so years of western scientific thought, human egotism and self-importance has been repeatedly punctured: we are not God-made masters of creation, but share most of our genes with a vacantly staring cow. Real and reasonable some of these anxieties may be. We must think what we want from the human genome project, scientifically and morally, and press government to regulate it to those ends. Citizenship will require some moral philosophy over the next decades. But we also need some sense of bravery to carry us into this new era, so that our anxieties don't blind us to the hope the human genome project could bring. One of the most painful moments in my journalistic career was when I sat in the home of a Muslim woman whose husband had left her. In her lap lay an adorable sleeping child, dressed in pink satin; on the walls were photos of another child - who had died of an incurable genetic disorder. She told me, with the terrible clarity of someone in a state of traumatised shock, that the child in her lap was unlikely to live much longer and her husband had divorced her because she was the carrier. If genetic research can alleviate such suffering, then there is reason to celebrate the announcement of the first drafts of the human genome. madeleine.bunting@theguardian.com

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: • New media and glamour are still rather awkward bedfellows this side of the pond. In America, rock goddess Courtney Love attends the Webbies while the only celebrity presence at the British version, the New Media Age Effectiveness awards held at the Grosvenor House hotel last week, was "mother's favourite" camp comic Graham Norton. That said, the guests did their utmost to make the evening swing. John Pluthero, chief executive of Freeserve - looking strained after a long week in which rumours were circulating about the lock-stock sale of the company to T-Online - declared to a group of guests that he felt like getting "really trashed" and then promptly disappeared in the direction of the ice sculpture, which was oozing vodka. He was not alone. The founders of e-commerce portal LetsBuyIt.com, who took the Grand Prix prize, must have been smarting from the knowledge that they were having to delay the flotation of their company (planned for last Wednesday) due to the current economic climate and industry speculation about their cashflow problems. But it was the editor of NMA himself, Mike Butcher, who was in for the biggest surprise of the evening. "I couldn't believe it. This woman pulled down her skirt and showed me her knickers... it was a G-string," he recalls a bit shakily. "I've been in a state of, er, deep memory recovery ever since."

*One of the hot topics at Monday's Eurotech conference in London was the threat of wireless viruses. After a nasty little strain called "timofonica", designed to disrupt the Telefonica network, was uncovered in Spain last week ("timo" being Spanish for prank), doom-mongers are predicting telephonic terrorism on a potentially catastrophic scale unless security measures are taken now.

*Pseudo.com, the US-based entertainment network, which in the last few months has grown from a two-horse "webshack" specialising in rap music and videogames to a mainstream broadcaster, is looking for "strong partners" in Europe as part of its mission to spread "pseudotainment" around the world. In the UK it will come up against competition from the recently launched virtueTV.com, which has already signed up artists such as Fatboy Slim, Suede and Stereophonics.

*News Network launched its recruitment lifestyle portal, Revolver.com, last week. Its headlining "scoop" is an interview with TV presenter Jon Snow in which he reveals a lifelong desire to be an airline pilot. Ah, le temps perdu.

fields.headline: Aroon Maharajh
fields.standfirst: www.musicunsigned.com
fields.trailText: Age? 33
fields.body:
Age? 33

Who is he? MD and founder of musicunsigned.com, an independent online music company (since September 1999). Ex-clothing manufacturer and merchandiser for radio stations and record companies.

What's the idea? "To showcase new talent in a new way on the net. Eight of our acts have already been signed, that means 10% of the acts on our site. I thought, if we could use the net and give some sort of evidence that these acts were working on the net, that they were getting global coverage, I could say: 'Listen, don't tell me they're not worth a record deal.' We're playing a major part at Glastonbury, sponsoring the Greenfields tunnel, transforming it into a sound spectacular where people can create their own sounds, and co-promoting the New Bands Stage. We've set up a competition featuring six bands on the website; two acts will be selected to perform at Glastonbury."

What's the thinking behind it? "As far back as November 1998, I saw these guys behind their desks inundated with CDs and demos. And I thought, we must be able to do something to try and showcase these acts. Why not use the net? We want to give every unsigned act as much exposure as possible. We want to give them their chance to go out there, get interviewed, get in the door. That's how it started. To be honest, I don't think the industry was that keen on the idea, but now everyone's talking about the net and things are changing."

How does it work? "Basically, anybody can submit their material to us. We'll listen to it. And if our A&R team thinks we could further someone in their music career, then we'll upload them and stream three of their tracks. And when we say stream, it's not downloadable, recordable or MP3."

Possible shortcomings? "The actual clarity of the lines could be clearer. We would like in the future to offer downloadable items or compilations of our music, but buying a CD over the counter takes a second and until PCs can offer that, we're not really interested."

What's next? "We've got our online radio station that launches in August - soundlocation.com. We're going to push the publishing side through, which is basically the rights ownership. Songlocation, our online plugging service, where writers can meet producers and producers can meet writers, is fantastic. Ad agencies can go there and buy tracks online. We've got the blue list directory, which is all free, basically the yellow pages for the music industry - we're hoping to make it global. Last year I jumped over the fences to deliver fliers at Glastonbury. This year we're sponsoring it."

webTitle: He's the best prime minister we've got

fields.headline: He's the best prime minister we've got
fields.standfirst:
But that does not mean that he is beyond all criticism

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Back in 1997 - a couple of days after I had been mildly critical of New Labour's education policy - a fellow survivor from the Wilson and Callaghan government telephoned to congratulate me on maintaining the sense of timing which had characterised my ministerial career. "It was rotten then," he said. "And it is rotten now." He justified his opinion of my tactical skill with the assertion that it was stupid to attack Blairism while Tony Blair himself was on the crest of the wave. Wait, he urged me, until the tide begins to turn. That is the time to sink them.
fields.body:
Back in 1997 - a couple of days after I had been mildly critical of New Labour's education policy - a fellow survivor from the Wilson and Callaghan government telephoned to congratulate me on maintaining the sense of timing which had characterised my ministerial career. "It was rotten then," he said. "And it is rotten now." He justified his opinion of my tactical skill with the assertion that it was stupid to attack Blairism while Tony Blair himself was on the crest of the wave. Wait, he urged me, until the tide begins to turn. That is the time to sink them.

Afraid that the maritime metaphor had been stretched to breaking point, I changed the image. Any fool, I said, could harass the government when it was in retreat. I wanted to see what was once called "the onward march of Labour" and I hoped that when the New Model Army had advanced deep into enemy territory, the high command would have sufficient confidence to wheel just a little to the left. My job was to provide maps of the country which we ought to occupy. In any case, I added, if he waited for "the project" to lose its popular appeal, we would wait for ever.

In one sense that remains my view. Labour will win the next election. But the idea on which it won the last - the notion of consensus government which accommodated every shade of reasonable opinion - has lost its charm. Three years ago it was enough for New Labour to look honest, efficient and committed to social justice. For the Tories seemed none of those things. Now, the euphoria over, voters want to know what the prime minister's generalisations mean. Until he satisfies their curiosity his image will remain blurred. The tent is now so big that all we hear is canvas flapping in the wind.

There was a Victorian bishop who wrote to an errant nephew, "Not only have you broken every one of God's commandments, you have also seriously inconvenienced me." I feel much the same about New Labour. It was painful enough to listen to the continual disavowal of long held beliefs even when Tony Blair was apparently invincible.

It is agony to endure the same heresies when they do not even guarantee the humiliation of William Hague and the destruction of a Tory party which is building its hopes of recovery on racism, chauvinism and good old-fashioned selfishness. In a memorably honest passage in his acceptance speech, Tony Blair told Labour's electoral college that half of his vote had come from people who only wanted to find a winner. Now that he looks vulnerable he will need new allies.

There will be no outright desertions - only a slight reduction in enthusiasm exhibited by Blairites who were left when the left was fashionable and Blairite when the political wind changed. My reaction will be different.

Because I feel the tribal loyalty which the prime minister so despises, I am only happy poking Tony Blair in the ribs when he is kicking William Hague in the teeth. The question that has worried me all week is not: "How could the Women's Institute be so unkind to such a nice chap?" but: "Do I now have a duty to pretend that I believe in the flexible labour market, regard the pensioners as lucky to receive a 75 pence increase and acknowledge Chris Woodhead as a hero of our time?" Thousands of Labour's supporters, whose reflex is to come to the aid of the party, are asking themselves the same questions.

Tony Blair does not make it easy for us to rally round his standard. I was just beginning to feel incensed by the Women's Institute hooligans when the prime minister told them that he would "have no truck with egalitarianism".

Then I joined in the slow hand clap. But I remembered, RA Butler's immortal judgment. He is the best prime minister we have got. And I want him to win again. That obliges me to do what little I can to help bring victory about.

However, it is old Labour that has the prescription for recovery. We have to go on administering the medicine.

To regain his place in national esteem, the prime minister has to make clear that he has policies which are built on a coherent and consistent philosophy. The only philosophy which is available is democratic socialism.

Not the lunacy of the Militant tendency, the well meaning nonsense of Bennism or even the Luddite policies of the Tribune Group of which Tony Blair was once a member, but what used to be called "revisionism". Tony Crosland's modernisation of Tawney's belief in a more equal society is waiting to be revised again. That may require the prime minister to offend the vested interests of the rich and privileged. But that is where salvation lies.

The bonus would be a vindication of the Women's Institute speech - old values applied to new circumstances.

webTitle: Come and visit where the cockroach is king

fields.headline: Come and visit where the cockroach is king
fields.trailText: Columnists are a staple of print journalism, and you probably have your favourites. But in most newspapers and magazines, columnists write for the broad audience and keep the subject matter within the bounds of mass appeal. With the exception of those writing for "edgy" print publications, most print columnists must play it safe and write to please a diverse group of readers.
fields.body:
Columnists are a staple of print journalism, and you probably have your favourites. But in most newspapers and magazines, columnists write for the broad audience and keep the subject matter within the bounds of mass appeal. With the exception of those writing for "edgy" print publications, most print columnists must play it safe and write to please a diverse group of readers.

It's different on the internet, where experimentation about what defines a "column" is constantly being extended. It's possible on the internet to write for a narrow audience - so narrow that traditional print publications won't touch such writers' work. Even a transmogrified cockroach can find work with a reputable online publisher and build an audience. Your favorite columnist online may, indeed, be a different animal.

Recently, I judged entries in the online category of the annual contest of the (American) National Society of Newspaper Columnists. (Entrants write for newspaper websites, not for the print editions.) "bernie" the cockroach was one of the entrants. Writing all in lower case - a cockroach wouldn't be able to hit the shift key and a letter simultaneously after all - bernie writes his weekly column in staccato verse about topics of the day for eXaminer.com, the website of the San Francisco Examiner.

bernie's readers are not told his columns are actually written by Virginia-based Mary Ann Hogan, a writing coach and story consultant. bernie is a new media descendant of "archy" the cockroach, who wrote a column for the New York Sun in 1916. It's indicative of the state of US newspapers today that cockroach musings are too far out for print publications, but fit right in at websites more willing to be colourful.

eXaminer.com, home to bernie, is one of those newspaper sites that believes in having lots of original (as opposed to just re-purposed from print) writing. Another fascinating online columnist on the site is the Night Cabbie, a real-life taxi driver who writes about his experiences with interesting customers.

While bernie and Night Cabbie are not newspaper employees, some print journalists are using the web as a more open and creative outlet. For example, Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram humour columnist Dave Lieber and his alter ego, JR Lieber ("the Yankee cowboy everybody loves to hate"), use the web for columns that won't work in print. He also uses the web to experiment with video columns - campy, self-made productions that have the feel of home movies. Those are produced in his own time, but the videos give Lieber an outlet for pushing "column" writing to places other than on dead trees.

Quite a few columnists write online while working for traditional news media companies. Rob Neyer writes an inside baseball column for ESPN.com, the website of the sports TV network. The column is written in "weblog" format, with today's items added on top of previous days' - often building on what went before.

At Canada's CBC News website too, online columns are taken seriously. Among the columnists is Martin O'Malley, one of Canada's most renowned print journalists and book authors who, late in his career, made the move to new media writing. CBC Online also publishes columns by a non-journalist, Saskatchewan farmer Jocelyn Hainsworth, who writes compelling accounts of life on the farm.

Hainsworth and Night Cabbie are typical of the non-journalists who attempt to make names for themselves as online columnists. Frankly, some of their work makes for better reading than the career writers'. Some websites, like the Star-Telegram's, even solicit online columnists in the hope of building new stars. The S-T invites anyone to apply to be a volunteer "cyber-columnist". Current citizen columns include aviation tales, tips on woodcrafting and Fort Worth police department news. Only those who get the S-T editors' seal of approval get published.

The examples above are a tiny smattering of what's available in the way of online columns. The central point is that columns on the internet can be very different from old-fashioned newspaper columns". While there's plenty of conventional column writing on the web, there's some amazing writing available that is at home only in new media.

If newspaper and magazine columnists leave you cold, look to the internet for variety, creativity, zaniness... and increasingly, quality column writing.

 bernie the cockroach: www.examiner.com/bernie

 CBC Online columnists: www.cbc.ca/news/viewpoint/

 Fort Worth Star-Telegram CyberColumnists: www.star-telegram.com/comm/reference/cybercol/howto.htm

 Night Cabbie: www.examiner.com/cabbie www.examiner.com/cabbie

 Rob Neyer column: http://espn.go.com/mlb/columns/neyer_rob/"

 Steve Outing is a Colorado-based columnist and analyst who covers internet media trends. He is also CEO and founder of Content Exchange (www.content-exchange.com. Email: steve@content-exchange.com

It's indicative of the state of US newspapers today that cockroach musings are too far out for print publications, but fit right in at websites more willing to be colourful. eXaminer.com, home to bernie, is one of those newspaper sites that believes in having lots of original (as opposed to just re-purposed from print) writing. Another fascinating online columnist on the site is the Night Cabbie, a real-life taxi driver who writes about his experiences with interesting customers. While bernie and Night Cabbie are not newspaper employees, some print journalists are using the web as a more open and creative outlet. For example, Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram humour columnist Dave Lieber and his alter ego, JR Lieber ("the Yankee cowboy everybody loves to hate"), use the web for columns that won't work in print. He also uses the web to experiment with video columns - campy, self-made productions that have the feel of home movies. Those are produced in his own time, but the videos give Lieber an outlet for pushing "column" writing to places other than on dead trees. Quite a few columnists write online while working for traditional news media companies. Rob Neyer writes an inside baseball column for ESPN.com, the website of the sports TV network. The column is written in "weblog" format, with today's items added on top of previous days' - often building on what went before. At Canada's CBC News website too, online columns are taken seriously. Among the columnists is Martin O'Malley, one of Canada's most renowned print journalists and book authors who, late in his career, made the move to new media writing. CBC Online also publishes columns by a non-journalist, Saskatchewan farmer Jocelyn Hainsworth, who writes compelling accounts of life on the farm. Hainsworth and Night Cabbie are typical of the non-journalists who attempt to make names for themselves as online columnists. Frankly, some of their work makes for better reading than the career writers'. Some websites, like the Star-Telegram's, even solicit online columnists in the hope of building new stars. The S-T invites anyone to apply to be a volunteer "cyber-columnist". Current citizen columns include aviation tales, tips on woodcrafting and Fort Worth police department news. Only those who get the S-T editors' seal of approval get published. The examples above are a tiny smattering of what's available in the way of online columns. The central point is that columns on the internet can be very different from old-fashioned newspaper columns". While there's plenty of conventional column writing on the web, there's some amazing writing available that is at home only in new media. webTitle: How long can this man make $14m last?

fields.headline: How long can this man make $14m last?
fields.standfirst:
Cash-flow problems last week forced two US dot.coms to ditch some or all of their staff. Greg Lindsay on why it's time for content sites to put up or shut down

www.salon.com
www.apbnews.com

In Hemingway's The Sun Also Rises, a character is asked how he went bankrupt. "Two ways," he replies. "Gradually and then suddenly." Last week US media critics were falling all over themselves to explain how APB News, an admired criminal justice news site, could go out of business the same way, quietly spending $2m a month for a year, knowing full well how little cash it had at the end, and then firing its employees all at once on June 5. Two days later, the famous "smart tabloid" Salon.com fired 13 of its 150 employees to cut costs now before burning any more of its stockpile of cash.

The firings at the two companies set the media on both US coasts reeling, but for different reasons. In California's Silicon Valley, the story was about the worsening climate for content sites. APB, Salon and their siblings had been the darlings of the stock market during the previous spring, but the Nasdaq crash in April had so reduced their market values (Salon's stock price has slid from a high of $15 to around $2 per share) that the traditional way of raising more money for an unprofitable company - selling more stock to the public at a wildly overvalued price - was suddenly ruled out. For content sites, it's time to start hauling in the profits that have always been just a year away or close up shop. APB suffered the latter. Salon has begun the necessary sacrificing of staff to achieve the former.

In New York, what received equal attention was the quality and type of the journalists being fired. Among APB's editors was Pulitzer Prize-winner Sydney Schanberg, whose reports from Cambodia later became the film The Killing Fields. Two days before pulling the plug, the company won an award for investigative journalism; on the day after its demise, a staffer won an award for international reporting.

At Salon, the victims included the company's sole media reporter, Sean Elder, and two of its books writers (responsible for half its total books coverage), Craig Seligman and Craig Offman. When asked by my employer, Inside.com, why books and media were among the more expendable topics for Salon, Elder replied: "Traffic, baby," explaining that: "Traffic for media never gets huge, compared to Britney Spears."

Traffic is the lifeblood of content websites, since, despite efforts to expand their options for making money (in the business, this is known as "monetising" traffic and "developing multiple revenue streams"), their business models still rely primarily on selling advertising, making them depressingly similar to traditional publishing.

While APB, as a private company, is too opaque for one to see how its advertising sales team failed to staunch the bleeding in time, Salon, which is publicly traded, has left a clear trail of what has gone wrong so far this year. The latest batch of troubles began in January, when sales senior vice-president Bruce Roberts resigned. The loss of his leadership apparently hurt Salon's sales team so badly that the company had to issue a warning on April 5 that it would miss its earnings estimates for the quarter, explicitly citing his departure. Salon hired his replacement just two days before the firings on June 7.

On May 19, the company's chief financial officer left. Todd Hagen, who had arrived at Salon from the security industry, decided to return there as CEO of security e-tailer AlarmX.com. A search for his replacement is under way. Just five days later, on May 24, Salon announced its earnings. The company brought in $2.6m for the quarter, less than the $3m it had predicted in January, but in line with the estimate issued in its warning. The next day, investment bank WR Ham brecht, which had taken Salon public in 1999 with solid but unspectacular results - many blamed its relatively un-tested Dutch-auction "Open IPO" system - announced it was lowering its revenue estimates for Salon's 2001 fiscal year. It predicted the company would only earn $14.3m in the next 12 months, nearly a 30% drop from its original estimate of $20.5m.

Hambrecht analyst Bill Lennan outlined his concerns to Inside.com at the time: "The revenue shortfall was pretty dramatic. This had to do with the loss of the senior VP of sales who left early in the year. They have tough organisation issues in a tough business. They see a rough road ahead, with dot.coms reducing their advertising."

Ironically, Salon had been very successful selling ads. Total ad impressions (the number of ads on each page multiplied by the number of pages) were up 27% to a new company high of 483m for the quarter. With Salon's market capitalisation currently hovering just under $30m, raising a large amount of cash via selling stock is impossible at the moment without giving the company away. CEO Michael O'Donnell has rejected every lowball offer that has crossed his desk thus far and has vowed to keep doing so. Achieving profitability is the only way out for Salon until its stock price improves significantly, which certainly won't be soon and conceivably could be never.

Which is why it's conserving the $14m or so it has remaining in the bank by trimming what it perceives to be dead wood from its table of contents. The travel section will go - along with editor Donald George; books has been cut in half; Elder speculates that his media reporting will be replaced by more cost-effective freelancers, and finally, Camille Peri and Kate Moses, the founding editors of the Mothers Who Think section and the wives of editor-in-chief David Talbot and executive editor Gary Kamiya, respectively, have been taken off the payroll - long after they had ceased day-to-day editing.

Salon's focus will now be on tightening its belt while simultaneously advancing its broadband strategy - developing audio and video content for readers with fast connections. On May 5, Salon purchased MP3Lit.com, which offers digital spoken-word recordings, and its subsidiary, LoudBooks, which will sell downloadable digital audiobooks. A television show is also in production with the cable network Bravo, video content for Salon's site is planned, and the company is building a state-of-the-art recording studio in its New York office for MP3Lit.com.

The key question is whether broadband will pay off before Salon can no longer afford to pay for it. At the time of its death, APB News was pursuing a similar strategy of selling its video assets, developing content to cell phones and other initiatives whose benefits were not immediate. But, as the firings demonstrate, Salon now has a very clear idea of how much time it has left to turn itself around - Talbot told Associated Press the $14m will last a year.

 Greg Lindsay works for the US media website Inside.com

webTitle: Many carers 'struggling to make ends meet'

fields.headline: Many carers 'struggling to make ends meet'
fields.trailText: People giving up the chance of work to look after disabled or elderly relatives are suffering serious financial hardship, according to a survey published yesterday by the Carers National Association.
fields.body:
People giving up the chance of work to look after disabled or elderly relatives are suffering serious financial hardship, according to a survey published yesterday by the Carers National Association.

It found one in five carers in the UK were buying less food, reducing their number of hot meals and buying out-of-date food. More than one in 10 could not afford to pay their rent or mortgage, and two in five struggled to pay for essential home repairs, according to the survey.

"Their financial difficulties have not been addressed," said Diana Whitworth, the association's chief executive. A £40.40 per week allowance was derisory. "To qualify, carers have to care for a minimum of 35 hours a week, which is equivalent to £1.15 per hour."

The survey of more than 2,000 carers found nearly three out of five live in households without any paid employment and one in three get income support. Four out of five said their financial circumstances became worse since becoming a carer and 60% expect them to slide further.

Nearly one in three carers had no savings, one in three were or had been in debt and were having trouble paying utility bills, and three in five said their financial worries were affecting their health.

The association said carers saved the Treasury £34bn.

fields.headline: An unshown film
fields.standfirst:
British complicity in covering up second world war crimes still seems to be subject to censorship

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Scarcely a day passes without an example of how the absence of a mature Freedom of Information Act denies our so-called free society knowledge we are entitled to have.
fields.body:
Scarcely a day passes without an example of how the absence of a mature Freedom of Information Act denies our so-called free society knowledge we are entitled to have.

Under our current system the political deceptions and lies of history remain undetected and undisclosed. I was, by chance, offered a disturbing reminder of this the other day at a private showing of a television documentary that remains on the blocked list. It is unshown and unknown to the wider world, perhaps even censored by some hidden hand. Until my chance invitation, it was simply not discussed, even by the chattering classes.

Let me explain. In 1947 the Labour government of Clement Attlee approved the bringing to Britain of the remains of an entire division of the Nazi Waffen SS, numbering some 8,000 men. The 14th SS Division, called the Galizien (Galicia), consisted entirely of Ukrainians, mostly from Polish Ukraine which had been taken over by the Soviets after the Molotov-Ribbentrop pact of August 1939.

The Ukrainian SS men's arrival was largely unpublicised at the time and they were distributed around the country in temporary camps to await resettlement. Fifteen hundred of them are still living in Britain today, their history and background cloaked in mystery. Deep suspicions remain, however, about their role as an important part of Hitler's war machine on the eastern front.

The unused (suppressed?), hour-long documentary was produced by Julian Hendy, a talented television writer and historian. It was scheduled to be shown on Yorkshire TV last year but was pulled at short notice with a promise that it would be shown this year. Since then there has been silence. The BBC became involved in discussions about Hendy's film at one point - but backed off.

The film is a stunning documentary about a phase of the second world war that has yet to be explained. Hendy shows the Galizien SS Division involved in horrendous war crimes in Ukraine and Slovakia. He provides eyewitness accounts and documentation of the murder by shooting, fire-bombing, hanging, mutilation and appalling torture of anyone who stood out in resistance to the Nazis - be they Poles, Russians, Ukrainians, Slovaks, Jews and non-Jews, partisan fighters or people just going about village life. Whole villages were destroyed by fire bomb ing; bodies were thrown into mass graves. The grim story is familiar enough to those of us who know what happened on that war front - but here is fresh evidence of something which has a new and sinister connotation, namely the British connection.

At the end of the war the remnants of the 14th SS Division slipped away from the Soviet occupying army into Austria to be made prisoners under the British (a better option than the Soviets). They were encamped firstly in Austria and later in Italy for interrogation - most of which was done casually and without expert interpreters to check details.

The British Foreign Office asked the distinguished war hero Brigadier Sir Fitzroy Maclean to cast his expert eye over the Ukrainians. He did so but found the task extremely difficult without suitable back-up resources. His report to London appears to have cleared the Ukrainians for entry into Britain - though what Fitzroy Maclean actually reported back to London is still far from clear. At any rate the former Waffen SS men were shipped to Britain in 1947, with their Iron Crosses in their pockets and Heinrich Himmler's praises still resting, privately, in their memories (they were honoured personally by Himmler after one of their more brutal escapades in Slovakia).

Not long after their arrival in Britain, once most of them had been absorbed into British life, a number of the former SS men were alleged to have been recruited by British Military Intelligence. The aim was to infiltrate them into the USSR - after all, the cold war was reaching a peak and these men had considerable knowledge and experience of a particularly vulnerable area of the Soviet Union. There are no surprises here, but we are far from knowing anything about that extraordinary episode, assuming there is truth in the allegation.

The cold war is over, the Soviet Union has disappeared, the war crimes commission has been wound up; only 1,500 of the old Galizien boys remain. So why the fuss about the documentary? Was it pulled by Yorkshire TV, and others, because it had negligible viewing power? Are there still good reasons of national security which prevent the story from being told? Or might the telling of this chilling tale raise questions, and skeletons, that are better left in their solidly locked cupboards?

No charges have ever been brought against the men of the 14th SS Division. Perhaps that will never happen: maybe, by now, we have all had enough of retribution. Yet none of this can adequately explain why a remarkable documentary film remains shelved and mostly unknown.

: Geoffrey Goodman is editor of the British Journalism Review

fields.headline: Water world
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Hickling Broad, Norfolk
fields.body:
Hickling Broad, Norfolk

Finding a bittern's nest is never easy - there are fewer than 20 breeding pairs in Britain. They are also hyper-shy and nest in one of the most inaccessible habitats - dense reedbed. So when Reg Land, conservation officer for the Norfolk Wildlife Trust, came upon one at their largest, most famous Broadland reserve, it was a rare moment. There on the platform of vegetation was a chick, the first to fledge at Hickling for 20 years. "The whole thing", according to Land, "was completely priceless".

It was a good deal cheaper than that. The recent restoration work to the reedbed, which has been an important factor in the bitterns' return, was only about £60,000. The overall cost of a scheme to improve habitats throughout the whole reserve was £600,000, mainly donated by the Heritage Lottery and the European Life Funds. This has enabled the raising of water levels, cutting old reedbeds, the reintroduction of grazing on derelict marsh and the creation of new paths, with wheelchair access wherever possible.

Another recent development has been the dramatic change in water quality. For years the water in this Broad and its system of dykes had been a turbid soup dominated by algae and adversely affected by high levels of phosphates, partly originating from gull droppings produced by an enormous roost. Over the last two decades, however, these nutrients have been flushed from the system and several years ago the water suddenly turned crystal clear. One of the agents in this transformation has been gradually expanding bed of water plants, known as stoneworts.

The Trust's newly completed improvements have complemented this natural restoration process and now, bar the recent high water levels, Hickling reserve is in its prime. The swallowtails are just emerging and marsh harriers are constantly on show, while the bittern are occasionally spotted from the newly constructed hide. Best of all will be a treetop observation tower to be completed this month that will allow spectacular panoramas over the whole Broads complex.

Private memos, as reported by newspapers, tell of bad times ahead
New Labour in power: special report

And so to Adversity with a capital A. Poll leads which used to top 30 points shrink to a paltry three. Ladies in hats boo the great helmsman. Erstwhile "friends" break cover and faith, dripping disillusion. Fleet Street sharpens its knives at the thought of an exciting election (so much better for circulation than a boring one). Ah adversity! Time to glimpse the lilies of their political livers. Time to see how tough a New Labour government really is. The first thing about such excitements, of course, is to eschew over-excitement. Labour is still ahead, even on yesterday's post-WI Mori poll.

We're in June of the third year, drifting into the kind of hot July when MPs abandon their cool. Nothing puts the wind up ruling politicians like the approach of their date with balloting destiny. Remember how Mrs T let her iron flake in ludicrous panic before 1987? Remember also that Labour is too used to losing elections to approach them with any ring of confidence.

Calm down, brace up. It will almost certainly be all right on the night. Any prudent prophet, putting his money on the bookie's counter, would still give Mr Blair a second term. What is not so soothing, though, is the way the machine he depends on fractures under pressure. It made a terrible hash of the London mayoralty. It impaled itself on its own hatpin last week. And the embarrassing leaks are starting to come, like bolts shearing in a submarine Downing Street as the depth charges drop.

In particular: whenever Philip Gould, Tony's supreme reader of the polls, writes a private memo to Alastair Campbell, somebody seems to copy the Sunday Times in. Yesterday's is a corker. TB is not "real"; he's "out of touch". (William Hague must have stumbled into the same focus group.) TB is "all spin and presentation"; he "doesn't care enough about the things that matter - crime, asylum seekers, drugs, responsibility". People "feel his government has put asylum seekers first, has put Europe first and put minorities first".

You may think this pretty ripe stuff from the guy who rolls the wicket for the spinners. If Blair had read a Daily Mail leader to the Women's Institute that, presumably, would have been his Goulden moment: and all those old Labour voices carping away would do well to fall silent and reflect what ordinary voters, thus invoked, appear to want.

But pause. Gould isn't finished yet. "However, even this problem is secondary to the most basic problem. TB promised a new Britain, a transformed NHS and public services, and all we have got is more of the same. Too little change, not too much." That is a charge which cuts to the bone - and one, in context, full of irony.

Let me tell you about Vote=33.19+00(Cum.PCIC) +0.29(Approval). That's one of Professor Christopher Wlezien's formulas at the University of Houston which, he says, allows him to predict election results far more accurately than any pundit. Fellow professors right across the States have similar formulas - and they're all firm for Gore in November, whatever passing pollsters say. Why? Because, suitably factored in with due mathematical weight, it's the economy, stupid. After almost a decade of growth, Americans aren't about to abandon the wagon train. They remain optimistic about the future. Bill Clinton's continuing popularity highs are no accident. A remarkable reversal, when you think about it. It used to be the Democrats who couldn't be "trusted" over the economy - the cross that Labour bore through decades of electoral damnation.

Now Labour has that trust in spades. Gordon Brown's war chest is so fat he could buy Oxbridge with the small change. The OECD garlands us with praise. But something is wrong. We're pessimistic about our future: tetchy, ungrateful, the slowest hand-clappers in town. How can this be so? It doesn't make conventional sense: the measliest reward for such hard-won "competence". Alas: we're back in the old Texaco trap. Long ago and far away, it may be recalled, Texaco ran a big advertising campaign which promised motorists a friendly smile when they filled up at the happy pump. It was not a great success. It perished, individually, the moment you pulled in and found a miserable attendant - as, in life, you were bound to. A pledge too infinitely human for instant redemption.

TB and friends have parked themselves on exactly the same, dismaying forecourt. They have promised - in perilously specific terms - to cut waiting lists and class sizes, reduce traffic congestion, make the trains run on time: but the specific has a general application. You, the ordinary punter, feel you've been promised quantum improvement. When the roof at your school still leaks or Dr Ledward is off sick again, you feel there are leaves on the line. The money pours in, but nothing is fresh and new overnight. Personal experience - however frail - feeds a cynical pessimism.

That isn't merely a presentational hiatus. It is the difference between running a public company in McKinsey's image and running a government. For governments need a certain distance from events on the ground; they need, in a way, to be "out of touch". Mr Clinton can be blamed for touching Monica Lewinsky, but otherwise the mesh of Congress and state and pressure groupery limits his responsibility for anything that goes wrong. He can rejoice in triumph and pass the parcel in failure.

Tony Blair has lurched, fatally, in the other direction. (The one which sees Gordon Brown - in logic - as the great panjandrum of Oxbridge entrance.) Local education authorities are failing the nation. So, apparently, are top civil servants and health service managers (and the consultants he was lauding over flu last Christmas). Now, after a fortnight's paternity leave, the prime minister wants to take charge of NHS reform himself. The most dispiriting news of the last few days is that Alan Milburn's new permanent secretary at health will also be chief executive of the NHS.

There's no distance to this. You might as well make Chris Woodhead permanent secretary at education. Politicians who, in another part of the forest can't even engineer modest reform of Westminster working hours, move in to play untutored, non- professional super-administrators: as competent or incompetent as their last exam result or death in a GP's waiting room. A guaranteed flop on the Texaco test. Government isn't about hand- delivering manifesto "targets". Mrs T's 1979 manifesto was a masterpiece of generality without a sniff of privatisation: it served and, indeed, you could say it set her free. TB's way, perhaps because of the lack of a hard edge of ideology (which is also its strength), is not just about centralisation at a time of supposed devolution, but of irritable, frustrated, personal centralisation. And that way, alas, lies - at the very least - the Texaco chainsaw massacre of his second term.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Mickey One
fields.body:
Mickey One

(Arthur Penn, 1965)

6pm, FilmFour

Arthur Penn, director of the blockbusting Bonnie And Clyde, was no less influential with this landmark American art house movie. The physical jolt he achieved with slow-mo violence in the gangster movie is attained here through a powerful combination of edgy realism and laughable surrealism. It was also a departure for Warren Beatty: his antsy, flip and funny Mickey is a hero for his time, and when his nightclub comic routine dies in the glare of the spotlights, he is heading towards tragedy.

Shine

(Scott Hicks, 1996)

8pm, FilmFour

Oscar-winning performance from Geoffrey Rush as David Helfgott, the classical pianist who broke down while playing Rachmaninov's gruelling third concerto, and remained stuck in a twittering, twilight world until redeemed by the love of a woman (Lynn Redgrave). Hicks directs this Australian production with tender care, and the lustre of a polished grand.

Predator 2

(Stephen Hopkins, 1990)

10pm, Sky Movie Max

The sequel to Arnie's rumble in the jungle with an invisible, eight-feet-tall alien switches to Los Angeles: it's a real jungle out there. Danny Glover is one of LAPD's finest undercover men, hunting the hordes of South American drug dealers infesting the streets - so the predator isn't such a bad trip, except that Gary Busey's Feds want it captured alive. More violent, nasty and tense than the original.

Two Days In The Valley

(John Herzfeld, 1996)

11pm, Carlton Cinema

Another crime thriller that concentrates more on the criminals than the crimes, while interweaving several stories together. Danny Aiello, James Spader and Teri Hatcher do their best, but the script lurches from violence to comedy and back again. In one scene we're asked to believe that Aiello's character, a hood who's just escaped after being shot and left for dead in a car that's blown up, would then take two hostages in a nearby house and force them to wait while he cooks pasta and eats it.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: It gets harder to find aspects of Ralph Vaughan Williams' music which have not been picked clean in the four decades since he died. Undeterred, Donald Macleod concentrates less on the music in Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3) than on the literature which inspired it. Vaughan Williams was a voracious reader who drew on such disparate authors as Bunyan, Shakespeare, Blake, and Housman for his settings. This morning, Macleod considers Walt Whitman's effect on the composer.

It is fortuitous that the Soho gay pub bombing should be back in the news as it heightens the relevance of the final edition of Why People Hate (8pm, Radio 4). In this case the target of hatred is "poofs", and historian David Starkey, a homosexual, questions those who believe something should be done about his sexual preference. His guests include Mark Simpson, who wrote a book attacking queer culture, and Jeremy Marks, who thinks gay men must be reformed.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 'Mastermind' is an impostor
fields.body:
'Mastermind' is an impostor

An Iranian defector who claimed to have masterminded the Lockerbie bombing is an impostor, according to US and Turkish intelligence officials. The defector told CBS television last week he had documentary evidence that Iran was behind the bombing, which killed 270.

Yesterday, however, Turan Genc, Turkey's security chief, said that the defector had no great significance and there was "nothing tangible" in his statements. FBI and CIA officials said the man would have been too young to play a prominent role in the Lockerbie bombing. Julian Borger, Washington

Chechens on the attack

Chechen fighters launched more than 20 attacks on Russian military positions in Chechnya, according to reports yesterday. There were no Russian fatalities. Russian troops captured 20 fighters, according to an army spokesman. AP, Nazran

Lorenzo's mother dies

Michaela Odone, whose fight to save her son from the brain disease ALD inspired the film Lorenzo's Oil , has died at 60. She and her husband succeeded where doctors had failed, to find a treatment for the hereditary disease.

Two killed by Taiwan quake

Two people died of heart attacks and 36 were hurt when an earthquake shook central Taiwan. Production of computer chips at plants nearby was not affected. AP, Taipei

fields.headline: Vintage voters
fields.standfirst:
Older people are living longer and their growing number gives them political clout. But will Labour manage to keep them on message?

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Older people are living longer and their growing number gives them political clout. But will Labour manage to keep them on message?
fields.body:
There is hot competition for the grey vote in British politics. It is not surprising. The chart shows the proportion of the electorate who are retired has grown significantly over the past 30 years from about 9% in 1970 to around 20% today.

As is well known, this trend is the product of a combination of increasing life expectancy among the population at large, together with a decline in the birth rate, which has produced a smaller proportion of younger voters than existed a generation ago. Retired people are living longer and many of them are leading healthier lives; their growing number gives them greater political clout.

But there is an additional reason for the parties to court the grey voters. This is the fact that they are more likely to turn out and vote than their younger counterparts. According to the 1997 British election study, about 19% of the electorate admitted that they did not manage to vote in the general election. But this was true of only 13% of retired people.

Of course, it is well known that respondents in surveys tend to exaggerate their willingness to vote in elections, but it is possible to check actual voting behaviour from polling records. When this is done the higher turnouts claimed by the grey voters are confirmed.

Grey voters tend to be significantly worse off than the rest of the population. In 1997 nearly half of them were in the bottom quarter of the income distribution scale, while this was true for only a fifth of voters in general.

This was not just a matter of the meagre state pension, which is now much lower than average incomes. Grey voters are likely to be less well-educated, or to have any qualifications in comparison with their younger counterparts. They were also more likely to be in low-paid jobs when they were working, compared with younger voters today. Many of them worked in unskilled or low-skilled jobs in manufacturing industries, which did not have occupational pension schemes. This has left them relying on the basic state pension, which has not been linked to average earnings for nearly 20 years.

Despite the fact that it was the Tory government led by Mrs Thatcher that broke the link between average earnings and the state pension, the Tories have traditionally enjoyed more support among grey voters than Labour. This has been true for a long time. The British election study of 1974, for example, shows that a quarter of a century ago some 41% of grey voters thought of themselves as Conservatives and 37% thought of themselves as Labour supporters.

This was roughly the reverse of the picture for other voters, since 43% of them were supporters of Harold Wilson's government and only 35% thought of themselves as Conservatives. This pattern continued throughout the 70s and 80s, so that by the time of the 1992 general election 43% of grey voters identified with the Tories and only 34% identified with Labour.

One of the remarkable things about the 1997 general election is that New Labour reversed this long-established trend and won more support among grey voters than did the Tories. In that election 38% of grey voters supported Labour and only 29% voted Conservative. So the party did well in attracting support from a group of people who were normally rather Conservative.

The bad news for Labour is that this state of affairs has now changed. In a Gallup survey conducted in April of this year, 37% of electors preferred Labour and 24% the Tories, when answering a question about their voting intentions. The grey voters were very different, however, with only 24% supporting Labour and 38% the Conservatives. Thus it appears that the grey voters have returned to their traditional allegiance and this must count as a success for William Hague, who is acutely aware of the importance of this group for Tory election strategy.

Why has this happened? One reason appears to be that grey voters are more likely to disapprove of the government's overall record to date than voters in general. In the Gallup survey, close to 50% of voters under the retirement age approved of the government's record. In sharp contrast nearly 60% of grey voters disapproved. There were also large differences between grey voters and the rest of the electorate in their attitudes to which party is best at running the economy.

About 52% of voters under the retirement age thought that Labour was the best party at managing the economy. In contrast, only 38% of grey voters thought this, and 44% of them preferred the Conservatives.

Perhaps most significant of all, 53% of grey voters disagreed with the statement "the government treats people like me fairly", compared with only 41% of other types of voters. The other side of the coin is that only 43% of grey voters agree with this statement compared with 56% of voters in general.

Overall then, there is a sense of grievance among the grey voters which is not apparent among the rest of the electorate and this is putting them off New Labour, even though many of them voted for it in 1997.

Probably the only way that the Blair government can turn this around is by a policy initiative designed to open up clear blue water between itself and the Conservatives. The issue of restoring the link between average earnings and pensions comes to mind. If Gordon Brown restored the link it would provide a formidable electoral stick with which to beat the Tories, since William Hague would not be able to match such a promise. This is because he has committed his party to a policy of reducing taxation over the lifetime of a government.

But there is the central problem. Such a commitment would cost a lot of money in the long run, and it is not clear that New Labour wants to spend that kind of money.

Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at the University of Sheffield.

P.Whiteley@sheffield.ac.uk

The issue of restoring the link between average earnings and pensions comes to mind. If Gordon Brown restored the link it would provide a formidable electoral stick with which to beat the Tories, since William Hague would not be able to match such a promise. This is because he has committed his party to a policy of reducing taxation over the lifetime of a government. But there is the central problem. Such a commitment would cost a lot of money in the long run, and it is not clear that New Labour wants to spend that kind of money. Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at the University of Sheffield. P.Whiteley@sheffield.ac.uk

fields.headline: Is it legal?
fields.trailText: Chambers (Thursday, BBC1) began life on Radio 4, and so the dilemma for writer Clive Coleman has been to turn a highly witty, occasionally surreal portrait of barrister life into a homogenised BBC1 sitcom, complete with HAHAHA laughter-track.
fields.body:
Chambers (Thursday, BBC1) began life on Radio 4, and so the dilemma for writer Clive Coleman has been to turn a highly witty, occasionally surreal portrait of barrister life into a homogenised BBC1 sitcom, complete with HAHAHA laughter-track.

The pitfalls of the transfer from radio to TV were recently illustrated by the failure of People Like Us. On radio, this was a spot-on spoof of File On Four, a very specific joke with limited appeal beyond the context in which it first appeared. And so it proved.

Chambers, however - and perhaps against the odds - is a success, sitting comfortably in the tradition of Yes, Minister and Porridge. Chambers belongs to that highly unfashionable genre, namely the class-ridden institutional sitcom.

John Bird plays the mainstay of the partnership, and he is fantastic in the part: vain, lazy, self-important and thoroughly human. He'd love to fight your case, but he'd rather read a good Jilly Cooper.

In one of the stranger radio episodes, Bird finds himself stuck in the countryside, unable to cross a field until he pays the farmer. Bird offers professional advice by way of recompense. "Maybe you should sue, maybe you shouldn't - that's my advice." In episode one of the TV series, Bird explains to a naïve new partner that "the fee structure is complex. It's two grand a file". "But some of the files are empty," says the new partner. "That's what makes it complex," says Bird.

In this era of Coupling, Cold Feet and too numerous cool, loft-dwelling variations on Friends, it's a pleasure to see the return of old-fashioned, ie funny, situation comedy.

One of the stranger elements of Chambers is Bird's assistant, a mockney geezer called Vince, straight from the Ealing era of working class deferentialism. In the great tradition of institutional sitcom, Vince is the only one who really knows what's going on, but never lets on. It's totally anachronistic, possibly insulting, and - guess what? - it's believable as well.

fields.headline: Hafez al-Assad
fields.standfirst:
Feared and respected leader who raised Syria's profile but was ultimately unable to contain Israel

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: President Hafez al-Assad, master of Syria since 1979, was a towering figure of Arab politics, respected and feared in his own country and throughout the Middle East. His death, at the age of 69, marks the end of an era in the region.
fields.body:
President Hafez al-Assad, master of Syria since 1979, was a towering figure of Arab politics, respected and feared in his own country and throughout the Middle East. His death, at the age of 69, marks the end of an era in the region.

His achievements were threefold: he gave Syria years of much-needed, if somewhat repressive, stability; he turned his relatively small country, once the victim of other people's intrigues, into a major regional player whose views could no longer be ignored; and, with patience and dogged consistency, he fought to prevent Israel from imposing its will on the Arab world.

In the end, he came to terms with the fact of Israel's existence, and was persuaded to open negotiations for a permanent peace settlement. But his dream of containing the Jewish state within its pre-1967 borders, and of checking the spread of its regional influence by means of an Arab-Israeli balance of power, was not realised. To that extent, he died a disappointed man.

Assad's long rule was all the more remarkable in that he was not born a Sunni Muslim, the sect that has for centuries been the dominant orthodox mainstream of Islam, and from which Syria's rulers have traditionally been drawn. His family were Alawites, a heterodox outgrowth of Shi'ism, itself something of an opposition in Islam for the past 1,000 years.

In Syria, the Alawites were a small, down-trodden community, which, to escape persecution, had taken refuge in the mountains of the north-west. It was there, in Qurdaha - then a squalid village, but now greatly expanded and beautified as befits the leader's birthplace - that Assad was born.

His inheritance was bitter. To be born an Alawite in a country where sect and family count for much was to suffer from a built-in minority complex - which, to his credit, he always strove to surmount. To be born a poor country boy meant that he grew up resenting the privileged and arrogant land-owning families that made up Syria's ruling class - before they were routed by Assad's own Baathist revolution.

Politics was his life-long interest. As a schoolboy, he joined the pan-Arab socialist Baath party, and rose to be a student leader. He wanted to become a doctor, but his parents could not pay the fees, so he went to the military academy. He volunteered for the air force and passed out top of his class. He was sent on flying courses to the Soviet Union and to Egypt, and it was in Cairo, with an admiring eye on Gamal Abdul Nasser, the great Arab leader of his day, that he became a conspirator, plotting with a small group of fellow officers, like himself from minority backgrounds, to overthrow the Syrian government, a task accomplished in 1963.

In the next seven years, Assad clawed his way up the ladder until he emerged as sole leader in 1970 - a position he retained through wars, diplomatic crises, internal and external challenges and unrelenting stress. His revolution turned Syria's social and political structures upside down. The country boys triumphed, and none more so than the Alawites who, although no more than 12% of the population, came to occupy plum positions in every sector of life.

Externally, the main landmarks of Assad's life had to do with the struggle against Israel. As a young and inexperienced defence minister in the 1967 war, he presided over the loss of the Golan Heights. In 1970, he sent tanks into Jordan to help the Palestinians against King Hussein, but had to beat a humiliating retreat when Israel threatened to intervene. In 1973, he secretly planned the October war with Egypt's Anwar al- Sadat, but Israel turned the tables on them both, and by defeating Egypt took it out of the Arab military equation.

When the hardline Menachem Begin came to power in Israel in 1977, Assad faced a militant Likud determined to create a "greater Israel". To absorb the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza free from Arab challenge, Begin and his rugged defence minister, Ariel Sharon, conceived the daring plan of bringing Lebanon into Israel's orbit. In 1982, they invaded Lebanon and besieged Beirut, with the aim of booting out both the PLO and the Syrians, and installing a Maronite vassal ready to do their bidding.

Israel's brutal gambit posed a deadly threat to Assad. A Lebanon under Israeli control would have reduced Syria to insignificance. Rallying his allies, he fought back. Israel's troops were harried by guerrillas and took heavy casualties. Israel's adventure turned into a debacle and a dispirited Begin gave up the struggle. The US-brokered Israel-Lebanon treaty, which was to have consecrated Israel's influence over its neighbour, was torn up. From Syria's point of view, it was Assad's finest hour.

Throughout all these battles, he had an ally of sorts in the Soviet Union. Their longstanding relationship was founded on Soviet arms transfers, economic aid for Syria's major infrastructural projects, and political support in the common cause of reducing western and Israeli infuence.

However, the Arab defeat in the six-day war caused strains in the relationship. After 1967 - and again after 1973 - it became obvious that, while the Soviets were prepared to re-arm their Arab protégés, they were reluctant to give them the means to recover their lost territories by force, still less to defeat Israel in all-out war. Moscow was anxious to avoid a confrontation with the United States.

These hesitations - which contrasted with Washington's full-blooded support for Israel - infected Arab relations with Moscow, and it was at least partly for this reason that Assad never entered fully into the Soviet orbit. He insisted on retaining a large measure of freedom; he wanted arms and credit, but also autonomy. As a result, there were limits to what he could expect from Moscow - but it also meant that once the Soviet empire collapsed, he was not swept away like other leaders, in Eastern Europe and elsewhere, who had been more closely bound to Moscow.

When Gorbachev emerged, anxious to befriend the west, Assad was quick to grasp that a major prop of his world was gone. With great pragmatism, he corrected his aim and, by 1987, was busy making overtures to Washington. There is little doubt, however, that the end of the cold war - and the loss of Soviet support - were serious blows to his strategy of holding Israel in check.

The late 1980s and early 1990s were not easy years for Assad since they brought profound and, as seen from Damascus, unwelcome changes to the international and regional environment. The destruction of Iraq in the Gulf war further weakened Syria's strategic position.

When Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait on August 2 1990, Assad recognised at once that Iraq's aggression was a serious threat to Syria's interests - as it was to those of every other major player in the region. All realised that the combination of Iraq and Kuwait would dominate the whole Middle East system. Assad had long detested Saddam, a sentiment that was fully reciprocated. He sensed that if Saddam got away with his seizure of Kuwait, Syria would be his next target.

So Assad joined the American-led coalition and sent troops to help defend Saudi Arabia. But he did not welcome the Gulf war. As an Arab patriot, he deplored the destruction of Iraq, the depletion of Arab financial assets, the ever-greater influence of the US in the region, and the corresponding loss of Arab independence. Moreover, the Gulf war robbed the Arabs of any residual ability to challenge the Israel military. Israel's position became unassailable; it dominated the region.

Such was the impetus for the new phase of Middle East peace-making launched, under American auspices, in Madrid in October 1991. Assad accepted President Bush's invitation to take part in bilateral talks with Israel, but it was not what he had hoped for.

He had long argued that peace with Israel was not worth having unless it was comprehensive, involving an Israeli retreat on all fronts. He was opposed to separate deals, which he felt divided the Arab camp. So it was with great hesitation that he fell in with the Madrid formula of separate tracks, which was to Israel's advantage.

Assad was soon to suffer further setbacks. In September 1993, Israel reached a secret accord with Yasser Arafat's PLO, which put an end to the intifada in the occupied territories - without giving the Palestinians any substantial gains. Assad denounced the agreement, but declared he would not to fight it. A year later, a further blow fell when, in October 1994 and to Assad's dismay, Jordan concluded a peace treaty with Israel.

These agreements effectively brought the Palestinians and Jordan into Israel's sphere of influence - a development which Assad had struggled for years to prevent. With American encouragement, other Arab states - Morocco, Tunisia, Oman and Qatar among them - then developed ties of differing degrees of warmth and formality with Israel, further contributing to Assad's discomfiture. On January 21 1994, his eldest son, Basil, was killed in a car accident, adding a personal tragedy to his political problems.

Assad sought to strengthen his regional position by tightening his grip on Lebanon, by fostering his strategic relationship with Iran, and by keeping alive his Gulf war alliance with Saudi Arabia and Egypt. He was anxious, too, to keep open his lines to Washington, whose predom-inant role in the peace process he could not dispute.

But to Assad's great disappointment, the Clinton administration was to prove one of the most pro-Israeli in American history. Ending all pretence at even-handedness, it retreated from a strict land-for-peace interpretation of UN Security Council Resolution 242, once the keystone of US peace efforts, denounced Hizballah and Hamas as "terrorist" organisations - rather than recognising them to be legitimate national resistance movements to Israeli occupation - and refused to remove Syria itself from the state department list of states allegedly sponsoring terrorism. At the UN, the Americans protected Israel from international censure over human rights abuses, settlement building in the occupied territories and the confiscation of Arab land in and around East Jerusalem.

Faced with tremendous American and Israeli pressure, Assad's only course was to stand firm on principle. As a result, Syria's peace negotiations with Israel made slow progress. He offered Israel "full peace for full withdrawal", making clear that a normalisation of relations could take place only once Israel had committed itself to a full withdrawal from the Golan and southern Lebanon. He insisted that any security arrangements agreed for the Golan should be "balanced and symmetrical" rather than weighted in Israel's favour. Israel was not used to an Arab leader putting up such stiff resistance to its wishes.

Even his enemies conceded that, in his crisis-ridden career, Assad displayed two principal traits. The first was an exceptional degree of political foresight; cerebral and reserved, he plotted his moves with great deliberation. The second was a foxy and stubborn fighting instinct when driven to the wall, as he was by the Muslim Brothers at Hama in 1982 or by the Israelis in Lebanon a year later. On both occasions, he proved he could fight as dirty as anyone.

Although he started out as a soldier, Assad rarely wore uniform or harangued the crowd from a balcony. He seemed to shrink from human contact, spending long hours at his desk and living a dull, exemplary life with his wife and children. Money, women or luxuries seemed to have no hold on him. Power was his drug.

The source of his authority over his security chiefs, military commanders and party bosses seemed to lie in his superior intelligence. His favourite instrument of government was the telephone. With visitors, however, he could exercise considerable charm, and those who knew him intimately reported that he had a sardonic sense of humour and was often shaken by gusts of silent laughter.

 Hafez al-Assad, politician, born October 6 1930; died June 10 2000

webTitle: Schröder faces the flak over Germany's Dome

fields.headline: Schröder faces the flak over Germany's Dome
fields.trailText: Gerhard Schröder's standing is at risk from the disastrous start to Expo 2000, the world fair in Hanover. As officials confirmed at the weekend that ticket sales were running at barely half the expected level, opposition politicians stressed the German chancellor's personal role in overseeing preparations for the event.
fields.body:
Gerhard Schröder's standing is at risk from the disastrous start to Expo 2000, the world fair in Hanover. As officials confirmed at the weekend that ticket sales were running at barely half the expected level, opposition politicians stressed the German chancellor's personal role in overseeing preparations for the event.

The chancellor was head of the regional administration in Lower Saxony in June 1990 when its capital, Hanover, won the right to stage Expo 2000. He remained in the job until two years ago. Mr Schröder's standing is thus even more closely tied to the success of the event than was Tony Blair's to that of the Millennium Dome.

Amid fears that taxpayers will be called on to meet huge losses, MPs urged Mr Schröder to convene an all-party meeting with the organisers to find ways of attracting more visitors. Josef Hollerith of the Christian Social Union (CSU), the Bavarian arm of the Christian Democrat movement (CDU), added: "As joint initiator of Expo, the federal chancellor is jointly responsible for the world exhibition's success."

Expo 2000, which opened on June 1, is the latest in a long line of "universal expositions" stretching back to 1851. The or ganisers were hoping to lure 1.2m in the opening week, but on Saturday officials said attendance during the first eight days had been a mere 650,000.

Germany's finance minister, Hans Eichel, reiterated the government's readiness to pick up the tab."The world fair is good and important for our country," he told the newspaper Bild am Sonntag. "Should money be lacking at the end, we will help out together with the region of Lower Saxony."

Local officials of the Green party, which is in coalition nationally with Mr Schröder's Social Democrats, estimated that, at the current rate of attendance, the fair could rack up a loss of more than £400m.

Oswald Metzger, the national budget spokesman for the Greens, said: "The state underwrote Expo and can demand from the organisers that they come up with something."

There were hopes that more visitors would turn up over the Whitsun holiday weekend. But Adolf Roth, CDU chairman of the budgetary committee of parliament, said that unless there was a sharp improvement "the organisers are going to have to change their approach".
