webTitle: Race bias at trials prompts six death row reprieves

fields.headline: Race bias at trials prompts six death row reprieves
fields.standfirst: Cases add to unease over Texas record on executions
fields.trailText: Lawyers will today begin legal moves to waive death sentences handed to six prisoners in Texas, after the state's attorney general admitted that racial bias had been a factor in their trials.
fields.body:
Lawyers will today begin legal moves to waive death sentences handed to six prisoners in Texas, after the state's attorney general admitted that racial bias had been a factor in their trials.

The admission represents an embarrassment for the Texas governor and presidential contender, George W Bush, who has claimed that he has never presided over the execution of an innocent person during more than five years in office.

The review of the cases was forced on Texas by a supreme court decision last week, which overturned the death sentence of a convicted murderer because an expert prosecution witness at his trial had testified that the defendant's race could be a factor in deter mining whether he should face execution.

Walter Quijano, a clinical psychologist, had argued that Victor Saldano could be considered dangerous on the grounds that Hispanics were "over-represented" in prisons, and therefore more of a threat to society.

Under Texas law, the question of whether the defendant represents "a continuing threat to society" is one of the criteria for imposing the death penalty.

On discovering that Mr Quijano had provided similar testimony in six other cases, resulting in death sentences, the office of the state's attorney general, John Cornyn, notified the defence lawyers in each case that the state would not oppose their motion to have the sentences overturned.

"The people of Texas want and deserve a system that affords the same fairness to everyone," Mr Cornyn said in a statement.

He added that his staff had examined the records of 218 inmates executed in Texas since 1982 and found that none of the executions were based on "this kind of testimony" by Mr Quijano.

It was not clear over the weekend whether previous executions may have resulted from racially charged testimony.

Defence lawyers and civil rights activists have long pointed to the fact that while black Texans represent only 11% of the state population, they account for more than 40% of inmates on death row.

The Texas record on the death penalty has come in for close scrutiny as Mr Bush's presidential bid gathers speed, at a time of creeping unease about the possibility that innocent prisoners are being executed. Texas leads the nation in executions and critics have argued that its system is weighted towards prosecutors.

Much of the criticism has stressed the often poor quality of defence lawyers who - in the absence of a state public defender's office in Texas - are appointed by local courts and frequently lack experience or basic competence.

One death row inmate, Calvin Burdine, is struggling to overturn his 1983 conviction on the grounds that his court-appointed lawyer slept through much of his two-day trial.

Another, Gary Graham, who faces execution on June 22, was convicted on the strength of a single witness to a 1981 murder. His defence lawyer failed to present the jury with a police ballistics report showing that the lethal shot in the case could not have been fired from Graham's gun. He also failed to interview up to six witnesses who later said Graham was not the man they saw carry out the killing.

In a New York Times interview yesterday, Graham's former lawyer, Ron Mock, admitted he had failed law school exams at a Texas university, had at one time owned 11 bars at the same time as practising law, and been a heavy whisky drinker at the time of the trial, but he claimed: "It never affected my performance."

Five other death row inmates have petitions against Mr Mock for providing ineffective legal defence.

webTitle: Anti-hunt bill distracts from real issues, claims sports minister

fields.headline: Anti-hunt bill distracts from real issues, claims sports minister
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Kate Hoey, the outspoken sports minister, yesterday warned Tony Blair that his proposed fox hunting bill was a waste of time which would distract attention from important issues such as health and education.
fields.body:
Kate Hoey, the outspoken sports minister, yesterday warned Tony Blair that his proposed fox hunting bill was a waste of time which would distract attention from important issues such as health and education.

In a provocative intervention on the eve of the publication of an official inquiry into hunting, Ms Hoey, who opposes a ban, said the government and MPs should steer clear of the issue, which was a "moral area". She told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost: "I am not sure it is the government's job to make these sorts of decisions. It is getting us away from the issues that matter on the health service, on education, on jobs."

Her remarks came as the home secretary, Jack Straw, prepared to publish an official inquiry into fox hunting, chaired by Lord Burns.

In a statement to the Commons today, Mr Straw is expected to outline plans to introduce a multiple choice bill which would give MPs a chance to vote on a range of options - including an outright ban, setting up regulations to curb hunting or maintaining the status quo.

Ms Hoey is entitled to reiterate her opposition to a ban, even though she is a minister, because the prime minister, who personally opposes fox hunting, has said MPs will be given a free vote. But there will be surprise that Ms Hoey, who is bound by government collective responsibility, has questioned the merits of the proposed bill.

Ms Hoey said she would support a compromise to set up a regulatory body to control "excesses". She added: "There is a need, and everyone accepts there is a need, to control the numbers of foxes and therefore we get into the judgment about what is the best way of doing that ... I think there is an opportunity here to get some kind of regulatory authority to get rid of some of the excesses of hunting that people within hunting themselves don't like."

The Burns inquiry is likely to include findings that will be welcomed and rejected by both sides. Supporters of a ban will be disappointed because the inquiry is expected to reveal that there is no conclusive evidence to show that foxes suffer physical pain and terror when being chased by hounds.

However, they will welcome other findings, including research that shows farmers massively over-estimate the size of the fox population and the danger it poses.

fields.headline: Mladic at large in suburbia
fields.standfirst:
Guardian finds general wanted for war crimes pruning roses at his villa in Belgrade
Serbia: special report
War crimes in the former Yugoslavia: special report
fields.trailText: Neighbours call him the general, bodyguards patrol his garden and his name still inspires fear, but Ratko Mladic's dreams of greatness are slowly suffocating at 119 Blagoja Parovica.
fields.body:
Neighbours call him the general, bodyguards patrol his garden and his name still inspires fear, but Ratko Mladic's dreams of greatness are slowly suffocating at 119 Blagoja Parovica.

A slope-roofed villa in a sleepy cul-de-sac in west Belgrade and orders to lie low are not how the self-styled Napoleon of the Balkans expected to end a career of conquest and nation-building. Indicted by the war crimes tribunal in the Hague for slaughtering Muslims in Bosnia, the man who tried to carve out a greater Serbia is confined most days to a quarter-acre patch of suburbia.

The west is looking for him, bounty hunters and assassins are picking off ex-comrades, but in this villa Mr Mladic hopes to be safe. The location was discreet and secret - until it was revealed by the Guardian.

The Mladic villa is in a posh enclave built in the late 1980s to accommodate diplomats. They never came, partly because of the havoc wreaked by Mr Mladic's Bosnian Serb forces, including the 1995 Srebrenica massacre during which 7,000 died.

So now number 119 is occupied by the ex-general, his wife and bodyguards, who watch while the couple potter in the garden and entertain guests. But guests are few, for Mr Mladic has been cast from the golden circle of his former friend and mentor, President Slobodan Milosevic.

After the Dayton peace accord ended the Bosnian war Mr Mladic moved to Belgrade, but not to a hero's welcome. He was judged to have gone too far. The president's wife, Mira, is reported to have said the general was "not normal".

A deal was struck. Mr Mladic, 57, was given a villa, not luxurious but comfortable, and a monthly salary in exchange for staying out of sight. For a narcissistic general who came to believe the mythology of his military genius, it was a painful fall, but he accepted.

"He still wants to be the centre of attention. He can't help it, he thinks he must always be important," said one visitor to his home.

On the first night of Nato's bombing last year he hammered on neighbours' doors, ordering them to evacuate since warplanes would target his house. In fact his home was untouched.

One Yugoslav Army general scoffed: "No matter what he thinks he's yesterday's man. He turned up at a medal ceremony in January and strutted around as if he owned the place. He had no right to be there. Unbelievable."

Many who served with him loathe him for alleged bullying, hubris and egomania. The choice of the suburb of Banovo Brdo, rather than the smarter district of Dedinje, was a calculated slight, even though neighbours include Vuk Draskovic, head of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, Rade Markovic, head of state security and Zdravko Colic, a pop star.

A conspiracy of silence envelops the neighbourhood, for it is in no one's interests to advertise the presence of a man whose favourite artillery commands were "Roast" and "Pound them senseless".

When asked about Mr Mladic, several neighbours went white. The government has withdrawn its bodyguards so Mr Mladic has had to make his own arrangements. They stand outside green sentry huts at the front and back of the villa with handguns and walkie-talkies in black leather shoulder bags. Strangers who approach face arrest. Between shifts the guards sip beer on the terrace of a nearby bar.

Their boss, a heavy drinker, prefers to socialise once a month at a racecourse less than a mile away. In March he shocked observers by turning up at a friendly football match between Yugoslavia and China. "Looks like he's finally getting restless," said one acquaintance.

The net is closing in on suspected war criminals. Last week Ljubisa Savic, a former Bosnian Serb paramilitary commander, was shot dead in eastern Bosnia in a gangland-style killing.

Radislav Krstic, a general who served under Mr Mladic at Srebrenica, is being tried in the Hague. Prosecutors hope his boss and the then-Bosnian Serb political leader, Radovan Karadzic, will also face a charge of genocide.

Even with his address no longer a secret, Mr Mladic is likely to remain safe in his villa as long as President Milosevic remains in power. Ringed by a brown picket fence and dotted with rose bushes, this patch of Serbia is all he has left.

fields.headline: Brian Statham
fields.standfirst: Reliable fast bowler behind England's success over Australia
fields.trailText: Brian Statham, who has died aged 69, was among England's finest bowlers. He took 2,260 wickets in first-class cricket, 252 of them for his country. First in tandem with Frank Tyson, and then Fred Trueman, he was a captain's dream because of his sheer reliability in length and line. "George" Statham (and you wouldn't catch a contemporary calling him Brian) simply did not know the way to send down a wayward ball.
fields.body:
Brian Statham, who has died aged 69, was among England's finest bowlers. He took 2,260 wickets in first-class cricket, 252 of them for his country. First in tandem with Frank Tyson, and then Fred Trueman, he was a captain's dream because of his sheer reliability in length and line. "George" Statham (and you wouldn't catch a contemporary calling him Brian) simply did not know the way to send down a wayward ball.

He was fast, though not ferocious. He did not often summon up the kind of aggression which threatened a batsman's ribcage. His skill was his uncanny accuracy. He resented a wasted delivery and, watching county players in more recent years, would shake his head in despair at the number of times a batsman was not forced to play the ball. His philosophy, devoid of fancy theories, was, essentially, to bowl straight. In fact, his talents were infinitely more than that. He hit the deck hard, could seam both ways and had a disconcerting line in variation.

After retirement, he served on the Lancashire committee. His advice was sometimes asked; he gave it quietly, almost reluctantly. He was the most self-effacing of men. At Old Trafford, he was a revered figure and much affection was bestowed on him. But during his playing career and after, he ran many a boundary's distance from self-publicity. He could never have faced the photographers or sat for hours behind a mike like his chum Trueman.

Born to a working-class family in Gorton, Manchester, Statham was a Lancashire player from 1950-68. He made his debut on his 20th birthday after doing national service in the RAF, and having some 2nd XI and club and ground matches. Lancashire liked the look of him. More than that, they needed him.

Statham quickly made an impact. He might have been the most shy member of the dressing-room, but became positively loquacious with the ball in his hands. There was no question of leaving him out for the Roses match that first summer. Twice he fell on his back at the end of his run. Maybe we should put it down to nervous tension, though George was mostly renowned for his calm, phlegmatic temperament. He would bowl all day if asked; it seemed as if the cliche "workhorse" had been made for him.

He appeared the obvious successor as captain when Ken Grieves gave up. Instead, Lancashire made it clear they were looking elsewhere. In the end, without a suitable candidate, they sheepishly approached Statham. He was never one for internal politics; without fuss or the semblance of a public huff, he accepted, and was in charge from 1965-67.

He gave the county excellent, unostentatious service for many years. His bowling consistently exasperated a succession of batsmen, many of whom found that he could be, whatever his reputation, decidedly whippy, and not only on a greentop. At Coventry, he took 15-89 in the match against Warwickshire in 1957; he also took 15 wickets against Leicestershire at Grace Road in 1964. He took more than 100 wickets in a season 13 times, reaching 139 at an average of 15.01 in 1959.

Great Test bowlers are recalled in pairs: Larwood and Voce, Lillee and Thomson... and, yes, Statham and Trueman. They were different in build and skills. Up against Freddie, George could look as though he needed an extra Lancashire hotpot or two. They complemented each other perfectly. If Trueman was letting a few fly, Statham retained equanimity by continuing to pitch on an impeccable length.

In the Tests against the Australians in 1954-55, Statham was in marvellous form with Tyson at the other end. He toured Australia four times, having gone out first as a replacement bowler. He also toured India, South Africa and the West Indies. Like many a bowler, he enjoyed the occasional batting feat as a low order left-hander. And he was always reliable in the field, seldom putting down a catch in the deep.

Statham captained the players against the gentleman, and was admired as much for his demeanour as for his exceptional bowling. He was non-contentious by nature and team-mates could only recall one occasion when he was overtly unhappy about an lbw decision.

He was awarded the CBE in 1966, and, after retiring from cricket, worked for Guinness for some years.

 John Brian 'George' Statham, cricketer, born June 17 1930; died June 11 2000

fields.headline: Rebels battle over islands
fields.standfirst: Solomon Islands: special report
fields.trailText: The fragile truce between rival rebel factions in the Solomon Islands was threatened yesterday after a third rebel group reportedly entered the conflict, seizing a provincial city in a remote chain of islands.
fields.body:
The fragile truce between rival rebel factions in the Solomon Islands was threatened yesterday after a third rebel group reportedly entered the conflict, seizing a provincial city in a remote chain of islands.

Australian radio said that 45 heavily-armed fighters invaded the town of Gizo, 235 miles northwest of the capital, Honiara, from the Papua New Guinea island of Bougainville, killing one man in the attack.

It said the identity of the group, which also seized a police station on Choiseul Island, is unknown.

The dead man was believed to be a member of the Malaita Eagle Force, the group that seized Prime Minister Bartholomew Ulufa'alu and key installations in Honiara on the island of Guadalcanal last Monday.

Andrew Nori, the leader of the Malaita Eagle Force, said the new group's mission was to intimidate people originally from Malaita. "Their mission is to try to oust Malaitans from the western province," he said.

There was no comment from the rival militia force, the Isatabu Freedom Movement, which is trying to force Malaitans to leave Guadalcanal.

The Australian foreign minister, Alexander Downer, and his New Zealand counterpart, Phil Goff, were upbeat after talks with the main rebel groups and Mr Ulufa'alu on Saturday.

Western diplomats in Honiara said yesterday's attack could spark fresh violence in the capital. Mr Downer said he hoped the assault would not affect the ceasefire agreed by the two main groups last week.

webTitle: Montenegrins vote in test for pro-west leader

fields.headline: Montenegrins vote in test for pro-west leader
fields.trailText: Security forces were on alert yesterday during elections in Montenegro that pitted supporters of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, against backers of the pro-western government in a state that is teetering on the brink of war.
fields.body:
Security forces were on alert yesterday during elections in Montenegro that pitted supporters of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, against backers of the pro-western government in a state that is teetering on the brink of war.

The polls come after days of heavily policed rallies in the capital, Podgorica, and the coastal city of Herceg Novi.

Although the vote is for local governments in the two cities, it is viewed as a key test of opinion in the only republic still left alongside Serbia in Yugoslavia.

The pro-Milosevic party has joined with hardline parties to form a Coalition for Yugoslavia and the pro-west forces are grouped under the For a Better Life coalition, whose main party is that of the pro-western president, Milo Djukanovic.

After casting his own vote, Yugoslavia's prime minister, Momir Bulatovic, accused the US and the EU of spending £12.5m in Montenegro with the "aim of buying votes".

Mr Bulatovic, a close aide to Mr Milosevic, was referring to large amounts of international aid that have enabled Mr Djukanovic's government to pay salaries double those of state employees in Belgrade.

"What is happening now is really indecent," Mr Bulatovic said. "We see foreign centres of financial and political power pouring money in and giving false promises."

Tension increased on the eve of polling when the Yugoslav army chief of staff, Nebojsa Pavkovic, said Montenegro was "supported by foreign factors", adding that "destructive forces in the country are trying to break its unity".

He added: "We send a message to all of them, including their commanders, that the Yugoslav army is united, qualified for combat and has proven experience. We will prevent civil war at any price."

The pro-Milosevic bloc has made allegations of ballot-rigging and warned that if it loses, it will not accept the result lying down.

webTitle: Brunel's rusting giant sends a new SOS signal

fields.headline: Brunel's rusting giant sends a new SOS signal
fields.trailText: The SS Great Britain, Isambard Kingdom Brunel's great propeller-driven iron ship, which revolutionised ship design when it was launched in 1843, is decaying so fast that its hull will be completely destroyed within 25 years.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The SS Great Britain, Isambard Kingdom Brunel's great propeller-driven iron ship, which revolutionised ship design when it was launched in 1843, is decaying so fast that its hull will be completely destroyed within 25 years.

A condition report on the ship, which has spent the past 30 years in dry dock in Bristol, where it was built, has shocked its trustees. It shows that years of expensive work have done nothing to arrest corrosion of the hull. Some of the restoration work - including an expensive new deck which rotted within 10 years and has now been replaced - has made the ship's problems worse.

Matthew Tanner, the ship's curator, said: "This is simply one of the most important and influential ships in the world, but we have a terrifyingly small window in which to save her."

Brunel, the maverick engineering genius, had already built an enormous wooden paddle ship, the Great Western, but realised he needed to build bigger to beat the competition to carry passengers to America. His solution was a propeller-driven iron ship, with sails to save fuel in the right winds. The Great Britain was launched by the technology-loving Prince Albert in 1843. However, its design was considered so radical that only 50 nervous passengers bought tickets for the first journey to New York, despite the ship's luxurious facilities.

The report says extensive conservation work must begin within five years. Rust is swelling the ship's iron plates, which are laid in the same way as the planks of a clinker-built wooden boat, and bursting them off their ribs. Dozens of rust holes are stuffed with chicken wire to stop pigeons flying into the hull and the 19th century dry dock itself is leaking, so the ship is surrounded by damp.

Long before it collapsed, the ship would become so dangerous that the public would be barred from visiting.

Ships were never designed to last longer than a few decades and the long-term conservation problems, particularly once they are taken out of the water, are notorious. The famous tea clipper, the Cutty Sark, kept in dry dock at Greenwich, in south-east London, has similar problems.

The Great Britain's trustees, along with conservation architect, Julian Harrap, have devised a striking solution: a glass artificial waterline, which would cut the humidity, stop the rot, give the illusion of the ship floating on water, and still allow visitors to walk around the hull on the floor of the dock. The glass alone would cost £1m, and the trustees have applied for a lottery grant towards the £7m project.

The Great Britain had a long but star-crossed working life. In 1846 it ran aground in Northern Ireland. None of the 180 passengers, including a troupe of 48 German dancing girls, was injured, and a group of clergymen conducted a service to calm their nerves.

The ship lay on the beach "like a useless saucepan", as Brunel raged, for a year until he devised a rescue so expensive that it bankrupted the vessel's operators.

The ship was sold in 1850 for £18,000, a fraction of its original cost. Converted to sail it took thousands of emigrants to Australia. In 1861 it carried the first England cricket team to tour Australia - they played 12 matches, won six, lost two and drew four. In 1886 it ran aground again on the Falkland Islands and spent another 50 years as a floating wool store. Then in 1937 the ship was abandoned at Sparrow Cove. Historians never forgot the Great Britain, and eventually Jack Hayward, the Bahamas-based millionaire, backed a spectacular rescue, which led to the ship being towed back to Britain in 1970.

More than 4m people have visited the ship since then, but visitor numbers have been falling and are now down to 100,000 a year. The trustees are convinced their new plan would reverse the slump.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
British failure on child poverty
Britain has one of the worst records on childhood poverty in the industrialised world, according to a report by Unicef. Nearly 20% live in families below the official poverty line - judged as household income below half median earnings. Countries such as Sweden, Norway and Finland suffer rates below 5%. Britain is placed behind Turkey, Poland and Hungary at 14th out of 19 countries surveyed.

Nearly 20% live in families below the official poverty line - judged as household income below half median earnings. Countries such as Sweden, Norway and Finland suffer rates below 5%. Britain is placed behind Turkey, Poland and Hungary at 14th out of 19 countries surveyed.

Malaria blamed on military error
Eighteen soldiers from the Parachute Regiment who contracted malaria after being sent to Sierra Leone were not issued with the correct drugs because of a military supply error, the Ministry of Defence admitted yesterday.

Smoking linked to meningitis
Babies whose parents smoke are more likely to harbour the meningitis bacteria, according to research by a team of scientists at Edinburgh University. Smoke helps the bacteria adhere to the tissues lining the throat.

Round Britain boat record
The three-man crew of the Spirit of Cardiff power boat yesterday set a record by circumnavigating the 2,222 nautical miles of the British Isles in five days, six hours and five minutes.

£7.8m ticket
One ticket won the £7.8m jackpot in Saturday night's lottery with numbers 1, 14, 15, 35, 44 and 47. The bonus ball was 34.

webTitle: The best pimp scene:   Sweet and Lowdown

fields.headline: The best pimp scene:   Sweet and Lowdown
fields.trailText: Chicago. The early 1930s. Emmett Ray (Sean Penn), widely regarded by connoisseurs as the second greatest jazz guitarist in the world, is called away from his pool game by the arrival of a pair of modishly-dressed young women.
fields.body:
Chicago. The early 1930s. Emmett Ray (Sean Penn), widely regarded by connoisseurs as the second greatest jazz guitarist in the world, is called away from his pool game by the arrival of a pair of modishly-dressed young women.

"What you got?"

One of the women reaches into her purse, producing a wad of bills.

"Here's your end."

A disgruntled Emmett counts the money.

"Thirty dollars? It's almost midnight. Thirty dollars?"

"It's hot, Emmett."

"I'm sorry, Emmett, business is slow. It's a Jewish holiday."

"Yeah, yeah, and last night it was raining, and the night before that you had food poisoning.."

"Right, because I ate that dinner that you made!"

One of the women takes Emmett to one side.

"Listen Emmett, I don't know how to tell you this, but while I was in... bed with one of the johns you sent me, he got very excited. And he got a heart attack. And he dropped dead."

Emmett looks panicked.

"Oh god. Which one?"

"The salesman from Detroit."

"Ooh. What d'you do next?"

"Nothing. I picked up my clothes and left. But then..."

"But then what?"

"I thought I might have left one of the cards."

The colour drains from Emmett's cheeks.

"What? What?"

"Well, Emmett, I told you, a pimp doesn't need business cards."

See also: Taxi Driver, Casino, Desperately Seeking Susan

Don't see also: Sharky's Machine

Pointless trivia: The George Gershwin song Sweet And Lowdown is actually on the soundtrack of Woody Allen's Manhattan

webTitle: Trueman mourns the loss of his strike partner Statham

fields.headline: Trueman mourns the loss of his strike partner Statham
fields.trailText: Cricket lost one of its most honest, least egocentric souls yesterday with the death of Brian Statham, a man who fitted the popular notion of the fast bowler in much the same way as Mahatma Gandhi could be deemed a typical politician.
fields.body:
Cricket lost one of its most honest, least egocentric souls yesterday with the death of Brian Statham, a man who fitted the popular notion of the fast bowler in much the same way as Mahatma Gandhi could be deemed a typical politician.

Best known for playing Wise to Fred Trueman's Morecambe in one of the game's most fabled double acts, Statham wrested the world record from Alec Bedser in 1963 with his 237th Test wicket, finishing with 252 at 24.84 in 70 Tests. He had been suffering from leukaemia and passed away peacefully at home in his beloved Lancashire. He would have been 70 on Saturday.

A firm friend and room-mate for many years, despite their rivalry in Roses matches, Trueman had been aware of the gravity of Statham's condition since February but maintained a vow of silence. He organised two testimonial dinners in 1989 when Statham had fallen on hard times.

"This is very sad news," he said yesterday. "I telephoned two weeks ago and he was not very well and I was intending to ring back today. He was often in pain but never complained [or] made a fuss."

Known with equal affection as "Gentleman George" and "The Whippet", the latter an homage to frame and endurance as much as sheer speed, Statham was lissom and largely uncoached. He had few pretensions to elegance. The approach to the stumps brought to mind an agitated stick insect, an image accentuated by his double-jointedness (in one deft movement, he would peel off his sweater with his right arm).

Yet the persistence and accuracy were matchless, the motto: "If they miss, I hit". He boasted an average of 16.37 and no bowler of comparable pace has ever done more to combine the penetrative with the curmudgeonly.

A heavy smoker with a penchant for ale, he held little truck with modern fitness regimes. "If I want to get fit for bowling, I do a lot of bowling," he declared somewhat sardonically in 1974 and a lot of bowling he did.

Standing 20th in the all-time list of wicket-takers with 2,260, he bowled a shade under 101,000 balls for Lancashire and England. His 1,816 victims are a Lancashire high.

His best Test analysis, fittingly, mirrored the size of his heart. At Lord's in 1955, he bowled unchanged for 3hr 45 min, securing victory almost singlehandedly by ejecting seven South Africans for 39. It was there, against South Africa in 1960, he settled the issue with match figures of 11 for 97: England's first "tenfer" for 22 years.

Arguably the only bowler to forge more than one legendary partnership, he was outshone by Frank Tyson then Trueman at Test level, yet turned the tables domestically, leading the national averages three times, an honour denied both.

"He was a top-class man," added Trueman. "So unassuming and laid-back, a great ambassador. In 50 years we never had a wrong word and for me, and everyone connected with the game at that time, this is terrible news."

webTitle: Trescothick and Cox shoot down Spitfires

fields.headline: Trescothick and Cox shoot down Spitfires
fields.standfirst:
Kent 179-9
Somerset 180-1
fields.trailText: After a run of success in the National League, the Somerset throng must have been dreading the return of Rahul Dravid to Taunton. In the same way that the Indian batsman threw the bat for 145 and shared a record stand with Saurav Ganguly to snatch the World Cup away from Sri Lanka's grasp last May, there was every possibility he might swing it again, this time for Kent Spitfires, to ruin the fun that has elevated Somerset Sabres to the top of the First Division.
fields.body:
After a run of success in the National League, the Somerset throng must have been dreading the return of Rahul Dravid to Taunton. In the same way that the Indian batsman threw the bat for 145 and shared a record stand with Saurav Ganguly to snatch the World Cup away from Sri Lanka's grasp last May, there was every possibility he might swing it again, this time for Kent Spitfires, to ruin the fun that has elevated Somerset Sabres to the top of the First Division.

As it was, they need not have worried since Dravid's visit to the crease lasted no longer than the time it takes to eat a pasty. Instead, the home supporters were treated to a magnificent display from two of their own players, Marcus Trescothick and Jamie Cox, who effortlessly produced the bulk of the 180 runs required to pull off Somerset's fourth successive victory in this competition.

The combination of left and right-hander at the top of the Sabres' order seemed to flummox Kent's bowlers, though after a shaky display by their batsmen earlier, with the exception of a swash-buckling Matthew Fleming, the gloom was already upon them before they bowled a ball.

Trescothick and Cox took advantage, fixing their sights on the hospitality box windows. Trescothick was first to his half-century with a hard-hit drive through extra cover for his eighth boundary and Cox followed soon after, having struck two sixes and five fours.

Their superb partnership of 145 was finally broken in the 29th over, when Cox was caught at extra cover off Kristian Adams. But by then the win was virtually in the bag, and at the end Trescothick was unbeaten on 92.

The entertainment was mainly confined to the steady stream of runs, but it was a different story while Kent were batting. Their 45 overs were a roller-coaster ride of drama and wickets, starting with the eighth ball of the innings, when Steffan Jones dismissed Matthew Walker.

The dramatic departure of Dravid, caught behind for eight, was followed by a peculiar misunderstanding in which Alan Wells was judged to be run out by the umpire Alan Jones, only to be called back after Jamie Cox sportingly pointed out that the ball had been dead when it broke the stumps.

Kent in any case slipped to 112 for eight, and hard as Matthew Fleming tried to salvage the innings with a flamboyant 63, victory was completed with 9.5 overs to spare.

webTitle: Harvey's variety act steals the show

fields.headline: Harvey's variety act steals the show
fields.standfirst:
Glamorgan 225
Gloucestershire 226-3
Gloucs win by seven wickets
fields.trailText: Freakish is a word that has been readily associated with Ian Harvey and Gloucestershire over the past year, but while they are stocking up the one-day trophies, no one is going to become too concerned about that.
fields.body:
Freakish is a word that has been readily associated with Ian Harvey and Gloucestershire over the past year, but while they are stocking up the one-day trophies, no one is going to become too concerned about that.

Five wickets for Harvey brought Gloucestershire an unprecedented three successive wins in Lord's finals as the county whose achievements last summer were widely regarded as fun but fortuitous demanded the right to usurp an ageing Lancashire side as the leading one-day specialists in the land.

Mark Alleyne, Gloucestershire's captain, certainly felt that way after this trophy had been secured by seven wickets with 19 balls to spare. "Lancashire have deserved the credit over the years, and have the trophies to prove it, but things move on. Our success has been called a fluke and a freak. They can't say that now."

"The Freak" was also a nickname bestowed on Harvey by his Australian team-mate, Shane Warne. Matthew Maynard, the defeated Glamorgan captain, preferred to call him "unique". Whatever way you look at it, Harvey's adaptable medium-pace has had an extraordinary impact down West - this five-wicket haul was his sixth in 30 one-day matches for the county.

To face Harvey is to bat in a hall of mirrors. Deliveries come in all shapes and sizes. Reality is forever changing, deception abounds. Yorkers, slower balls (at least two varieties) and other subtle ruses never allowed Glamorgan's batsmen to settle.

Maynard's combative and astute century had driven Glamorgan forward on their first Lord's appearance for 23 years but Harvey's reappearance in the closing overs forbid any thoughts of a final flourish.

"Harvey put the crushes on us with his last four overs," Maynard said. "It was a vital spell. I was on top of my game when he came back into the attack, but he mixes it up so much that you can't quite set yourself to hit him. That's what makes him so dangerous. He has a belief that whatever trick he attempts, he can pull it off. Every now and then you get a unique one-day bowler and he is just that."

Harvey's development of a slower ball originated from an unusual source. Countless batsmen have studied Steve Waugh's batting technique; few have watched videos of his slower ball. Harvey did that at the Australian Cricket Academy, and has combined his knowledge with the daring to experiment when the pressure is at its height.

His 16 one-day internationals have brought only limited success (eight wickets at 65 question whether Harvey's variety act can ever play successfully in the elitist circles), but since Gloucestershire received word from Allan Border, the former Australia captain, that he would be a good overseas acquisition, his effect at county level has been remarkable.

Experimentation is in vogue throughout Gloucestershire's bowling ranks - not just among the old sweats, such as the captain Mark Alleyne, but in the likes of Jamie Averis, a fixture in the side these days, and whose growing ability to bowl at the death was identified by Alleyne as a factor in the county's improvement.

Harvey's impact came with the new ball and the old. Robert Croft, spooned high to mid-off, and his fellow Victorian, Matthew Elliott, dragged on. His return was even more striking: Keith Newell, Alex Wharf and Steve Watkin all floundering. Maynard, desperate to get back on strike, was run out by Kim Barnett's direct hit from point four balls before the end.

A total of 225 was competitive, but slightly lower than Maynard had envisaged. Only Michael Powell had lent him much support, and even his 48 required 97 balls. The damage inflicted by Harvey was then continued by Gloucestershire's openers, Barnett and Tim Hancock, in a cavalier opening stand of 80 in 16 overs.

Steve Watkin, presented with his first Lord's final at 35, found rhythm deserting him, Barnett feasted once more on his notorious square slash until he dragged on a wide one from Croft, and Hancock's bel ligerent half-century ended with Owen Parkin's brilliant return catch. Set fair, Alleyne and Matt Windows, making good use this season of his move up the order, then sensibly milked a limited attack in an unbeaten stand of 95.

So hail the new one-day specialists. However much Harvey and Gloucestershire rail at the label, it is a fair one. Harvey's impact in the championship has been less evident and Gloucestershire, languishing in the Second Division, showed their priorities by resting four players for last week's championship match against Essex.

"It won't become a habit," Alleyne asserted. "We are not about to lose interest in the championship. We want promotion."

Maynard, as the beaten captain, found little comfort in his gold award - rarely has it been so glowered at - but he will value it one day. He batted wonderfully.

As an animated crowd of 20,000 basked in the sunshine, their contented chatter enlivening a previously drenched season, and Maynard drove first Jeremy Snape, then Averis thrillingly through the offside, it was finally possible to watch a succession of planes rising beyond Heathrow without wishing to be on every one of them.

webTitle: Goodwin a cut above tourist class

fields.headline: Goodwin a cut above tourist class
fields.standfirst:
West Indians 407 & 12-0
Zimbabweans 275-8dec
fields.trailText: The West Indian pace bowling looks to be coming to the boil nicely with some healthy competition for places.
fields.body:
This is a grand idea, taking both this summer's tourists and, in the lull between series, pitting them against one another. West Indies of course are preparing for this week's first test, so need to get their five-day game up to speed.

The Zimbabwean imperative on the other hand leans towards the limited-overs triangular tournament which begins in about three weeks' time. Splitting the difference between test and one-dayers and playing over three days seems about right then, and if the weather is set fair, as it has been over the weekend, then Arundel takes some beating as a venue.

On Saturday, a crowd of 3,000 was treated to the sublime sight of Brian Lara making 176 as easily and smoothly as downing the first banana daiquiri at a Tobagan beach bar. Yesterday, with fewer in attendance, but against bowling significantly more testing than that faced by the Prince of Port of Spain, they saw Murray Goodwin reiterate the lasting impression made against England at Trent Bridge that he is an extremely good player. With trees and the castle as backdrop, Goodwin made 126 in a stay of four-and-three-quarter hours, rattling out those same cuts and pulls and front-foot punches that drove the England bowlers to distraction, before he swung distractedly at Nixon McLean and the second new ball and to his evident annoyance was caught at backward point. This is a fellow who can get in and once he does so, resents being moved.

The West Indian pace bowling looks to be coming to the boil nicely with some healthy competition for places. The two old stagers Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose (three matches on the tour and not a ball bowled between them) and Reon King are keeping their powder dry for the first test, and so Franklyn Rose and McLean battled it out for the fourth pace spot.

Rose, who took three for 62, including two wickets in successive balls with the second new ball, will almost certainly play this week, but it was McLean, with four for 64, who gave the batsmen a real hurry-up: Trevor Gripper did well to guts it out for 42.

The best batting of the Zimbabwean innings came while Goodwin and Dirk Viljoen were adding 103 for the fifth wicket and although there was a flurry of wickets (Neil Johnson did not bat because of a side strain) Andy Flower declared shortly before the close at 275 for eight, a deficit of 132, leaving West Indies five overs to bat in their second innings. They made 12 without loss, Adrian Griffiths and Ram-naresh Sarwan probably vying today for the chance to accompany Sherwin Campbell at the top of the order on Thursday.

Campbell himself, although overshadowed inevitably by Lara's brilliance took the chance offered by steady but unspectacular bowling and a slowish pitch to feather his own nest, reaching 141 on Saturday but adding only a further five yesterday morning before he was run out by Paul Strang's throw from cover. It was the younger Strang brother, Bryan, the left-arm medium pacer, who took the bowling honours for Zimbabwe, though, for having picked up Lara, Jimmy Adams and Sarwan on Saturday, he added Mahendra Nagamootoo and Corey Collymore yesterday giving him five for 68.
